HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
R.H. Macy announced plans to shore up its operations. The preliminary plan that was sketched out was Macy's first public acknowledgement that its problems go far beyond excessive debt. Four of the six strategies, which were presented to creditors last week, go to the heart of the way the bankrupt retailer merchandises and markets itself, indicating that the problems will take more time to fix than analysts had expected. [Page D1.]
A "merger announcement" from Mario Gabelli, a money manager, on the TV show "Wall Street Week," sent shares of BHC Communications and United Television up in early trading, but their gains were trimmed later in the day. [D1.]
Boeing promoted Philip M. Condit to president, and he was widely viewed as heir apparent to Frank Shrontz, the aircraft maker's 60-year-old chairman. [D1.]
Bank of Boston agreed to acquire Society for Savings, Hartford, in a stock deal worth about $200 million, furthering the carving up of the Connecticut banking market by larger banks. [D3.]
Biogen shares fell 75 cents on Nasdaq to $22.75 after Vicki L. Sato, a 44-year-old former Harvard biology professor said she would leave the company, where she was the top research manager, for a similar job at Vertex Pharmaceuticals, a Cambridge start-up company. Its shares rose 50 cents, to $9.50. [D3.]
Medco Containment Services announced a $436 million agreement to acquire Diagnostek Inc., a drug distributor that recently disappointed investors, through an exchange of stock. [D3.]
Meyer Blinder was sentenced to 46 months in prison on Federal charges of racketeering and securities fraud. The 70-year-old founder of a Colorado penny-stock brokerage firm was convicted of bilking thousands of investors of millions of dollars. [D3.]
 
International
Cortland, N.Y., where Smith Corona is laying off 875 of its 1,300 workers before moving its typewriter manufacturing operations to Mexico, is feeling the pinch that other communities may suffer under a North American Free Trade Agreement. [A1.]
The U.S. said it had agreed in principle to buy billions of dollars' worth of bomb-grade uranium from retired Soviet nuclear arms in a bid to bolster the shaky economy of the former Soviet Union and to reduce the risk of nuclear accidents and theft. [A1.]
 
The Economy
Sales of new homes slipped 2.6 percent in July to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 563,000 units, the Commerce Department said, despite cheaper mortgage rates and a median price of $115,000, which was down sharply from June. [D5.]
 
Markets
The Dow industrials fell 10.26 points to close at 3,257.35 in a late selloff, ending a streak of four winning sessions. [D6.]
The Treasury bond market was little changed ahead of the Labor Day weekend, as investors focused attention on European markets and the outlook for the dollar. [D13.]
The dollar declined in uneventful trading, while the mark and the Swiss franc benefited from a move to quality. [D14.] Energy futures prices extended their recent strong gains. [D14.]
 
Today's Columns
The effectiveness of managed care is being questioned as a means of slowing the rise of health- care costs. The Congressional Budget Office says it appears not "to have affected systemwide costs." Milt Freudenheim: Business and Health. [D2.]
Shares of restaurant companies have held their own after a banner 1991. Despite the recession, Americans are spending 43 cents of every food dollar eating out. Market Place. [D6.]
Time Warner Cable's New York 1 News plans competition for broadcast TV's local newscasts, eschewing their sensationalism and accent on crime news. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D11.]

HEADLINE: Mystery Man Pushing the Pawns

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SVETI STEVAN, Yugoslavia, Aug. 31

 BODY:
The Yugoslav economy, never the world's strongest, has collapsed during the civil war of recent months. But one pugnacious businessman has continued to wheel and deal at a furious pace, culminating with his bold financing of the scheduled comeback of the United States chess genius Bobby Fischer against his old rival Boris Spassky in this Adriatic resort not far from the fighting.
In the remnants of Yugoslavia, now a cash-only economy where anything goes, Jezdimir Vasiljevic is known as the "mystery man." He appears to enjoy the title. "I like to be mysterious," he said, pulling hard on a cigarette and mopping the sweat from his brow, "because I like to keep people guessing." Asked about his net worth, all he will say is "millions," adding coyly that his group's sales now amount to about $3 billion a year.
 
'A Believer in Money'
 Officially, Mr. Vasiljevic is the owner of a recently established private bank-cum-trading company called Jugoskandic, whose interests include the horse racing track in Belgrade and a large shipping company. Unofficially, he has his hand in just about everything. 
 A stocky 43-year-old man with a gold watch, crocodile-skin shoes and shrewd, somewhat furtive blue eyes, this restless entrepreneur may perhaps be seen as a particularly lurid example of the businessman thriving in the chaos of the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe. In Yugoslavia, war has compounded the disorder into outright economic chaos, but quick-witted audacity and confidence in one's ability to set the rules remain effective attributes.
He has offered prize money of $5 million -- unprecedented for a chess match -- to lure Mr. Fischer out of 20 years of seclusion to the sun-drenched borders of the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Of this, the winner will take $3.35 million and the loser $1.65 million.
"Just imagine," Mr. Vasiljevic (pronunced vass-ill-YEA-vich) said in an interview. "The financial difference between winning and losing is $1.7 million. Never will chess have been played with such intensity and purity."
An aide, Janosz Kubat, who is the director of the chess match, refined this thought for his boss. "Mr. Vasiljevic is a great believer in money," he explained. "He really believes you can get anything done and persuade people to do anything, with money."
If that maxim may hold some truth anywhere, it is now particularly true in Yugoslavia, a rump state half the size it was two years ago where economic activity has degenerated into a free-for-all.
Shaken by annual inflation of more than 10,000 percent, deprived by international sanctions of such essential products as gasoline and its industry in ruins, the country now operates largely on a mixture of smuggling and black market operations. Credit cards, checks and other financial instruments of the West are a thing of the past as the country has lurched toward a Lebanese approach to life in which the prevailing view is "sauve qui peut," or "escape if you can."
 
Black Markets, Gun Running
 Just what role Mr. Vasiljevic has played in the midst of all this is a matter of dispute, though most people agree that it has been considerable. News reports here have linked him to activities including the hiring of mercenaries for the Serbian army, arms purchases in Israel, sanction-breaking imports of crude oil and effective domination of the frenetic black market in dollars now operating on the streets of Belgrade. Some accounts have suggested he is a financial front man for the hard-line Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic.
Mr. Vasiljevic denied that he had played any role in financing the war and said he had never met Mr. Milosevic, much less been a front man for him. He also dismissed reports of his buying arms on a trip to Israel last October, adding, "All I have tried to do is provide medicine and clothes for those who are suffering, and most recently, I've presented $500,000 to the Red Cross for victims of the war whatever their ethnic group."
A friend and prominent member of the Serbian Jewish community, Klara Mandic, hinted that Mr. Vasiljevic had made the arms-buying trip to Israel. "I just cannot say anything about this for obvious reasons," she said. As for the black market in dollars, Mr. Vasiljevic acknowledged that he was indeed active in this.
"Buying money on the street, is that what you call the black market?" he asked. "Sure I'm doing that, but so is the Government." The beleaguered Government has, in fact, said it will arrest anyone who trades on the street in dollars, where the black market rate has soared to 400 dinars, compared with an official rate of 200 dinars.
"Black market dollars are all making their way to Mr. Vasiljevic and his Jugoskandic bank," said Momir Pavlicevic, a director of the Serbian Chamber of Commerce. "I personally believe the bank is engaged in dangerous speculation and deals related to the armed conflict. It is offering hard currency interest rates of 10 percent, which are incredible. I would not be surprised if a collapse happens."
Every day, long lines may be seen outside Jugoskandic's branches in Belgrade. Mr. Vasiljevic said he was able to offer the high interest rates because he was satisfied with smaller profits than other banks. "Look at those big buildings the banks have in the United States," he said, "all built with customers' money. I prefer to give more to the customer."
 
A Rags-to-Riches Mystery
 He started with very little himself. Born in a small village 50 miles from Belgrade, he made his way to Austria in 1967 when he was 18 years old, living in an immigrants' camp and working as a laborer cleaning buildings. After this, the two decades until his return to Yugoslavia are sketchy.
All Mr. Vasiljevic will say is that he lived in several countries, including Australia, Belgium, Canada and the United States. "God knows the sectors I worked in, everything that makes money, almost," he declared.
Pressed for a little more detail, the mystery man revealed that he had worked as a broker in the precious stones and precious metals businesses. Where? All he would say is that he spent some time at diamond exchanges in Belgium.
In any event, by the time he returned to Yugoslavia in 1987, he was rich enough to start Jugoskandic, whose main activity, he said, was import-export trading. As specific as ever, he said this trading activity included about 1,500 different items. "But the sanctions are obviously causing a few problems and they are deeply unfair," he added.
 
Promoting a Brash Plan
 Obviously a fierce nationalist, Mr. Vasiljevic has described the chess match, scheduled to begin on Wednesday, as "open war against the embargo." Mr. Fischer has been warned by the United States Government that he could face a heavy fine or imprisonment for engaging in what is regarded as a business activity in Yugoslavia.
In theory, the chess match is supposed to bring Mr. Vasiljevic a profit through planned book and movie ventures tied to the games. It is also supposed to give a decisive lift to Mr. Vasiljevic's most ambitious project to date.
The chess series -- falsely billed as a world championship -- is to be played on the coast of Montenegro, the smallest republic in the old Communist state, on a stretch of land that the businessman recently acquired from the Montenegrin Government for a consideration of $500 million over five years. Mr. Vasiljevic wants to turn the 150 acre-site, which has four hotels and a casino, into a privately held state.
Here is the plan. Businesses registering in Sveti Stevan -- and the idea is to lure banks, trading companies and shipping concerns, among others -- would pay an annual income tax of just 2 percent. (Mr. Vasiljevic has already registered his own companies here, so he knows personally that this is advantageous.) Meanwhile, film and music festivals, conventions and other activities would bolster the standing of this projected mini-Cayman Island -- and raise Mr. Vasiljevic's income as well.
"The happenings at Sveti Stevan will dim the glory of the Cannes Film Festival, of the Pulitzer Prize and the Nobel Prize," Jugoskandic says in a brochure displaying Mr. Vasiljevic's brash style.
All this seems like a lot to hope for in a war-ravaged country, particularly when much has been banked on Bobby Fischer, a man at least as mysterious as Mr. Vasiljevic. But the entrepreneur, while smoking continuously and tapping his crocodile-skin-sheathed feet, insisted that he was not worried.
"Mr. Fischer is not eccentric," he said. "He just wants everything to be perfect. That is what makes him the champion of the world."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
One Channel Says Crime Doesn't Pay

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
"There are eight million stories in the Naked City," a stern-voiced announcer said in narrating that police drama set in New York. The producers of a 24-hour local news cable television channel that begins operations a week from today are painstakingly planning to insure that potential viewers and advertisers will not tune in to eight million stories about crime.
New York 1 News, as Time Warner Cable calls its service, will compete against local newscasts on broadcast television stations that are infused with enough sensationalism to fill a newsstand's worth of tabloids. Cable television often presents counterprogramming for somewhat younger, more affluent audiences, and New York 1 News will present alternative fare for those seeking information beyond what local newscasters delight in describing as "senseless slayings" -- no doubt to distinguish them from the sensible ones.
 
Not the Murder Network
 "It is not the New York City Murder Channel," Paul Sagan, vice president of news and programming at New York 1 News, asserted during an interview last week at the channel's office at 460 West 42d Street, near 10th Avenue. The office was bustling with start-up activities, from news anchors rehearsing to sets being built. 
 Ellen Mullins, the channel's marketing director, said, "We're going to stress the credibility of the product versus tabloid shows."
New York 1 News can do that, Mr. Sagan, a former news director at WCBS-TV, said, because unlike broadcast television "we don't have to be all things to all people."
"How do you make a broad-interest product to interest people at preset times?" he asked rhetorically, referring to his broadcast news rivals. "You turn out just 'gee whiz' stories."
By contrast, when New York 1 News signs on next Tuesday at 1 P.M., Eastern time, it will be available only to the 850,000 subscribers to Time Warner's six New York cable systems.
Or, as Phyllis Kessler, general sales manager, put it, advertisers should be delighted that unlike other media available to anyone, "this is the only medium you can buy that's prescreened for credit."
The less bloodthirsty approach seeks to address "some advertiser concern, or potential objection," that ad sales executives have faced since they began selling commercial time two months ago, said Larry J. Fischer, president of Time Warner City Cable Advertising, which is handling sales for New York 1 News.
Yet in meeting those concerns, the channel risks veering too far in the other direction, toward what Ms. Kessler described as spending "a lot of time celebrating New York." If one thing sends inveterate watchers of New York newscasts reaching for their channel-changers faster than incessantly gory reports, it is squishy-soft "good news" features.
So the introductory advertising campaign, by Dale Pon Advertising Inc. in New York, disobeys Johnny Mercer's advice by not eliminating the negative while accentuating the positive.
Posters on buses and telephone kiosks, in a fluorescent lime green chosen to match "an eye-opener" of a suit of Ms. Kessler's, carry the theme " 'Cause there's only 1 New York." Television commercials present fast-paced shots of local faces and places from Broadway to the Bronx Zoo.
" 'I love New York' is from a different era than we live in now," Dale Pon, the agency's president, said in a telephone interview, referring to the tourism campaign that became an anthemic salute to the city.
"This is a very difficult place to live and work, but nevertheless worthwhile," he added. "That's the thrust of our campaign."
Despite any perceived need for an around-the-clock information service focusing on New York's five boroughs, New York 1 News is arriving at a dreadful time for the local economy and, by extension, local advertising. Ad revenues will have to be wrested from other media, since most marketers are not raising ad budgets.
And not one of the four similar services around the country, including Channel 12 for Long Island, is yet profitable.
Still, the Time Warner executives are optimistic.
"For a product that's not even on the air, we have contracts well into the seven figures already," Ms. Kessler said. Among the several dozen advertisers signed, she added, are the New York Chevrolet-Geo and Buick dealer associations, New York Telephone, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the U.S. Healthcare and H.I.P. health plans, and Off Track Betting.
Rates for a single 30-second spot range from $200 to $750, compared with as much as $11,000 for one on "Eyewitness News," WABC-TV's "Naked City" of newscasts and New York's top-rated local broadcast news program.
The New York 1 News sales efforts have concentrated on offering advertisers sponsorships, at 13-week minimums, of regular program segments on subjects like weather and travel, at an average cost, Mr. Fischer said, of around $3,000 a week.
One national advertiser, Anheuser-Busch Inc., has become sole sponsor of an hour-long daily sports report at midnight, earning for its product a place in the show's title, "Budweiser Sports on 1."
Mr. Sagan said, however, that no news program would have a sponsor's name attached, denying New York 1 News a contemporary version of a practice prevalent in the early days of broadcast television. For instance, before NBC teamed Chet Huntley and David Brinkley, it presented the "Camel News Caravan," with television's first anchor, John Cameron Swayze, "hopscotching the globe for headlines."

GRAPHIC: Photo: An advertisement for New York 1 News, a 24-hour local news cable television channel that is to begin operation on Sept. 8. (Carrie Boretz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Some Silver Linings for the Dollar

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
There could be some good news for the American bond market in the serious troubles that are facing the bond markets in Europe.
It is possible that the outcome of a French referendum on European currency unity could mean lower interest rates there. And that would help stem the decline of the dollar, whose recent fall to record lows against the German mark has, at least temporarily, stalled the bond rally here. 
 This is the view of John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers in New York. He believes that if the French reject the Maastricht Treaty, there are three possible outcomes and two of them help support the dollar.
The third alternative, however, would weaken the dollar and probably slow growth in Europe even more, which would also hurt the American economic outlook.
On Sept. 20, the French vote whether to approve the treaty, which outlines the steps to a single currency and a European central bank by the end of the century.
 
Would Raise Inflation Fears
 If the referendum is defeated or, Mr. Lipsky said, if investors and speculators decide ahead of time that it is likely to be defeated, there could be turmoil in the European bond markets because the outlook for an economically joined Europe with declining inflation will be thrown into doubt. The British pound, the Italian lira and the French franc could fall.
Mr. Lipsky argues that the following actions could be taken to try to limit the damage should the French reject the treaty:
*Interest rates could be raised to prop up the currencies in countries like Britain, France and Italy.
*As an alternative to raising interest rates, currencies within the European Monetary System, which tied Europe's major currencies in fixed trading ranges, could be revaluated or realigned.
*The central bank of Germany, the Bundesbank, could indicate that interest rates there would not be increased. The Bundesbank would send this signal by easing short-term market interest rates. The bank would do this if it decided it wanted to avoid the potential damage from either a currency realignment or interest rate hikes in other countries.
 
Good Move for Dollar
 Such action by the Bundesbank would help the dollar, which has been pulled lower by the very high interest rates in Europe, by indicating that the attractive European rates would not go any higher. And a realignment, Mr. Lipsky said, would open the way to lower interest rates because the weaker currencies would be set in lower trading ranges versus the mark.
The one problem here is that Mr. Lipsky and others still believe the most likely option is raising interest rates to defend the weaker currencies.
"That has to be seen as the most likely outcome," Mr. Lipsky said. Just last week European finance ministers said they opposed any realignment. One reason is that such a move could derail the movement to a single currency. And the credibility of the Bundesbank as an inflation fighter could be damaged if it signaled that it would tolerate lower interest rates.
 
Treasury Market
 The bond market was little changed yesterday in slow trading ahead of the Labor Day weekend. The market is still constrained by a weak dollar while supported by a string of economic data that show slow economic growth and declining inflation.
In late trading in the secondary market, the 7.25 percent 30-year bond was offered at 98 4/32, up 5/32, to yield 7.40 percent, down from 7.41 percent on Friday.
In the weekly auction of three-and six-month bills, the average discount rate rose for the third consecutive week.
The focus of traders this week is on Friday, when the Labor Department releases the employment report for August. The data are expected to be a little confusing because they will include new jobs created through a special Government supplemental jobs program. That data also distorted the job increase of 198,000 reported for July.
 
Expect Little Change
 The unemployment rate and the associated data will be the first clear indicator of the how the economy performed in August, and traders are looking for information to confirm that the economic recovery has not picked up steam.
"Most people are expecting data that is not threatening" to the current view of the economy, said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chemical Securities in New York.
Mr. Fine said he expected nonfarm payroll jobs to increase about 75,000 after the jobs from the Government program are subtracted. These jobs could add 100,00 to 125,000 to the total.
'Seventy-five thousand is barely growing," he said. It is just marginally faster than a snail's pace."
Following are the results of the weekly auction of three- and six- month Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: For Ferraro, Cheers of '84 Are Still Resonating

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
They had made this pilgrimage once before, grandmother and 11-year-old granddaughter, heading off together to a political rally to get a glimpse at living history, at Geraldine A. Ferraro, the first woman to be nominated by a major party for the Vice Presidency.
That was in 1984. Since then, Wendy Fresn has grown old enough to vote. Her grandmother, Florence R. Corron, broke down political barriers herself, becoming, as she puts it, the "first and only" woman to be elected a Town Supervisor in Clinton County. She's still serving strong at age 70. 
 And last week, the two were lined up again in Plattsburgh, N.Y., to see Ms. Ferraro, now a candidate for the United States Senate, undeterred by Ms. Corron's credentials as a Republican officeholder. "I was so upset when she lost," said Ms. Fresn, fumbling for words to describe her girlhood grief at the rout of the Democratic ticket of 1984. "Now that I'm old enough, I'm able to control what happens because I'm voting."
More than eight years have passed since Ms. Ferraro, a three-term Congresswoman from Queens, walked onto a convention stage in San Francisco to a roar of raw emotion, as the delegates below cheered, danced and cried.
 
Stars and Suffragettes
 Now, a grayer, more battle-hardened Ms. Ferraro is in a four-way Democratic primary race for a Senate seat from New York that has moved into high intensity in its final weeks. But as Ms. Ferraro crisscrosses the state, it often feels as if the race of 1984 has come out of suspended animation.
Her opponents complain that she has become the front-runner in the Senate race based on a skin-deep "star quality" gained in the Vice-Presidential race. The women who flock to Ms. Ferraro's campaign events say there is more than just her notoriety: They talk passionately about how much it meant to them to see a woman run for Vice President and how much they want her to have a second chance.
In the introductions along the campaign trail, Ms. Ferraro's name is once again paired with the suffragette Susan B. Anthony. The screams and cheers that greet her have a slightly soprano pitch, a woman's tone. And in a campaign year when Marilyn Quayle, the wife of the Vice President, is using phrases like "essential natures" to imply that a woman's place is back in the home, Ms. Ferraro knows how to hit the countertones that she perfected eight years ago.
"Equality," she mused at a recent breakfast fund-raiser in Manhattan. "I guess that means with men," she said, her voice dropping low, husky and sarcastic. "Isn't that sweet?"
The darker more troubling side of the Vice-Presidential campaign has returned as well. The news organizations and Ms. Ferraro's opponents have raised questions once more about her husband's business dealings and about whether the candidate and her family have had uncomfortably close associations with organized-crime figures.
Eight years ago the drumbeat of charges derailed her campaign. This time Ms. Ferraro is fighting back by attempting to turn the campaign attacks into a feminist issue that will rally female voters to her side on Sept. 15. She has portrayed herself as a Joan of Arc, an Anita F. Hill, a woman martyred for daring to take on the male establishment. It makes no matter that the candidate most aggressively leveling the charges against her is also a woman, the New York City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman. The State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, and the Rev. Al Sharpton are the other candidates for the right to oppose Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato on Nov. 3.
"This race is not about Gerry Ferraro, the shady supporting player from America's most-wanted list whose bio is created by innuendoes glued together over the past 70 years," Ms. Ferraro said at the fund-raiser, held last Wednesday in Manhattan to celebrate her 57th birthday.
In a touch of the true confession politics that characterized the Democratic National Convention, she implied that she had exhibited the most durable family values by standing loyally with her husband, John A. Zaccaro, and with her son, John Jr., who was convicted of selling cocaine.
She called herself "a mother and wife who understands that life is not always perfect, but where family is, family puts its arms around each other and is there. When there's troubles you go through them."
Upstate in Malone an interviewer on a cable station almost apologetically backed into several questions about the allegations against Ms. Ferraro's family, never actually asking her to address them.
 
Calling for Issues
 Ms. Ferraro, who has compared the charges to "McCarthyism," dismissed The Village Voice -- where the allegations resurfaced late last month -- as a "left-wing weekly." Then she asked that viewers to join her against negative campaign tactics. "It's gutter politics," she said, staring intently at the woman asking questions. "It's really awful."
She added, "I would hope the voters would demand -- not only in this race, I'm talking about the Clinton-Bush matchup -- demand where people stand on the issues."
Wednesday evening, two lone protesters screamed "Violent pornographers, Gerry!" and waved pictures of nude, bound women, as Ms. Ferraro ignored them and raised her voice to address women gathered outside a restaurant for a fund-raiser for the New York City chapter of the National Organization for Women.
One of the demonstrators, Page Mellish, said the pictures were distributed by Star Distributors Inc., a pornographer linked to organized crime that was a tenant in a building in which Ms. Ferraro's husband owns a 50 percent interest and is managed by a family company that lists Ms. Ferraro as an officer. Television commercials run by Ms. Holtzman have accused Ms. Ferraro of taking $300,000 in rent from the pornographer.
But other women who still line up for Ms. Ferraro's autograph and use phrases like idol and heroine to describe her seem willing to accept her premise that she is being victimized. "She's paying the price," said Nancy DuFrain, a Clinton County legislator, arguing that the scrutiny of Ms. Ferraro's husband and her family was a double-standard applied to a female politician. "Does Bobby Abrams have a wife?" she demanded. "I don't know. And what does her uncle do?" She made sure to have her picture taken with Ms. Ferraro.
For Chris Hobsen Whalen, 33, who was waiting for Ms. Ferraro to appear at a luncheon for business and professional women, the drug conviction of the candidate's son made the Senate contender even more appealing. "Just to overcome it personally in her private life is a plus," she said. "That helps her understand what real people go through."
Ms. Ferraro's staff members say they have seen no slippage in the polls despite the resurrection of allegations about family businesses. And the candidate says she is not surprised. Ms. Ferraro said she had done extensive polling before entering the Senate race in 1991 to see whether she could withstand such a barrage. "I was not going to get into a race that wasn't winnable," she said. "I wasn't going to kid myself."
 
Shifting Spending Priorities
 For the most part, as she campaigned across the North Country last week, Ms. Ferraro was able to ignore the allegations that are being blared in television commercials downstate, where 70 percent of the primary electorate is.
She campaigned instead by lashing into the Republican administration for the stalled national economy. She called for cuts in military spending, for more money for education, and for a Federal jobs program rebuilding the nation's aging infrastructure. "The system is not working," she said to one luncheon crowd. "I know it. You know it. George Bush knows it. And Dan Quayle may not know it, but Marilyn will tell him."
But with at least 55 percent of the typical New York primary electorate made up of women -- and the number expected to go still higher this month, drawn out by the candidacies of Ms. Ferraro and Ms. Holtzman -- Ms. Ferraro always comes home to women's issues, particularly abortion rights.
When she ran for Vice President, Ms. Ferraro gave a mixed message on abortion. She said that as a Catholic she personally would not have an abortion. But she also added that if she were raped and became pregnant she was not certain she could be "so self-righteous." She insisted that each woman should have the right to make her own choice on the issue.
Now she simply speaks out forthrightly about a woman's right to choose, dispensing with the former caveats. "In 1984 people didn't know me and I had to explain myself," she said recently, when asked why she no longer brings up her own scruples when discussing the volatile issue. "I'm 57 now," she added. "I can no longer say, 'If I were ever to become pregnant,' so it's academic."

HEADLINE: Dominican Immigration Alters Hispanic New York

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
Jackie Saltares remembers a time not that long ago when the Puerto Ricans were the undisputed kings of Hispanic New York and Spanish Harlem was the spiritual and physical center of their realm.
El Barrio, the neighborhood, was home to thousands of Puerto Ricans who settled into cramped walk-up apartments on the narrow side streets and who bustled along the wide shopping avenues, eager if weary travelers on the road to the American Dream. 
 Now, an increasing number of immigrants from the Dominican Republic have come to El Barrio, snapping up apartments and businesses that were once the domain of Ms. Saltares's countrymen. When she walks down her block on East 115th Street, the three bodegas and two beauty parlors owned by Dominicans loom as reminders of just how aggressively the new arrivals are staking their claim.
 
'There's Another Dominican'
 "Every time you turn around, there's another Dominican," she said. "It's like our neighborhood doesn't belong to us anymore."
That neighborhood is not just El Barrio. It is the entire territory of Hispanic New York -- its politics, its economy, its society. And Ms. Salteres's unease underlines a debate, sometimes friendly, sometimes not, in that territory that echoes from El Barrio to the Bronx, Brooklyn and beyond as Puerto Ricans try to adjust to a changing world.
Members of both groups acknowledge that this rivalry could hinder their intertwined aspirations for power and influence in an increasingly Hispanic city: according to city and census records, Hispanic New Yorkers grew from 16.3 percent of the population in 1970 to 19.9 percent in 1980 to 24.4 percent in 1990. The rivalry manifests itself in grumblings, tensions and slights ranging from silly stereotypes to accusations of exclusion and nationalistic "me first" myopia. In many ways it is a late 20th-century reprise of the jousting played out generations ago by other struggling immigrants, the Irish and the Italians, the Germans and the Jews.
In part, it is a matter of demographics. In one generation, a big change in immigration has wrought a major shift in the city's Hispanic population. The Mexican Consulate, for instance, estimates that since the mid-1980's, the number of Mexicans living in the New York metropolitan region has grown from 60,000 to more than 200,000.
New York has ever-increasing numbers of Central and South Americans and especially Dominicans. While 20 years ago Hispanic New Yorkers were almost always Puerto Rican, the 1990 Census estimated that the city's 896,763 Puerto Ricans now account for about half its Hispanic population, probably less when illegal immigrants are taken into account.
Dominicans, their migration spurred by political upheaval in the mid-60's and by economic hardship in later years, have become the city's second-largest Hispanic group, numbering 332,713, with thousands more illegal and uncounted.
And while both groups still live on the struggling side of success, the Dominicans have made substantial economic progress in a single entrepreneurial generation, buying up bodegas, restaurants and livery-cab fleets around the city.
 
Is Political Agenda Too Puerto Rican?
 As Dominicans come into their own, some feel they are being held back in politics and community organizations where their concerns are given lip service while the leadership pursues a narrowly Puerto Rican agenda.
Dr. Rafael Lantigua, an internist active in Dominican political and community affairs, said that when a Hispanic Congressional seat was proposed for the West Bronx and Washington Heights, some Puerto Rican politicians suggested one of their own as a possible candidate without consulting with the Dominican community. He said that when Dominican political types questioned the move, they were told to be patient.
"We all sit at the table when it comes time to draw lines," said Guillermo Linares, the first Dominican elected to the City Council. "When the time comes to determine who represents all of us, we no longer find ourselves at the table."
One high-ranking city official who is Dominican was more blunt, when he said that the Puerto Rican politicians wanted them to ask for permission rather than consult.
"We're never going to do that," he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. "For that we'd go back to the island."
Some Dominicans insist with some smugness that they will outpace a Puerto Rican community that they feel has never realized the advantages of their dual benefits of being the city's longest-established Hispanic group and one that is born with United States citizenship.
Considering themselves the pioneers among the city's Hispanic groups and the leaders in struggles for bilingual education, voting rights and fair financing for social-service groups, some Puerto Ricans worry that the newcomers are riding on their coattails. And they are quick to add that they remain the main political bloc, accounting for some 80 percent of the city's registered Hispanic voters.
"Other groups may be forgetting that we busted our backs to make New York a bilingual town," said Representative Jose E. Serrano, who is Puerto Rican. "In typical Puerto Rican fashion we will share those gains with all our Latino brothers. But now that the fruits are coming in, the people have to admit publicly how this happened. We can't run the risk of someone rewriting history and making it look like New York City became a bilingual town in 1985."
Despite the misgivings in the city, many from both groups see their futures bound together by a common language and concerns, and there are members of both groups working together for their communities. They anticipate reaping the benefits of their political and civic cooperation. The existing tensions are the growing pains of an evolving relationship.
"You find like in any good marriage, there's a lot of conflict," said Palmira Rios, an assistant professor of urban planning at the New School for Social Research, "But somehow you continue living together."
Even though Jackie Saltares had qualms about the growing Dominican presence in her neighborhood, she knew that the two groups had more in common than not. It's a weird feeling, she said, made all the more odd by the fact that one of her closest friends is a Dominican woman who dispelled her teen-age notions that Dominican women were rubes or husband-hunting hussies.
"I know there's this ongoing feud between Puerto Ricans and Dominicans, but I never really understood it," she said, adding that the two groups shared too many ethnic, cultural and historic bonds to allow themselves to be bogged down in bickering. "This doesn't make sense to hate yourself."
 
Act of Kindness Amid the Brickbats
 Jose Luis Reyes, a 28-year-old Dominican immigrant who works as a clerk at a Washington Heights variety store, chuckled at the brickbats tossed between his compatriots and Puerto Ricans.
"Some Puerto Ricans say Dominicans come here to get welfare," he said, standing on the sidewalk, a hectic array of shoes, T-shirts and soccer balls behind him. "The Dominicans say that Puerto Ricans live off the government."
His more nationalistic friends sometimes taunt Puerto Ricans by reminding them that their island is a United States possession. "They say that Puerto Ricans don't have a real flag," he said.
Mr. Reyes doesn't buy into that talk; he once worked for a Puerto Rican store owner who took him under his wing, giving him a chance to earn a decent wage and inviting him to his house to unwind after work.
Nonetheless, he wondered why Puerto Ricans have not made more strides, especially in the business world, given the head start they have on other Hispanic immigrants in both time and citizenship.
Marlene Cintron, a Puerto Rican who is the director of the Office of Latino Affairs for Mayor David N. Dinkins, said her recent marriage to a Dominican sparked some mean-spirited offhand remarks about his citizenship at a fund-raising reception, where she was seated at a corporate table with several influential New Yorkers.
"A white woman who is married to a Puerto Rican came over to comment on my marriage," Ms. Cintron recalled. "She finished her statement and said, 'We were wondering if your husband needed papers.' At which time the rest of the table proceeded to laugh. I left very hurt."
Personal slights notwithstanding, in her circle, where she is in contact with the political leaders and community advocates for the city's various Hispanic groups, Ms. Cintron sees no major strife between Dominicans and Puerto Ricans. "Those who understand real empowerment understand that we need to do it together," she said.
In many measures -- income, education, poverty rate -- the two groups are seemingly indistinguishable, said Professor Rios of the New School. "The idea that one community is so much better or worse doesn't really hold," she said.
Dominicans own most of the city's bodegas in large part because of a generational shift, buying them from Puerto Rican owners who decided to retire or whose college-educated children sought broader opportunities in the mainstream labor force. Ms. Rios noted that while social indicators for the city's Puerto Rican population paint a bleak picture, they overlook the fact that an increasing number of Puerto Rican professionals have moved away from the city.
Still, Dominicans who work for community-based groups say that nonprofit groups founded by Puerto Ricans will gladly serve Dominican clients while refusing to allow Dominicans into leadership and decision-making posts.
Several community advocates noted that during the recent disturbances in Washington Heights, most of the city's Hispanic elected officials, nearly all of them Puerto Rican, made little effort to reach out to the Dominican community.
"I think a lot of Puerto Ricans were confusing their agenda as the only one on the table," said Moises Perez, the executive director of Alianza Dominicana, a social service agency in Washington Heights. "Now, they have to share space at the table."
 
Squabbling Fiercest When Pie Is Small
 Mr. Perez said that the rivalry boils down to squabbling over limited financing.
"Some people in the Puerto Rican community are taking the low road and see it as Dominicans and other Latinos taking over what they built," he said. "But others who are more visionary understand that we have to look at the pie as having to be bigger than it has been. We have to fight for a bigger pie."
In practical terms, Puerto Ricans still constitute some 80 percent of the city's registered Hispanic voters, making them crucial to the victory of any candidate wooing that vote. One senior Puerto Rican elected official said that the Dominican community did not have the votes to elect one of their own to Congress, and that those victories they have had were propelled by Puerto Rican votes.
"We gave them a Council seat and we may give them an Assembly seat," said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "We got to fight it for them each time. They have got to wait some time. It's not their time. It's hard politics."
A growing segment of younger Hispanic residents, raised in the city and sharing a common outlook as New Yorkers, have been building coalitions that would reap benefits for all. Many see the squabbles as infighting among political elites that in the long run will do little to lift either community.
As executive director of Alianza Dominicana, Mr. Perez said he was heartened by those efforts. Nonetheless, he made clear that the work was long and time was short.
"We either share it or we compete," he said. "And if we compete, get ready to run."

HEADLINE: Boeing Names a President Who Is Seen as Future Chief

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

 BODY:
The Boeing Company yesterday named Philip M. Condit president and a member of the board. Although Frank Shrontz, Boeing's 60-year-old chairman and chief executive, said he had every intention of keeping his position until he reached the company's customary retirement age of 65, Mr. Condit's promotion was widely viewed as the naming of an heir apparent.
Mr. Condit, who is 51, has most recently been an executive vice president and general manager of Boeing Commercial Airplane Group's 777 division, where he had primary responsibility for developing the company's newest commercial jet. 
 "The world has changed and we have to change with it to remain viable, and I can use some help in doing that," Mr. Shrontz said at a news conference yesterday in Seattle, where Boeing has its headquarters. He said development of the 777 was far enough along that Mr. Condit's move would not jeopardize the program. "It is an appropriate time to bring somebody over here to give me some assistance in long-term direction," he said.
Mr. Condit's promotion had little effect on Boeing's stock, which has been depressed lately, and closed yesterday with a loss of 12.5 cents, at $37.25, in a down market on the New York Stock Exchange. But analysts said he would prove a popular choice to head Boeing, which is the world's largest commercial aircraft manufacturer.
"He's a guy that's just charged with energy," said Howard A. Rubel, an analyst with C. J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell. "If you look across the ranks of all the people there," Mr. Rubel said, "he in lots of ways personifies all the good things Boeing stands for -- engineering excellence, hard-nosed attention to performance, and willingness to listen. He's the right choice for the company for the 90's."
Boeing is under increasing pressure as the recession takes its toll on airlines, reducing their orders for new airplanes. Although still the dominant commercial aircraft supplier, with a 55 percent market share, Boeing faces ever stronger competition from the Airbus Industrie consortium in Europe, which last month broke Boeing's long hold on United Airlines as a customer, winning an order for as many as 100 new medium-range jetliners.
In this environment, Mr. Condit said it was more important than ever for Boeing to focus on its customers, and he cited his experience working with airlines to develop the 777.
"It is one of the things Boeing has always done well, but it is also something that if you don't pay attention aggressively, it can get away from you," Mr. Condit said in a telephone interview. On the 777, "we went out and very consciously said we want airline people here," he said. "We actually had them into the design review, and we've never done that before," he added. "So, they were a part of the process."
Wolfgang Demisch, an analyst with UBS Phillips & Drew, said that Mr. Condit's management of the 777 project demonstrated an ability to work both with customers and with suppliers, who now play more of a partner role on new aircraft.
"That requires a greater willingness to communicate and interface with people who are not working for the same entity," he said, adding that Mr. Condit "has a demonstrated track record at working with people outside and working well with them."
Mr. Condit will be succeeded by Alan R. Mulally, vice president-engineering of the 777 project since 1989.
Unlike Mr. Shrontz, whose background is in accounting, Mr. Condit is an engineer. He came to Boeing in 1965 as an aerodynamics engineer on the original supersonic transport program. He spent three years on the 747 program, and moved up through a series of positions in engineering management, production, sales and marketing. He became executive vice president of the commercial airplane group in April 1985.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Boston Bank Will Acquire Savings Unit

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The carving up of the Connecticut banking market by larger banks moved ahead yesterday as the Bank of Boston agreed to acquire the Society for Savings, Hartford, in a stock deal worth about $200 million.
The merger is a signal that both Society, a savings bank with $2.8 billion of assets, and the Bank of Boston, with $32 billion in assets, have weathered the downturn of the region's economy and real estate market, and are now healthy enough to consider long-range prospects, not just solving immediate problems. 
 With the addition of Society, Bank of Boston's Connecticut subsidiary will become the fourth-largest bank in the state, moving up from eighth.
 
$470 Million Raised
 In expectation of acquisitions in a region where there are many weak banks, the Bank of Boston earlier this year raised $470 million through sales of common and preferred stock.
The current deal calls for each share of Society stock to be exchanged for eight-tenths of a share of Bank of Boston stock. Society's shares rose $2.625 yesterday, to $15.125, in over-the-counter trading, and Bank of Boston stock fell $1.25, to $20.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Society, which lost a total of $116.9 million in 1990 and 1991, has earned $3.5 million so far this year and is expected to earn more in coming quarters because its problems with bad loans are waning.
But the industry still faces problems in Connecticut. Nine other savings banks in the state with assets totaling $5.9 billion have 10 percent or more of their assets in badly delinquent loans or repossessed real estate -- a level considered perilously high.
Several commercial banks are also troubled by bad loans, the largest being the Union Trust Company of Stamford, with $3.3 billion in assets. Its parent company, Northeast Bancorp, is considering whether to find a partner, analysts said.
Although Society had considered other offers to buy parts of its business, and on May 29 said it had decided to remain independent, the latest offer apparently was too good to refuse.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Shows Some Losses In a Day of Quiet Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined yesterday in uneventful trading on world currency markets.
Dealers said trading was light, as holidays closed markets and financial institutions in London and Hong Kong. 
 The dollar was hindered by a worse-than-expected report on single-family home sales in the United States during July. The Government said seasonally adjusted sales of new homes fell 2.6 percent from the previous month despite the lowest mortgage rates in 19 years.
Among European currencies, the German mark continued to benefit from high interest rates. The Swiss franc drew strength as investors "moved to quality" amid uncertainties surrounding Europe's plan for political and economic union, said Randolph Donney, research director at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 123.42 yen, down 0.18 yen from Friday's close. During the European trading day, the dollar was quoted at 123.28 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 123.05 yen, unchanged from Friday.
The British pound was quoted at $1.9810 in Europe, down from $1.9815 late Friday in London. In New York it cost $1.9880 to buy one pound, more expensive than Friday's $1.9825.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday, included: 1.4030 German marks, down from 1.4090; 1.2495 Swiss francs, down from 1.2610; 4.7825 French francs, down from 4.8000; 1,071.25 Italian lire, down from 1,077.50, and 1.1950 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1966.
Gold prices rose in limited trading. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $342.70 an ounce, up $2.80 from Friday. The Republic National Bank said gold was up $2.45 an ounce, to a late price of $342.20.
On the Comex in New York, silver for current delivery settled at $3.730 an ounce, up from $3.674 on Friday.

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Managed Care: Is It Effective?

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
TRYING to slow the rise in health-care costs, American employers spent some $13 billion last year for managed-care services. But national spending on health continued to grow at double-digit rates, leading some experts to question the effectiveness of managed care.
Managed care typically includes a review of each case before agreeing to pay for treatment. The payers often also encourage patients to use networks of hospitals and doctors to meet cost- and quality-related standards of care, often at discounts. 
 Many health-care proposals in Congress and state legislatures rely heavily on managed care for cost control. But the Congressional Budget Office discouraged hopes for savings in a recent report to the House and Senate tax-writing panels.
"The growth of managed care does not appear to have affected systemwide costs," the Budget Office said in a staff memorandum to Congress. "Based on existing knowledge, it cannot be assumed that further growth of managed care would reduce either the level or the rate of increase of systemwide health-care spending," although it added that "reliable evidence on the effectiveness of managed care is relatively sparse." National spending on personal health care grew by 10.7 percent, to $282 billion, last year.
Some companies report that managed care has helped slow the rise in their health costs. But hospitals and doctors often order more tests and procedures and raise fees to patients not under managed care.
The largest savings have shown up at health maintenance organizations in which doctors work on salary or in a group practice, the Budget Office added. It suggested that overall spending might be reduced by 10 percent in the unlikely event that everyone with health insurance joined this type of H.M.O. About 39 million people are enrolled in H.M.O.'s, of which 15 million are in staff and group models. Fifty million more are eligible to use discount networks.
Gary Yeaw, group insurance director at Allied- Signal Inc., which spent $400 million in 1991 on employee and retiree heatlh care, said staff model H.M.O.'s had yielded much better results than more loosely organized medical networks. He said health costs for 48,000 Allied-Signal employees in all types of H.M.O.'s had increased 10 percent to 11 percent annually since the company made a strong commitment to managed care six years ago, compared with increases of 20 percent a year for 22,000 employees under traditional coverage.
"We feel managed care is working, but clearly more needs to be done," Mr. Yeaw said.
Several managed-care advocates said it was too early to judge the concept. Alain Enthoven, professor of management at Stanford University's business school, said H.M.O.'s would have to compete more vigorously on prices. Doctors and hospitals are not chosen on the basis of cost, partly because the burden is shared through tax deductions, and most employers are not hard bargainers.
Joseph W. Duva, a partner and managed-care expert with Ernst & Young, added that most employees could still choose a doctor and hospital regardless of price.
Patricia Wilson, a principal with the A. Foster Higgins benefits consulting firm, argues that employers need to buy health services like other commodities. "You have to get your hands dirty," she said, and deal with doctors and hospitals on prices and specifications. But she added, "Many employers do not have the resolve to do it."
Dr. Paul M. Ellwood, chairman of Interstudy, a nonprofit managed-care research organization, said that employers, patients and doctors also needed to know more about the likely results from a given test or treatment to make informed choices. "There's more to managing care than a straight bottom line on costs," he said.
Harold S. Luft, a professor of health economics at the University of California, San Francisco, said that even when H.M.O.'s produced savings, employers and unions often took the savings in added benefits like prescription drugs and eyeglasses, instead of pushing them to cut premiums. He added that H.M.O.'s were too small in most regions to resist community pressures to pay for the use of expensive new medical equipment.
Dr. David M. Eddy, a professor of health policy and management at Duke University, said that "even if managed care is the answer, I doubt that it is the only answer." He added, "If we are going to control costs, we need a system in which the decision makers feel pressure to provide high quality care and control costs.
Kenneth S. Abramowitz, a health-care analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, estimated the cost of managed care was about $13 billion in 1991 for about 90 million people in H.M.O.'s and other networks, plus 40 million in traditional health plans that second-guess physicians.
And Bill Custer, research director of the nonprofit Employee Benefit Research Institute in Washington, said it might be five years or more before "a nice national study is available."

HEADLINE: White House's View of Dollar

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31

 BODY:
The White House said today that the United States was not trying to depress the value of the dollar as a means of spurring American exports.
Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said the dollar's decline "largely reflects the fact that U.S. interest rates are 6.5 percentage points lower than German interest rates." 
 He added that the United States "does not believe that a lower dollar is necessary for its export competitiveness."
Mr. Fitzwater said he did not think there was any connection between the fall of the dollar and President Bush's proposal for across-the-board tax cuts.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Restaurant Issues Hold Their Own

BYLINE: By Kenneth N. Gilpin

 BODY:
CONSUMERS may have less money to spend, but dining out is decidedly not out.
According to the National Restaurant Association, the average family spends 43 cents of every food dollar at restaurants. That number, which includes everything from takeout pizza to meals on airliners, has never been higher. This year, the group estimates that food service sales will reach $262 billion, up 5.6 percent from the $248 billion spent in 1991. 
 Such statistics have helped the stocks of most publicly traded restaurant companies hold their own fairly well this year, after a banner performance in 1991. For the year through last Friday, the 23 restaurant stocks tracked on a daily basis by Montgomery Securities have declined by 6 percent, compared with a 1 percent drop in the Standard & Poor's 400 average.
In some respects, the drop should have been expected, because prices of those same stocks rose a hefty 59 percent in 1991, compared with a 27 percent increase in the S.& P. 400 average.
That the drop this year was only 6 percent is surprising, given that the industry has seen no growth in spending on an inflation-adjusted basis in nearly three years and is raising prices at the slowest pace in close to three decades.
Declining labor and food costs have helped lift profit margins at many restaurant companies, as have lower interest rates. But analysts say the main reason big chains have done more than survive during the recession is through expansion.
"The fact that food costs have been very favorable has helped a little bit," said Barry M. Stoufer, a partner at J. C. Bradford & Company in Nashville. "But the bulk of the earnings growth has been due to unit expansion."
To be sure, the lingering recession has brought changes in where people go to eat, but people continue to eat out.
"There is no evidence to support the notion that a recession will stop people from going to a low-cost restaurant," said Michael G. Mueller, a managing director at Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. "Unless there is a depression, people won't curtail that sort of spending."
Jostling for market share in this enormous business are a relative handful of public companies dominated by the McDonald's Corporation.
Joseph Doyle, an analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham who has McDonald's on his buy list, acknowledges that McDonald's domestic earnings growth has probably peaked and will be a "fairly modest" 6 to 7 percent in the near to medium term. But the real growth potential lies abroad, Mr. Doyle says.
"In normal times, McDonald's foreign business can grow at a 20 percent annual rate," he said. "But right now there are recessions abroad as well, which tells me that this year's foreign earnings might grow in the area of 13 to 14 percent."
McDonald's stock closed at $42.50 a share on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, off 25 cents.
Other analysts are more cautious about McDonald's, a company they say is being squeezed by hamburger chains like Rally's Inc., whose restaurants mostly have only drive-up counters, and by companies developing niche markets by catering to aging baby boomers, like Brinker International and Applebee's International.
Chili's, a chain owned by Brinker, "is perceived now as offering better value than many fast-food chains," said Caroline Levy, the restaurant and food analyst at Lehman Brothers.
Ms. Levy, who called Brinker's management "one of the best" in the country, said she was also excited about the potential of Romano's Macaroni Grill, a Brinker division that next year will have 23 restaurants across the country.
"Macaroni Grill is one of the hottest new concept restaurants today," she said of the Italian food chain. Brinker stock closed at $36 yesterday, up 62.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Mr. Stoufer at J. C. Bradford keeps his focus on the smaller companies, and currently has two particular favorites, Morrison Inc. and Longhorn Steaks, two over-the-counter issues.
Known primarily as a cafeteria company, Morrison operates a casual dining division that contributes a little over 50 percent of the company's earnings, Mr. Stoufer said. Morrison stock closed at $24 a share yesterday, down 25 cents.
Longhorn, a casual dining steakhouse chain that went public in March, "is a classic growth stock," in Mr. Stoufer's opinion. "Their earnings should be growing at 30 percent to 35 percent a year." Longhorn, which went public at $16 a share, lost 50 cents yesterday, closing at $18.75.
Analysts noted that chains with higher-priced restaurants, like the Quantum Restaurant Group, TW Holdings and Chart House Enterprises, stand to benefit the most when the economy finally returns to robust health.

HEADLINE: Rebellion a Factor Keeping Egypt Out of U.S. Air Campaign in Iraq

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Aug. 31

 BODY:
When President Hosni Mubarak and his advisers considered the reasons for staying out of the American-led air campaign to protect Iraqi Shiites, it was a rebellion in southern Egypt, rather than southern Iraq, that was on their minds.
In recent months, Egyptian officials have grown worried about a sporadic and sometimes violent rebellion in the southern region, known as Upper Egypt for its Nile River topography compared to the lower-lying, northern Nile delta. 
 A small group of hard-line Islamic fundamentalists scattered in Upper Egyptian villages has battled the police and declared war on Mr. Mubarak and his Government.
Considering the strength of the fundamentalist opposition movement threatening Algeria's leadership, said one senior Government official here, it made no sense for Egypt to stoke anti-Western feeling by joining an American-led offensive to control the southern skies of an Arab country -- even if its leader is Saddam Hussein.
"It just adds fuel to charcoal" that "is still very hot," the official said, referring to the spread of Islamic fundamentalism. "The situation in parts of Egypt is very volatile."
The rebellion in southern Egypt is not considered an immediate or serious threat to Mr. Mubarak, but diplomats say it was one of several factors influencing Cairo's decision to keep its distance from the West in the current showdown with the Iraqi President.
 
Assertive Reconnaissance
 Saying it wanted to protect Shiite Muslims from Iraqi air attacks, a Western military coalition began enforcing an air shield over southern Iraq last week. United States and British planes have patrolled the skies in southern Iraq since Thursday without incident, although they have threatened to shoot down any Iraqi aircraft that ventures below the 32d parallel.
Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and some other gulf states have given logistical support to the Western pilots, but only Kuwait has publicly praised the air operation. A year and a half after Egypt and Syria joined American and European forces in ousting Iraqi troops from Kuwait, Arab governments are wary of being perceived as marching in lockstep with the West.
In southern Egypt, more than 50 people, including at least a dozen police officers, have been killed since March in battles among Muslim gunmen and security forces, and in clashes between Muslims and Coptic Christians. In the most serious incident, 14 people, including 13 Coptic Christians, were massacred by Muslim militants in May near Asyut, about 200 miles south of Cairo.
The fundamentalists say their goal is to purge Egyptian society of Western secular influences and turn the country into a Muslim state governed under strict interpretations of Islamic law.
Responding to the militants' violent campaign, the Government in Cairo adopted a law last month introducing the death penalty for members of terrorist groups.
At least six attacks on tourists or tourist sites in Upper Egypt have been reported this summer, including a firebomb attack on a French tour bus in July in which four passengers reportedly were slightly injured.
Arab governments say the political situation and mood in the region are different now from the situation two years ago, when Mr. Hussein's troops charged across Iraq's border into Kuwait. Then, Egypt, Syria and several gulf states rallied behind the Western-led military drive to defeat a leader viewed as the neighborhood bully.
The biggest concern now expressed by Arab governments is that the Western air operation will lead to a de facto partitioning of Iraq, creating a Kurdish zone in the north, a Sunni Muslim zone in the center and a Shiite Muslim zone in the south. Just as Turkey is wary of the Kurds, some Arab countries are concerned that the Iraqi Shiites and their fellow Shiites in neighboring Iran will gain a foothold on the Arabian peninsula.
Governments like Egypt's, whose foreign and economic policies are closely tied to those of the West, fear that the allied campaign on behalf of Iraqi Shiites will somehow embolden foes on the religious right and threaten their internal stability.
There is also concern that Iran and its allies will make gains in exporting their fundamentalist revolutions. Egypt has accused the Sudan, on its southern border, of sending weapons and infiltrators into Upper Egypt to foment revolution.
Rifaat Said, an Egyptian political leader who has organized a national campaign to unite Muslims and Christians, said Cairo should have gone further and condemned the allied air zone, saying it would only benefit Iran and the fundamentalists inside and outside Egypt.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Week;
'Did Not!' and 'Did So!' Frame the Tax Debate

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 31

 BODY:
As the choice between Bill Clinton and George Bush moves this week toward the traditional Labor Day opener of the general election race, it is clear that earlier fears were overstated.
The 1992 Presidential election will not degenerate entirely into a cheap, shallow, demagogic discussion on such issues as the parenting skills of Woody Allen and the party affiliation of God. While that sort of thing will remain a secondary subject of dialogue, the primary focus will be a debate on the economic future of America. 
 This, however, sounds a good deal loftier in the abstract than it is turning out in the concrete. So far, the great economic debate has gone along something like this:
Mr. Bush: You raised taxes and fees 128 times as Governor of Arkansas.
Mr. Clinton: Did not.
Mr. Bush: Did so.
Mr. Clinton: Did not, and anyway you raised taxes plenty yourself as President.
Mr. Bush: Did not, and if you were President, we'd have the biggest tax hike in history.
Mr. Clinton: Will not. It wouldn't be as big as the one you signed, the second-largest in history.
Mr. Bush: Tax and spend.
Mr. Clinton: Tax and spend.
Mr. Bush: Fearmonger.
Mr. Clinton: Fearmonger.
On its promissory side, the discussion is not much more elevated than it is on the accusatory. Mr. Bush, in his speech accepting his party's nomination, held out the glittering pledge of an across-the-board tax cut if re-elected, but was utterly vague as to how he would accomplish such a thing.
With an equal attention to detail, the Clinton campaign's first general election television commercials, unveiled Sunday, asserted that a Clinton Presidency would create eight million new jobs, in a presumably unintended echo of Mr. Bush's failed campaign pledge of four years ago to create 30 million new jobs.
There is no reason to think the level of dialogue will become greatly elevated over the course of the next two months; where it is at currently appears to satisfy the needs of both sides.
In the room at the Clinton campaign headquarters where James Carville, the chief strategist, spins and weaves, a sign on the wall reminds everyone: "The economy, stupid." The obvious point of the sign -- that for Mr. Clinton to win this race the subject must remain President Bush's handling of the economy -- tends to mask another point. The language of the sign consciously echoes a sign seen above the desks of office wits everywhere: "Keep it simple, stupid." A reasoned, nuanced debate on the nation's economic health is not likely to serve Mr. Clinton as well as a simple message: this country is in terrible economic shape and it is George Bush's fault.
Likewise for Mr. Bush, only more so. With polls showing consistently that most Americans have made up their minds on the subject (they do believe the economy is in rotten shape, and they do blame Mr. Bush), what he needs to do is change the subject to how much worse it would be if Mr. Clinton were President.
To this end, the Bush campaign has adopted, and plans to continue to adopt, a tactic of hitting Mr. Clinton almost daily with charges that he would, in one way or another, ruin the economy. Subtlety is not the point. The headlines of the Republican press releases read like supermarket tabloids: "True Confessions of a Tax-Addict," and "Clinton as Dukakis, The Trojan Horse Unveiled."
The Clinton campaign answers with "How About a No-Lie Zone?" and "George Bush and Taxes. No Help for the Middle Class."
The most illuminating episode in the debate to date has been the Bush campaign's charge that Mr. Clinton, as Governor, raised taxes and fees 128 times in Arkansas. The Republicans first floated this in a press release on July 29, and it was later voiced by Vice President Dan Quayle and the House Republican whip, Newt Gingrich of Georgia, and even by Mr. Bush himself, in his acceptance speech, when he asked people if they would trust him -- "a man who raised taxes one time and regretted it?" or Mr. Clinton, "who raised taxes and fees 128 times and enjoyed it every time."
While there is room to legitimately criticize Mr. Clinton's record in raising taxes as Governor of Arkansas, press reports cited the 128 figure as exceptionally distorted because it strongly suggested that the figure referred to 128 separate tax increases when in fact it included a number of separate provisions of the same tax increases and many routine fee increases. The Wall Street Journal, citing the Congressional Research Service, noted that these methods of accounting applied to the Federal Government under Ronald Reagan and George Bush would arrive at a figure of 327 tax increases and 250 tariff increases.
But Bush campaign officials show no concern over this, and promise to continue using the figure. "What does it really matter whether the number is 128 or 58 or whatever?" said one Bush official, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "That's not important, is it? What's important is the big picture. Who do you trust to be President? Who has a history of raising taxes and who does not? The 128 figure is just an illustration of the real issue, that's all."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%);

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Issues: Job Training;
President Joins Debate On Retraining Workers

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31

 BODY:
In offering a comprehensive skills and education plan for workers, the Bush Administration has joined in a debate over an issue that has grown in importance during the Presidential campaign.
The Democratic nominee, Gov. Bill Clinton, several months ago outlined an apprenticeship and training proposal that is much more ambitious than the Bush plan. Still, the Administration's proposal would be a significant expansion of the Government's job training efforts. 
 In addition to tripling the money the Labor Department now spends on retraining workers, the Administration seeks to establish a school-to-work program involving 1 million young people. Parts of the plan were proposed in limited form in April, but Congress did not act on the proposal.
"This is a new national commitment to job training," the President said in announcing his plan at a technical school in Union, N.J., last week.
The Clinton forces responded to the President's plan by calling it imitative and unfinanced, and questioned the President's commitment.
"This is just another false promise from a man who says anything as a candidate but does nothing as a President," Gene Sperling, economic policy director for Governor Clinton, said on Friday.
But there was no disputing the need to retrain the nation's labor force, only the means by which it should be accomplished. Indeed, this is one of the relatively few subjects about which both camps have offered plans detailed enough to invite more than philosophical comparison.
One major difference is that Mr. Clinton would require companies with 50 or more employees to spend 1.5 percent of their payroll to train their workers. Those spending less than this proportion, which the Clinton campaign says is the current corporate average, would be required to pay the difference into a fund for training workers of smaller companies.
This mechanism would produce enough money to make the Clinton apprenticeship plan five times as big as the one proposed by President Bush, whose aides speak of a program in which vocational schools are closely monitored and apprentices trained for existing jobs.
 
Two Main Elements
 The Administration plan consists of two main elements, one for retraining adult workers, at a cost of $2 billion a year, and the other for training for young people costing $1 billion.
For adults, the centerpiece of the strategy is what the Administration calls skill grants -- vouchers of up to $3,000 a year for two years for workers to refine job skills or learn new ones at colleges or trade schools.
Workers would also be eligible for counseling and job-search assistance. In addition, workers who had lost their jobs, had exhausted their unemployment insurance and were in retraining programs would be eligible for Federal assistance until until they found a job.
The skills grants would be available to workers who have lost their jobs or have been notified that their jobs are being eliminated and to workers in industries who fear job losses in the future.
The Administration estimates that 400,000 of 1.2 million workers affected each year by plant closings and large layoffs would use the vouchers, with about 150,000 of them needing Federal assistance while they complete their training. An additional 165,000 workers threatened by obsolete skills and technological shifts are expected to use skill grants for continuing education and training.
The new program would replace two major Labor Department programs dealing with laid-off workers, Trade Adjustment Assistance and Economic Dislocation and Work Adjustment Assistance.
Of the $2 billion the Administration would provide a year, two-thirds would be distributed to the states. Of the remaining $670 million, half would be used to ease the effects of the recently signed North American Free Trade Agreement and half would be spent on workers hurt by layoffs and plant closings in the military industry and in industries affected by the Clean Air Act, among other businesses.
For young people, the Bush plan has four components: the Youth Training Corps, a National Youth Apprenticeship Program, an anti-drug program and a doubling of the Junior Reserve Officer Training Corps.
In the proposal for the Youth Training Corps for 16 to 21 year olds from poor families, 25 centers, able to accommodate 43,000 students, would be added to the 30 existing Job Corps centers. Students would learn basic skills by working on conservation and environmental projects, some at unused military bases.
Steve Hofman, an aide to Labor Secretary Lynn Martin, conceded that the Clinton plan was more ambitious but criticized it as "a centralized program" that would not be as responsive to local needs as the Bush plan.
"We are striving to tap into local labor markets and conditions that are different from community to community," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Bill Clinton greeting a supporter yesterday in Little Rock, Ark., after leaving a restaurant. (Associated Press)
