HEADLINE: Budget Fight Goes On in California

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 31

 BODY:
With only hours to go before the Legislature was due to adjourn for the year, the two-month-long budget crisis in California reached a flashpoint this afternoon when Gov. Pete Wilson threatened to veto the budget bill because he could not accept an education spending plan approved earlier in the day by the state Assembly.
The new impasse, more of a dispute over future financing for public education rather than a clash over this year's spending, could wreck the budget package, major components of which passed the Legislature over the weekend. 
 A solution to the crisis had seemed almost in hand over the weekend when the Senate passed a budget plan acceptable to the Governor. The Assembly, too, approved an overall spending plan, but the Democratic majority in that house refused to go along with the education spending plan.
In an attempt to outmaneuver the Republican Governor, the Assembly's Democratic leadership negotiated this afternoon with conservative Assembly Republicans, who dislike the Governor, to try to get their support for the education plan passed today. The Democrats hoped to secure enough bipartisan support to send the plan to the Senate before midnight.
 
What Happens Next?
 It was not clear what would happen, should agreement not be reached by midnight. The Governor and the Legislature each has the power to call a special session.
The latest confrontation came as the state Capitol boiled with fury during the 63d day in which the most populous state has gone without a budget, the worst such crisis since the Great Depression. As of today, the state has paid its employees and creditors with $3.2 billion in i.o.u.'s and has stopped paying for the health care for the poor. As the Governor spoke to reporters, disabled people in wheelchairs staged a noisy demonstration outside his office, chanting "sign or resign."
Mr. Wilson said he was prepared to sign the budget, but not with the school plan pushed by the Democratic Speaker of the Assembly, Willie L. Brown Jr., which the Governor said could "lead to a seriously unbalanced budget."
On Saturday, the Senate passed a complete budget, both the overall financial blueprint and the dozen additional bills that are essential to put the budget into effect. The Senate package did not call for new taxation and was acceptable to the Governor.
 
Problems in the Assembly
 Later that day, the 80-member Assembly passed the overall blueprint but waited until Sunday night to take up the additional "trailer" bills. It passed three of them, which mainly cut $1.3 billion for local governments, and came back today to deal with the remainder, including spending on education.
There is no disagreement on the overall amount by which the budget has to be reduced. With revenues having fallen this year for the first time since before World War II, both sides have agreed to cut spending by 3 percent, from an estimated $55.1 billion last year to $53.5 billion this fiscal year. The Democrats two months ago gave up on the notion of raising taxes as politically infeasible in a recession that has hit California harder than most states.
About the only item that does not get cut is spending for public schools, kindergarten through community colleges. The budget allows state support to local school districts to grow somewhat to accommodate increases in enrollment and to keep spending per pupil at last year's level.
But a constitutional amendment passed by voters in 1988, called Proposition 98, requires that 40 percent of state revenues go to schools except when revenues falter. The dispute now is what to do about Proposition 98.
The Legislature has accepted Governor Wilson's plan to keep school spending steady with a series of bookkeeping acrobatics. This is how it works: The state "recaptures" $1.1 billion it paid to schools last year on the ground that, because of the drop in state revenue, the schools were overpaid. That money is made up this year by "lending" the schools $959 million from their Proposition 98 entitlement from future years, to be "repaid" over the next two budget years.
This brought howls from teachers unions and school administrators, who argued that it permanently reduced their financing by cutting the base on which future support is calculated.
To guard against an almost inevitable lawsuit from school districts challenging this plan, the Governor insisted on inserting a "poison pill" into the bill. This would allow him to suspend Proposition 98, and cut school financing, in the case of a successful lawsuit. The Senate accepted this approach.
But the Assembly, responding to the pressure from educators, who are powerful political forces in California, drew up a different kind of poison pill. In the case of a successful lawsuit, it would withhold the $959 million in "loans." Speaker Brown argued that this was a more effective tactic "because no school would run that risk" and file suit. He urged Governor Wilson to come "to the table of reality."
Governor Wilson denounced the Brown plan as a budget buster. If a lawsuit were successful, he said, spending would rise by about $2 billion: the lost $1.1 billion "recapture" plus the lost $959 million "loan." "There will not be a balanced budget if there are gaping holes in it," he said.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Buy Uranium Taken From Bombs Scrapped by Russia

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
The United States announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to buy billions of dollars' worth of bomb-grade uranium from scrapped Soviet nuclear arms in an attempt to bolster the shaky Russian economy and to reduce the risks of nuclear accidents or theft.
The agreement, which would require the formal approval of both Governments, calls for highly enriched uranium from Russian nuclear arms to be diluted for sale as commercial reactor fuel. It would be the first such agreement, and, if approved, would be a major step to reducing the dangers that made the cold war so unnerving. 
 "It's a big deal," said Barry Daniel, director of public affairs for the Energy Department, which will buy the uranium. "This provides a way to move the highly enriched uranium from nuclear weapons dismantled in Russia into this country and to keep it out of the wrong hands. It also provides capital to Russia, and part of the proceeds go to increasing the safety of nuclear reactors over there. It's a win-win situation."
The agreement was announced late yesterday by the White House after months of secretive negotiations. In a statement, President Bush said it "illustrates how foreign policy accomplishments can promote our domestic economic well-being while making the world a safer place to live."
The agreement calls for the United States to buy at least 80 metric tons of highly enriched uranium, with no less than 10 metric tons being bought in each of the first five years and no less than 30 metric tons thereafter. Private experts said that at prevailing market prices, that might amount to $5 billion or more over the period of the agreement.
Experts generally praised the agreement. "It's very significant," said Dr. Thomas B. Cochran, a senior scientist with the Natural Resources Defense Council, a private Washington group. "It doesn't prevent them from making new material. But what it does do, which is very good, is to remove a lot of excess weapons material from storage facilities that would otherwise be available for theft or sale to third parties."
 
Natural Ore Enriched
 Natural uranium ore is made up of a mixture of isotopes, or forms of the same element with different atomic weights. Less than 1 percent of it is uranium 235, the fissionable isotope used in bombs and reactors. Uranium for most American nuclear power reactors is enriched to a level of about 3 percent, while fuel for bombs has more than 90 percent. The agreement would basically reverse that enrichment process, diluting uranium 235 from bombs with natural uranium for use in commercial nuclear power plants.
Early this year, the Russians lined up several American companies that were eager to dilute highly enriched Russian uranium from warheads and to sell it as reactor fuel. And they repeatedly lobbied for the plan with Federal officials.
In July, Viktor N. Mikhailov, head of Russia's Atomic Energy Ministry, discussed the potential sale in Washington with top officials of the Energy Department, which oversees the nation's production of nuclear arms and civilian reactor fuel.
Among the American companies eager to make agreements are Allied-Signal Inc., an aerospace and chemicals company based in Morristown, N.J., which signed a preliminary agreement with the Russians.
"We think it is a terrific agreement," said David G. Powell, senior vice president for public affairs of Allied Signal. "Basically this is the beginning of a very productive arrangement by which we would in essence beat swords into plowshares, taking weapons-grade uranium and making it into fuel for nuclear power plants for peaceful uses."
Allied Signal and Nuclear Fuel Services of Erwin, Tenn., signed an interim agreement with Russian officials in July to buy 11 tons of highly enriched uranium by mid-1993, with similar amounts each year thereafter. No price was disclosed.
A major question is whether Russian bomb-grade uranium can be sold without significantly driving down prices on world uranium markets.
 
Any Impact on Budget?
 Russia, starved for cash, has already sold large quantities of natural and mildly enriched uranium in Western markets, feeding a price decline that has driven some producers out of business and threatening the uranium-enrichment business of the Energy Department, the world's largest supplier of commercial reactor fuel. Mr. Daniel, the Energy Department spokesman, said American uranium purchases would have no impact on the overall Federal budget because of money recouped from resales and from large savings in the department's own enrichment program.
The White House said the purchases "would have no adverse impact on American consumers or jobs in the uranium mining or processing industries." It said the department would use the uranium to reduce electricity costs at its enrichment installations.
The cost of the purchases, Mr. Daniel said, will be "in the billions, but I can't put a specific number on it." He added that the purchases would probably occur over 10 to 20 years.
Dr. Cochran of the Natural Resources Defense Council said that the agreement "favored the mining industry over the consumer because the alternative would be to sell it on the open market, which would reduce the prices of uranium and electricity."
By having the Energy Department make the purchases, the Government apparently believes it can insure that the influx of new supplies will not throw market prices into a decline.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Global Issues Weigh on Town As Factory Heads to Mexico

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CORTLAND, N.Y., Aug. 26

 BODY:
When the red brick buildings on Main Street were new eight decades ago, and the autos were bulky, black and few, a local steel company brought hundreds of low-wage workers here to upstate New York from Italy and the Ukraine rather than pay more to local workers.
Today, the steel company has long since closed and a rainbow of sleeker vehicles cruises Main Street. But once again a big local employer, this time the Smith Corona Corporation, is looking for cheap foreign labor. 
 Rather than importing foreign workers, however, Smith Corona announced last month that it was moving its typewriter manufacturing operations to Mexico, most likely to Tijuana. Although it plans to keep its much smaller engineering, distribution and customer service divisions here, Smith Corona will lay off 875 of its 1,300 workers in the next 12 months.
 
'Starting All Over Again'
 Smith Corona workers were generally unwilling to discuss the pending layoffs. But one worker who did talk was Barbara E. Miller, who assembles the typewriter mechanism that flicks the correction ribbon into place. "At 50, I'm not really looking forward to starting all over again," she said recently, as she sat on a hay bale near the large gray barn that she rents with her husband. "I have five weeks of vacation; it's back to scratch."
Corporate decisions like the one by Smith Corona have become a centerpiece in the national debate over President Bush's recently announced free trade agreement with Mexico and Canada.
The company's move highlights the continuing loss of high-wage manufacturing jobs to countries where labor costs are significantly lower.
The free trade agreement is "going to be responsible for a lot of these moves, and the least the American people can expect of their Government is some assistance," Ronald T. Walsh Jr., Cortland's Mayor, and a Democrat, said over bacon and eggs at the Community Restaurant on Main Street.
Free-market economists say that while towns like Cortland may be hurt by the trade pact, the nation will benefit over all as consumers save on everything from cantaloupes to T-shirts. Some factory relocations are good, economists contend, because they show that companies are doing business wherever they are most efficient, thereby increasing North America's overall economic output.
Most economists also contend that technological change is a larger factor than foreign trade in producing blue-collar layoffs. Smith Corona, whose typewriters have been a common graduation gift for several generations of Americans, employed 4,400 people in the mid-1970's. The company halved its work force in the late 1970's and early 1980's when it began building typewriters with fewer mechanical parts and more electronic equipment. The mechanical parts required considerable labor but the electronics can be stamped together cheaply.
Smith Corona's move followed a similar decision in October by the Zenith Electronics Corporation to send most of its remaining American television production to Mexico from Springfield, Mo. These moves were among the reasons for President Bush's announcement this month that, if re-elected, he would budget an extra $2 billion a year in Federal aid for workers who lose jobs because of foreign competition, environmental regulations or post-cold war shrinkage of the United States military.
Unemployment in Cortland County, at 8.3 percent in June, has been below the state average, in part because new industries, producing everything from garbage cans to packaging material, have flourished in this county of 49,000 people.
 
Staying With Typewriters
 As for Smith Corona, some analysts would attribute its problems to its own management, which continued making portable typewriters while the rest of the world moved on to portable computers.
"Their market analysts simply did not seem able to come to grips with the way things were moving," said Raymond G. Thorpe, a Republican and the Town Supervisor of Cortlandville, an area of dairy farms and cornfields that includes Smith Corona's factory and surrounds the much more populous city of Cortland. "They could have diversified into a lot of other areas to keep going, but they didn't do it."
G. Lee Thompson, the chairman and chief executive of Smith Corona, said the company had briefly participated in a joint venture in the personal computer market and found the market unprofitable. Personal computers with basic accessories cost at least $1,000 and are too complicated and expensive to compete with typewriters, which sell for less than $400.
Manual typewriters are no longer made in the United States, and only a few are imported each year from India, Brazil and elsewhere. Smith Corona also makes personal word processors, which basically consist of a computer printer, a computer screen and a keyboard but have very little computer processing power.
Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, contends that the United States is better off when companies move to Mexico and keep some operations in the United States -- as Smith Corona is doing -- rather than move halfway around the world to Southeast Asia.
Mr. Thompson and Jerry K. Pearlman, Zenith's chairman and chief executive, said they had to seek lower labor costs abroad. Moving to Mexico would keep more jobs in the United States than would moving to Asia, they contended in separate telephone interviews, adding that the prospect of a free trade agreement had not affected their decision.
"I believe, short term, there are going to be some displacements," Mr. Thompson said. "I believe long term the United States, Canada and Mexico have to form an alliance."
More and more companies are setting up operations south of the border -- nearly 2,000 factories in northern Mexico employ 500,000 workers to make goods for the United States while paying little or no tariffs under a Federal program to help Mexico. The moves reflect the extent to which technology, managerial skills and investment money have become more mobile than workers, turning poor countries into increasingly attractive places to build factories.
John R. McGrath, Smith Corona's senior vice president for operations and engineering, said labor costs accounted for a quarter of the cost of making a typewriter, and that moving to Mexico would allow Smith Corona to cut labor costs by four-fifths. Although moving will cost $15 million, it will save that much money every year after that, he added.
Smith Corona, which is traded on the New York Stock Exchange but is nearly half-owned by Hanson P.L.C. of Britain, pays manufacturing workers $11 an hour. Fringe benefits and factory supervisor compensation push the company's labor costs to $18 an hour. It estimates that labor in Mexico will cost less than $4 an hour.
 
Competition Overseas

 
 Smith Corona must reduce its costs to compete with low-priced typewriters imported from Japan and Southeast Asia, Mr. Thompson said. Labor costs in Asia are considerably lower than in the United States, though Japan's advantage may be partly a function of more efficient manufacturing processes. Mr. Thompson, however, blames the Bush Administration for not doing more to shield the company from unfairly cheap imports.
Over the last 12 years, the Commerce Department has repeatedly found Smith Corona's archrival, Brother Industries of Japan, guilty of selling its typewriters at unfairly low prices. But Brother has mostly avoided paying punitive Customs duties, by selling typewriters not subject to duties and by opening a typewriter assembly factory in Bartlett, Tenn.
Both Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic Presidential candidate, and President Bush have detailed plans for extra Federal spending on job training programs to help unskilled and semiskilled workers like those at Smith Corona. But these programs will not help Smith Corona's workers if the economy does not start growing more quickly.
The New York Department of Labor has "a lot of money ready to spend, but after 18 months of recession here in New York, what can we do?" said Roger A. Evans, a department economist. "The tougher issue is the job market."
Judy K. Davison, Cortland County's employment and training grant administrator, said her office had over the years met virtually all requests for help, although it has sometimes done so by asking local schools and colleges to accept students without collecting any tuition.
Aside from the job impact, city and county leaders played down the overall effect on the community. Smith Corona plans to keep the only large building it owns here while allowing leases on other buildings to expire, so local leaders do not expect an immediate drop in property tax revenues. Local leaders also say that a third of the company's workers commute from neighboring counties and that the company has not been a strong supporter of civic causes.
"They have been a modest citizen-donor type," Mr. Thorpe of Cortlandville said.
 
City Loses Aid
 When reductions in state revenue-sharing last year forced the City of Cortland to cut its budget for parks and youth programs by $143,000, to $492,000, the community responded by raising much of the money through voluntary donations. Cortland Asphalt Products resurfaced a 100-car parking lot in a park for a fraction of the usual price, saving the city $15,000. Smith Corona sponsored a swimming pool party for children that cost less than $300, said Francis N. Tokar, the city's parks and youth programs director.
David P. Verostko, the company's corporate vice president for human resources, said an annual fund-raising drive for the United Way was "the one major activity we do."
Smith Corona's severance pay policies are quite limited. The company, which earned $22.1 million on sales of $371.7 million during its fiscal year that ended on June 30, is offering half a week's pay for each year of service.
To receive the money, which Mr. Thompson describes as a "job continuance package," employees must stay with the company until they are actually laid off.

HEADLINE: George A. Roeper, 81, Educator in Michigan

 BODY:
George A. Roeper, an educator and founder of the Roeper City and Country School in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., died Aug. 24 in Oakland, Calif. He was 81 and lived in Oakland.
Mr. Roeper died of pneumonia, said Loiro Zinser, a spokesman for the school. 
 An authority on the education of gifted children, Mr. Roeper and his wife, Annemarie, founded the school in 1941, soon after they fled to the United States from their native Germany. The couple, who had met when Mr. Roeper was a student at a secondary school operated by Mrs. Roeper's parents, sought students of diverse ethnic and economic backgrounds. The school, which was begun as a lower school, began offering a high school program in the mid-1960's. Mr. Roeper retired as head of the lower school in 1979 and Mrs. Roeper as head of the high school in 1980.
Mr. Roeper was active with Amnesty International and was an early member of the Comparative Educational Society, which examines the education in other countries.
In addition to his wife, he is survived by two sons, Thomas, of Amherst, Mass., and Peter, of Oakland; a daughter, Karen, of Oakland, and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Review/Fashion;
Lighthearted Elegance In Resort Collections

BYLINE: By BERNADINE MORRIS

 BODY:
At a time when many fashion designers admit that most women's attitudes toward fashion are as sluggish as the economy, the leaders have produced fresh, lively party clothes that may turn things around. The best of these styles have a lot of movement and swing -- there's nothing like a swirling panel or a rustling petticoat to stir up enthusiasm.
Every designer has his own approach. Geoffrey Beene alternates his sculptural dresses with multilayered full skirts so light they seem buoyed by air. Arnold Scaasi's entire collection is a flower garden of tropical as well as sedate English blooms. Bill Blass revives the comfortably loose caftan and brings it up to date by adding a pair of pants. Oscar de la Renta turns out the ball gowns his customers still demand, but makes them as easy to wear as play clothes. 
 The new party dresses are scheduled to begin appearing in the stores in November, after women presumably have bought their winter coats and other cold-weather gear and are looking forward to Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's Eve as well as jaunts to warm climates like Florida and the Caribbean.
The clothes are part of recently shown collections labeled cruise and resort, which occupy designers between their fall and spring showings. The designers agree that the cruise and resort category of fashion is increasing in importance every year.
The rising significance of resort wear has little to do with whether more people are signing up for cruises in the sun or spending more time at Florida beaches; it has more to do with the growth of the Sun Belt, where the winters pass almost unnoticed, and the need for stores to offer fresh merchandise before bona fide spring styles start arriving.
 
Not Just for Resorts
 While women escaping the snows of, say, Chicago or Minneapolis offer a ready market, many stay-at-homes, too, are attracted to the cheerful, sometimes headstrong designs. Many can be worn to holiday parties. And many can be pushed to the side of the closet and brought out when summer arrives. Many women have found over the years that the best summer fashions appear in the resort collections.
The strongest common denominator of this year's resort and cruise wear is a sense of indomitable good cheer among the designers. They hope women looking at the styles will share their upbeat perspective.
"Women are not buying as much as they used to," Mr. Blass said. "Those who bought eight styles at a time, for instance, are now picking three or four. Some are staying away from the fashion stores, though they're spending money on their houses, horses and even travel.
"We're handling this by making clothes that are attractive and wearable -- no pieces made specially for the runway, everything comfortable. We hope that will cheer them and bring them back to the fold."
Geoffrey Beene's new clothes aren't all fluffy, but they are all dedicated to movement. Seams slither over the body, appearing in unpredictable places, hardly ever at the sides. Fabrics are light to begin with and cut to avoid bulk. Pants, for example, are designed without waistbands to avoid double thicknesses of material. Jersey is favored because of its stretchiness. A great inventor of new shapes, Mr. Beene is counting on his modern, architectural designs to attract women to his resort clothes.
Arnold Scaasi offers a kaleidoscope of colors in his realistic and abstract flower prints. Beads and sequins fill in the blooms and sunflowers; petunias and cabbage roses are all recognizable among the foliage. In a room full of his dresses, you can almost smell the scent.
His dress shapes are on the traditional side, but there is a new element this season: pants.
"They just look right to me," the designer said, speaking of his many party pants. "I hope women will love them."

HEADLINE: The Talk of Hollywood;
After Months of Political Attack, The 'Cultural Elite' Fires Back

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 31

 BODY:
It's war!
The entertainment industry, led by television, and Vice President Dan Quayle were in open conflict today in a noisy, angry and even funny clash that has sharply intensified the uneasy political mood in Hollywood.
Although there are, most certainly, some highly visible Republicans in town supporting the re-election of President Bush and Mr. Quayle, the dispute over "family values," the "cultural elite" and single motherhood has whipped up heavily Democratic Hollywood into an us-versus-them furor. "I've never seen a time where people have responded this viscerally and taken the attacks so much to heart," said Gary David Goldberg, the creator of "Brooklyn Bridge" and other series. 
 Last night, Hollywood's resentment at the attacks spilled over in the nationally televised 44th Annual Prime-Time Emmy Awards. The creator of "Murphy Brown," Diane English, laced into Mr. Quayle for criticizing what he described last spring as the show's glorification of single motherhood. Joining Ms. English in ridiculing Mr. Quayle during the three-and-a-half-hour awards presentation were the show's star, Candice Bergen, and an array of stand-up comedians and television stars. Critics said the show was otherwise so tedious that it made this year's soporific Academy Awards program seem riveting by comparison. Except for the Quayle-bashing.
"Boy, Quayle is just getting stomped here," said one of the show's hosts, the comedian Dennis Miller. He remarked at one point that Mr. Quayle "better learn how to spell potato because if the economy keeps going down the way it is, that's all we'll be eating."
Perhaps the most biting comment was made by Ms. English. "I would like to thank our sponsors for hanging in there when it was getting really dangerous," she said. "I would also like to thank in particular all the single parents out there who, either by choice or by necessity, are raising their kids alone. Don't let anybody tell you you're not a family."
And then Ms. English added, "As Murphy herself said, I couldn't possibly do a worse job raising my kid alone than the Reagans did with theirs."
The attacks angered Mr. Quayle and his staff. Speaking to a crowd of supporters this morning on the airport tarmac in Huntsville, Ala., Mr. Quayle glanced at notes on index cards and said: "Now did you all see the Emmys last night? Did you see that my favorite TV show got a lot of awards? Now, 'Murphy Brown,' listen closely, 'cause I'm only going to say it once. You owe me big time."
"But I do want to make a serious point," he went on. "Last night they said I attacked single mothers. That is a lie. Last night, they said that I believe single mothers and their children are not families. That is a lie. Winning an Emmy is not a license to lie. Hollywood doesn't like our values. Hollywood doesn't like our beliefs. Hollywood can go ahead and laugh at the American people. They can go ahead and lie about what I said. But I can tell you this: I'm going to continue to speak the truth. I'm going to continue to speak up for traditional values. And I'm not going to back down."
Mr. Quayle's spokesman, David Beckwith, was even more slashing. "Diane English is lying," he said. "She's distorting Quayle's remarks. If she's doing it because of her left-wing political beliefs, that would be one thing. But I think she's partially motivated by money and ratings, which is what seems to make Hollywood go." Ms. English did not respond to several telephone calls.
Hollywood, which takes itself and its politics very seriously, is fervently embracing the Democratic ticket of Gov. Bill Clinton and Senator Al Gore. Generally, over the years, Democratic and liberal politicians have looked on Hollywood as a kind of necessary evil. Because so many people here have so much money, politicians with palms outstretched traipse almost weekly now into fancy homes and plead for money at wine-and-cheese parties. The drawback for politicians, who grit their teeth when they come here, is that they must generally endure what they view as silly questions and sillier lectures from Hollywood liberals.
This is not to say that Hollywood politics are strictly Democratic. Stars like Arnold Schwarzenegger, Tom Selleck, Bruce Willis and Chuck Norris are believed to Bush-Quayle supporters. But Republicans are a minority in the entertainment business. The number of movie stars and executives writing checks for the Democratic ticket make up the not-so-silent majority. And the Republican convention earlier this month, with its theme of "family values" and sporadic attacks on Hollywood, has appeared to deepen the sense of anger in Hollywood -- to a degree.
A major outdoor fund-raiser on Sept. 16, sponsored by the Hollywood Women's Political Committee, which supports liberal issues and politicians, was sold out even before the invitations were printed, and hundreds of people are being turned away. But Danny Goldberg, a senior vice president of Atlantic Records and the chairman of the American Civil Liberties Union Foundation of Southern California, said, "With all respect to the committee, I think the main reason it was sold out is because Barbra Streisand is going to sing."
 
A Rock and a Gauntlet
 Several Hollywood power brokers said the attacks by Mr. Quayle were only one reason for the surge of interest and involvement in the campaign.
Today, for example, David Geffen, the millionaire businessman and record producer, had lunch with Mr. Clinton in Little Rock, Ark., and made plans to raise more money for the candidate. "Everyone feels this is a very crucial election not so much because the Republicans are attacking Hollywood, but because of the state of the economy, the cities, the homelessness, the poverty and the total lack of concern by this Administration," said Mr. Geffen, speaking from his private plane en route to New York.
Barry Diller, the former chairman of Fox Inc., and one of the central figures in town, said of the Quayle attacks: "It would take a dumbbell not to have this big a rock hit him and not think actively about politics this time around. It's not that this community acts with particular responsibility running through its pores. But to generically indict it is much more than questionable.
"The issue isn't cultural elitism. The issue, really, is what are the responsibilities of this community as it regards sex and violence. Those are valid issues deserving of an awful lot of thought. They deserve to be raised, but not this way, not this way at all."
Bob Burkett, the senior vice president for corporate affairs for Interscope, a movie and record production company, and an important Hollywood fund-raiser for the Democrats, said: "No question that gauntlet has been laid down to this community. We've decided to pick it up."
And Marge Tabankin, the executive director of the Hollywood Women's Political Committee, said: "The community feels targeted. It's created a chill and fear reminiscent of the 50's. Let's face it: We feel we're being used as whipping boys."

HEADLINE: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;
Antitrust Trial Resumes

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
An economist argued in Minneapolis that damage claims made by eight players in their antitrust suit against the league were not sensible, and he said the players were not damaged by the Plan B system. BRUCE OWEN, an economist hired by the owners, said the $4 million damage claim made by the players' economist, MICHAEL GLASSMAN, was incorrectly measured.
The trial resumed yesterday morning after a weeklong break while Judge DAVID DOTY attended to another case. The eight plaintiffs were free agents in 1990 but were protected by their teams under the league's Plan B system. 
 The plaintiffs argue that Plan B unfairly blocked them from negotiating with other teams. No protected players have changed teams under Plan B. Using Glassman's estimates, the eight players would have received an average salary $500,000 higher than their 1990 contracts in an open market.

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 4; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Guatemala Peace Moves Need Support

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Any human-rights movement, however tentative, between the Guatemalan Government and the guerrillas is good news ("Guatemalan Rivals in Rights Accord," news article, Aug. 9).
I traveled to Guatemala in a Witness for Peace delegation last month and met with a variety of human rights activists and campesinos. According to people I talked with, the military and Government are carrying out a bloody campaign of repression against indigenous people. For many campesinos, the civil defense patrols have come to be the symbol of repression, dominance and control by the Government over their lives. 
 The patrols may be voluntary on paper, but in reality, they are not. I talked with men who said that they had no choice but to participate in them. If they refused, they were labeled subversive and subjected, with their families and villages, to further Government terror or repression.
I witnessed a miracle, though. One small village in the highlands of Huehuetenango had succeeded 18 months earlier in reclaiming its rights under the Constitution and has been able to resist the army and stop participating in the patrol. This one example gave me much hope. However, it is a rare instance where the Government has honored the rights of campesinos regarding the patrols.
That is why the negotiations between the Government and the guerrillas are so important. The United States -- which is in part responsible for the existence of the patrols because our Central Intelligence Agency backed the coup in 1954 that led to the war -- can now help. I urge our Government to continue suspension of military aid to Guatemala, and to condition economic aid upon demonstrated progress in respect for human rights in Guatemala.
Such actions will send a strong message to the Guatemalan Government and thereby encourage human rights progress. We must support these negotiations in whatever way possible, so that the Guatemalan Government and the guerrillas can move forward and forge peace for their country.
 
MARY D. WACHTEL
Brooklyn, Aug. 20, 1992

HEADLINE: Family Values and the K.K.K.

BYLINE: By Diane McWhorter; Diane McWhorter is writing a book about race in Birmingham, Ala.

 BODY:
I entered a time warp recently while listening to a tape recording of a political rally in May 1963.
The 29-year-old celebrations of "family values" playing in my earphones were strangely similar to the sentiments expressed at the Republican National Convention two weeks ago. 
 There were tributes to God ("We need to go back to the old-time religion") and wives ("I wonder how the ladies can sit there across that breakfast table anymore and [not] ask your husband, Now what are you doing in this fight? Don't you love our children?") There was a good cop-bad cop format that paired bland civic pieties with apocalyptic denunciations of Communists, journalists and Democrats.
The 1963 spectacle was a Ku Klux Klan rally in Birmingham, Ala.
Family values was the centerpiece of the old Klan ideology. The knights of the Fiery Cross were America's ultimate "religious warriors." They insisted that their anti-black terrorist mandate came from G-O-D.
This year, race has not yet emerged as hot campaign demagogy, thanks to the Democrats' own unabashed courtship of the white vote.
The Republicans have thus been forced to spray their birdshot on everyone who is, you know, "different." And in its aversion to difference, the religious right-wing of the Republican Party has less in common with the Klan of the 1960's than with the Klan of the 1920's. The nationwide phenomenon then punished anyone not certified as "100 percent American." Even President Warren Harding joined up.
The Klan's favorite quarry was Catholics, who were presumed to be carrying out a plan to make America a Vatican colony by destroying the monogamous Protestant family. This, evidently, gave license to lurid anti-Catholic propaganda, as in one Georgia politician's assertion that the bishop of Savannah kept a pen of white sex slaves.
A Freudian dynamic was born again: The nighttime missions of the Klansmen were vicarious indulgences in vice, in the name of virtue. They shone flashlights into cars on lovers lanes and wreaked vigilante justice on, for example, a man who dug a tunnel under a public school restroom to spy on girls. Today's family-values voyeurs need look no further than the newsstand for the righteous thrill of catching a Presidential candidate in flagrante delicto.
Just as cheap titillation is an understudy for genuine passion, so can a political party's sophomoric mischief be a substitute for moral passion. Members of the Republican Party's youth arm hit on a sublime outlet for ideologically correct prurience when they trailed Nina Totenberg, a National Public Radio correspondent, around the convention floor, asking her if she had had an affair.
Patriotic high jinks have historically been a diversion from the more spirit-deadening requirements of America's real business. Employers encouraged the culture police of the 1920's because white antipathy for hyphenated Americans was excellent insurance against unionization.
Similarly, the Republicans of the 1980's were able to persuade non-immigrant working people to reject their natural allies, in a backlash that still goes by the label "Reagan Democrats." But in the 1990's bust economy, can the limp bait of family values seduce them anew into identifying with the privileged minority?
The Klan of the 1920's collapsed when one of its leaders -- the Indiana Grand Dragon -- was convicted of the rape and murder of a young woman. The Republican Party of 1992 won't need so grotesque a hypocrisy to show how corrupt the ideology of "family values" can be.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

Companies
With 30,000 workers striking seven G.M. plants, the U.A.W. is fighting for job security as the company campaigns to cut costs by subcontracting work to outside suppliers, many of them nonunion, and reduce its work force by 74,000 people by 1995. The strike is also a personal response to J. Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, the Spanish engineer who is leading G.M.'s Detroit cost-cutting. [Page A1.]
General Mills announced a $450 million deal for RJR Nabisco's ready-to-eat cereal business. Shredded Wheat, Spoon-Sized Shredded Wheat and Shreddies. will join Wheaties, Cheerios and Total, while Nabisco will be able to retire some of its debt. [D1.]

Salomon named Robert Mundheim general counsel, succeeding Robert Denham, who was named chairman earlier. The appointment was the last significant management post to be filled in the aftermath of last year's Treasury market scandal. [D3.]
 
The Economy
Natural gas prices are expected to rise, as a result of Hurricane Andrew's assault on oil-and-gas operations in the Gulf of Mexico. The Minerals Management Service said that 13 platforms were toppled by the hurricane as it raced into Louisiana and that 100 more were damaged, more than initially estimated. [D1.]
The insurance industry expects to pay $7.3 billion in claims in Florida because of Hurricane Andrew, making it the most expensive catastrophe ever for insurers in the United States. [D1.]
Little economic improvement before next year was signaled by the Index of Leading Economic Indicators, which edged up one-tenth of 1 percent in July after falling three-tenths of 1 percent in June. Construction activity declined six-tenths of 1 percent in July. The manufacturing sector, as gauged by industrial purchasing managers, grew modestly in August. [D1.]

Cuba has reduced incoming telephone calls by two-thirds when Florida's Cuban emigre community is urgently trying to reach Cuban friends and relatives after Hurricane Andrew. [D3.]
The United States agreed with Russia to buy bomb-grade uranium from scrapped Soviet nuclear arms. [D2.]

Run-flat tires developed by Goodyear and Bridgestone rely on differing technologies to avoid changing tires on the highway. [D5.]
The first noninvasive test to diagnose cystic fibrosis, or detect the presence of the gene that causes the disease, uses DNA in cells collected by brushing the inside of a person's cheek. [D5.]

The dollar sank to another low against the German mark, falling below 1.40 for the first time to 1.3903 marks in late trading. Central banks did not intervene in the exchange markets. [D14.] Wheat futures prices rose sharply. [D14.]

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
No Pressure? No Problem. New Tires Run Flat.

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
For years, tire companies have sought to produce a passenger-car tire that would continue to run even after deflating. But the race among the world's giant tire producers recently grew more intense when both the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and the Bridgestone Corporation of Japan announced the separate development of what they call run-flat tires.
Bridgestone's tires, which require special wheels, are currently available on some customized Chevrolet Corvette models. Goodyear, which apparently hurried to make its announcement after Bridgestone introduced its run-flat tire, says its version will work with regular rims. But Goodyear is not expected to have its tires on the market until late next year.
 
 
An Earlier Version
 The notion of such a product -- a tire that will carry a passenger car 50 to 200 miles or so after being deflated -- is not new. Continental A.G., the German tire company, tested one eight years ago on certain Mercedes-Benz models. But that product would also have required the auto makers to build a special wheel, a prospect the car companies dismissed as too costly. 
 Many industry analysts and experts are now questioning whether the new tires will be widely accepted. They contend that there is enough demand for run-flat tires, but that the expense of retooling cars with new wheels would serve as a deterrent. At the right price, however, consumers may be receptive, because the product would virtually eliminate the need to change a tire along a busy highway or at some other inconvenient place.
The typical passenger-car tire uses air pressure to support the car's weight. In a run-flat tire, the sidewalls are about 50 percent thicker to help support the weight when the tire deflates.
 
 
55 Miles an Hour
 Bridgestone says its run-flat tire, the Expedia, can take a car at least 50 miles at a speed of 55 miles an hour once the tire has deflated. Goodyear said its Eagle Extended Mobility Tire, to be introduced by 1994, would be capable of running 200 miles after it lost its air, at a speed of 55 miles an hour.
The Bridgestone tire, which was jointly developed by the research and development staffs in both Japan and in the United States, calls for a special rubber compound and a low-pressure support insert. The insert enables the tire to keep its strength to support the weight of the car when the air has seeped out of the tire. The tire is held in place by a special double-beaded rim.
"Without the special rim, the tire could come unseated while operating without air," said Richard W. Brennan, a product specialist with Bridgestone/Firestone Inc., the Nashville-based American unit of the Bridgestone Corporation. "That would make it more dangerous in turning corners. You would have a lot less vehicle control."
Bridgestone's run-flat tire also includes a low-pressure sensor mounted on the rim that sends a radio signal to the dashboard, where a light will alert the driver whenever a tire's air pressure drops to less than 25 pounds a square inch. The Goodyear tire also has an electronic sensor that can tell the driver when air has seeped out of the tire.
The distance a car can travel with a deflated tire depends on the speed, the number of corners a driver must turn and the outside temperature. "As rubber heats up, it deteriorates," Mr. Brennan said. "When the rubber is heated, there is a chemical reaction that can break down the strength of the rubber."
Typically, when a tire runs flat the rolling resistance causes friction that generates a large amount of heat, causing the rubber to break down and the tire to be ruined. With the run-flat tire, the rubber insert supports the load, although the tire will still appear flat. The new tires also use a special rubber compound that not only generates less heat, but also enables the tire to withstand greater heat.
For now, Bridgestone said, its tire is being offered only by distributors of the Calloway Corvette, a special high-performance version of the sports car. The cost of the package, including four tires, four wheels and the air-pressure-sensor system, is about $5,000. Bridgestone said the tires should be available for luxury touring cars like the Lexus and Mercedes within three years.
The Goodyear tire will differ from Bridgestone's chiefly in that it will not require a specially constructed wheel. Goodyear said its run-flat tire could be used on any standard wheel, making the system much less expensive, although it will not disclose the likely price.
Donald L. Knight, director of devlopment for original-equipment tires at Goodyear, said, "Our tire has been designed to maintain itself to the wheel at zero-inflation pressure." He said the wide design of the tire and the modified design of a mold ring -- used in the process of "curing" it when it was made -- prevented the tire from coming off the wheel when it was flat. Indeed, because of the construction of the tire and the stiffness of the sidewalls, it is never truly "flat," even when depleted of air.
 
Vague About the Details
 "It's a tighter, more secure fit," Mr. Knight said, declining to be more specific. "The exact details on how that happens is the part that's patented," he said.
Goodyear has been noticeably vague in outlining the details of its new tire, saying that it will be "available on an upcoming American performance car," but not providing a hint about which one. The company also declined to say when the tire would be available, although many analysts predicted it would be on some 1994-model sports cars.
Mr. Knight of Goodyear said that the technology could fit on lightweight vehicles that have tires with shorter sidewalls, as opposed to large family and luxury cars. "The smaller the distance between the wheel and the road, the more apt this type of tire could be used," he said. "The taller it is, the more difficult the design would be."
 
 
Unlikely to Spread Fast
 Harry W. Millis, an independent tire-company analyst in Cleveland, says the Goodyear tire has a good chance of being accepted by car makers because it requires no change in the design of the wheel. "If the technology is not too expensive, the Goodyear tire has a good chance," Mr. Millis said. But, he added, it is unlikely that the Goodyear run-flat tire "will move out of the sports car area any time soon."
Although he expects wider applications eventually, "the car makers don't move very quickly." He added, "I expect it will be five to 10 years before it finds wide usage."
Mr. Millis considers the prospects for the Bridgestone to be less bright. "Obviously, a $5,000 set of tires and wheels are not going to find a major market," he said. "It may be more difficult than they expect."

HEADLINE: Insurers' Florida Tab: $7.3 Billion

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Sept. 1

 BODY:
The first formal survey of the damage caused by Hurricane Andrew in Florida has found that the insurance industry will pay out an estimated $7.3 billion in claims, making it by far the most expensive catastrophe ever for insurers in the United States.
The insured losses, calculated by an industry group that specializes in estimating the cost of catastrophes, are more than 70 percent higher than the losses caused by Hurricane Hugo in 1989. They do not include, however, a host of uninsured losses, ranging from the damage to electrical systems in Dade County to the costs of calling out the military. 
 Although paying out more than $7 billion is certain to cause a great deal of pain for dozens of companies, analysts said the $160 billion industry has more than adequate capital to meet the claims and that the losses reported today were in line with expectations earlier in the week. Andrew, they said, is unlikely to cause solvency problems for any leading property and casualty insurers.
 
'Awfully Big Number'
 "By anybody's count this is an awfully big number," said G. Alan Zimmermann, an analyst with Prudential Securities in New York. "But the one thing this industry is very effective at is spreading risks. The system will be able to handle this."
Previous estimates of the damage caused by Andrew in Florida were made up largely of guesses by officials in charge of emergency services on the scene and have generally ranged from $15 billion to $30 billion. Today's announcement was a preliminary tally of only part of that damage conducted by teams who have surveyed the destruction in five Florida counties on the ground and from the air. The survey did not include the cost of damage to the area's infrastructure, the cost of relief and other government programs, the cost to uninsured businesses and homes, nor did it include the toll for agriculture or any losses in Louisiana.
According to Gary R. Kerney, the director of catastrophe services for the property claim service division of the American Insurance Services Group, the tightly compact storm brought its most severe damage in Dade County, where the total insured losses reached $6 billion. The total of damages in Broward, Palm Beach, Monroe and Collier Counties was $1.3 billion he said. Mr. Kerney added that approximately 685,000 claims were expected to be filed.
The organization made a similar estimate of $3.9 billion for the damages caused by Hurricane Hugo shortly after what was then the most expensive hurricane in American history hit South Carolina in 1989. That number was later revised to $4.2 billion, or $4.5 billion in 1992 dollars, in insured losses. Those insured damages are believed to be less than half of what was perhaps more than $10 billion in total destruction.
So far in Florida, however, the sheer size of the devastated area and the lack of street signs or working telephones for most policyholders have limited the ability of companies to process claims and estimate the size of their individual company losses. A spokesman for State Farm, the largest insurer in the area, with more than 20 percent of market share, said that if today's estimate held up its losses would pass $750 million. Its losses were more than $460 million in Hurricane Hugo.
Allstate, the second-largest carrier in the area, said it would announce its losses on Wednesday morning. "This is going to be high," said Wayne E. Hedien, the chairman and president of Allstate, in a telephone interview today. "But we have $8 billion in surplus and we can handle it."
Paul Schattenberg, a spokesman for U.S.A.A., a San Antonio-based insurer, said that his company estimated it would pay out $150 million in losses in Florida for Hurricane Andrew. The company paid out $107 million for Hurricane Hugo.
Hurricane Andrew is likely to raise a host of questions for individual companies as they tally up losses and calculate how much of the cost they can pass on to their own insurers -- reinsurance companies. Insurance companies and reinsurance companies have spun a spider's web of agreements to spread the costs of large catastrophes.
Among the unanswered questions today is how much of the cost will be borne by the Lloyd's of London insurance market, which has been severely shaken by several years of bad losses. Experts say that foreign reinsurers including Lloyd's and other European reinsurers may have to pay as much as 30 percent of the losses.
 
Some Tax Write-Offs
 Another mitigating effect for American insurers is that about one-third of losses can be recouped through tax write-offs. According to the Insurance Information Institute, an industry trade group, the top writers of homeowner and commercial insurance in Florida are State Farm, Allstate, Nationwide Insurance, Prudential, U.S.A.A., Chubb, Cigna, Continental, USF&G, Travelers, ITT Hartford Insurance, Fireman's Fund and Aetna.
A question that is likely to be debated for weeks to come is what the impact of the storm will be on property and casualty pricing particularly in commercial lines of insurance. Competition in many property casualty lines has forced prices to unprofitably low levels for years and the hopes of investors in recent days has been as it was immediately after Hurricane Hugo: that the losses will sap the industry's surplus capital sufficiently to force all companies in the industry to raise prices.
But many analysts and an economist, Orin Kramer, who specializes in insurance industry issues, said that the damage from Andrew alone appeared insufficient to turn prices upward. "This is a big hit," Mr. Kramer said, "but I think it might take as much as $40 billion to turn things around. I don't think this can do it alone."

HEADLINE: Stocks Up Despite Signs of Weak Economy

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The stock market closed marginally higher yesterday, even though several new reports gave unflattering assessments of the economy.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 8.91, to 3,266.26. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 9 to 7 on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume was a moderate 174.4 million shares, up from 160.23 million in the previous session. 
 Market analysts said they had found nothing remarkable in the new reports on construction activity, purchasing trends or leading economic indictators. "I think the market is still biding its time, waiting for some more conclusive economic data, or more conclusive election information," said Robert F. Dickey, a stock analyst for Dain Bosworth Inc. in Minneapolis.
The Commerce Department said construction activity fell by an unexpected six-tenths of 1 percent in July; economists had been looking for a five-tenths of 1 percent rise. The Government also said its chief economic forecasting tool, the index of leading economic indicators, rose one-tenth of 1 percent in July, which was expected.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said its index of purchasing activity showed slower growth in the manufacturing sector in August.
Airlines staged the strongest advance of any industry group during the day, ahead of scheduled fare increases this weekend, but Mr. Dickey said the rise was technical.
"They've been pounded so badly," he said, referring to the devastating effects of the recession and recent fare wars. AMR was up 1 7/8 at 57 3/8; Delta Air Lines, up 2 3/8 at 52 3/8, and UAL, up 3 3/8 at 107 1/2.
Eugene Peroni, an analyst for Janney Montgomery Scott in Philadelphia, said while the broader market was moving within a predictable range, a handful of stocks were advancing based on a favorable earnings outlook.
The most actively traded Big Board issue was RJR Nabisco, down 1/8 at 8 1/2. Diagnostek, a New Mexico-based mail-service pharmacy, closed unchanged at 16 1/2 in active trading after its largest competitor, New Jersey-based Medco Containment, agreed to buy Diagnostek for $436 million. Raychem gained 3 at 35, a day after the California technology company was awarded a large contract from Ameritech for fiber-optic installation in the Midwest.
Other active issues included Merck, down 3/8 at 48 1/4; and Telefonos de Mexico American depository receipts, up 1/8 at 45 1/4, and Global Marine, unchanged at 2 3/8.
Hurricane Andrew continued to be felt in the financial markets. American Reliance fell 2 5/8 at 17 5/8, a loss of 15 percent, a day after the New Jersey insurance company predicted large losses because of hurricane damage in southern Florida.
The New York Stock Exchange's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.99 at 229.02, while the American Stock Exchange's market value index was up 0.66 at 381.44.

HEADLINE: No Cookie-Cutter Answers in 'Mommy Wars';
Women Are Struggling With Their Choices About Having Jobs or Staying Home

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: YORKTOWN, N.Y.

 BODY:
There are no maps to motherhood in 1992, so Anne Jaffe is struggling to find her way, trying to make peace with her choice to be a full-time mother rather than pursue a full-time career.
"I feel like I'm a disappointment for the women who have worked so hard to broaden opportunities for other women," said the 36-year-old Mrs. Jaffe, once a co-president of the student body at Stanford University and now a mother of two and a volunteer at the Yorktown Community Nursery School. 
 Mrs. Jaffe is on the front line of what some call "the mommy wars": conflicts that play themselves out in the minds of women, in the schools and community groups where they measure themselves against mothers who took different paths. The tensions are particularly evident in places where mothers have the economic luxury of choosing whether to stay home full time or work outside the home.
Recently the wars have spilled into the national political arena, with Marilyn Quayle championing the fact that she gave up her law career for the sake of her family, and Hillary Clinton defending her decision to combine the two.
"Each side has something to protect," said Kathleen Gerson, a sociologist who specializes in gender and family issues at New York University. "Sometimes I wonder if the war has just begun."
A survey published three years ago by Child Magazine quantified some of the tensions mothers feel. Nearly half the stay-home mothers surveyed, 49 percent, said employed mothers did not spend enough time with their children; one-fourth said employed mothers put their own needs before their children's. Among working mothers, 50 percent said they worked primarily for financial reasons but half said they would keep their jobs even if they could get their salary without working.
Even as skirmishes continue in the "mommy wars" -- a term that gained nationwide attention when it appeared in a Newsweek article in 1990 -- more mothers keep joining the work force and the older their children are, the more likely they are to have jobs outside the home. About 75 percent of those whose youngest child is under 18 work, as against 55 percent of those with children under age 3, according to a recent analysis by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
"What was a little brook has now become an ocean of women, and women with children, working," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the bureau's regional commissioner.
Barbara Reisman, executive director of Child Care Action Campaign, a national advocacy organization, said: "The fact that we still think about it as a mommy war says a lot about where we failed to come in terms of gender issues. Why is this about mothers? Where are the fathers?"
But it is about mothers at places like the Yorktown nursery school, a modest, red-shingled building here that houses one of the oldest parent cooperative nursery schools in the state. While at least one parent from every family is required to take part in everything that goes on at the school, from classroom work, to fund-raisers, to maintenance and renovations, the mothers are the ones who most often carry the load, even in families where both parents work outside the home.
There are no Murphy Browns here. The women are married, ranging in age from their 30's to their early 40's, from families that can afford to wrestle with the question of whether the mother needs to bring home a paycheck. Most are college educated and held jobs outside the home before their children were born.
The subject of mothers and work is rarely debated openly at the nursery school, which has an enrollment of 76. The talk that swirled around the noisy playroom on a recent morning concerned play dates, a child's ear infection that kept a mother up all night, and how women must stick together in a world controlled by men.
But in separate interviews with three of the women, the discussion was more candid, reflecting the struggles and the complexities of their lives: one as a full-time mother, one as a mother with her own business, one who straddles those two worlds by working part time.
 
Career Aspirations Instilled by Father
 Laurie Hander Leahy is the mother of 5-year-old Max and a caterer, a career she began dreaming about when she was 12. "My entire life is not about watching his first step," she said. "My life is about him but also working."
Economic freedom has always been one of her goals. When she and her husband, Richard, the owner of several appliance stores in Westchester County, decided to have a child, it was only after they agreed they could afford, first, a 24-hour baby nurse to feed and change diapers, and then a live-in nanny.
"I knew I would never stay home full time with a child," said Ms. Leahy, who is 37. "There are times I have regretted it. I've missed a lot. Sometimes I think, 'Wouldn't this be great to spend more time and be here?' But you can't have both."
Ten days after her son was born, she drove her red BMW convertible back to Food Fantasies Catering Company in Harrison, N.J., where being owner sometimes requires her to work more than 100 hours a week.
Ms. Leahy considers herself "a father's daughter," much like her friend, Mrs. Jaffe, and says that has a lot to do with her goals.
"My father treated us as he would have treated boys," said Ms. Leahy, the daughter of an accountant in West Orange, N.J., and a mother who raised three girls. "He encouraged the same education, the same aspirations for career. What he taught us was that working hard was a good thing and I interpreted working as working outside the home. I never thought about being a mom. In the back of my mind, I figured one day eventually, it would come with the territory of being female."
It is the little things, Ms. Leahy said, that bring out the differences between mothers who stay at home and mothers who are employed, things like how much they talk about domestic issues and children. For the last two years, she worked on the nursery school's financial committee and was the driving force behind a raffle that set records for the school, raising $3,000 each year.
"They had ridiculously low goals and I pushed them," she said. "They just weren't realistic in dealing with money because they're not making it."
 
Others' Confidence Feeds Self-Doubt
 Mrs. Jaffe, who was the head of the school's fund-raising committee at the time, acknowledged that there was some surprise about Ms. Leahy's approach, but she said it was not a cause of dissension.
"We all sort of looked at her like, 'Now that's a new thought,' " Mrs. Jaffe said. "It wasn't that we were unrealistic. The school just got in a pattern of selling tickets to friends and family. And she said, 'We can make it much bigger. You guys are treating this like peanuts.' People were excited."
The seemingly breezy confidence of employed mothers like Ms. Leahy is at times intimidating to Mrs. Jaffe, not, she says, because of anything the women say but because of her own doubts. In the "mommy wars," she said, her worst enemy is herself.
"I feel very awkward going to a party and meeting a woman with a high-powered career who also has children," said Mrs. Jaffe, who has seen a therapist about her feelings about motherhood. "If the working mom's children are behaving beautifully and my children are being very rude or bratty, I feel like there's an expectation out there; if you're going to spend full time with children, they should show better behavior, they should be exemplary. I find myself literally becoming livid at my children, not because their behavior was so outrageous but because I felt humiliated. I feel like somehow this is my job."
But what she perceives in Ms. Leahy, a sense of self worth derived from working, has not erased Ms. Leahy's doubts about how she succeeds as a mother.
Recalling a recent weekend in the Hamptons with her son, she said: "I saw him respond to me being there all day long. I think children react to the harried schedules that working moms have. It's a conflict when you're staking new territory. Sometimes it works and sometimes it doesn't."
 
The Pull of Work, The Pull of Home
 Bobbi Ornstein has tried to reconcile the conflict by working part time. "I didn't want to be away from him so much," the 42-year-old physical therapist said of her 3-year-old son, Douglas. "He might adjust to it better than I would but it would be hard for me."
Mrs. Ornstein works, she said, because she and her husband, Robert, a psychoanalyst, can use the money. And she has little sympathy for women who are not driven to work full time by economic necessity.
"Since mothers haven't been working full time for that many years, we have yet to see the results of the upbringing of the children," she said. "We don't know what these children are going to be like but it's hard to imagine it's going to be terrific."
Mrs. Ornstein grew up in a middle-class family in the Mill Basin neighborhood of Brooklyn, where her father was a textile salesman and her mother stayed at home to raise her.
"Although I wasn't a strong feminist, I did believe I would work, but I would do it differently than my mother did," Mrs. Ornstein said. "She was a very dependent person and I never wanted to be in that position. I wanted to do everything to counter that."
Mrs. Ornstein considers herself a late bloomer in many ways. She started her career as a physical therapist after her first marriage ended when she was in her late-20's. She was married for the second time at age 36. She gave birth to Douglas at age 39.
It was not until she was pregnant that she realized how strongly she felt about devoting time to motherhood, even though she said she loved her work.
"I guess something happened from the time that I was pregnant and he was born that changed my thinking," she said. "I couldn't leave this baby full time. It was too important to me. I couldn't leave him with a stranger."
 
Show and Tell And Cookie Jars
 Mrs. Jaffe was a career women and, at the nursery school, it is the mothers who have full-time careers with whom Mrs. Jaffe most identifies herself, at least in her own head.
"I'm my father's daughter and I always pictured myself having a very interesting career," said Mrs. Jaffe, who describes her father as a hard-driving man who was a vice president of an international contracting company.
She used to be a political campaign consultant in California, and was starting a software consulting business -- the business cards were already printed -- when she decided to stay at home to raise her daughter, now 7, and her son, 5.
"I'd wake up in the morning and I'd look at my daughter and I'd look at the list of phone calls I was supposed to make and they didn't seem that important."
Now her life is more like that of her mother, a homemaker who raised 12 children.
"A lot of women take stock of what their man is about, whether he has a lot of drive, and we fill the vacuum left," said Mrs. Jaffe, whose husband is a research manager for International Business Machines. "I know some whose husbands have very little drive and initiative so the women develop really good careers. My husband has a lot of drive and I fill in the space where he isn't. The hidden thing is that even those of us who are feminists tend to respond to the needs of others."
Mrs. Jaffe said she tends to gravitate these days to women who also stay at home, "only because I still feel a little inadequate with women who have a career, especially when I hear about their jobs."
"It's like show-and-tell time," she said, "and I don't have anything to show and tell."
At the nursery school, Mrs. Jaffe and the other mothers agree that the "show and tell" of real life is much more ambiguous than the lines being drawn in the Presidential campaign, that the choices facing mothers are complex ones, and that even the question of cookies can produce second-guessing about their lives.
Mrs. Jaffe says that for her one of the rewards of motherhood is the look on her children's faces when she is baking, particularly if the cookies are oatmeal and chocolate chip.
But that doesn't stop her from empathizing with mothers who pick up cookies at the grocery on their way home from work.
"Everybody is doing their best and everybody wants to know their best is right, too," she said.

HEADLINE: Bank Funds And C.D.'s Dip in Yield

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit slipped another notch in the week that ends today, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, a Florida-based interest rate publication.
The publication said banks were setting rates in a narrow range and waiting for the Government to make another economic assessment. "Thus far the indicators have all been mediocre at best, but the next employment report could shed more light," The Monitor said. 
 At the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills on Monday, rates were up slightly for the second consecutive week. Interest rate watchers consider the auction a reliable barometer of how banks could eventually set rates for depositors in the weeks ahead.
The average rate at auction for a three-month bill this week rose 3 basis points, to 3.17 percent, while the rate for a six-month bill rose 2 basis points, to 3.26 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 
Money Market Yield: 2.98%
 Robert J. Hutchinson, managing director of retail consumer marketing for Chemical Bank, said he saw no increase in rates over the short run, but noted that analysts and economists expected rates to move up in the next year or so. "But if they do, it still won't be the type of increase that will make depositors happy," he said.
While he acknowledgedthat some depositors had left banks to seek higher rates elsewhere, Mr. Hutchinson said, "There are still a substantial number of bank depositors who remain because of the security and safety afforded in short-term liquid bank accounts."
The combined average yields at New York area banks in the latest week posted small declines, with a money market account down 2 basis points, to 2.98 percent, and the yield on three- and six-month certificates slipping a basis point, to 3.03 percent and 3.23 percent, respectively.
At commercial banks the yield on a money market account was off 2 basis points, to 2.82 percent, while a three-month certificate was unchanged at 2.91 percent and a six-month certificate was off one basis point, to 3.06 percent.
Depositors at savings banks saw yields on money market accounts fall 2 basis points, to 3.14 percent, and a three-month certificate slip a basis point, to 3.17 percent. The yield on a six-month C.D. was 2 basis points lower at 3.39 percent.
 
Largest Changes
 The largest adjustments of yields in the New York area were at First Nationwide, which dropped its money market yield by 15 basis points, to 3 percent, at Anchor Savings where the three-month C.D. fell 10 basis points, to 3.15 percent, and at Home Savings of America, where a six-month C.D. was also down by 10 basis points, to 3.25 percent.
Outside the New York market, the yields at 20 large banks were down a basis point, with an average bank money market account at 2.89 percent and a six-month C.D. at 3.11 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar at Low Against Mark As Officials Do Not Intervene

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON

 BODY:
The dollar sank to another low against the German mark yesterday, stung by another round of negative economic news and left undefended by central banks, which chose not to intervene in world currency markets. The dollar also approached an all-time low against the Japanese yen.
In late trading, the dollar dropped to 1.3903 marks, down from 1.4030 on Monday, and falling through the 1.40 level for the first time since Germany's modern currency was established after World War II. It was the fourth time in 10 days that the dollar set a successive low against the mark. 
 Traders and analysts described yesterday's fall as a gradual and orderly extension of the long decline that the dollar began in April, as the yawning discrepancy between interest rates in the United States and Germany fed a growing stream of international funds from dollars into marks. An investment in three-month bonds in Germany now earns 9.75 percent, while a similar investment in the United States nets only 3.14 percent.
"It's a gradual chipping away by interbank traders who don't have much incentive to buy dollars," said David Gilmore, senior foreign exchange analyst at MCM Currency Watch. "I don't think anybody sees the dollar going into free fall."
After the index of leading economic indicators showed only anemic growth in July, the dollar fell to 122.84 yen, close to the yen's all-time low of 121.05 yen set in November 1988, and down from 123.05 yen on Monday. The British pound also gained ground against the dollar, moving to 2.0020, up from $1.9880.
Mr. Gilmore and other analysts said the calm, if pessimistic, nature of yesterday's currency markets reflected a decision not to intervene by the Federal Reserve and other central banks, which tried repeatedly to prop up the dollar last month.
"The central banks have retreated on intervention because it won't work at this point," Mr. Gilmore said. "They're going to let the market find a bottom on its own."
Efforts by the Fed to actively buy dollars, he said, would increase the market's volatility as traders try to anticipate sudden increases or drops, which then become steeper with the increased activity. Without any sign of intervention yesterday, traders watched the dollar drift downward slowly, bottoming at 1.3895 and rebounding to 1.3903 by 4:30 P.M.
Robert White, senior vice president of Interstate Bank, said market fundamentals like the interest-rate differential, a weak American economy, and political uncertainty in an election year all pointed toward an ever-lower dollar.
"The only favorable point for the dollar is intervention," Mr. White said. "And that isn't coming right now."
Mr. White noted that the dollar's fall has not markedly affected the stock and bond markets, which are of more concern to Washington than is the dollar.
