HEADLINE: U.S. to Buy Russian Bomb Uranium

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
The United States announced on Monday that it had agreed in principle to buy billions of dollars' worth of bomb-grade uranium from scrapped Soviet nuclear arms in an attempt to bolster the shaky Russian economy and to reduce the risks of nuclear accidents and theft.
The agreement, which would require the formal approval of both Governments, calls for highly enriched uranium from Russian nuclear arms to be diluted for sale as commercial reactor fuel. It would be the first such agreement, and, if approved, would be a big step to reducing the dangers that made the cold war so unnerving. 
 "It's a big deal," said Barry Daniel, director of public affairs for the Energy Department, which will buy the uranium. "This provides a way to move the highly enriched uranium from nuclear weapons dismantled in Russia into this country and to keep it out of the wrong hands. It also provides capital to Russia, and part of the proceeds go to increasing the safety of nuclear reactors over there. It's a win-win situation."
The agreement was announced by the White House after months of secretive negotiations. In a statement, President Bush said it "illustrates how foreign policy accomplishments can promote our domestic economic well-being while making the world a safer place to live."
The agreement calls for the United States to buy at least 80 metric tons of highly enriched uranium, with no less than 10 metric tons being bought in each of the first five years and no less than 30 metric tons thereafter. Private experts said that at prevailing market prices, that might amount to $5 billion or more over the period of the agreement. The experts generally praised the agreement.
"It's very significant," said Dr. Thomas B. Cochran, a senior scientist with the Natural Resources Defense Council, a private Washington group. "It doesn't prevent them from making new material. But what it does do, which is very good, is to remove a lot of excess weapons material from storage facilities that would otherwise be available for theft or sale to third parties."
 
Natural Ore, Enriched
 Natural uranium ore is made up of a mix of isotopes, or forms of the same element with different atomic weights. Less than 1 percent of it is uranium 235, the fissionable isotope used in bombs and reactors. Uranium for most American nuclear power reactors is enriched to a level of about 3 percent uranium 235, while fuel for bombs in enriched by more than 90 percent.
The agreement would basically reverse that enrichment process, diluting uranium 235 from bombs with natural uranium for use in commercial nuclear power plants.
Early this year, the Russians lined up several American companies that were eager to dilute highly enriched Russian uranium from warheads and to sell it as reactor fuel. And they repeatedly lobbied for the plan with Federal officials.
In July, Viktor N. Mikhailov, head of Russia's Ministry of Atomic Energy, discussed the potential sale of Russian uranium in Washington with top officials of the Energy Department, which oversees the nation's production of nuclear arms and civilian reactor fuel.
Among the American companies eager to make agreements are Allied-Signal Inc., an aerospace and chemicals company based in Morristown, N.J., which signed a preliminary agreement with the Russians.
"We think it is a terrific agreement," said David G. Powell, senior vice president for public affairs of Allied-Signal. "Basically this is the beginning of a very productive arrangement by which we would in essence beat swords into plowshares."
 
Interim Pact in July
 Allied-Signal and Nuclear Fuel Services of Erwin, Tenn., signed an interim agreement with Russian officials in July to buy 11 tons of highly enriched uranium by mid-1993, with similar amounts each year thereafter. No price was disclosed at the time.
A big question is whether Russian bomb-grade uranium can be sold without significantly driving down prices on world uranium markets.
Already, the cash-starved Russians have sold large amounts of natural and mildly enriched uranium in Western markets, feeding a price decline that has driven some uranium producers out of business and threatened the uranium enrichment business of the Energy Department, the world's largest supplier of commercial reactor fuel.
 
No Budget Impact Seen
 Mr. Daniel, the Energy Department spokesman, said American uranium purchases would have no impact on the overall Federal budget because of money recouped from resales and from large savings in the department's own enrichment program.
The White House said the purchases "would have no adverse impact on American consumers or jobs in the uranium mining or processing industries." It said the Energy Department would use the uranium to reduce the electricity costs at its enrichment installations.
The cost of the purchases, Mr. Daniel said, will be "in the billions, but I can't put a specific number on it." He added that the purchases would probably occur over 10 to 20 years.
By having the Energy Department make the purchases, the Government apparently wants to insure that the sudden influx of new material does not throw prices on the world uranium market into decline.
Dr. Cochran of the Natural Resources Defense Council said the agreement "favored the mining industry over the consumer, because the alternative would be to sell it on the open market, which would reduce the prices of uranium and electricity."

HEADLINE: Fixing Corporate America's Short-Term Mind-Set

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
Business school professors tend to be an anonymous breed, and their research is often denigrated as a blend of big words and small ideas. Yet Michael E. Porter of the Harvard Business School stands out as a genuine star. When he speaks, people in business, finance and government listen -- frequently paying handsomely to do so. He commands up to $25,000 a lecture.
Mr. Porter's three major books on economic and corporate competitiveness are footnote-filled doorstop tomes, but roughly a half a million copies have been sold. His instructional videos sell like hotcakes. Besides business clients, he has increasingly worked as a brain for hire, with clients including New Zealand, Canada and the Basque region of Spain. He did a pro bono study of the Massachusetts economy last year that helped shape the thinking beind the cost-cutting and business development programs of the state's Republican Governor, William F. Weld. 
 The 45-year-old professor's current subject of choice is why the American financial system puts the nation's companies at a competitive disadvantage, and what can be done to correct the problem. And over breakfast at the Charles Hotel here, Mr. Porter held forth at length on that topic with an energetic earnestness one might expect from a man whose Who's Who entry includes a 95-word italicized "mission" statement ("My work has sought to make a positive impact . . .).
 
2-Year Study of Issue
 Mr. Porter has just finished as research director for a two-year study of the issue jointly commissioned by the Harvard Business School and the Council on Competitiveness, a private group of executives, academics and union officials. Twenty-five heavyweight scholars, from Lawrence H. Summers, chief economist of the World Bank, to Alfred D. Chandler Jr., the Pulitzer prize-winning business historian, were signed up to do original research. A summary was published in late June, and Mr. Porter testified before the Senate Banking Committee. He has written a Harvard Business Review article entitled "Capital Disadvantage: America's Failing Capital Investment System" and a book is planned for next year.
In 1990, the assignment from the council -- headed by John Young, president of the Hewlett-Packard Company, and George Fisher, chairman of Motorola Inc. -- was to explain the short-term perspective of American industry. The complaint of America's corporate myopia has simmered for two decades, with plenty of anecdotal evidence and no shortage of purported explanations ranging from corporate America's emphasis on quarterly earnings performance to a national culture of instant gratification.
But before long, the direction of the study shifted somewhat. "We started out to look at time horizons, but it quickly became apparent that that was the wrong question," Mr. Porter explained. "The much broader problem is the American system of allocating investment capital, and it's a system that is threatening the competitiveness of American companies and the long-term growth of the American economy."
The study has marshaled some fairly compelling evidence to support the contention that American managers do make fewer long-term investments than their peers in Japan or Europe. For example, one research paper was a survey of roughly 300 large companies worldwide that found that American companies considered 21 percent of their investment projects long term, meaning no profits were expected during the first five years of the project. By contrast, the Japanese companies said 47 percent of their investments were long term, and the Europeans said 61 percent were.
 
Americans Outpaced
 American corporate profitability is higher than in Germany or Japan. But, as the study documents, there seems to be little direct connection between higher corporate profits and long-term returns to shareholders. Japanese shareholders have achieved higher returns (primarily in long-term capital gains) than holders of American shares for the last two decades, and German shareholders have outpaced Americans for more than a decade.
The explanation, Mr. Porter suggests, is that by demanding high near-term profits the American system is counterproductive, sapping growth by lowering American investment to rates far below Japan and Germany. And the additional investment in Japan and Germany has paid off for everyone in the long term -- shareholders, workers, companies and the economy.
Mr. Porter calls the American capital system "fluid," with the ownership of companies increasingly fragmented and transient. Institutional shareholders like pension funds and mutual funds have increased their share of corporate equity from 8 percent in 1950 to nearly 60 percent in 1990.
However, because of laws and regulations that prod the funds to be prudent and spread their investment risks, the big institutions each typically hold small stakes of a percent or so in hundreds or even thousands of different companies. And they trade with increasing frequency; the average holding period of stocks has declined from more than 7 years in 1960 to 1.9 years today.
 
Dedicated Investment Systems
 Japan and Germany, according to Mr. Porter, have dedicated capital systems. In these highly competitive nations, banks, related companies and friendly institutions own the controlling stakes in major companies, and hold those stakes for years. Granted, share prices in these countries can be volatile, as the long slide in the Japanese market demonstrates. But the long-term stakeholders are not traders, so corporate managers are not so eager to please the stock market.
"In Japan and Germany, the traded capital market is decoupled from management behavior," Mr. Porter said.
The Porter solution is to make the American system more like the dedicated setups abroad. Even in America, he says, there are models that point the way. Permanent family ownership in companies mimics the patient capital of a dedicated system, with the benefits evident in success stories like Motorola, Hewlett-Packard, Cargill and Hallmark. And Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway is cited as Mr. Porter's ideal institutional investor, taking big stakes in companies and betting for the long haul.
Mr. Porter would prod the rest of corporate America in that direction with regulatory and tax changes. Among other things, he would allow banks and other companies to hold large stakes in corporations, sit on the boards and even share insider information, as long as the recipients sign agreements not to trade on that information for a year or so. He would shift the capital gains tax so that the rate declines over time as an investor holds onto shares.
 
Favoring Long Term
 "These steps would go a long way to change the fundamental goals in the American system," Mr. Porter said. "They would give management a set of signals that are more aligned with the long-term health of companies instead of the current stock price."
Mr. Porter's notion of encouraging institutional investors to behave more like owners meshes with the recent trend of big investors to become more vocal on issues like executive pay. And the Securities and Exchange Commission proposed in June to allow big investors to talk to each other about a company whose shares they hold without having to report the communication.
Yet Mr. Porter is calling for a big change, not piecemeal evolution. To skeptics, his vision of American companies being controlled by groups of big institutional investors, each holding 5 or 10 percent stakes, looks like a 21st-century version of a smoke-filled railroad cars of the robber baron days.
Legislative efforts to allow such big holdings, they say, would face stiff political resistance. "It just goes right against the grain of the fear of concentrated power in America," said Robert Glauber, a former under secretary of the Treasury who is now a fellow at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard.
 
Investors Seem Reluctant
 Mr. Porter replies that with the American economy challenged in an era of global competition, times have changed and attitudes are shifting as well. "This is not the closed world of the 20's and 30's anymore," he said.
Key players in the Porter vision would be institutional investors, but they sound reluctant to go as far as Mr. Porter would like. The California Public Employees Retirement System has about one-third of its assets of $67 billion in equities. It has invested in roughly 1,000 companies, typically holding 2 percent or less in each company. The pension fund is studying whether it should take larger holdings in fewer companies.
"The problem is that when you place bigger bets on fewer companies, you increase your risk," said DeWitt Bowman, chief investment officer. "I don't think we can all be Warren Buffetts."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael E. Porter, a Harvard professor, says new rules on investments could help get managements to pay more attention "to the long-term health of the company instead of the current stock price." (Sam Ogden for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Squeeze Hurts A Health Niche

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
PROFITING from pressures to get patients out of expensive hospital beds quickly, companies that provide intravenous nutrition and drugs in the home have been on a roll. Sales of these so-called home-infusion companies tripled in three years to $3.2 billion in 1991 and may reach $4 billion this year, analysts said.
But when health-care stocks began slipping early this year, some high-flying home-infusion stocks were hit even harder. Many investors who thought the economy would pick up this year switched from health care to cyclical stocks like autos and chemicals. 
 Companies like Baxter International's Caremark division, Critical Care America and T<2> Medical Inc. can provide hundreds of intravenous therapies, notably to treat cancer and AIDS patients. About 100 new home therapies are approved each year. The pace should quicken as more products of biotechnology move out of the laboratories.
Baxter, a diversified hospital supply company, plans to spin off Caremark later this year as a separate entity that will be listed on the New York Stock Exchange. Caremark, with about $775 million in 1991 home-infusion and related sales, dominates a market served by 10 medium-sized companies and dozens of small mom-and-doc partnerships. Baxter, which has been selling at 18 times 1991 earnings, hopes to push Caremark into the home-infusion league, where Critical Care America shares soared to 30 times earnings.
Critical Care, which has about 8 percent of the infusion market, plunged to $33.875 from a high of $63.75 in January. It closed yesterday at $35.625, off 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. The company, based in Westboro, Mass., took extra lumps when Massachusetts Blue Cross and Blue Shield chose lower-bidding competitors (including Caremark) to serve patients with traditional insurance. Critical Care shares dipped again on the news that it planned to merge with Medical Care International, a chain of surgery centers, although many analysts praised the deal.
The home-infusion companies have already had to make price concessions to stay on the preferred list of large health maintenance organizations and other managed-care networks, just as hospitals and doctors do. But Critical Care and three other infusion companies spurned by Massachusetts Blue Cross are suing to block the practice for traditional insurance. Massachusetts tightly regulates such matters, and the outcome of the lawsuit is uncertain. The companies got the Legislature to take their side, but Gov. William F. Weld vetoed the bill in July.
T<2> Medical, based in Alpharetta, Ga., and largely owned by physicians, is one of the larger infusion companies, with about 5 percent of the market. T<2> shares dropped sharply to $17.75 from a 12-month high of $67.75 after state and Federal authorities announced they were cracking down on doctors who refer patients to their own companies. T<2> shares declined 37.5 cents yesterday, to $25, on the Big Board.
Todd Richter, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds, said the growing squeeze on home-infusion prices had not yet affected profits, but "people fear that this trend will hurt the earnings growth that has been expected." For the longer term, he likes Healthinfusion, based in Miami, which closed at $11.75 yesterday, up 62.5 cents, about 19 times earnings, in over-the-counter trading.
Karen Reilly at Fred Alger Management, which is holding Critical Care shares but sold some in the first quarter, said pricing pressures would eventually hurt the company's profits. But she likes the stock because, she said, "They seem to stay on the leading edge with new products and technologies."
Kenneth S. Abramowitz at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company said cost containment was an "evolutionary negative" for most health-care companies. "What matters" he added, "is whether it has enough exciting new products to offset that negative. Critical Care and Baxter do."
Randall S. Huyser at Furman Selz noted that managed health care already accounts for 20 percent of Critical Care's sales, and he estimated that this would grow by several percentage points a year. Looking at the bright side, he said that managed-care payers provide steady business, reducing marketing and billing costs.
Among infusion companies, Mr. Huyser likes Critical Care as well as several companies that trade over the counter: Total Pharmaceutical Services, a smaller, Los Angeles-based company, which has been growing through acquisitions ($19 yesterday, up 50 cents); Curaflex Health Services in Rancho Cucamonga, Calif., which went public in March at $13 ($10.25 yesterday, up 25 cents), and the Homedco Group, based in Fountain Valley, Calif., which also supplies oxygen for mainly elderly home-care patients ($25.25, unchanged).
Dorothy E. Ryan at Robertson Stephens also likes Homedco and two infusion companies that provide a package of related services: Tokos Medical Corporation, based in Santa Ana, Calif., which specializes in high-risk pregnancies ($23.125, up 87.5 cents), and U.S. Homecare, based in Hartsdale, N.Y., which offers services for children and AIDS and cancer patients ($10, up 50 cents).

HEADLINE: AFTER THE STORM;
PRESIDENT PLEDGES MONEY TO REBUILD IN SOUTH FLORIDA

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOMESTEAD, Fla., Sept. 1

 BODY:
President Bush came here today and promised to rebuild Homestead Air Force Base, an economic mainstay of South Florida that was virtually destroyed last week by Hurricane Andrew. In a three-hour visit this morning, he also said the Federal Government would pay almost all the costs of rebuilding public property and services in Florida.
Ordinarily the Federal Government would pay 75 percent of such costs and the affected state would pay 25 percent. Washington, however, has paid the entire cleanup bill for at least one other recent disaster, Hurricane Hugo in 1989.
 
No Estimate on Cost
 In addition, the Federal Emergency Management Agency will issue grants of up to $11,500 to families who can prove they lack insurance for their homes or belongings or who are not being helped adequately by other emergency services. 
 Officials said they could not gauge how much the additional Federal aid would cost. "That's a figure we're not going to know for quite some time," said a spokesman for the emergency management agency, Phillip S. Cogan. But the costs of reconstructing southern Dade County threaten to dwarf the amount spent after Hurricane Hugo. Today the private insurance industry, in its first formal estimate of the storm damage, said it would have to pay out $7.3 billion in claims, compared with $4.2 billion in private claims paid after Hurricane Hugo. [Page D1.]
 
'Proud of the Spirit'
 Tonight, having returned to Washington, the President gave a brief televised speech from the Oval Office in which he described the relief effort as "unprecedented in size and impact." He urged Americans to keep donating materials like diapers, baby formula, lumber and plastic sheeting for roofs, and said more volunteers were needed for makeshift medical clinics or cleanup duty in Florida.
On his trip to Homestead, the President said: "We met doctors and firefighters spending sleepless vacations lending a helping hand. Through the eloquence of their action, I've been reminded that America will always be a nation of neighbors."
Mr. Bush, who also visited storm victims in Louisiana, was accompanied on his trip by his wife, Barbara, and Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney. The President praised the civilian volunteers who have borne the brunt of the reconstruction effort in south Dade County.
"I'm so proud of the spirit of the people down here," Mr. Bush said during his Florida visit, which included stops at a military field kitchen, a newly built tent settlement meant to house thousands who were left homeless, a public school now functioning as a shelter, and Homestead City Hall.
With Gov. Lawton Chiles and the bulk of the state's Congressional delegation on hand, Mr. Bush landed at the remains of Homestead Air Force Base as a half-dozen airplanes were spraying nearby neighborhoods with insecticide to kill the mosquitoes that have flourished since the storm.
The President and his entourage drove by a wrecked air control tower, a pair of ruined hangars and the rubble of military housing.
Mr. Bush's decision to rebuild the air base was greeted with applause and cheers by local residents. The base, which employs about 4,000 civilians and 4,400 military personnel, means more than $405 million a year for the local economy, according to Pentagon estimates.
But Mr. Bush's decision, which comes as military bases around the country are being closed to save money, is likely to arouse criticism elsewhere. Even some members of Florida's Congressional delegation have said they would prefer to see Homestead's functions transferred to the nine other Air Force bases in Florida.
Mr. Bush gave no estimate of how much it would cost to rebuild the base. But Gen. Merrill McPeak, the Air Force Chief of Staff, said last week that "it would take hundreds of millions of dollars to put that base back into the shape it was.
 
How It Would Work
 President Bush is likely to finance the cleanup efforts by declaring a national emergency, which allows Congress to appropriate money outside normal budgetary restrictions. It is also possible that he will use money already in the Pentagon budget, since the military has a large role in the cleanup.
Mr. Chiles, who has clashed with Federal officials over the Government's response to the hurricane, said he was glad to see Mr. Bush back for a more thorough look at the disaster area. Last week Mr. Chiles, a Democrat, dismissed the President's first trip, which focused on a shopping mall in an affluent suburb closer to Miami, by remarking, "He went to South Miami and looked at a downed tree."
Today Mr. Chiles said he thought that "anytime you get on the ground, it's useful." The Governor said that Florida needed "a world of help" and that it was only fair that the state "not be required to put up 25 percent or 10 percent" of the reconstruction costs.
With Mr. Bush's announcement today, the Federal Government will shoulder the entire cost of projects like debris removal, sewers, public safety and the reconstruction of schools, museums and other public buildings.
 
'Angry, Frustrated'
 Although the pace of Federal relief efforts has quickened since late last week, criticism has persisted, especially from Democrats. "People are angry, frustrated and shocked" by the slowness of the Government response to the hurricane, said Representative Dante Fascell, a Democrat whose district includes Homestead. "Certainly, if the Federal Government had responded on Day One, instead of Day Four or whatever it was, that would have made a tremendous difference," he said. Mr. Fascell is not running for re-election.
But Mr. Bush seems to have muted other critics with the sheer force of the military relief effort. "Last Thursday, I asked where the hell was the cavalry," said Kate Hale, the Dade County emergency services director, whose angry, televised cry for help is seen by many as having spurred the Bush Administration. "Today, there's no doubt where they are: They're here."
Her enthusiasm was milder when she was asked about President's Bush's visit to Homestead this morning and whether she felt political motives lay behind it. "What can I say?" she responded. "The guy came down, and he had good news. As long as he has good news, God bless him."
Later in the day, Mr. Bush flew to Louisiana and visited a recreation center in Jeanerette, where relief supplies donated by individuals and charities are being distributed by volunteers. "This is the very best about America, pitching in to help someone else," Mr. Bush said.
 
Into the Sugar Belt
 That was a theme he restated in tonight's Oval Office speech. Repeatedly, he commended Americans for their voluntarism, and specifically endorsed the relief efforts of the American Red Cross and a new private campaign called We Will Rebuild, headed by Alvah Chapman, the retired chairman of the newspaper chain Knight-Ridder Inc. who is a Miami civic leader.
The message of private charity and public-spiritedness seemed to fall on sympathetic ears in Jeanerette, a small town in the heart of the south-central Louisiana sugar belt, where the damage and human need has generally been manageable by local government and private relief agencies.
Mr. Bush and his party then went inside the recreation center to look at the heaps of food and other supplies that have been donated from all over the country.
Appearing on the front porch where food packages were being distributed, Mr. Bush was greeted by a few cheers. He then handed a bag of food to Elliot Allen, 13 years old. Asked what the President had said, the boy said, "He told me not to eat it all at once."
Mr. Bush gave a bit of good news to sugar cane growers, whose losses from the storm are estimated at $200 million, pledging to hold sugar imports to current levels.
"While there is damage to the sugar crop, we are not going to raise the sugar import quota," Mr. Bush said. The quota is designed to supplement the American sugar crop with enough sugar from 40 foreign countries to keep a stable price.
Mr. Bush headed back to Washington from Louisiana late this afternoon.
The President's tour of Homestead disrupted relief efforts for most of the morning. Citing security requirements, the police blocked streets all along Mr. Bush's route, preventing trucks and other vehicles from ferrying supplies to relief sites, and forcing many volunteers to sit idly in the sweltering heat.
Mr. Bush's first stop was a military field kitchen outside Campbell Drive Middle School, where several hundred people were being served a breakfast of grilled tuna, hash brown potatoes, pears, apple sauce and juice. Since late last week, the kitchen has been feeding those residents of Homestead who have no homes or food. Troops were put to work cleaning up the site an hour before the President's arrival.
"We love you, but we need your help now," Antonia Vazquez de Pereira called out as Mr. Bush inspected the kitchen in the company of Col. Al Sullivan, commander of a military task force that arrived here Friday. Amid Spanish-accented chants of "Bar-bar-a, Bar-bar-a," Mrs. Pereira and another Hispanic woman made their way through the crowd to Barbara Bush and embraced her, crying quietly.
"I lost my house totally, and I don't have any help," Mrs. Pereira, a native of Peru, said when asked what had made her approach the Mr. and Mrs. Bush. "We are citizens and we need it. We don't need promises, we need houses, food, medicine, now. And for the adults, we need work. Most of us are immigrants, and we have worked very, very hard for this country."
 
Skeptical Viewer
 Also watching from the fringes of the crowd with a great deal more restraint and skepticism was Venus Sookram, who grows Indian vegetables and fruits just outside town on a 20-acre farm that was severely damaged by the storm. He said he had been to see the Federal disaster authorities on Monday, looking for financial assistance, but was discouraged by what he described as an inflexible bureaucratic response.
"I think it's a good idea, his being here, but let's see what he is going to do," Mr. Sookram said.
Mr. Bush seemed particularly interested in the small radios the Army has been distributing, with batteries, to Homestead residents in order to improve communications to areas without power. The President approached 5-year-old Tremaine Franklin and told the boy to "be sure you get your mom and dad to listen, because it tells all the things people are trying to do to help."
"What we are trying to do is saturate the communities around here with transistor radios," Colonel Sullivan explained. "That way, they can tune in and find out where aid is available."
 
Visit to the Tents
 Mr. Bush also stopped at the first of the tent settlements that had been built by the military. Although no Homestead residents have yet been moved into the tents, the President seemed impressed by the speed with which the military has acted.
"They've done a great job setting it up," Mr. Bush said to his military escort, Col. Humberto Rodriguez. Homestead's City Manager, Alex Muxo, was also at the President's side and gently pointed out that there are some major flaws in the system that have made Homestead residents reluctant to move into the tents.
"I think what we're going to have to do is actually go out to the neighborhoods," he told Mr. Bush. "We're already bringing some mental health people in to assure them they will be safe here, because what we're finding at the shelters is that people will go eat lunch and dinner, but they don't want to stay there. They want to secure the personal belongings they have."
Mr. Muxo then told the President that to provide some level of comfort, the tent settlements would have day-care facilities and would show movies. "Oh, for heaven's sake," a pleased Mr. Bush replied. "These guys certainly have it set up nice."
By the time Mr. Bush arrived at Homestead City Hall for a final briefing, local officials said they had made it clear that the situation was far graver than the President had indicated last week. "I think he's seen it," Mr. Muxo said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
G.M. Ultimatum to Parts Makers Brings Showdown With Workers

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 1

 BODY:
United Automobile Workers, meet Jack Smith, Inaki Lopez and G.M.'s new cost-cutting team.
The spreading strike at the General Motors Corporation, which now involves more than 30,000 workers at seven plants, is the first concerted reaction by G.M. workers to the company's campaign to cut costs and reduce its work force by 74,000 people by 1995. The strike is threatening to affect nearly twice as many plants and workers by the end of this week. 
 The cost-cutting effort by the company, which involves shrinking its North American operations and scrutinizing just about every significant purchase from roller bearings to disk brakes, is being led by a new management team that includes John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s 54-year-old president, and J. Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, a 51-year-old Spanish engineer who arrived here four months ago and has shaken motordom to its entrenched roots.
Mr. Lopez, who was in charge of purchasing for G.M. Europe when the overseas operation was restructured by Mr. Smith, resulting in impressive gains in profits and productivity, has created something of a firestorm in the auto industry. Nicknamed the "Grand Inquisitor" by European auto executives, Mr. Lopez was appointed vice president for worldwide purchasing in Detroit in April.
 
Demands for Productivity
 He promptly shook up the clubby world of G.M. suppliers -- including the company's vast parts-making divisions that supply 70 percent of the components in G.M.'s vehicles. He declared that all contracts would be put up for bid and that 50 percent improvements in productivity were expected in three years.
The clear message to the auto workers' union is that the price cuts Mr. Lopez wants from G.M.'s parts operations could lead to plant shutdowns, divestitures and fewer union jobs. Although Mr. Lopez is not personally responsible for all of that, he has become a symbol of a changing G.M. that says it wants to be leaner and more competitive.
"This is all about whether management has the ability to improve the competitiveness of our company," one G.M. middle manager said.
But in Lordstown, Ohio, where G.M. has a complex of plants that make everything from fenders to the subcompact Chevrolet Cavalier, becoming more competitive has meant a loss of jobs. And job security, which has been a leading issue between the company and the union for years, is the U.A.W.'s battle cry as it heads into contract negotiations next year with G.M.
In many respects, the current strike is a dress rehearsal for the 1993 labor talks. And there is already talk here that this dispute holds the potential to be a protracted showdown reminiscent of the union's bitter -- and unsuccessful -- strike against Caterpillar Inc. this year.
The current strike exploded from a local dispute into a national showdown partly because G.M.'s top management was focused on its corporate restructuring, the recent issuance of new stock and broad strategic planning to shore up profits.
The current strike started in Lordstown last week when the U.A.W. protested the elimination of 240 tool-and-die-making jobs because the work was being shifted to an outside supplier. The union was dusting off an age-old strike strategy by walking out of a plant that makes body parts for a number of G.M.'s best-selling models, including full-sized vans and the Saturn subcompacts.
In the past, G.M. often bowed to pressure when organized labor staged a strike at a small plant that is intended to cause larger problems, steadily affecting more and more operations.
But this time, G.M.'s top management is clearly on notice from directors that it must stabilize the auto maker's finances in North America, where it lost $7 billion last year.
Although the union helped G.M. start the innovative Saturn car-making venture, the strike proves the union is also willing to damage Saturn's sales to dramatize its distaste for strategies that take away jobs.
 
 
Memories of Caterpillar
 Stephen Yokich, head of the union's G.M. department, wants to be the next U.A.W. president; he and other officers must prove that the union can deal more effectively with job losses than it did during the strike at Caterpillar.
"Mr. Lopez has met with Steve Yokich and said their talks were excellent," a G.M. spokeswoman, Antonette Simonetti, said today, referring to talks before the strike began. "He said he admires union workers and they should work together to make operations competitive.
"But he said there is only one class of G.M. supplier, not internal and external. He's said to workers, 'Let's work together.' "
Because G.M. makes a higher proportion of its parts itself, with costly union labor, many G.M. parts -- and, therefore, G.M. vehicles -- are at a serious cost disadvantage to the Ford Motor Company, the Chrysler Corporation and Japanese auto makers that buy parts overseas or from nonunion shops.
 
 
'A Lot of Pressure'
 "We had Lopez into our plant," said Jack Withrow, the president of the Lectron Corporation, a G.M. supplier in Rochester Hills, Mich. "There's a lot of pressure on price -- all our supply contracts are being rebid. He wants double-digit decreases, not the 2 or 3 percent G.M. had been asking for."
John Casesa, automotive analyst for Wertheim Schroder & Company in New York, said: "G.M. has been evading these issues since World War II. The longer you wait, the tougher it gets."
But Mr. Casesa says he thinks the G.M. strike will not explode into a confrontation like the one between Caterpillar and the auto workers. Rather, it will be a "sneak preview," he said, of next year's bargaining for a new contract to replace the current one, which expires in the fall of 1993.
Mr. Lopez received his assignment from Jack Smith, G.M.'s new president. Mr. Smith was installed only last April by board members who are not part of management who had grown impatient with the company's progress under Robert C. Stempel, the chairman. During negotiations with the union in 1990, Mr. Stempel spoke of his determination to "grow the business," which union bargainers understood as a commitment to keep work and jobs inside the company.
 
 
Turnaround in Europe
 Mr. Smith and Mr. Lopez helped lead the turnaround of G.M.'s European operations in the 1980's. Auto industry analysts credited them with consolidating what had been a divided, expensive operation into a highly profitable business with well-managed marketing, distribution and cost-control operations. Mr. Smith went on to head all of G.M.'s international operations until the board dismissed his predecessor as president, Lloyd E. Reuss, and gave Mr. Smith a mandate to rescue G.M.'s North American automotive operations.
"G.M. is in a tough economic position," said Harry Katz, professor of labor relations at Cornell University. "Management is making its moves, and the union is looking for bargaining leverage."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE STORM;
After Andrew, Another Unannounced Visitor: George Bush

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOMESTEAD, Fla., Sept. 1

 BODY:
When Ramon Rodriguez and Adela Antonini whistled at George Bush from the doorway of their windowless apartment, they never expected that the President would just drop by, unannounced.
And while they were honored, seeing that the President did not visit any other hurricane-damaged homes during his trip here, they were really hoping to see someone more important. 
 "It would have been better if the manager of the building came," Ms. Antonini said. "No offense to Bush, but we don't need our morale boosted. We need our ceiling plugged."
For the most part, the hot, tired and mosquito-bitten hurricane victims here only knew that the President had come to town because their streets were blocked for most of the morning.
 
A Language Barrier
 And many of those who encountered him at the emergency shelters he toured did not understand a word he said. They speak Spanish and Haitian Creole, not English.
Still, some Homestead residents were thrilled that the President had come to see the damage for himself. "How could he have a cold heart after he sees that our babies are thirsty and sick?" Mauricio Reyes, a farm worker, said.
And others, while skeptical that Mr. Bush's motives were political, said they would take whatever attention they could get. "The man was here, the man will be on TV, and the world will keep thinking about us," said Tawana Sheets, 22 years old, who lost her home and her job at a plant nursery in the last week.
A block away from one emergency shelter, Janine Powell, 54, rested on a toilet in front of the rubble that used to be her home. (It was the only thing resembling a piece of furniture she could salvage.)
"I think the President should come sit where I'm sitting and see the devastation from our perspective," she said. "But seriously, he needs to know how desperately we need him. And if he doesn't come through, well -- Homestead for Clinton, I say."
Some storm victims, delayed in their salvaging and scavenging efforts by the roadblocks for the President, vented their frustrations in sarcasm and hostility.
A temporary receptionist at the Homestead City Hall, Shawanna Williams, 18, was yelling at the police officers guarding Mr. Bush's meeting with local officials.
"I just want to know what he's going to do," said Ms. Williams, who is living with her two babies and 10 other relatives in a Florida City house without a roof. "If something like this happened up there where he's at, bet you his stuff would get fixed up right quick."
Patsy Nieto, 27, cradled her 4-month-old baby, waiting to complete her drive north to pick up a tent that would replace her demolished home in Leisure City.
"I don't think President Bush ever cared about us low-income people to begin with, so why start now?" Mrs. Nieto said.
Few Homestead residents knew that the President had announced that he would rebuild the Homestead Air Force base, a linchpin of the local economy.
 
From Diatribe to Blessings
 When Elisa Gonzalez learned of his announcement, she stopped in the middle of an anti-Bush diatribe.
"Well, God bless, he's doing the right thing," said Mrs. Gonzalez, who sells subscriptions for a cable television company. "All we want is for our beautiful, proud community to get a second chance."
And Homestead's Police Chief, Curt Ivy, who described his first view of the post-hurricane landscape as "something out of some acid rock album cover," said the town would "get more positive" toward the President once the news circulated.
At one shelter, the Homestead Middle School, Gloria Sanchez, 28, and her children rested on the foam mattress that has been their home since Hurricane Andrew destroyed the Everglades Labor Camp in Florida City, a trailer park for migrant workers. Mrs. Sanchez, who is Mexican, did not bother to venture into the courtyard where Mr. Bush addressed reporters.
"He is not really our President," she said. "And especially now. Because if there is no chance for work here, then we will just return to Matamoros."
Fabien Baptiste, a Haitian refugee who nursed her 2-month-old daughter at the shelter, only wanted to know if Mr. Bush was going to transfer them to the tent city.
"I stayed in his army's tents in Guantanamo, on my way here," she said.
As Mr. Bush drove away from the Homestead City Hall, he addressed the small crowd through a loudspeaker.
"Good luck to you all," the President said.
And Beth Brago, a Dade County teacher who lives in a severely damaged house in the Redlands, snickered a response.
"We need more than luck, sweetheart," she called after the motorcade. "Luck never put food on the table for my children."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Congressional Race;
Dueling Incumbents Revisit House Bank Scandal

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WATERLOO, Iowa, Aug. 30

 BODY:
The House bank scandal is being replayed in a fierce Congressional contest here between two incumbents who clashed in the partisan war that the scandal unleashed in Washington.
On one side is Representative Jim Nussle, a 32-year-old conservative Republican freshman who is best known for putting a paper grocery bag over his head on the House floor to dramatize his outrage over Congressional perquisites and overdrawn checking accounts. 
 Reapportionment, which reduced Iowa's allotment of House seats to five from six, has forced Mr. Nussle into a tight race with Representative Dave Nagle, a 49-year-old liberal Democrat who prides himself on his close ties to the House Democratic leadership. Mr. Nagle, who has served three terms, also attracted attention during the House bank affair by asking the House to resist a Justice Department subpoena of the House bank records of all members. He said the action infringed on the separation of powers between Congress and the Administration.
 
Political Fault Line
 Mr. Nagle argued in a speech that the lawmakers were obliged to protect the Constitutional separation of powers between the executive and legislative branches. He concluded by saying that when Congress was pushed by misguided constituents, "public opinion be damned."
The wide fault line between the Republican and Democrat will clearly test how Iowa voters view the Congress -- as part of the problem or part of the solution for the nation's economic malaise. While Mr. Nussle tells voters, "I'm running on the platform that we have to start saying no" to reduce the $4 trillion national debt, Mr. Nagle offers a vision of corn price supports, highway expansion and dam and bridge repair projects to stimulate Iowa's stagnant economy.
Almost everywhere Mr. Nussle goes he receives comments about his paper bag, which is seen by some as a sophomoric stunt but by others as an effective tactic to help close the House bank and expose members who abused their checking privileges.
At a coffee shop on the outskirts of the town of New Hampton, Mr. Nussle was greeted Thursday by Ray McDermott, 78, a motel owner who placed a grocery bag next to Mr. Nussle's plate of eggs. "Here's your working suit," Mr. McDermott said, pointing to the bag. "You say the Democrats have ruined the country by running Congress for 38 years, but the first 26 were pretty good. You should be ashamed of your party."
Mr. Nussle patiently talked with the man and appeared to impress several passersby with his cool.
The next day the Republican lawmaker visited a vocational school in Mason City, where students greeted him by passing small paper bags around the room.
"One person can put a bag on his head and make a difference," Mr. Nussle told them, and repeated his "Lead or Leave" pledge that he will retire from the Congress in 1996 unless the annual budget deficit is cut in half.
Mr. Nagle said in an interview that if the race was decided on the issue of Congressional reform, he would lose, even though he overdrew his House bank account a mere four times over 39 months. "I will win," he said, "if the economy is the main issue."
Calling the race "a choice between anger and hope," Mr. Nagle spoke Saturday morning at a ceremony opening a new low-income housing project, a women's rights rally and a machinists union hall, where he quoted Franklin D. Roosevelt and spoke of a need for an activist Government.
Bud Sanders, 51, a union steward, liked what he heard. "We look for people who understand our needs," he said. "Nussle doesn't. He might as well walk around with a sack on his head."
In the afternoon, Mr. Nagle was at a chemical company family picnic, where he reminded 200 employees and their families of how he had successfully lobbied the Czechslovak Government to drop an application for an import fee waiver on a chemical also made by the Iowa plant.
"It's about time the Government did something right," said Keith Oldham, 61, as he slapped Mr. Nagle on the back. A retired fire chief, Mr. Oldham said his wife, a receptionist with the chemical company, probably would have lost her job had it not been for the Congressman's efforts. "I like Nussle for making his point the way he did," he said, "but I suppose I'm going to have to vote for Nagle because he helped my family."

HEADLINE: Cold Spring Journal;
The Vision That Wasn't. Or Was It?

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OLD SPRING, Ky., Sept. 1

 BODY:
The first clue to why this town of 2,800 people was braced for anywhere from 10,000 to 100,000 visitors Monday night came about nine miles south of Cincinnati, where a sign outside of Leisure Time Sports advertised "Lady of Light T-shirts."
Farther along Route 27, the highway that pretty much defines Cold Spring, every lawn, driveway and business parking lot was blocked off with yellow plastic police tape. And across from St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, a small contingent of military police from the National Guard was standing watch. 
 The excitement began building two months ago, when the pastor of the church, the Rev. Leroy Smith, told a small prayer group that at midnight on Aug. 31 he expected either an appearance or a message from the Virgin Mary. The prediction came, he said, from a "visionary" in Batavia, Ohio, whose identity he would not disclose.
By mid-July the predicted event was fodder for headlines, newscasts and talk shows, and both church and town officials were rattled by the prospect of what somebody called "a Woodstock for Catholics."
In the end the crowd probably numbered fewer than 8,000 people, and whether the Blessed Virgin was among them seemed to be a matter of a special kind of faith. But the quest for the miraculous at St. Joseph's Church here is far from unique. Indeed, it would not even have occurred except for a growing movement built around a swelling flow of reported apparitions and messages from Mary.
A day that started with a Mass before a thousand people on the parish parking lot ended with a hush at midnight. Inside the church, to which only 1,500 parishioners -- and no cameras or tape recorders -- were admitted, Father Smith paused in saying the rosary. Now the thousands gathered in the parking lot heard him say over loudspeakers, "Let us take a moment to welcome Our Lady into our midst."
The intensity of the moment was broken only by the winking of flashbulbs. A small clump of people pointed at a pine tree.
"It was like a silhouette figure and Mary had her arms out, and first we saw it above the tree and then it rose above the church," Shirley Richardson, a 22-year-old hair stylist who had grown up in the parish, said later.
Joel Schirmer, an 18-year-old from the Cold Spring area, had nothing similar to report but "was not disappointed," he said, adding, "To tell the truth, I didn't expect to see anything."
A priest who was inside the church, the Rev. Edward Carter, who teaches theology at Xavier University in Cincinnati, said, "I saw nothing out of the ordinary." Nonetheless, he described "a profound experience of peace and serenity" in the congregation, and likened it to the mood reported by visitors to famous sites honoring visions of Mary.
He referred, in particular, to Medjugorje, the Croatian village where six young people have been claiming to experience virtually daily appearances of Mary for more than a decade.
The millions of pilgrims from the United States to Medjugorje are a chief root of the current enthusiasm. Father Smith has been to Medjugorje nine times. So had about a quarter of those at the morning Mass.
Many of the hundreds who endured a day of blazing sunshine on lawn chairs and blankets in the church's huge parking lot were ready to be satisfied with serenity rather than a vision. They prayed and sang hymns and put petitions for help from God in a big cardboard box by a stone grotto with a statue of Mary in it.
Some displayed rosary beads with links that had turned a gold color. Sometimes, they said, this had happened instantaneously at Medjugorje; in other cases, the color changed over time.
Knots of people hunched over Polaroid photographs of the sun that showed rectangular glows of light -- the door to Heaven, some said -- and shadows in which the figures of Jesus, Mary or angels were discerned.
But many who peered at the rosary beads or photographs were quick to say that such marvels, including the possibility of a midnight apparition, were not important in themselves, but only as ways of drawing people to prayer and faith in Jesus.
"If it changes the person interiorly, it is a valid experience," said Marianne Tomlinson. "But they have to be truly seeking the truth and not the spectacle."
Ms. Tomlinson, a 36-year-old Cincinnatian who had gone to Catholic schools, said that last February she was "ready to join a hopping Protestant church" where she could "praise God openly," as she had done in a Catholic charismatic group until it disbanded.
A priest had helped her to become interested in Marian devotions, she said, and she "now prays two hours a day" and understands the Mass as she never had before.
At Leisure Time Sports, a half-mile closer to Cincinnati along Route 27, Gary Chism was busy silk-screening T-shirts with the inscription "Lady of Light" above a design of Mary's head and diagonal rays.
"I'm not Catholic, so for me to design a shirt like this was kind of out of the ordinary," said Mr. Chism, who was reared as a Baptist. "The world's in such bad shape, with the economy, drugs, violence. This is a ray of hope for people who need something good."
His wife, Bobbi, had some observations on the purchasers. "Some of them come across as really sincere," she said, "and some come across as fruitcakes."
Bishop William A. Hughes, whose diocese of Covington, Ky., includes Cold Spring, had told Catholics to be cautious about giving credence to predictions of extraordinary visions or messages, and he said he was pained at so much curiosity about them.
Father Smith himself warned that "we should not be looking for the spectacular." But during the Mass he quoted more messages from Mary "sent" to him by the visionary. At the nighttime service he announced more messages from Mary and Jesus that he said had been received Thursday by people in Arizona.
Bishop Hughes released a statement late today, saying, "After visiting with Father Smith today, I am convinced that nothing of a miraculous nature occurred in St. Joseph Church last evening." He praised the crowd for its reverence and respect, and apologized to the citizens of Cold Spring "who may have been inconvenienced."
At Leisure Time Sports, Mr. Chism reported that Lady of Light T-shirts were "more popular today than yesterday." He was still trying to fill orders for the shirts.

HEADLINE: CALIFORNIA HURDLE IS SCHOOL SPENDING

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 1

 BODY:
Negotiators for the State Legislature entered intense talks with Gov. Pete Wilson's staff today to resolve a dispute over future state support for public schools, the last remaining hurdle to ending California's two-month budget crisis.
People on both sides familiar with the negotiations said they were trying to find some face-saving concessions to offer Speaker Willie L. Brown Jr. and the fractious Democratic-controlled Assembly as inducement to vote for the main elements of the Republican Governor's plan. 
 The dispute revolves not around this year's actual appropriations but around the Governor's efforts to make his school-spending plans immune to challenge in the courts.
The deliberations came as the state staggered through its 63d day without a budget. The lawmakers worked past their deadline of midnight Monday before recessing early today. Leaders said they were prepared for another long session.
 
The Pressure Builds
 Intense pressure is building for a solution as the state continues to pay its bills with i.o.u.'s. It has stopped paying for health care for the poor; it will owe doctors and hospitals nearly $270 million by Thursday.
Over the last two months, the lawmakers have grudgingly yielded to the Governor in agreeing to balance this year's recession-racked $57.6 billion budget with many deep and painful cuts but no new taxes. No agreement has yet been possible, however, on the numbingly complex plan that Mr. Wilson has offered to hold down increases in school spending in future years.
The Governor has demanded and obtained legislative agreement to "recapture" $1.1 billion overpaid to local school districts last year under a state Constitutional provision called Proposition 98 that guarantees the public schools and community colleges 40 percent of state revenues, which is about $24 billion this year. To keep school spending steady this year, he would "lend" the schools $959 million from future years. This would reduce the original base on which support in future years is based.
 
Wanting a 'Poison Pill'
 And to protect this plan, he wants a "poison pill" in the legislation that would suspend Proposition 98 and allow him to cut spending should any school district successfully challenge the plan in court.
Democrats in the Assembly and educational interests, including the powerful California Teachers Association, opposed the Governor's idea.
But they have been discussing a number of concessions as the price of their support, including adding $100 million to the base of school support next year, changing the formula by which daily attendance is calculated, restoring some of the cuts suffered by community college and rolling back some of the fee increases forced on the two state university systems. Among other means, they would pay for this by cutting the state bureaucracy, laying off public information officers, for example.
"We've put to bed 99.967 percent of all spending," said Assemblyman Phil Isenberg, a Democrat from Sacramento who has been a leader in the budget issue. "The rest is some turf protection and giant egos."
 
Assembly Is the Key
 The difficulty was to get the two-thirds majority of 54 votes required in the 80-seat Assembly in which both liberal Democrats and conservative Republicans are unhappy with Governor Wilson. The Senate had earlier passed the bulk of his budget proposals and was expected to go along with whatever compromise he reached with the Assembly leadership.
The daylong negotiations followed a hectic legislative night on Monday, during which both houses passed all the necessary legislation to resolve the stalemate except for a school-spending plan acceptable to the Governor. After that, an aide to Mr. Wilson said, Speaker Brown telephoned the Governor and there was a "polite" conversation in which the two agreed to end the impasse and send their representatives to work out the details of the compromise.
"Anybody who thinks the Governor has won is crazy; none of us are winning," said the Senate Republican minority leader, Kenneth L. Maddy of Fresno, during the debate the other day. "We've all lost, in terms of the credibility of the public."
The Governor's aides hope he will benefit from public anger this November, when all the seats in the Assembly and half in the Senate are up for election. They hope to raise the number of Republicans in the 80-seat Assembly to 37 or 38 from the current 33. Assuming an alliance with conservative Democrats, the Republicans would have a working majority and could probably force Mr. Brown out as Speaker. Twenty-five of the incumbents are leaving the house, and 15 or so others are in tough races.
In addition, the Governor has mounted a voter initiative that would amend the State Constitution to give him considerable additional powers over budgetary matters and welfare grants.

HEADLINE: Teachers in 3 States Strike, Signaling Wider Unrest

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
Teachers in three states have gone on strike in work stoppages that could spread to three other states. And union leaders and education analysts say the bitter mood among teachers goes beyond wage and compensation issues.
In the largest of the strikes, 10,000 teachers in the Detroit school system walked off their jobs on Monday, as did teachers in four other Michigan school systems of Mount Pleasant, Clarkston, Grand Haven and Plainwell. In Illinois, teachers in Harrisburg, Rochester, Bethany, Tri-Valley and Belvidere are on strike, as are teachers in the Bennington, Vt., school district. 
 The number of strikes, while smaller than in past years, could grow if current negotiations break down in several school districts in Pennsylvania, Massachusetts and California. In addition, leaders of the National Education Association and the American Federation of Teachers, the two national teachers' unions, say there is another factor that could create more strikes: More teachers than in recent years are returning to work without contracts, many for the second or third year.
But a national school board expert said the teachers' demands were unrealistic, given the nation's economy.
"Unions are trying to force the issue, and they have no concerns about resources," said Thomas A. Shannon, executive director of the National School Boards Association in Alexandria, Va., which represents 15,350 local school boards. "School boards cannot print money, and they are constrained by law in the revenues available to them."
More than at any point in the recent past, say union leaders and education analysts, teachers feel mounting frustration not just over pay and benefits, but over the level of state aid to school financing, which has led to teacher layoffs, larger class sizes in many schools and a dearth of basic supplies.
The current disputes are "a little bigger than just school boards versus the teachers," said Michael Kasserly, interim director of the Council of Great City Schools, which represents 45 of the nation's largest urban school districts. "It's an economic climate that's exacerbating tensions and divisions, in an education environment that's badly underfunded in the first place."
Indeed, at issue in some districts is not whether teachers should get more money, but whether local school districts can rescind previously set pay increases and health benefits that were struck in more prosperous times.
The average teacher's salary in the United States in 1991-92 was $34,213, according to the American Federation of Teachers.
Last year, said Keith Geiger, president of the National Education Association, the largest teachers' union with 2.1 million members, teachers across the nation received an average pay increase of just under 5 percent. That amount exceeded the rate of inflation last year, but teachers this year will be hard pressed to win increases near that level, Mr. Geiger said.
 
'Angry and Bitter'
 "We're used to being told there's no money for salary increases," Mr. Geiger said. "But this year for the first time not only are we not getting pay increases, you can't even get the $300 to $500 to $1,000 a year incremental pay increase."
Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, which has 796,000 members, said the current unrest masks the moods of many teachers, who he said are going back to school "angry and bitter."
"They think that things are pretty hopeless," he added.
Mark Gniewek, a computer science teacher picketing outside Detroit Northern High School yesterday, told The Associated Press that he and his colleagues were angrier this year than during their last strike, a five-week walkout in 1987. "I think a lot of teachers would go back to work for a very little raise," he said. "What's being offered now isn't really a raise."
Detroit has offered a 3 percent salary bonus in exchange for attending 50 hours of workshops without pay.

HEADLINE: As Serbs See War: Foreign Plots and Ingratitude

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 29

 BODY:
Isolated and embittered, the people of Serbia seem gripped by a kind of national psychosis fed by the Balkans' grim history and by visions of intricate international plots to humiliate them.
Their dark mood was captured by a crowd here this week on a central thoroughfare, Kneza Mihaila Avenue. Standing beside banners saying "Western countries want to rape Serbia!" and "Serbs need media justice," they signed a petition to Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, protesting United Nations economic sanctions. 
 Ugljesa Jovanovic, a 32-year-old electrical engineer in the crowd, shook with rage. "I absolutely do not understand the West," he said. "Why does the United States want to persecute Serbia, which resisted Hitler and gave more than it was ever asked? Why are we alone singled out when there have been crimes on all sides in this war?"
Such anger is widespread in what is left of Yugoslavia, and it complicates the West's calculations on how to end the fighting between the Serbs and opposing forces in newly independent republics.
In theory, the United Nations sanctions against Yugoslavia, adopted in May, are supposed to turn the people of Serbia, the dominant republic in the truncated new Yugoslav federation, against their hard-line President, Slobodan Milosevic. This in turn would help speed a move toward compromise in the conflict in Bosnia and Herzegovina, most of which has been captured by Serbian forces. But the anger toward the outside world appears stronger than any directed at Mr. Milosevic.
There is no question that the sanctions have caused considerable hardship and that with the onset of winter, this could lead to growing political opposition to Mr. Milosevic. But the street protests of June and July have faded.
"We are pretty hard-headed under pressure and able to endure," said Momir Pavlicevic, an official of the Serbian Chamber of Commerce. "Now the U.S. and Western attacks on us are bringing us Serbs together, and I think they are reinforcing Mr. Milosevic."
To many Serbs, the war is largely the result of foreign myopia. In this view, violence became inevitable after 1.5 million ethnic Serbs found themselves marooned, without guarantees, in new countries after rapid recognition of the independence of Croatia, Slovenia and Bosnia and Herzegovina.
These Serbs say other governments have no right to dictate policy because they bungled in the breakup of old Yugoslavia and so are at least partly responsible for the war.
Arguing this way, many Serbs resort to conspiracy theories to explain their status as pariahs. Among these are that a German-Austrian-Croatian alliance, a grouping that existed during World War II, is once more dominant in Europe and bent on revenge against Serbia for its resistance to fascism.
It is also suggested that the United States has bowed to pressure from Saudi Arabia and Turkey and is supporting Bosnia's Muslim President, Alija Izetbegovic. The Muslims of Bosnia, the biggest single ethnic group in the republic, have been under relentless attack by the Serbs. "Mideast oil is more important to Washington than Serbia," said Vuk Rosandic, a 23-year-old musician. "So we have been ditched by the United States, a country we thought was our firm ally."
 
All Sides Commit Atrocities
 Many Serbs are convinced that abuses in Bosnia and Herzegovina have been no more terrible than those by Croatian or Muslim forces, that the plight of more than 450,000 Serbian refugees from Croatia and Bosnia has received far less attention than the suffering of Muslims or Croats, and that the Serbian fighters in Bosnia are not under Belgrade's control. Thus it follows that they believe they are the victims of a gross injustice.
Their indignation was sharpened by comments last week by the Acting American Secretary of State, Lawrence S. Eagleburger, at Yugoslav peace talks in London. His statement that "it is the Serbs, alas, who are most guilty today of crimes" was the most widely reported here of any remark made during the conference.
Mr. Eagleburger served here as United States Ambassador. "He is supposed to understand the situation," said a former Yugoslav diplomat who knows the Secretary well, "and he comes out with this."
Of course not all Serbs see plots against them and some concede that the policies of Mr. Milosevic, with his driving vision of a Greater Serbia, have been the main cause of the Yugoslav crisis. But not even those who oppose him and have sided with the conciliatory policies of the new Yugoslav Prime Minister, Milan Panic, blame him for giving support to Serbs in the newly independent states of the former Yugoslavia. Very few argue that Belgrade should have left these ethnic Serbs to fend for themselves.
Particularly galling to Serbs, who fought the Germans in two world wars and suffered heavily in the concentration camps of the puppet Nazi state of Croatia during World War II, was the European Community's quick recognition last year, under German pressure, of Croatian independence.
"Germans have made some serious mistakes," said Aleksandar Nenadovic, a political commentator, "and the worst was to hurry the recognition of Croatia and Slovenia without insuring that all ethnic communities throughout the old Yugoslavia had guarantees. We will not forget that."
As viewed here, the current drift in Europe involves a resurgent Germany, opposed as ever to Serbian power, a Germany that has secured its long-sought access to the Mediterranean through a subservient Croatia. This new Germany, many argue, is now bludgeoning Washington into an anti-Serbian policy.
They see themselves as isolated and united, heroically defending a truth that the world is blind to, but that will emerge in the end. Tough fighters in many wars, they again rally to the cry, "Only Solidarity Saves the Serb!"
Mr. Nenadovic, the political commentator, said that many here had been moved by the country's isolation to the defiant view that "the Serbs are best off alone and fighting everyone, and that is something their computers in London and Washington cannot understand."

HEADLINE: 23 States Face Suits on School Funds

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
As schools reopen this week from the summer break, many begin the new year under a cloud: Increasing numbers of states face lawsuits over their failure to close spending gaps between rich and poor school districts or their failure to give adequate aid to all schools.
Twenty-three states are embroiled in suits, most filed since 1990, over how they finance school districts. Three others -- New York, New Hampshire and California -- could face lawsuits again if plaintiffs make good on threats to appeal or refile cases that were decided this year. 
 By comparison, 11 states faced such suits five years ago, with most now settled.
 
Seeking Long-Term Solutions
 "Whatever comes out from these rounds of court cases, people should be thinking about long-term solutions and not short-term solutions," said Robert Berne, the assistant dean of the Wagner School of Public Service at New York University who has testified in several cases. "Giving cash infusions without anticipating inflation, growth or the cost of school reform may win you the short-term battle, but you don't win the war."
Chris Pipho, an analyst for the Education Commission of the States, a Denver education research and policy organization, said: "School finance is back on the front burner. Finance issues had taken a back seat to education reform in the 1980's, but the issues of equity and adequacy are too big to ignore."
The growing number of lawsuits reflects several problems, not the least of which is the lingering effects of the recession. For much of the 1980's, when resources were more plentiful, many states addressed spending disparities among schools by giving more money to poorer school districts. But the recession has hobbled those efforts.
 
Compounding the Problem
 Outdated ways of financing school districts have compounded the problem. Most school budgets still come primarily from local property taxes; thus, the more affluent the area is the more money its school district receives.
In addition, most school finance formulas do not take into account the mounting expenses caused by an increasing number of students who need special academic and social assistance.
But some states have started to search for remedies. In Massachusetts, for example, a business group last year proposed a plan, embraced by state legislators, that reflects what many school finance experts have proposed: Let education improvements and needs dictate the amount states allocate to schools.
Although the notion seems simple, basing school financing on educational needs would be difficult for two reasons. First, it requires states to abandon the decades-old approach of basing their school aid primarily on the number of students per district. Second, it is always debatable which education improvements and needs deserve financing.
Nowhere is the fight for equalizing state aid among school districts more divisive than in Texas.
 
Taking Texas to Court
 The State of Texas has been in and out of court over school financing since 1968, when a San Antonio sheet-metal worker, Demetrio Rodriguez, became the lead plaintiff for a group of parents in the predominantly Hispanic and property-poor Edgewood Independent School District.
Mr. Rodriguez's original suit, as well as a second suit filed by the Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund, asserted that the state did too little to correct the gap in wealth between rich and poor school districts.
Some districts, with highly valued commercial and residential property, can afford to spend nearly $20,000 on each student every year. Other districts, like Edgewood, cursed by bad geography and homes too modest to generate much in the way of taxes, spend about $3,000 a year per student.
Such a gap means classrooms in well-off districts may be outfitted with the latest in technology and textbooks and well-equipped science laboratories while classrooms in poorer areas must settle for outdated school books and little technology, let alone science labs.
Three times Texas has tried to remedy the problem and three times in as many years the Texas Supreme Court has rejected the plans as insufficient. In its most recent rejection, the State Supreme Court gave the Texas Legislature until May 1993 to correct the problem, and Gov. Ann W. Richards is expected to call a special legislative session this fall to address the disparities, which rank among the greatest of any state.
Increasingly, lawsuits are challenging states on another front: whether all schools, rich and poor, are receiving adequate financing to give students a quality education.
The American Civil Liberties Union is testing that approach in Louisiana, where it filed a lawsuit five months ago charging the state with underfinancing all public schools.
The A.C.L.U. says the underfinancing results in deficient educations. Some school districts use history textbooks so outdated that in their pages men have not yet landed on the moon. Some buildings have been allowed to deteriorate to to the point where sewers back up into the restrooms in a heavy rain. Some schools do not even have indoor bathrooms.
While many states struggle to maintain at least their present levels of financing, West Virginia, Tennessee and Kentucky have taken the lead in trying new ways to pay for schools.
All three states have assumed a larger responsibility in supporting schools than ever before through raising more taxes at the state level, putting a cap on how much rich districts can raise locally and giving more aid to all school districts, with larger allocations going to the poorer districts. Although these plans do not address all the discrepancies in school wealth -- and lawsuits are still active in West Virginia and Tennessee -- they have gone far toward closing the gaps.
Experts say school financing should at least reflect the higher cost of doing business in urban areas, which tend to have more youngsters who require special academic and social assistance. These experts also say that education needs should drive state financing if they can be properly defined and measured.
