HEADLINE: Networks Intensify The Courtship Of David Letterman

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
David Letterman is the most wanted man in television. Though no decision can be made about his future television home, the intensity of the courtship of this NBC late-night star by other prospective suitors has increased in recent weeks and so has NBC's own interest in doing everything it can to keep Mr. Letterman from going elsewhere.
The odds may have changed recently in the Letterman sweepstakes, but the race to sign the late-night comedy star to a new contract won't -- and can't -- begin until NBC first negotiates with Mr. Letterman. John Agoglia, the president of NBC Enterprises, said yesterday that the network's contract calls for an exclusive negotiating period with Mr. Letterman, which will not begin until early next year. Mr. Letterman's contract will expire in April. 
 NBC still expresses the hope that it can keep Mr. Letterman despite the acknowledged friction between the star and the network's management, which began last year when he was passed over as the successor to Johnny Carson on the network's flagship late-night program, the "Tonight" show. The job went to Jay Leno.
 
Making Presentations
 Several executives from NBC, other networks and syndication companies said yesterday that the situation was unusually complex mainly because of Mr. Letterman's NBC contract. While representatives of other networks and syndication companies have made what they call presentations to Mr. Letterman's representatives at the Creative Artists Agency in Los Angeles, no formal negotiations have taken place.
"Nobody wants to be accused of tampering with NBC's rights in the contract," said one senior network executive, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Indeed, NBC has explictly told those interested in Mr. Letterman that a lawsuit could ensue if the network perceives its exclusive negotiating period was violated.
One chief concern is the "onerous nature of some aspects of the contract" as one network programming executive, who has met with Mr. Letterman's representatives, put it. NBC declined to spell out the specific nature of the contract, saying it did not want to talk about conditions that may apply should Mr. Letterman decide to leave the network.
But one syndication executive and one senior executive from another network said Mr. Letterman might be prevented from starting a new television show for up to a year after his contract with NBC expires. "They can exercise an option and keep him off the market," the syndication executive said of Mr. Letterman.
The option would be put into force should Mr. Letterman make a deal with another party and not return to NBC to allow the network to match the offer. Because NBC has a year in which to match any competitive offer, it could, and probably would, exercise its option to keep Mr. Letterman off the air, the executive said.
Despite repeated requests to comment on the matter, Mr. Letterman has declined to be interviewed.
 
The Future of 'Nightline'
 Much of the speculation about Mr. Letterman's plans has been wild, including suggestions that ABC has committed to dropping its highly regarded late-night news program "Nightline," if Mr. Letterman can be signed. Phil Beuth, the ABC executive in charge of late-night programs, is one of the few network executives who has said on the record that he is not negotiating with Mr. Letterman.
That does not mean ABC would not be in the running for Mr. Letterman at some point. But Joanna Bistany, the senior vice president of ABC News, said the network remained unshakably committed to "Nightline." "The network has no plans to remove 'Nightline' under any circumstances," Ms. Bistany said. "The show is staying at 11:30 P.M."
Executives from CBS, Fox and several syndication companies say they are extremely interested in Mr. Letterman and will actively pursue establishing a new show for him should he become available.
 
'He May Get an Offer'
 What CBS has to offer is access to the 11:30 P.M. time period, which Mr. Letterman, whose NBC show is broadcast at 12:35 A.M., has made a chief priority. In an interview in January, Mr. Letterman said he was getting too old to have a show on that late at night.
Mr. Letterman would probably stand to make the most money if he chose to go into syndication. The syndication executive said, "He may get an offer of $20 million from somebody in syndication and he'd make nothing like that with a network." No one has said what Mr. Letterman earns. Mr. Leno has said he was paid $3 million a year by NBC while Arsenio Hall, whose late-night show for Paramount has been a major hit in syndication, makes $12 million a year.
 
An Improving Relationship
 But syndication also represents more of a risk, as was proved this year when a similar late-night show starring the comedian Dennis Miller failed quickly for the Tribune Entertainment Company. In syndication, a show may not necessarily appear at the same time on all stations, and it is much harder to promote than a network program.
But all the outside parties in the Letterman matter have agreed that NBC still retains some opportunity to re-sign Mr. Letterman. "C.A.A. knows it's just good business to allow NBC a whack at keeping him," a syndication executive said of Mr. Letterman's agents. For one thing, he said, the NBC offer will be a starting point in negotiations for any competitor.
NBC executives said they believed the network's relationship with Mr. Letterman, which they acknowledged was strained for much of the past year, has improved lately, since the arrival of a new producer, Peter Lassaley.
But part of that may reflect an increased commitment by NBC to keeping Mr. Letterman. NBC says it can argue to Mr. Letterman that any options presented by others have pitfalls, from the questionable lineup of stations that can be put together by a syndicator, to ABC's commitment to "Nightline," to the problems CBS might have in making the deals necessary to assure all its affiliates would carry Mr. Letterman's show at 11:30 P.M.
Still, NBC is unable to give Mr. Letterman the 11:30 P.M. slot because it went to Mr. Leno. Mr. Leno's program has experienced some early problems of its own, but no NBC executive has yet suggested that the resolution of the problems with Mr. Letterman will be to reconsider the decision to continue with Mr. Leno as the star.
One senior NBC executive said the network would hold off on negotiating with Mr. Letterman as long as it could. "We want to be best able to assess the entire situation, from ratings to sales to how the economy is looking at that point," he said.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Even Jose's Departure Was Huge

BYLINE: BY GEORGE VECSEY

 BODY:
THOSE of us who were sitting halfway up in the Skydome in 1989 will never forget the moon-launch trajectory of the home run that kept soaring until it finally connected with something solid: the fifth row of the fifth deck. That was the Canseco home run, all 480 rising feet of it.
And nobody who was in the Oakland Coliseum on Monday night will ever forget the mysterious sight of Lance Blankenship suddenly becoming the answer to a trivia question: Who was the pinch-hitter on the night of the Jose Canseco trade? 
 "I was standing in the dugout, just waiting to watch Josie bat," said Bob Welch, the injured Oakland pitcher who knows it is never a good idea to turn your back on a Canseco swing. "All of a sudden, they called him back from the on-deck circle. He was stunned. The whole place was quiet. Everybody was down."
There are a lot of people in baseball, including some in the Oakland clubhouse, who think the A's got the better of the stupendous trade just before the midnight trading deadline. The A's may win a World Series with Ruben Sierra hitting and Bobby Witt and Jeff Russell pitching, but it will always be the Canseco trade.
The most flamboyant star in three World Series, the man who slammed his Porsche into his wife's BMW during a family squabble, the man who hit home runs into the fifth deck of the Skydome, the man who grinned and flexed his muscles when the crowd chanted "Ste-roids! Ste-roids!" was traded. Out of the game. Out of first place. Out of Oakland.
Welch watched his buddy clear out his locker and conduct a news conference, while the game was still on, still in uniform, still in shock. Everybody was in shock.
"It didn't hit me until I was driving back after the game," said Welch, who lives in San Francisco. "I was thinking about how sad Josie must feel, and I got to the toll booth and the guy didn't know who the heck I was, but I said to him, 'Hey, man, the A's just traded Jose Canseco. How do you feel about that?' The guy just said, 'I'm bummed, dude, I'm bummed.' "
The fans are bummed whenever a star is traded. The Red Sox and the Yankees never did pull the trigger on the Williams-for-DiMaggio trade, and the Cardinals never traded Musial, and the Cubs never traded Banks, but the Red Sox sold Babe Ruth because Harry Frazee needed money to finance a Broadway show, and Country Slaughter wept as he took off his St. Louis Cardinals uniform when he was traded in 1954.
The fans were bummed when Connie Mack strip-mined the original Athletics franchise in Philadelphia because he needed the money, and 50 years later the fans were bummed when Charles O. Finley did the very same thing with the franchise in Oakland.
In the old days, the owners had all the hammers, in the form of lifetime control of a player, but nowadays the players have free agency and they deserve it. But it is understandable when the owners unload a player because he might be hard to sign, the way the Mets did to David Cone last week. At least Cone wasn't standing in the on-deck circle when he was traded to Toronto.
Maybe this was a shrewd ploy by the baseball owners to take the focus off their own divided bumbling, as each of them comes up with some personal and petty reason why Fay Vincent isn't being nice to them in his job as commissioner. They will meet in Chicago tomorrow to try to pull their industry together, but in the meantime they have tossed some scraps to the fans.
The Cone trade and the Canseco trade may only be the first rumblings that these jokers are all going to scuttle their high-priced players to avoid being the first major league team to tap out during a season. Given the economy, it's inevitable, like a game of musical chairs. Somebody's going to go down.
Texas was not prepared to pay whatever massive figures Sierra is going to demand at the end of this season. Canseco's moodiness, his leaving a game in the eighth inning recently, the resurgence of Mark McGwire, the healing of Dave Henderson, all made a Canseco trade even thinkable. And the A's need pitching.
"A lot of players get traded," Welch said, speaking for himself and most of his teammates, "but there's only one Josie. Who's going to come out early to watch us stretch? Who's going to come out and scream at us? They came out to the yard to watch Josie."
Baseball players are realists, not fans. Tony La Russa passed the word around the dugout on Monday night that this was a baseball deal, intended to give the A's two more arms in September and October, and the players have great respect for Sierra. But no matter what happens later, the strange doings on Monday night will always be the Canseco trade.

HEADLINE: ON RACING;
2-Year-Olds and Up Had a Fine Summer

BYLINE: By Joseph Durso

 BODY:
If you saw a herd of horses, trainers, riders and grooms driving south along the New York Thruway yesterday, you saw the annual migration from Saratoga Springs back to New York City, where the season will be resumed this afternoon at Belmont Park after five weeks in stately splendor and commercial success under the shade trees upstate. For the next seven weeks, New York will offer you nine races a day six days a week, with 28 stakes and nearly $6 million in purses.
Unfortunately, it can't offer you Saratoga Springs. No knock on the Big Apple or Santa Anita or Arlington or anyplace else. But Jerry Lawrence, general manager of the New York Racing Association, puts it this way: "Saratoga is the most solid race meet in the country, both from a business and esthetic standpoint." 
 The esthetic part is no secret: 30 stakes races in 30 days, star horses from all over the country, everybody gathering in a state-fair mood in the foothills of the Adirondacks a couple of furlongs down Route 9 from the summer homes of the New York City Ballet and the Philadelphia Orchestra.
The business part is no secret either. Twice as many people a day go to the races upstate than downstate. In the last five weeks, Saratoga drew 761,931 customers, a gain of 4 percent over last year, and they bet $103 million, up 3 percent from last year. On an average afternoon, 25,398 people went to the races in Saratoga, and 6,842 more went to Aqueduct in Queens to watch TV monitors and bet on the races 200 miles away. At betting windows across the state, $294 million was chanced on the Saratoga races in the last five weeks.
"In a period of depressed economic activity," Lawrence said before leaving the land of Adirondack opportunity, "Saratoga was not only able to hold its own, but it thrived. People think there's good value for their entertainment dollar. This thing is working."
So, if it's working for five weeks, why not get greedy and go for six?
"When we feel this meet can be expanded," Lawrence said, "we'll expand it. But I don't know when that will be, if ever. You have to look at the supply of horses, the shrinking foal crop, the 600 people who work for us from downstate, the needs of the community, people going back to school. And you have to worry that the daily average might be diluted. My best guess is we'll be back for five weeks next year."
Meanwhile, Belmont will jazz up its fall agenda to compensate for the fact that it's not Saratoga. It starts today with the Grade I Gazelle Handicap for fillies. Mostly, it will cluster some major races into two horse carnivals billed as "super Saturdays." One will be built around the $500,000 Woodward Stakes on Sept. 19; the other will be built around the $850,000 Jockey Club Gold Cup on Oct. 10 and will serve as the prelude to the Breeders' Cup championships at Gulfstream Park in Florida three weeks later.
At least, they're learning. People may not want to spend an entire day commuting to the track to get immersed in a two-minute horse race, but they'll probably show up if you provide a story line. Racing can't court the public with a pennant race, but it can court the public with a horse race that builds toward another horse race. You know, a scenario like the Triple Crown, the American Championship Racing Series or the Breeders' Cup.
Saratoga, for all its upsets, did produce several solid candidates for this year's Breeders' Cup and maybe even for next year's Triple Crown.
The two big races for 2-year-old fillies, the Adirondack and the Spinaway, were won by Georgia E. Hofmann's undefeated Sky Beauty, although she was disqualified for interference and was demoted to third place on Monday in the Spinaway. The two big races for 3-year-old fillies, the Test Stakes and the Alabama, were won by Earle Mack's November Snow. Both fillies are trained by Allen Jerkens, the man who beat Secretariat twice and Kelso three times. The two main races for 3-year-old colts, the Jim Dandy and the Travers, were won in upsets by Konrad Widmer's Thunder Rumble.
The moment of truth of the Saratoga season? That's easy. The moment when Gov. Mario M. Cuomo drove into the track and watched his first live race in New York State in nine years.
It was the $1 million Travers Stakes, and it was won by the New York-bred Thunder Rumble. But the crucial thing was that the horse was cheered on (and apparently wagered on) by the New York-bred Governor, who also expressed his support for racing in the state and implied that he was no longer aiming to dismantle the New York Racing Association.
Jerry Lawrence was asked if the Governor's visit was truly the highlight of the booming Saratoga season. He coughed diplomatically and replied patriotically: "One of the highlights, for sure."

HEADLINE: Plowshares From Russia

 BODY:
What an astonishing turnaround! For four decades Americans have cowered before the threat of nuclear annihilation from the Soviet Union. They have dug fallout shelters and marched to ban the bomb. They shivered at the 1959 movie "On the Beach" that portrayed a doomed species after nuclear war. And they kept on shivering into the 1980's over theories of a devastating "nuclear winter" and film images of "The Day After."
Meanwhile, hoping to head off Armageddon, America built enormous arsenals of atomic weapons that could reach anywhere. And then, when the enemy just kept building bombs, the strategists put their faith in Star Wars, incredible defenses to bat down an atomic blitz. 
 But now, in the wink of a capitalist's eye, comes a better solution. Under a new agreement in principle, the United States will simply buy many of those feared warheads from Russia and convert them to fuel for nuclear reactors. Dreaded nuclear swords will become peaceful nuclear plowshares. Instead of a nuclear firestorm, we will have a nuclear fire sale.
The agreement will not end all risk of a nuclear holocaust. The United States and Russia each retain thousands of nuclear weapons, more than enough to obliterate the globe. Until those arsenals are reduced to a bare minimum, and until the world finds surer ways to protect against renegade or terrorist use, no one can breathe easily.
But the new agreement will reduce the risk that uranium from thousands of weapons Russia has agreed to dismantle will fall into the wrong hands. And it will give that cash-starved republic a needed infusion of hard currency.
Under a contract to be negotiated within a year, the Department of Energy will buy some 500 metric tons of highly enriched uranium from dismantled Russian warheads over 15 to 20 years, at a cost in the low billions. The uranium will be diluted to make commercial reactor fuel.
The Bush Administration is wisely determined to minimize any adverse economic impact. It swears the agreement will not cost anything because the purchases will be offset by reductions in the Energy Department's reactor fuel production. And the impact on uranium miners would be eased by phasing in the new fuel gradually. Even the American nuclear industry seems pleased.
In Russia, the proceeds can boost economic reforms and ease the transition to a market-based economy. The Russian Federation will also spend some to upgrade the safety of its reactors, a threat to nearby nations.
What a wonderful way for America to help Russia, and America -- and the world.

HEADLINE: 6 Counties That Shine In Ratings For Bonds

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
Although fiscal success stories are hard to find in the New York region, they do exist: 6 of the nation's 28 most credit-worthy county governments, for example, are in the suburbs of New York City.
These counties have had sound credit ratings for more than a decade. But experts say their fiscal strength is remarkable now because of the recession, which has been longer and deeper in the New York region than in most of the nation. 
 "There is an institutionalized conservativeness in these counties," said Michael Johnston, a vice president of Moody's Investors Service Inc., which has given its highest rating, Aaa, to the bonds issued by Westchester County in New York and Bergen, Middlesex, Morris, Somerset and Union counties in New Jersey.
"These are mature, well-managed counties that have seen recessions come and go," Mr. Johnston said. "They prepare for them."
They also tend to be rich counties, where tax revenue comes primarily from homeowners rather than from businesses. And they often have governments that have been under the firm control of a single party for many years, thus avoiding the fiscal uncertainty of partisan budget battles.
 
The Westchester Model
 Among all New York-area counties, Westchester fits that mold best, with homes that sell for an average of $325,000, and several enclaves where values exceed $1 million. The county also benefits from taxes paid by more than a dozen large corporate headquarters. Moreover, its Board of Legislators has been in the hands of one party, the Republicans, for two decades.
Westchester has received triple-A ratings from both Moody's and Standard & Poor's since 1971. But Stephen V. Reitano, the county's Commissioner of Finance, said that maintaining the rating had not been simple. Hoping to shift costs to private industry, thus strengthening its own finances, he said, the county turned over its bus system and garbage-burning plant to private companies in the 1980's.
Westchester, with a 1991 budget of $1.1 billion, had a cash surplus of $22 million for that year, he said, up from $17 million in 1990.
Analysts said each of the most fiscally sound counties has maintained cash surpluses -- often building them up in times of economic expansion as an insurance policy against recessions. They also hold borrowing to a minimum.
In Union County, N.J., which has maintained its Aaa rating from Moody's since 1978, officials said they had struggled to maintain a surplus as insurance against unforeseen shortfalls, increasing the county's reserve from $4.5 million in 1990 to $7 million last year.
"The rating agencies expect to see a rainy-day fund, and we've got it," said Ann Baran, the Union County Manager.
 
The Exception
 But in Union, as elsewhere, retaining the highest rating has not been easy during the recession. Among measures Union has taken in the last year are a reduction of 100 county employees, bringing the work force down to 3,100, and an increase in fees for use of its golf course and parks.
Unlike most of the highest-rated counties, Union, which adopted an appointive, county-manager system of government in 1976, has had frequent shifts of control between Republicans and Democrats on its elected Board of Freeholders. But maintaining its Aaa rating has been a consistent priority.
"No one wants to be the one in office when a bond rating is lowered," said Lawrence M. Caroselli, the county's director of finance.
In Morris County, which has maintained its Aaa rating since 1975, officials employ an unusual form of self-policing of their credit standing. To maintain a cash surplus, the county's budget planning process each year deliberately fails to account for interest payments it is assured of receiving on certificates of deposit and other investments, and when the interest checks are received they are deposited in an account set aside as surplus.
Morris County officials said the method was not foolproof. Indeed, because interest rates have plummeted this year, the county's income -- and its surplus -- will be smaller than the $13.1 million it had in the bank at the end of 1991. Glenn Roe, the county's assistant treasurer, estimated that the year-end surplus would be about $8 million, still enough to protect its high credit rating.
 
The Price of Squabbling
 If wealth, stability and conservatism are the keys to a high credit rating, the two counties on Long Island offer lessons in how not to do things. Both are wealthy but have been plagued by political turmoil of late, and both have turned to short-term borrowing to deal with large budget gaps.
Suffolk, for example, has held a Baa1 rating from Moody's and a BBB rating from Standard & Poor's on and off for four years.
Although neither of the rating agencies advise investors not to buy the bonds of any government, Wall Street has traditionally considered a rating of BBB from Standard & Poor's or Baa1 from Moody's to be only slightly above the minimum required to be "investment grade," or reasonably safe.
"Suffolk has historically had a volatile political environment," said Mr. Johnston. He added that the low rating had resulted from periods of fiscal excess, which have left the county without a cash reserve, and the problems faced by the Grumman Corporation, its largest private employer.
Amid much political maneuvering, Suffolk is addressing its budget crisis by raising its sales tax a half percentage point, to 8.5 percent, the maximum allowed by state law, and it is deliberating borrowing $36.5 million to close the 1991 budget gap.
 
The Nassau Nightmare
 The problems in Nassau have been even more stark.
After years of affluence and one-party control of government, by Republicans, a crisis developed last fall when a budget shortfall of more than $100 million loomed in a budget of $1.9 billion. Rather than raise property taxes 24 percent, as proposed by the County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, the county Board of Supervisors opted to make across-the-board budget cuts. But the cuts and related layoffs proved so unpopular that further layoffs were rescinded without any compensating budget cuts or tax increases.
In January, saying Nassau was in "the most serious financial stress in years," Moody's lowered its rating from A1 to A. Now, according to county officials, Nassau may be downgraded again.
"We feel we are fiscally strong, but we are greatly concerned," said Kenneth Cynar, a spokesman for Mr. Gulotta. "The problem is that we are bogged down in political bickering."
In the latest move to solve the county's budget problems, the Board of Supervisors last week authorized $675,000 in short-term borrowing to cover the payrolls of certain departments through Oct. 31. But the vote followed heated partisan debate. Although the measure did not result in a further downgrading of Nassau's credit rating, it clearly made the county more vulnerable.
"The need to develop and implement a long-term restructuring plan and find a less fractious decision-making process remains the principal issue" for Nassau, Moody's said in an advisory to its clients issued last week.

HEADLINE: EATING WELL;
Pollack or Cod? Fish or Foul? F.D.A. Takes a Closer Look

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS

 BODY:
Beluga caviar is selling for $32 an ounce wholesale and lumpfish roe for $1 an ounce, and the Food and Drug Administration says that someone in the New York region is making a pretty penny selling the latter as the former.
The agency said that if it hadn't been for a change in its own policy, the substitutions might have continued undetected for years. In April 1991, the agency's Commissioner, Dr. David A. Kessler, told the board of the National Fisheries Institute that the F.D.A. intended to find and prosecute institute members who substituted less expensive, less desirable species of fish for more valuable ones. His comment received a standing ovation. 
 Although no laws have been changed and no new ones introduced, and even though the F.D.A.'s budget for seafood enforcement has received only a token increase -- around half a million dollars -- there has been a change in the agency's attitude about enforcement. And while that is no substitute for inspection and regulation of seafood safety, the agency's primary mission, its increased enforcment activity against fraud has been noticed by the industry.
When industry members realized that the Commissioner was serious, they began to pass tips to the agency about deceptive industry practices, the beluga substitutions being one of them. Concern among legitimate businesses had been increasing in recent years, because illegal practices had become more widespread.
"We've been asking the F.D.A. to do a more consistent job on economic enforcement since 1985," said Lee Weddig, executive vice president of the National Fisheries Institute, a trade association in Washington for the fishing business.
"What the industry desires," said Tom Billy, the director of the agency's office of seafood, "is a level playing field." Since Dr. Kessler announced his decision, actions taken against deceptive practices in the fish business have increased; in the New York region, for example, the actions have involved more than $1.5 million worth of fish at wholesale in the first 10 months of the 1992 fiscal year, as against $454,000 for all of the 1991 fiscal year.
Even though the F.D.A. is eager to call attention to the new actions, it refused to name companies involved because many claims have not yet been resolved.
More than a decade ago, the agency decided that it didn't have enough money or people to prosecute businesses that sell five ounces of candy as six, colored water as fruit juice, frozen or processed foods as fresh, or frozen water at lobster prices. Since then, it has concentrated almost all its efforts on food safety and left such fraudulent practices to industry self-policing.
Food safety remains the agency's most important job, Dr. Kessler said, but he added that selective actions against deception are sending a message to the food industry that the F.D.A. means business. The agency has earmarked 1 to 2 percent of its $40.5 million seafood inspection budget, which was increased last year, to provide greater resources for finding and prosecuting fraud. The Agriculture Department is responsible for meat and poultry inspection; the F.D.A. for fish.
Some fraudulent practices in the seafood industry involve things like selling a cheaper fish, like Alaskan pollack, for a more expensive one, like cod; overglazing, or adding water to a frozen product and charging fish prices for the frozen water; using sodium tripolyphosphate excessively to make fish retain water, so it is heavier; overbreading shrimp so the bread crumbs will bring shrimp prices; calling cheaper species by names that imply they are more expensive; selling processed or previously frozen fish as fresh, and engaging in the caviar caper.
Consumers can protect themselves against some deceptive practices by becoming more familiar with fish species, but that is not easy. Mary Snyder, chief of the policy guidance branch of the F.D.A.'s Center for Food Safety and Applied Nutrition, compares that task to becoming a wine expert.
Many fish have distinctive characteristics, and people who learn them are more likely to be able to detect the substitution of a cheap species for a more expensive one. But some species are so similar that it takes electronic equipment to tell them apart.
Among the most common substitutions are Pacific rockfish, which normally sells at $2 a pound, for red snapper, at $12 a pound; yellowtail at $2 to $3 a pound for mahi-mahi at $6 to $8; mako shark at $4 to $5 for swordfish at $8; John Dory at $2 for orange roughy at $6; Alaskan pollack at $1 for cod at $3 to $4, and sea bass at $2 to $3 for halibut at $8 to $9.
In the pursuit of this sort of fraud, the F.D.A. has uncovered food safety violations as well.
In July, the Government seized about 6,000 pounds of fish that was labeled cod and pollack but was less expensive species. Much of it was badly decomposed. The company from which the fish was seized freezes and compresses fish into blocks, then cuts it into smaller blocks and sells it to institutions. The seized shipment was headed for the University of Illinois. It was not the first time the company had been charged with substituting species.
Seizure is one of several steps the Government can take when statutes are violated. It can also get injunctions to keep companies from repeating illegal actions, and such injunctions can shut down a company. The most serious action is criminal prosecution, which can result in fines and jail sentences.
The F.D.A. can also send warning letters, and it has sent more than 1,000 about overglazing to seafood dealers. Safeway, the supermarket chain, sent copies of the letter to its suppliers and warned that suppliers who continued the illegal practice would be turned in to the F.D.A. It has made good on its threat, and the F.D.A. is investigating.
The increased F.D.A. enforcement has made a difference, said Mr. Weddig of the National Fisheries Institute. "I have had a very marked reduction in the number of complaints from people in the industry who felt they were being taken advantage of," he added. This shift is particularly true in the scallop industry.
The use of sodium tripolyphosphate in scallops to make them retain water has frequently been abused. The F.D.A. has a temporary policy permitting scallops to be soaked in a bath of the compound for 10 minutes and to absorb an additional 3 percent of their body weight in water. Scallops naturally contain 75 to 79 percent water. If they exceed 80 percent water they can no longer be called scallops; they must be called "scallop product" and the amount of added water must be declared on the label.
Recently in New Bedford, Mass., investigators for the F.D.A. found scallops that had been soaked for three to seven days in a bath so warm that they had decomposed.
Charging shrimp prices for bread crumbs is also common. A Federal standard for frozen breaded shrimp requires the product to contain at least 50 percent shrimp. But no standards exist for other frozen breaded seafood. In 1991, the agency seized $5,000 worth of breaded shrimp that was only 41.4 percent shrimp. The agency has also begun enforcing a regulation prohibiting the sale of heat-processed or previously frozen food as fresh. It is also cracking down on the practice of calling refrigerated caviar "fresh" when, in fact, it is preserved in salt.
Perhaps the most esoteric, and potentially the most costly deception, found by the F.D.A. involves sturgeon roe, the only roe that can be called caviar in the United States. A company that was selling whitefish roe under the name American golden caviar can no longer do so. The agency said it is on the trail of several companies in the New York area that sell lumpfish, catfish and salmon roe as caviar. Salmon and lumpfish roe are worth $1 an ounce; under its own name, catfish roe is worthless. Beluga caviar sells for $32 to $35 an ounce wholesale.
The F.D.A. has hired a zoologist to show that some so-called caviar is, in fact, roe from far less costly sources. The agency's New York district director, Edward Warner, said the substitution was "no accident."
Because the agency does not have the resources to pursue all instances of deception, it is training state and local authorities to do the work, too.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 9, 1992, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
The Eating Well column in The Living Section last Wednesday referred incompletely to Federal policy regulating the use of the word caviar on food labels. Only sturgeon roe can be called simply caviar. The roe of other fish can be labeled caviar only in conjunction with the name of the fish. For example, caviar made from salmon roe can be marketed as "salmon caviar."

HEADLINE: Dartmouth Redesigns Medical Training To Give Future Doctors a Human Touch

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HANOVER, N.H., Aug. 28

 BODY:
Nervous students in surgical gloves and aprons filed into a flourescent-lighted laboratory here and lined up alongside steel tables where cadavers lay ready for dissection.
Instead of feeling pressured to maintain a stoic composure, these first-year medical students were encouraged not to suppress their emotions but to cry, laugh, faint or leave the room if they wanted to. None did, but many said they appreciated the "permission" to do so. 
 "It's an eerie feeling when you walk into a room with 22 dead people," said Annie Tewel, a second-year student who coached the new students through their first day of anatomy class. "We try tell them it's O.K. to feel weird, upset about what they're doing."
 
Community Service
 This more sensitive approach to an age-old medical school tradition is part of a new program at Dartmouth Medical School, intended to inspire future physicians to be more human in their relationships with patients. It includes curriculum changes that will have students spend less time in lectures and labs and more time serving the community.
The catalyst for change at Dartmouth is the former Surgeon General C. Everett Koop. He has returned to his alma mater to create the C. Everett Koop Institute, which will link the medical school to undergraduate pre-med students. Through it, Dr. Koop hopes to produce a "new kind of medical student," one who is dedicated to promoting health and preventing disease and is sensitive to the social and economic circumstances of patients.
"How do you do this?" he asks rhetorically. "By requiring them to teach preventive medicine to someone once a week for four years and to serve as a social advisers to distressed families."
Starting next year, Dartmouth will require its medical students to teach preventive medicine in nearby public schools as assistants to teachers and as instructors to children. Students will also be linked with needy families from the surrounding area whom they will advise on health care as well as on social services.
 
Mentoring Relationship
 Faculty members will serve as the students' mentors, advising on patient care. "This kind of mentoring relationship can make all the difference in training a medical student to be a good clinician," said Dr. Koop, who will head the institute and teach surgery.
Although few medical schools require students to perform community service, Dr. Koop believes such changes are essential if the nation is to have doctors who can better respond to the social and psychological needs of patients.
Many technological advances in the last decade have changed the way doctors practice medicine, Dr. Koop said, but in their preoccupation with learning and using new techniques, some doctors have lost sight of the human side of the doctor-patient relationship.
As Dr. Koop addressed Dartmouth's newest medical students this week, he reminded them: "There was a time when a medical doctor was one of the most respected professions. Today's physician's claim to that respect has dwindled."
To restore that respect, Dr. Koop and others said, medical schools must create a new model for medical education, one that introduces students to patients earlier and combines scientific instruction with practical experience. Several other medical schools are already doing so.
 
'Information Overload'
 Medical students have traditionally spent the first two years of school in lectures and laboratories and the last two years training in a hospital setting.
"Most people feel there is a tremendous information overload during the first two years of medical school," said Dr. Jonas A. Schulman, associate dean of education at Emory University's School of Medicine in Atlanta. "What all of us are trying to do is get students involved with patients early, before they are able to visualize them as diseases."
At Emory and dozens of other schools around the country, students are being introduced to less passive ways of learning. Harvard's "New Pathway" curriculum, introduced in 1985, places students in small groups rather than large lecture halls and encourages them to develop problem-solving skills by studying hypothetical cases.
Stanford University allows students to choose between a traditional track and a self-designed curriculum that can include electives in arts and literature and opportunities to serve as health care advisers in public schools and clinics for the homeless.
"The time is ripe for change because all parties -- students, faculty and public -- agree the system isn't working," Dr. Koop said. "Nobody doubts patients are dissatisfied. Medical faculties realize they are teaching a group of people who are not satisfied with their education. The average medical student feels disappointed, let down by his education."
The key to changing the system, said Dr. John Duffy of Dartmouth, is to excite students about practicing general medicine.
"What we are hoping to do is to expose students to dilemmas of physicians as generalists, but also give them enough time in this setting to learn the rewards," said Dr. Duffy, a former Assistant Surgeon General under Dr. Koop and the medical school's newly appointed assistant dean of admissions.
Dartmouth students will spend the last two years of their medical education working mostly in out-patient settings rather than in hospitals, where patients tend to be very sick and need the care of specialists. Students will also be given opportunities to work alongside generalists in clerkships.
 
Concern Over Specialization
 Dartmouth's emphasis on the work of such generalists -- family doctors, internists and general pediatricians -- comes at a time when many educators are concerned over the trend toward specialization. In the last decade the percentage of young doctors entering primary care specialities dropped by 14 percent, from 37.3 percent in 1981 to 23.6 percent in 1989, according to a survey by the Association of American Medical Colleges.
While most curriculum changes will not be put into effect until next year, Dr. Koop began spreading his message to first-year medical students here this week. It was a message that most students embraced.
"I think he is absolutely right about the need to restore the public's respect for this profession," said Gary Davis, a first-year student who said he came to Dartmouth because of its emphasis on primary care.
"This is a very confusing time in medicine," said Emily Transue, another first-year student. "I chose Dartmouth because it was looking at what the profession ought to be doing.
"I may feel differently next year if I'm afraid of not passing the boards," she said, referring to a series of competency tests that all medical students must pass at the end of their second year before they can go on. "I believe you can pick up technical skills and information you need to know along the way, but you can't just pick up how to have good relationships with patients. You have to know how to build them."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 10, 1992, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sept. 2 about changes in medical school curriculums referred incorrectly to an associate dean of the medical school at Emory University in Atlanta. He is Dr. Jonas A. Shulman.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Beverly Hills' Symbol of 80's Finds Tenant

BYLINE: By Morris Newman

DATELINE: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.

 BODY:
THE sale and leasing of a long-vacant 78,000-square-foot office building has come as a welcome relief for the unaccustomedly soft office market in Beverly Hills. It has also provided a happy ending for a building that spent years in limbo as an asset of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the bailout agency for the savings and loan industry.
The building, the former headquarters of the Columbia Savings and Loan Association on Wilshire Boulevard, had become something of a symbol of both the overconfident 1980's and the chastened 90's. Columbia was a high-flying institution that had invested heavily in the market for high-yield junk bonds in the late 80's. 
 Columbia developed the building, clearly intending it as the company's headquarters, in 1989. Built for $50 million -- a cost of about $640 a square foot -- it was one of the most expensive office buildings of its size ever constructed in the Los Angeles area.
Some of the cost went to the building's architecture, an avant-garde cage covered in marble, granite and copper. Other costs, however, reflected Columbia Savings' extraordinary preoccupation with security. Television cameras scour nearly the whole interior, while certain rooms are reinforced structurally to withstand robbery or even terrorist attack.
It was not terrorists, however, but the failure of the junk-bond market that proved the undoing of Columbia Savings. Like the assets of so many other insolvent savings institutions, the building eventually became the property of the Resolution Trust Corporation.
Last spring, the R.T.C. sold the Columbia Savings building to the Casden Company, a local apartment and office developer based in Beverly Hills, for an undisclosed price, although people close to the transaction indicated the sales price was about $2.5 million -- a fraction of the building's construction cost. The building was built on leased land, reducing its value to an investor.
In June, the new owner leased the entire building for 15 years to International Creative Management Inc., a prominent talent agency formerly based in West Hollywood. The lease agreement is worth $60 million "on a gross rental term basis," according to Alan Casden, chairman of the Casden Company, who described the transaction as "one of the largest leases ever to be done in Beverly Hills -- if not the largest."
The lease of the three-floor former Columbia Savings Building is a significant event in Beverly Hills, which traditionally has been a high-priced office market of small tenants in small, "luxury" office buildings.
Local zoning restricts most new construction to three stories, and few buildings are larger than 100,000 square feet. The typical Beverly Hills tenant is a small professional firm occupying 2,000 to 5,000 square feet, according to Jeff Resnick, a broker with the First Property Realty Corporation of Los Angeles, which represented Casden in lease negotiations.
Historically, vacancy rates generally stayed in the single-digit range. That changed two years ago, when Columbia Savings and the securities firm Drexel Burnham Lambert, two of the city's largest tenants, vacated their buildings and dumped about 200,000 square feet on the market. By July 1991 the Beverly Hills office vacancy rate was 26.2 percent in July 1991, according to the Beverly Hills Chamber of Commerce. Currently, the vacancy rate is 17.3 percent.
International Creative Management's president, James Wiatt, said he chose Beverly Hills after looking for several years in West Hollywood, where the talent agency had been based for 20 years. "At different points, we had looked for property on which to build in West Hollywood," he said, "but there was nothing available.".
Mr. Wiatt added that the unfinished interior made it possible to design the offices to suit the talent agency, which, he said, "made the building an incredibly attractive proposition for us."
International Creative Management is among the entertainment firms that have recently left Hollywood and West Hollywood to relocate in Beverly Hills. Part of that phenomenon reflects the low level of new construction in those areas, coupled with the availability of attractive new office buildings in the city where many entertainment-industry figures live.
Recent entertainment newcomers to Beverly Hills include Playboy Enterprises Inc., United Talent Agency and Inter Talent Agency Inc.
Irving Azoff, chairman of Giant Records Inc., bought a 32,396-square-foot building on Wilshire Boulevard to house his company, a building also previously owned by Columbia Savings.
The recent spate of entertainment-related leases has not put the Beverly Hills market back on entirely solid ground, however, in light of the continued economic troubles both in California and nationally, according to Mr. Resnick, the office broker.
"I was talking to a landlord who has one million square feet in the city, who told me that one-third of his tenants are in trouble," he said.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE STORM;
Normal Economic Existence Is Years Away in Storm Area

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOMESTEAD, Fla., Sept. 2

 BODY:
Despite the vast scale of Federal aid to hurricane victims that President Bush has announced, southern Dade County will take years to rebuild the houses and businesses it needs, say economists, business owners and local officials.
The President, who visited here on Tuesday, took a large first step toward reviving the local economy when he pledged to reconstruct one of its sturdiest props, Homestead Air Force Base, which employed almost 5,000 military personnel. Most roads have been cleared of debris, though not of horrendous traffic, and the battered telephone, electricity and water systems are expected to be strung back together in weeks or a couple of months. 
 But there is much more to the economy here than roads and the military. The homes, shopping strips, farms, offices and all the other places where people live and work are today nothing more than gruel for a front-end loader. The day when the 355,000 people in the disaster zone do regular jobs, shop in regular stores, watch television under a leak-proof roof in a home with a front lawn is a long time off.
 
No Trees; Few Stores
 For example, the area's agricultural base, a source of much money and many jobs, is in ruins. South Dade County had the nation's main concentration of lime groves and produced much of the country's avocados and ornamental house plants. But today the fields west of Homestead, Princeton and Goulds contain little more than broken sticks. While new lime trees can be planted tomorrow, it will take five to eight years before they produce as much fruit as they used to. For avocado trees it will be even longer.
Then there are the stores. Along a 20-mile stretch of U.S. 1, the main business corridor, about 1 store in 50 is open. The vast majority are destroyed or heavily damaged; others that are structurally sound cannot do business because they have no electrical power or because their owners and employees have lost their homes and must now concentrate on finding shelter.
Further, just as customers need stores, stores need customers, and it is hard to see where the people here will get much disposable income to shop with for some time to come. All at once, tens of thousands of people have lost both jobs and houses, and now they are essentially living as Federal welfare recipients.
"We're looking at two, three years to get any kind of normalcy," said the Vice Mayor of Homestead, Ruth Campbell.
Olin P. Wright, a Homestead Councilman, predicted: "Sixty days for necessities. Five years to bring the city back to where it was."
No one knows how the businesses that sustained the communities will respond to what is being called the nation's costliest natural disaster. A few new businesses -- primarily builders and merchants of motor homes that banks and insurance companies can use as mobile offices -- are pouring into the area because it is clear that their products will be needed. But some owners of long-established businesses are talking about leaving for good.
 
The Question of Rebuilding
 Dr. Robert Faine and Curtis Gardner stood recently in the parking lot of the Campbell Square shopping center, where they both had businesses, across from Homestead City Hall. Dr. Faine, a dentist who has practiced here for 21 years, lost his office to the storm, and while he would like to open another, he wonders how long it will be before he sees any but the most desperate patients.
"Do you think that any of these people are going to think about anything that isn't essential for the next year or two?" he asked. "But I've got no place to go. I'm going to try to reopen."
Mr. Gardner owned the Sonny's Real Pit Bar-B-Q restaurant and had 35 employees. The building stands, but its interior is a windswept ruin.
"I lease the premises," Mr. Gardner said. "But what is the lessor going to do? What's the person who owns the square going to do? Why not take what insurance money he can get and get out of Dodge?"
 
Ready to Move Away
 Just southwest of Homestead, in Florida City, the Starvin' Marvin convenience store reopened last Thursday. "We don't know if we'll stay open," said Khalid Hafeez, district manager for the chain. "We are going with the flow of the city of Homestead. Look around now and it's total devastation." He said six of his nine employees there had already quit and moved away.
Anna and Gary McKeehen are waiting for a Federal disaster check so they can move away, too. They had just finished paying off their mobile home, and they had cancelled the insurance policy that the lender had made them take.
Mrs. McKeehen worked in the women's clothing department of a Kmart. "The roof caved in and they lost everything there," she said.
Mr. McKeehen was a landscaper. Now the lawns are too cluttered with junk to groom, and, in any event, he has little left to groom them with.
"I had a utility shed," he said. "I had two mowers, one tractor, two Weed-eaters and two chain saws." After looters came through, he had only one Weed-eater and one mower.
The McKeehens, now living with Mr. McKeehen's father in North Miami, are talking about moving to Tennessee.
 
12 Years of Work -- Gone
 Tom and Carolyn Caldwell, who own an ornamental-plant nursery in Goulds, said that they had too large an investment to move but that it would be many years before they could restore a business it took them 12 years to build.
They had 5,000 anthuriums, a lush green flowering plant, and all were ruined. Mr. Caldwell said that even if he started today it would take 18 months for new anthuriums to grow large enough to sell.
Of tens of thousands of other plants, the Caldwells salvaged only a few Chinese fan palms. "I can never get back to where I was," Mr. Caldwell said.
Stephen Morrell, a former chief economist for Southeast Bank who is now an economics professor at Barry University in Miami Shores, equates the destruction here with that of bombed Japan and Germany in World War II. "Here in Dade County you had a reasonable similar occurrence without the bombs," he said.
The analogy could also apply to the recovery of south Dade County. "Clearly, they recovered, and you have to ask why," Mr. Morrell said. "The talent and skill and dedication of the people had a lot to do with it."
So did foreign aid, which is unlikely to be forthcoming for Dade County, though the Emir of Kuwait today announced a gift of $10 million to help both South Florida and the riot recovery in Los Angeles.
Further, the commitments of prime movers of the economies -- the governments and the banking systems -- were also crucial after World War II.
The Bush Administration, in the person of the President, has signaled such a commitment. On Tuesday, he announced an array of aid measures, including a pledge to have the Federal Government pay virtually all the costs of rebuilding public property and services instead of making the state pay 25 percent, as is customary.
In addition, Florida's big banks, in part to hold onto their big customer base in the county, seem prepared to bend some rules to help the economy. But no one knows whether local lenders alone can finance the replacement of so much that has been destroyed.
"I think you will see an increase in lending," said Buell G. Duncan, chairman of Sun Banks Inc. of Florida. "We're going to be making our own customers some loans you normally wouldn't make. We have an obligation to them. We're all in this together."
 
Buds of Economic Growth
 No one expects economic activity to dry up here. A temporary economy is already taking shape. The pick-up truck peddlers of tar paper and plywood came first; then came the peddlers of generators.
Now other businesses are gearing up. Tim Arb, a Coachmen Industries consultant helping out at Camptown R. V. Country Inc. on U.S. 1, said only 4 of dealership's 100 vehicles, costing $3,000 to $60,000 each, survived the storm. But Coachmen has already shipped 50 new vehicles to Camptown, and Mr. Arb said 200 more were on the way for businesses to use as temporary shops.
Plenty of people are finding work here, though not the same people -- the clerks and Hispanic farm workers -- who made up much of the pre-storm economy. Electricians, plumbers, carpenters and cabinet makers, many of whom had been laid off in Florida's recession-battered economy, are pouring into the region.
In Florida City, Mike Cook, a regional manager for Anheuser-Busch Companies Inc., is repairing his roof himself, but inside the house there is much more work needed, and he has hired Jerry Hale, a general contractor from Illinois, to do it. Mr. Hale, who had no place to stay when he came down on Friday, has pitched a tent on Mr. Cook's lawn.
"I booked $50,000 in work the first day," Mr. Hale said. "I've got 16 guys coming down from Illinois. From my experience, you're looking at three years of rebuilding here."
In the end, the strength of this area's recovery lies in the hopes of the people, and some here have still have plenty. George Cooper lost a popular restaurant and food market in Princeton. Next door on one side is an irrigation-supply dealership that lost his roof, Mr. Cooper said of the dealer, "He was open for business six hours after the hurricane."
Mr. Cooper has has reopened his own business, too, using one tent for a kitchen and another for the eating area.
"This place, in two or three years, you won't be able to recognize it," he said. "That was the first hurricane since 1965. We've got the best weather in the world November through April. In New York, you have bad weather every year."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
In Election Year, Politics Greases Arms Decisions

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2

 BODY:
The sale of F-16's to Taiwan announced by President Bush today is the latest in a series of arms decisions that experts say appear to be based as much on political considerations as on military ones.
In trying to fend off Congressional pork-barrel programs, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has argued that the Pentagon is not a social welfare agency and that decisions on new weapons program and arms sales should be made strictly on national security grounds. 
 But recently there have been a number of developments suggesting that economic and electoral factors figure in the Administration's decision-making. Even when the Administration has yielded to the will of the Congress it has sought a way to capitalize politically.
 
Reversal on Tanks
 On Friday, Vice President Dan Quayle announced during a trip to Michigan, where he visited employees at a tank plant, that the Pentagon would spend $250 million to begin work on upgrading the Army's M-1 tanks. Mr. Cheney and his top civilian aides had previously argued that the end of the Cold War had made the upgrade unnecessary and had refused to spend the money Congress had appropriated for this purpose.
The White House pledged on Tuesday to spend hundreds of millions of dollars to rebuild Homestead Air Force Base, which was a candidate for closing before it was devastated by Hurricane Andrew. Though Mr. Cheney argued there was a military rationale for the rebuilding, he acknowledged today in a television interview today on Cable News Network that concern for the economy of South Florida was a major consideration.
The likelihood of a $5 billion sale of 72 F-15's to Saudi Arabia also has potential benefits in Missouri, Connecticut and California. Mr. Cheney argued for the sale today, asserting that the move would strengthen ties with the Saudis. But the Bush Administration has been under intense pressure from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, which is based in St. Louis, and Missouri lawmakers to sell the planes so that the aircraft company can keep open its production line.
In all cases, Administration officials insist that the decisions are, as Mr. Cheney has put it, "consistent" with American national security interests. But they do not deny that the moves have important political benefits for the Administration.
Representative Les Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat who chairs the House Armed Services Committee and who has been mentioned as a possible Defense Secretary in a Clinton Administration, was less charitable.
He told reporters that the sale of planes to Taiwan was driven by politics and that the decision to rebuild Homestead was "bad stuff" since the base had been a candidate for closure.
"He's got himself stuck by being slow on the response" to the hurricane, Mr. Aspin said of President Bush. "He is now overcompensating by talking about rebuilding Homestead."
The Administration's recent decision to upgrade the M-1 tanks illustrates the White House skill at taking credit for a move it has previously opposed. For years, lawmakers from Michigan and other Middle West states put money in the Pentagon budget for the upgrade of the tanks. But Mr. Cheney refused to spend it, arguing that the Pentagon could better use shrinking budget elsewhere. And when Congress appropriated the money anyway, he refused to spend it.
Earlier this year, the Bush Administration proposed that Congressionally appropriated funds for the tank upgrade be "rescinded," the procedure the Defense Department uses to avoid spending money that lawmakers tell them to spend. Congress refused to go along.
On Friday Mr. Quayle announced the decision to spend $250 million during a visit to a General Dynamics plant in Warren, Mich. The sum is only a down payment on the multibillion-dollar program that would be required to carry out the tank upgrade, which would involve fitting the tanks with new guns and electronic systems. "This should be welcome news to the Warren tank facility," Mr. Quayle said.
Though they have gone along with the decision to spend the $250 million, Mr. Cheney and top civilians are believed to still oppose the tank upgrade program. But now that Mr. Quayle's has given it such a strong endorsement, it will be more difficult for the Pentagon political leadership to block it.
Senator Carl Levin, a Michigan Democrat who has led the effort to get the Pentagon to upgrade the M-1 tanks, welcomed the decision, but objected to Mr. Quayle's spin.
"This is exactly the opposite of what they have been saying for the past three years," Senator Levin said.

HEADLINE: As Quake Wreaks Havoc, Chamorro Appeals to U.S.

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Sept. 2

 BODY:
A natural disaster added to the pressures facing President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro today as she struggled to deal with demands from Washington that she rid her Government of the influence of the opposition Sandinista Front.
On Tuesday night, giant waves set off by an earthquake lashed most of the Nicaraguan coast. Estimates of the disaster's toll, given today as 40 or more, were significantly increased late tonight. The Civil Defense chief, Lieut. Guillermo Guevara, was quoted in news agency reports as saying there were about 100 dead, 150 missing, 4,200 evacuated and 16,000 homeless. 
 Mrs. Chamorro had expressed intense frustration. In a radio broadcast soon after the disaster, she pleaded for the United States to restore its financial aid to Nicaragua, calling for an end "to problems and restraints" by "those who have had a commitment to our people."
The huge waves, called tsunamis and popularly known as tidal waves, were set off by an earthquake measuring 7.1 on the Richter scale with its epicenter about 35 miles off the Pacific coast. The waves, estimated at 20 to 30 feet high, struck the coast from the port of Corinto in the north to San Juan del Sur on the Costa Rican border.
The damage took place in an area several hundred yards wide along several hundred miles of shoreline, including fishermen's homes and boats, and some small hotels.
 
Swept Out of Their Homes
 Most of the victims were swept out of their homes and yards by the huge waves.
The Bush Administration had held up the $104 million in aid to Nicaragua remaining for this fiscal year last spring at the request of Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, who has complained of continued Sandinista power, especially in the army and the police, and the delays in return of property confiscated by the Sandinistas when they ruled the country from 1979 until 1990, when they were defeated in elections by a center-right coalition headed by Mrs. Chamorro.
She retained several senior Sandinista security officials, including the army commander, Gen. Humberto Ortega Saavedra.
Officials of the new leadership described the policy as an effort to forge a government of national unity and heal the wounds of the Nicaraguan civil war, but not the least of their calculations was the fear that without concessions the Sandinistas would not allow Mrs. Chamorro to take office. Whatever the reason, the armed forces and police have remained Sandinista strongholds.
The continued presence of Sandinistas in top posts has angered many of Mrs. Chamorro's supporters, and the State Department, after long supporting the Chamorro Government in public while criticizing it in private, has recently begun to say openly that it shares Mr. Helms's concerns. It announced on Tuesday that it was sending a delegation to Nicaragua today to discuss the issues raised by Mr. Helms, a conservative Reoublican.
Mrs. Chamorro recently had begun a series of moves that seemed to be aimed at meeting at least some of the criticisms from her own right wing and the United States, which organized and financed the contra rebellion against the Sandinistas during the Reagan Administration.
They included plans to announce the replacement of the police chief, Rene Vivas, a Sandinista often accused of using repressive tactics against former contras and of not obeying the Chamorro Government on matters like protecting property rights.
But on Tuesday, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, the Sandinista leader who lost the presidency to Mrs. Chamorro, said the Sandinista Front did not intend to allow the Government to replace Mr. Vivas. Mr. Ortega, the army commander's brother, suggested that if Mrs. Chamorro gave in to American pressure, the people would demand that she step aside. He denied that he was threatening a coup.
The money that Mrs. Chamorro wants released is the unused part of a $731 million, two-year aid package. The Government feels it must get the money soon to protect its currency-stabilization program.
In a further effort to resolve some of the issues linked to the aid cutoff, Mrs. Chamorro's chief minister and son-in-law, Antonio Lacayo, announced this week that the Government was working on a plan to indemnify owners of property confiscated in the Sandinista era without cause but which cannot now be returned to the original owners.
This would include property that is in the hands of third parties, including peasant cooperatives set up under the Sandinista land redistribution program. It would also include many urban tracts that the Sandinistas gave or sold cheaply to their followers.
Mr. Lacayo said that one method being considered to compensate those owners was giving them shares in state companies scheduled for privatization.
 
Corruption Is Charged
 The State Department decided to take a more public position of criticism toward the Chamorro policies after the release of a long report on Nicaragua prepared by Deborah De Moss, an aide to Mr. Helms, on behalf of the Republican staff of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
It urges, among other things, that aid to Nicaragua not be resumed until properties of several hundred Nicaraguans who became United States citizens are returned to them.
It complains of General Ortega's continued command of the army; contends corruption, some of it involving American aid, is "rampant," and charges that there has been a campaign to assassinate former contras.

HEADLINE: Late Buying Sends Dow Up 24.05, to 3,290.31

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks rose sharply yesterday after a late surge of buying in transportation, medical and retailing stocks helped to break the market's summer lull.
The stock market was also buoyed by further gains in bond prices and a steadier dollar. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average gained 24.05 points to close at 3,290.31. Advancing issues led declining ones, 1,110 to 617, on the New York Stock Exchange, while volume rose to 187.5 million shares, from 174.4 million on Tuesday.
Chartists noted that the stock market tended to rise a few days before the Labor Day weekend. And traders said yesterday's market action suggested that investors might be expecting a resumption of economic growth, even though few recent statistics pointed to a strong rebound.
"There's the feeling the economy may be bottoming out," said Paul Hennessey, a vice president in trading at the Boston Company.
The August employment report, due tomorrow, may set the tone for investors' perceptions. So far, "it still feels as if momentum is slowing," said Ron Hill, investment strategist at Brown Brothers Harriman.
After a surge led by airline stocks Tuesday, the Dow Jones transportation index posted another steep rise of nearly 30 points. Gains in that index usually bode well for the market.
"Transports are cyclical," said David Bostian of Herzog Heine & Geduld. "In general, there's the perception that maybe the economy will build strength."
The Dow Jones industrial average traded in a 10-point range through early afternoon, then began to tick up steadily until the closing bell.
Mr. Bostian said some buyers might be encouraged because "the market is not buckling." In addition, the steadier dollar could give the Federal Reserve room to lower interest rates again, he said.
 
Gains by Airlines
 Within the transportation group, AMR, the parent of American Airlines, rose 2 1/4, to 59 5/8, while British Airways gained 2 1/4, to 47 1/2. American President added 1 1/2, to 42 3/4, and Yellow Freight gained 1, to 26 1/2.
Retail stocks rose on traders' expectations of strong gains when they report monthly sales figures today. The Limited rose 1 1/4, to 23 3/4; Merry-Go-Round Enterprises gained 1, to 13, and the Gap was up 1 1/2, to 35 5/8.
In the medical sector, Critical Care America rose 2 3/8, to 38, while Medical Care International was up 2 7/8, to 52 1/4. And Oxford Health Plans added 1 1/2, to 30 3/4. It said that enrollment in its health plans passed the 100,000 mark on Aug. 1 and that the pace of growth could be sustained.
Still, United States Surgical lost 2 1/2, to 73 1/2, after Johnson & Johnson, the parent of Ethicon, a competitor, said it would announce a significant development in endoscopic surgery.
CBS rose 2 7/8, to 200. Smith Barney upgraded its recommendation to buy from hold on the stock.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 1.91 points, to 417.98, while the Big Board's composite index gained 0.99, to 230.01. Among secondary issues, the American Stock Exchange index was up 1.29, to 382.73, and the Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter stocks gained 5.64, to 571.25.

HEADLINE: No Inquiry On Neil Bush

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2

 BODY:
The Justice Department has let a 15-day deadline pass without filing a formal notice of a preliminary investigation of Neil Bush's role in a Colorado banking scandal, according to an order entered by a Federal court.
The three-judge court, which is responsible for the appointment of independent counsels, issued the order in response to a request by Frank Mandanici, a lawyer in New Haven whose late father was the mayor of Bridgeport from 1975 to 1981. 
 Mr. Mandanici asked Attorney General William Barr in July for an investigation by an independent counsel of possible crimes by the President's son in the collapse of the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association, in Denver.
Mr. Mandanici's older brother, John, was convicted of making false statements in an investigation in 1983, and he said his goal was to see that the son of a Republican President gets the same treatment as the son of a Democratic mayor. The law gives the Attorney General 15 days after receiving such a request to decide whether the facts warrant a preliminary investigation.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE STORM;
Money, and Gripes, in Loan Program

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS

 BODY:
When a natural disaster strikes, many businessmen and uninsured homeowners turn to the Federal Government for help in rebuilding, and in the 39 years of its existence the Government's main disaster loan program has distributed more than $15 billion.
Along with that record of accomplishment, however, is red tape that frustrates many applicants and and an overall loss rate of 9 percent. 
 Hurricane Andrew's destructive path through Florida and Louisiana is expected to generate $500 million to $700 million in disaster loan applications, according to estimates by officials of the Small Business Administration, which runs the loan program. A spokesman for the agency said that it had loan officers at 16 temporary disaster assistance centers in Florida and five in Louisiana and that they had issued almost 4,500 loan applications.
"We will be handing out checks for our first loans in Florida on Thursday," said Patricia Saiki, administrator of the Small Business Administration, responding to criticism that the Bush Administration's response to the disaster had dangerously lagged.
While the Federal Emergency Management Agency coordinates immediate relief efforts from clearing debris to providing food and shelter and emergency money grants to needy families, the disaster loans are the main direct Federal assistance to businesses seeking to rebuild and to homeowners seeking to replace uninsured personal property and cover the uninsured costs of rebuilding their homes.
 
$40 Million for Temporary Help
 Ms. Saiki said the agency was expecting to spend $40 million to keep 600 special temporary employees on the job reviewing loan requests in south Florida and Louisiana for up to six months.
Terry McKelvey, who lost both his restaurant and home when Hurricane Hugo struck Sullivans Island, S.C., in 1989, had nothing but praise for the help the disaster loan program gave him and his wife in rebuilding their home. But he was less than pleased about the volume of paperwork and the criteria he faced when trying to borrow to rebuild his restaurant.
"It was very frustrating because they seemed to be offering us an opportunity to get back on our feet with low-interest loans, but they wound up telling us we didn't have the cash flow to handle a loan," he said, referring to the rejected loan for the restaurant. "If we could have gotten our business going again, we would have had the cash flow. But they didn't see it that way. I think they were so afraid of fraud that they just labeled us as people out to take something."
Agency officials said the program approved loans only for those whose applications show "a reasonable ability to repay." The disaster loan program has an estimated 9 percent rate of loss over its lifetime, including loans that Congress has voted to forgive.
"We understand that we run a risky loan program," said Bernard Kulik, the Small Business Administration's assistant administrator for disaster assistance. "For one thing, we don't take collateral for our loans, and we base them on cash flow."
What has happened over the years, Mr. Kulik and other Federal officials said, is that Congress has voted to wipe out all or part of outstanding disaster loan balances. It happened after Hurricanes Betsy in 1965 and Camille in 1969, for example. The largest total forgiveness, and the last one, came months after Hurricane Agnes in 1972, when Congress voted to forgive what amounted to $478 million out of $1.02 billion in loans.
Discounting the forgiven loans, the loss rate for disaster loans would be about the same as those on other loan programs of the Small Business Administration, just under 2.5 percent annually, said a spokesman for the agency, Mike Stamler.
The Small Business Administration Disaster Loan Program, created in 1953, is the primary form of Federal disaster loan assistance to individuals and businesses outside of farming, though the Federal Emergency Management Agency's grant program is larger by far. According to a General Accounting Office study, F.E.M.A. spent $2.1 billion in helping victims of both Hurricane Hugo and the Loma Prieta earthquake in California in 1989 while the S.B.A. program gave out $1.3 billion in loans in those disasters.
The loans cover only uninsured losses with a limit of $20,000 for personal property, $100,000 for homes and $500,000 for businesses. The program also provides businesses with loans of up to $500,000 to offset the "economic injury" from slumping sales resulting from a disaster.
The terms and interest rates vary, extending up to 30 years and going as low as 4 percent for homeowners and business owners who are unable to get credit elsewhere. Homeowners with other sources of credit pay 8 percent interest and businesses pay 6 percent. At present, about 80 percent of the program's 141,000 outstanding loans are to homeowners for home repairs and rebuilding, Mr. Kulik said. But in dollar value, the $3.2 billion loan portfolio is split about evenly between homeowners and businesses.
So far this year, the program's average loan for home rebuilding is $23,000 and its average loan to businesses is $57,400.
The program's past is littered with stories of abuses growing out of the pressure for quick loans after a disaster. There have also been many occasions of lax internal controls and of the frequent need to use temporary employees to process applications.
Controls have been strengthened in recent years, but that has prompted many officials, like Mayor Joseph Riley of Charleston, S.C., to assert that the paperwork and fine print make it difficult for "mom and pop businesses" to take advantage of the program.
Mr. Kulik defended the policy, saying, "Some expect the Government to do whatever it takes to make them whole again."
