HEADLINE: A Jail Garden's Harvest: Hope and Redemption

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 2

 BODY:
The leeks, raspberries, swiss chard and rose fir potatoes that Cathrine Sneed and her inmate gardeners coax from the soil are not merely fruits and vegetables.
Rather they are metaphors for what went wrong in a prisoner's troubled past, lessons about how to live a healthy and honorable life, and proof that love and work make a garden flourish. 
 A 12-acre farm at a jail south of here in San Bruno and a half-acre strip of land behind a bakery at the tattered edges of San Francisco are Ms. Sneed's classrooms.
At the farm, the 37-year-old Ms. Sneed combines her careers as prison counselor and horticulturist by teaching gardening to county inmates, most of them serving four-to-six-month sentences for drug offenses. At the garden, she offers recently released prisoners a way to avoid the hazards of the street, to earn a little money and to continue planting, growing and harvesting.
A product of the hard streets who ran away from a troubled New Jersey family of 14 children, Ms. Sneed avoids the pieties that so often permeate jail-house rehabilitation. There is no need to preach about hope and redemption, she says; the vegetables, fruits and flowers preach for her.
 
Nature's Quiet Lessons
 First, there is the peace of a garden, so still that one can hear the butterflies. Long before they discover the therapeutic value of weeding and planting, she said, the prisoners delight in being away from the clatter of jail.
The simple process of weeding is a good place to start re-examining a life gone wrong. The weeds are whatever got in the way: smoking crack or whoring or stealing. Once they are gone, no longer leaching water and nutrients from all that grows around them, the vegetables and fruits thrive.
And what could offer a clearer message than cutting away old leaves and flowers so there is room for fresh growth?
"I take these big, giant crack dealers and show them the roses we've cut back," Ms. Sneed said. "And they say, 'These ain't no roses; these are dead sticks.' " So I say: 'You watch these dead sticks. They're just like you; get rid of the dead stuff and the new stuff will grow.' "
 
Helping Is Healing
 Less metaphysical lessons await the harvest. Produce from the prison garden, where more than 150 male and female inmates work each day, is donated to soup kitchens and AIDS pantries.
"They're here because they hurt people," Ms. Sneed said of her jail-house gardeners. "Now they have a chance to help. That's part of the healing."
The city garden was the brainchild of Elliot Hoffman, the founder and president of the Just Desserts bakery chain, a $15-million-a-year business. The garden's produce is sold, thus introducing the newly-released inmates to the rewards of commerce.
Mr. Hoffman was the garden's first client, buying fruit for his tarts and muffins, and rosemary for the bread baked at Tassajara, an independent bakery that Just Deserts recently purchased. Chez Panisse, Berkeley's temple of California cuisine, was Ms. Sneed's second client. Between them, Just Desserts and Chez Panisse buy about $100 worth of produce a week from Ms. Sneed's garden.
 
Inspiration in the Land
 The city garden, a recent addition to Ms. Sneed's horticulture program, came into being serendipitously.
The jail farm began in 1983, after Ms. Sneed read "The Grapes of Wrath," John Steinbeck's tale of itinerant California farm workers, while recuperating from a life-threatening kidney disease. She persuaded her boss, Sheriff Michael Hennessy, that inmates would find inspiration in the land.
The sheriff, her longtime mentor and friend, was an unconventional administrator. He also feared that Ms. Sneed was dying, and that if the garden was her last wish, he had no choice but to grant it.
As Ms. Sneed recovered, her horticulture program flourished. She saw mean, lazy inmates change before her eyes. Men and women who at first could not focus for more than a few minutes on weeding a strawberry patch soon lingered at the end of the day, unwilling to abandon a project that wasn't finished.
While learning about work, the inmates also learned about hope, but that lesson proved a cruel joke once they were released, with nowhere to go but the same streets that had already been their downfall.
"I could help get them some clothes, maybe a little job," Ms. Sneed said. "I could find out what the pimp had done with their babies. But I was not impacting their lives. When they went back to the world, they were squashed like bugs."
Enter Mr. Hoffman. Invited to tour the jail one day last year, he was impressed by the garden, but even more impressed by the intensity of the counselor who ran it.
Ms. Sneed was hoping to sweet-talk Mr. Hoffman out of some extra money for her jail garden, which operates on a shoestring of county funds and donations. But he started talking about this garbage-strewn lot behind his bakery. "Yeah, yeah," Ms. Sneed remembers muttering. "What I need is a check."
But she soon saw what he had in mind: sort of a halfway house for recently released jail-house gardeners. It took four months to clean the lot and find donated plants and tools. Then Ms. Sneed planted a garden and encouraged her graduates to come and work.
The garden's sales are barely enough to pay expenses, but by hounding foundations and local businesses for grant money, some months Ms. Sneed is able to pay the 40-odd gardeners as much as $60 for a 20-hour workweek. And even when the grant money runs out, as it did recently, they come around anyway, for the sunshine, the feel of dirt under their fingernails, the company of others who are struggling to stay sober, safe and out of jail.
Mr. Hoffman has made the ex-convicts welcome. They bring their children to play in the dirt or watch the bakers knead dough. They use the bathrooms and help themselves to day-old bread and cake, which is often the mainstay of their diets.
Some of the men and women at the garden have wound up employed at the bakery, although Ms. Sneed and Mr. Hoffman note that it is unrealistic to think that most of them are ready for mainstream work. Mr. Hoffman said that the first two ex-inmates he hired as bakers were chronically late or absent and had to be dismissed. But they continue to hang out at the garden, have not wound up back in jail and have not been destructive to others.
"We call them the strawberry men," Mr. Hoffman said. "They will never hold down a regular job, but they are productive in a special environment."
The very best of Ms. Sneed's gardeners are getting salaried jobs these days, thanks to a joint venture between the San Francisco County Sheriff's office and the city's Department of Public Works. For 10 weeks, as part of a demonstration project, eight of the former inmates were paid $8 an hour to plant 650 trees around the city. The city was happy with the work, and last month it agreed to hire 10 tree planters for three years.
Recently, as she drove from the city garden to the jail farm, Ms. Sneed detoured past a housing project here, its walls scarred with graffiti and its courtyards crowded with unemployed men and women, up to no good and about out of hope. This is one of the places Ms. Sneed had sent the members of her Tree Corps to plant saplings, and she wondered whether the young trees would survive the vandalism that is endemic here.
The trees looked fine this bright morning, and Ms. Sneed marveled that there seemed to be less litter than usual on the curb strips. That could be wishful thinking, she said, but what of it?
"I want them planting these trees not just because it's a job," Ms. Sneed said, "but because it is something that will last, that gives hope to other people. Instead of being a crack dealer, you can be a tree planter. That is the message my students have to communicate."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Cathrine Sneed, center, worked last month in a garden on Carroll Street in San Francisco with former inmates of the county jail. The garden program she runs offers recently released prisoners new skills and alternatives to the temptations of life on the streets. (Terrence McCarthy for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. Cooling Toward Sandinistas' Successors

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2

 BODY:
Nicaragua's relations with Washington have badly deteriorated over accusations that President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro has ceded too much authority to the leftist Sandinista Front.
A little more than a year ago, President Bush welcomed Mrs. Chamorro to the White House with promises of loans and trade concessions. But today, as Managua attempted to deal with a powerful earthquake unleashing giant waves that smothered several towns on the Pacific coast, Washington's preliminary offer of $25,000 worth of tents, water and food was viewed by Nicaraguan officials as inadequate. 
 Without fanfare, the Administration in June simply stopped spending the last $104 million of a two-year $731-million aid package for Nicaragua, and on Tuesday the State Department reversed its policy of publicly praising the Chamorro Government. Richard Boucher, the State Department spokesman, condemned Managua for failing to prosecute those responsible for the reported killings of former members of the contra army that fought to overthrow the Sandinistas with United States support in the 1980's.
The State Department's criticism came in response to a Senate report written by an aide to Senator Jesse A. Helms of North Carolina, alleging that Mrs. Chamorro was a figurehead manipulated by the Sandinistas.
The 144-page report alleged that the Chamorro Government has failed to return tens of thousands of homes confiscated by the Sandinistas and broken its promise to protect contras who laid down their arms. It also assembled a list of 217 former contras who have been assassinated since Mrs. Chamorro took office.
Seeking to avert problems with Mr. Helms and highlight its agreement with many of the report's conclusions, the State Department sent a delegation to Managua today led by Deputy Assistant Secretary of State John F. Maisto to demonstrate unhappiness with Mrs. Chamorro's policies.
Mr. Boucher said today that the Administration would be willing to grant more aid, depending on Nicaragua's needs. He added that the Maisto delegation would discuss with Nicaraguan authorities "strengthening democracy, human rights and the rule of law, professionalizing the security forces, returning confiscated properties or compensating rightful owners, and economic growth and development."
Ernesto Palazio, Managua's Ambassador to the United States, voiced little enthusiasm for Washington's response to the disaster. "We need more support," he said. "Certainly we expect our friends to come to Nicaragua's aid now that we face this new tragedy."
Representative Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey, chairman of the House Subcommittee on Western Hemisphere affairs, called the initial American aid response "ridiculous."
"Its become an outrageous situation," he said. "The Administration appears to like the theory of national reconcilation more than the practical reality."

NEW YORK CITY
 
HOMELESS, ADDICTED AND MENTALLY ILL
At first, Larry Hogue was just another shambling homeless man on the Upper West Side, but over the years his behavior became more bizarre. He vandalized cars, heaved rocks through the stained glass windows of a landmark church and knocked a schoolgirl in front of a truck. Mr. Hogue is among the growing ranks of mentally ill people who are also addicted to drugs, and his collision with the Upper West Side has offered a detailed look at the failure of the mental health system to help people like Mr. Hogue or protect the public from their depredations. As city officials and experts differed over the potential hazards of high lead concentrations in soil near the Brooklyn, Manhattan and Williamsburg bridges, Mayor Dinkins announced yesterday that he would form a task force to investigate and recommend solutions. B3.

A Queens grand jury yesterday found no criminal liability on the part of the police officer who killed a hostage by firing five bullets into him during a shootout with gunmen. No charges will be filed against the officer. B3.

HEADLINE: Investing Into the Wind: An Odd, Volatile Game

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
In May 1991, about 80 homeowners in the Hampshire Homes development of southern Miami filed suit against the Lennar Corporation, accusing Florida's largest home builder of shoddy construction with substandard materials. The company fixed some decoration and trim, but said the suits were groundless and the homes structurally sound.
Then came last week's hurricane. 
 Lennar's stock, which had reached $30.125 last Thursday in anticipation of South Florida's rebuilding, fell $1.625, to $26.625 yesterday, as lawyers announced that more homeowners, their houses ruined by the storm, had joined the suit. Lennar's decline on the New York Stock Exchange came despite the market's strong advance.
 
When Bad Is Good
 Whatever the case's outcome, Lennar's situation illustrates the perils of Wall Street's penchant for death-and-destruction plays. No matter how macabre the news, traders always look for something to celebrate. Makers of gas masks and poison antidotes, for example, won favor during the Persian Gulf war.
And after Hurricane Andrew devastated South Florida, construction, development and building-supply stocks all surged in anticipation of the rebuilding to follow. Lennar stoked the fires by responding with plans for thousands of new homes and apartments worth at least $100 million.
But several analysts say traders and brokers have gotten carried away, both in bidding many stocks up and in beating Lennar back down.
"Emotion got the better of reason," said Richard M. Lilly, the research director at J W Charles Securities, the second-largest brokerage firm based in Florida. "Literally, as soon as I got into the office, I had 100 of this firm's brokers calling me, asking how to profit from the hurricane."
Mr. Lilly, whose own house was damaged by the storm, said that several stocks were still puffed up with the recent winds. "They better be praying for another hurricane next week or they're going to be in a world of trouble," he said.
Louis S. Robles, a Miami lawyer, said that 100 homeowners in the West Kendall section of Hampshire Homes were now taking part in the suit. Five other Lennar developments are likely to join the suit, whose claims could run into tens of millions of dollars, he said. Mr. Robles spoke of inferior wood, nails and bolts, and of roofs only casually attached to homes.
"We were asking Lennar to fix the properties," he said from the telephone in his Jeep Cherokee as he headed toward another Lennar project. "Now we're asking for a lot more. Plus we want consequential damages, evacuation costs, loss of personal property, personal injury."
Lennar responded to the initial complaints by repairing what it called the fascia, or decorative trim, on some homes -- "not of a structural nature at all," said Alan J. Pekor, the company's financial vice president.
Since the hurricane, he said, the Miami-based company has been occupied with relief efforts, trucking food and water to its damaged developments. "Our people have been focused on dealing with human needs, not lawsuits," Mr. Pekor said. The lawsuit is so lacking in merit, he said, that Lennar will seek compensation for its defense costs.
Despite the economic slowdown, Lennar's profits rose 55 percent last year to $21 million, mostly from strong results at the mortgage and property-management subsidiaries.
Some investors say they are paying more attention to the healthy balance sheet than to calamities and lawsuits.
"I think some people were under the impression that the entire state is devastated, and Lennar gets to rebuild every home they ever built," said Katherine A. Collins, a manager at the Fidelity mutual fund group, the second-largest institutional holder of Lennar shares.
Despite the hurricane damage and lawsuit, she added, "if you liked Lennar before, there's no reason not to like it now."

HEADLINE: 63 Days After Its Cash Ran Out, California Passes Austere Budget

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 2

 BODY:
California's protracted budget crisis sputtered to an unhappy end early this morning when the weary State Assembly capitulated to Gov. Pete Wilson and approved the final elements of an austere budget 63 days after the state ran out of cash.
But the final package was so tenuous, with a pitifully small cash reserve of only $435 million in a $57.4 billion budget, that fiscal experts here warned that the State Government was likely to go broke again by spring and have to go through yet another painful round of cutting, barring an unexpectedly strong recovery from recession. 
 While the Republican Governor stared down the Democratic-controlled Legislature, he had little to gloat over. He will preside over the erosion of vaunted programs built under many predecessors, both Republican and Democrat, that helped make California prosperous and golden.
 
Prospects Look Bleak
 Under Governor Wilson, the gates to the state colleges will narrow, the poor, blind and disabled will find their meager allotments cut even more, and local governments will be forced to shut libraries and parks and cut back on police, fire and sanitation services.
Moreover, there was very little in the budget that addressed the underlying "structural" problems of California, a state long able to expect both rich public services and low taxes because of the relentless economic growth it has enjoyed since World War II.
Those problems date back at least to 1978, when voters passed Proposition 13, limiting the ability of local governments to raise property taxes and shifting much of the burden of government to the state. That was followed by other voter initiatives reserving fixed amounts of state support for schools and other purposes. Now, with revenues falling and the economy of the state mired deep in the post-cold-war recession with little hope of speedy recovery, the entire house of cards is collapsing.
 
$3.4 Billion in I.O.U.'s

 But for now, Californians can breathe a sigh of relief at the end of the state's worst fiscal crisis since the Depression.
State Controller Gray Davis today began to pay the vendors, doctors, hospitals, nursing homes and others who have not been paid for weeks. But he said he would still have to issue warrants, or i.o.u.'s, for a few more days until the state could borrow $3.5 billion on Wall Street. Major banks said today that they would resume honoring the i.o.u.'s, $3.4 billion of which have been issued since July 1.
After signing the budget at 1:45 this morning, Governor Wilson called it a "very difficult budget that reflects the trying times that we are experiencing, the worst economic times since the Great Depression."
He said he was pleased it contained no new taxes or deficit spending and chided the Legislature, saying he would have accepted this budget in June. "I am content with the result," he said. "I am not content it took two and a half months to get it."
 
Local Taxes May Rise
 While the budget includes nothing labeled as new taxes, it did include many higher fees that critics said amounted to the same. Also, with the state's having diverted $1.3 billion in property taxes away from local governments in order to balance the state budget, many local governments are likely to try to raise taxes and fees.
The end came shortly after midnight after a day of intense negotiations during which the Democratic and Republican leaders, Assembly Speaker Willie L. Brown Jr. and Assemblyman Bill Jones, tried to obtain some facing-saving concessions from Mr. Wilson to make the legislative surrender seem less ignominious than it was.
The Governor did grant minor concessions, and the 80-member Assembly, in a fitful dispirited session passed the Governor's plan, 55 to 9, with some agreed-upon amendments on educational financing. The Senate concurred a short while later, with not a vote to spare.
"Clearly this measure represents a compromise," Mr. Brown told a hushed chamber. "It represents the best decision we could make tonight to solve the budget problem."
Democrats gave up weeks ago on trying to persuade the Governor to raise taxes. His popularity plummeted after he raised taxes by $7 billion to resolve a $14 billion budget gap last year. The dispute, rather, boiled down to how to allocate school spending and how the budget would affect such spending in future years.
Unlike most other government services, the Governor's budget increases school spending this year to keep per-pupil spending even with last, to accommodate 200,000 new pupils. But it does so with a complex mechanism that "recaptures" excess state support given school districts last year, then "lends" them $973 million this year, to be repaid in later years.
The Legislature reluctantly agreed today to this plan, which was vigorously opposed by the powerful California Teachers Association and other school interests because they feared it would permanently reduce the base for school spending in the future.
But they obtained a few concessions, lengthening the pay-back period from two to three years, absolving the obligation to repay should there not be enough money to provide the same per-pupil spending as the previous fiscal year, and specifying a certain base for financing should the courts overturn the recapture provision.
The Governor also agreed to calculate school attendance figures on which spending is based on a daily rather than hourly basis and to increase community college fees from $6 to $10 rather than $12 a credit. The Governor had earlier retreated on a proposal to force 110,000 children to delay starting kindergarten until next year.
 
A Losing Battle
 "We fought hard and essentially lost," Bill Honig, the elected Superintendent of Public Instruction, said in an interview. He said that by holding school spending essentially flat, California would continue to fall behind other states in school support, falling from 34th to 39th among the states in per-pupil spending, just above South Carolina. New Jersey is No. 1, and New York second. Twenty years ago, California spent 15 percent above the national average.
In an interview, Delaine Eastin, the chairwoman of the Assembly Education Committee, said the education forces had given up because the state could no longer suffer the pain. "This battle will go to the courts and the streets now," she said.
The resolution only intensified the antipathy toward Governor Wilson felt not only by Speaker Brown but also by members of the Republican right wing, many of whom joined liberal Democrats in demanding, futilely, that the Governor cut his own bureaucracy to help bolster education support.
"Pete Wilson isn't getting tough, he's getting mean," said Ross Johnson, an Orange County Republican whom Governor Wilson forced out as minority leader last year. "Governor Wilson seems intent on preserving, even expanding, the prerogatives of the power of the Governor of the State of California. There's nothing conservative about that." A bill to cut the bureaucracy, including eliminating 108 public information officers, passed the Assembly on Tuesday night but failed to get the needed two-thirds majority in the Senate.
 
Squeeze on California
 California's troubles are rooted in a squeeze between growing demands for schooling, welfare, health and other programs at a time of declining personal income and revenues during the worst economic slump since the 1930's.
The state has lost about one million jobs, particularly in the high-income aerospace and military industries, since the recession began. According to the State Department of Finance, the main source of state revenues, the personal income tax, is already running 10 percent below expectations for the fiscal year that began July 1.
Anticipating the cuts signed into law today, numerous state agencies, school districts and university campuses had already imposed cutbacks in programs.
For example, when final figures are ready, they are expected to show that enrollment at the 20-campus California State University system dropped to about 270,000 students this fall, down by around 20,000, because of lack of needed classes and increased fees. The Sacramento campus was expecting next year to drop to a 10-year-low of about 17,000 students.
At a news conference this afternoon, Mr. Wilson argued that the state should never again be subjected to this kind of budget crisis, and urged reforms in the state's fraud-ridden Workers Compensation program and passage of a constitutional amendment he has put on the November ballot to cut welfare grants further and give him potent new powers in times of fiscal crisis.
It was difficult today to determine who would pay the ultimate political price for the budget fiasco, but the Controller, Mr. Davis, certainly spoke the truth when he said, "I don't think the people who were messed over in this dispute will forget."

HEADLINE: Japan Is Tough, but Xerox Prevails

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEBSTER, N.Y.

 BODY:
A case study in how to beat the Japanese: When the Xerox Corporation began designing its new high-speed photocopying machine, the Model 5100, it had world markets in mind, especially the Japanese.
But it took a different tack from American auto makers, which, in pursuit of Japanese markets, tried to sell cars with steering wheels on the wrong side. Xerox took great pains to understand the needs of its foreign customers, developing a machine for the Japanese that would duplicate the delicate kanji language characters, for instance, or would handle the flimsy papers used in Japan. 
 Now the American machine, capable of producing high-quality reproductions faster than anything made by Japanese manufacturers, has become the biggest-selling high-speed paper copier in Japan. A spokesman for Fuji Xerox, an independent affiliate that distributes the 5100 in Japan, said its sales there were approaching 90 percent of the high-speed market.
 
Customers Are Pleased
 Xerox's Japanese competitors declined to comment on the success of the American product but the company's Japanese customers are clearly pleased. The NEC Corporation, one of the country's biggest electronics companies, has purchased 22 of the big copiers. "The machines are better than anything we can get in Japan," a spokesman said. "We are not concerned that it is an American product. We wanted the best and most efficient machine."
The Model 5100, the people who built it and the approach they took have played a major part in rescuing an American corporation from damaging competition by the Japanese.
In the early 80's, the situation at Xerox had become so bad that as David T. Kearns, its former chairman, later wrote: "If nothing were done to correct things, we were destined to have a fire sale and close down by some time in the 1990's." Japanese companies -- Canon, Sharp, Toshiba, Ricoh and Minolta -- had made the company a special target, he said, and were hurting it badly.
Unlike the makers of television sets and other consumer electronic products, many of which closed American factories or sold them to foreign companies, Xerox chose to fight: The strategy was to beat the Japanese at their own game, and Xerox went on a quality binge.
The Xerox approach is by no means trouble free. But by and large management consultants and the company are pleased with the results and believe they hold great promise for American competitiveness.
First, Xerox directed attention to working and factory conditions. Lifts were installed at each work station at its plant in Webster, near Rochester, so that the 5100 frame would be raised to a comfortable height for assembly-line workers. Changes were made, too, so that completed parts would flow smoothly to assembly areas. Workers were given daily reports on the quality of products they were working on. Employees were given extra training in quality techniques.
Walking through the sprawling Webster plant, clean and brightly lighted, one encounters many assemblers who say the management attitude and the plant atmosphere have changed markedly. "Until four years ago they didn't care how you put the machines together, as long as you did it in time," said Randy Parry, who has been with the company for 23 years. "And so people hurt themselves -- they had back problems, wrist problems, all kinds of problems." He said the managers once had a list of corporate goals, with consumer satisfaction No. 1 and employee satisfaction fourth or fifth on the list. "Now it is No. 2," Mr. Parry said. "The company knows employee satisfaction has a direct relation to customer satisfaction."
Again copying its Japanese competitors, Xerox resolved to develop formal, long-term-planning, replacing its one-step-at-a-time approach. The Japanese plan product development as if it were a military campaign. "They relish thinking about how do we get from here to there," Mr. Kearns said, "and map it out on big charts.
Xerox formed development teams, as a growing number of American manufacturers are now also doing: designers, engineers, manufacturing experts, marketing specialists, repair people.
Improved communication is a premium. Team members hope to spot problems early, and spread the warnings. Quality problems in the production of American goods have oftenbeen traced to the sequential system of product development. One phase may be completed and frozen in stone before work begins on the next. Manufacturing specialists estimate that 80 percent of a product's costs are built in during the design phase.
 
Gap in Its Markets
 The conception of the 5100 occurred in 1984 when the company perceived a gap in its markets between their 1090 machine, which can produce 92 copies a minute, and the 5090, a highly automated model that spins out 135 a minute. In contrast with the model 5090, which is intended to be run by a trained operator, the 5100 was to be made simple enough to be used by ordinary office workers.
The team was then increased to about 50 people, who defined the machine's broad features, prepared sales estimates and began looking hard at the economics. Subgroups focused on such elements details as the optical systems used in the reproductions, or the automatic document handler and stapler.
The specific-design phase began in early 1986, when some 200 people worked on blueprints for 5,000 individual parts. It was decided then to use the company's manufacturing complex here for assembly but to buy parts worldwide, and parts suppliers were brought in to help in planning.
All along the way, manufacturing costs had to be evaluated. Unlike those in Japanese product development, the costs had to be kept low enough to generate a rate of return on investment that would satisfy stockholders. Relatively free of stockholder pressure, Toshiba, for example, is prepared to lose money for 10 years on flat panel video displays.
As problems were discovered, team members were still around to cope: One was that electricity is generated at 60 cycles a second in northern Japan -- but 50 cycles in the south. "You have to design a power supply that can switch," said David Erwin, a Xerox vice president.
In June 1990, field testing intensified. About 40 machines were placed with customers with quick-print businesses, people not slow to complain when things go wrong. "If there is any kind of problem, it will show up in these field tests," James J. Miller, a marketing manager, said. Found acceptable, the machine was introduced in Japan in October.
Xerox will not disclose figures on sales but says it is pleased with sales around the world. The company's revitalization since the early 80's has been dramatic, and the 5100 is given a major share of the credit. The stock, which hit its lowest level in 1982 -- $27.125 a share -- since it was listed on the New York Stock Exchange in 1961, is now at $76.25, and quarterly losses reported in 1984 and 1985 are replaced by robust earnings now, $139 million in the second quarter of 1992.
Xerox received the Federal Government's Baldrige Award in 1989 as the nation's leading large manufacturer of high-quality products. And early this year, Buyers Laboratory, an American consumer-oriented group, rated its Model 5100 as the "Most Outstanding Copier Overall for 1991."
Despite the 5100 triumph, Xerox and American competitiveness still needs work.
The paper-handling mechanism the American model had to be redesigned, for example, because the heavier American paper "jammed like mad," Mr. Miller said, and delayed introduction six months.
"The best Japanese companies have characteristics in management structure, training and career paths that become advantages" said Prof. Steven Wheelwright, a manufacturing specialist at the Harvard Business School. Japanese executives tend to be broadly trained in a variety of disciplines, including engineering, marketing and finance, he said. As a result they can form smaller, faster teams. "The best Japanese companies have development teams one-third to one-quarter the size of Americans," he said. "The smaller the team, the faster you can move."
Speed counts. The 5100 was developed with traditional optical copying technology -- but already the industry is moving toward converting documents to digital information before reproduction. So how long the 5100 remains out front is a question.
Still, Xerox is generally regarded as having been quicker than most American manufacturers in competing internationally with high quality. Paul A. Allaire, the chairman, says the company is addressing the criticisms, particularly the slowness question. "We should be able to cut 18 months to 2 years out of the cycle," he said.
A number of other changes will be made, such as adding the company president to the development team. He will hold periodic reviews at which team members will describe current mistakes. The idea, again, is communication, and team members are not going to be skewered, Mr. Miller said, but added:
"Nobody likes standing up in front of the president and saying, 'I screwed up.' "

HEADLINE: Growth in Average Income Trailed Inflation Rate in 1991

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2

 BODY:
Income growth for the average American lagged behind inflation in 1991 for the first time in nine years, the Government said today.
"This very nicely reflects the mood of the electorate," said Paul Getman, an economist with Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa. "They're being squeezed very hard by rising taxes and rising health costs on the one hand, and by negligible increases in wages and salaries on the other." 
 The Commerce Department said average per capita income grew 2.4 percent, to $19,092, last year, slightly more than half the 4.4 percent inflation rate.
It was the smallest increase in nominal income since 1961, during the Kennedy Administration, although economists said the drop in inflation in 1991 was one reason for the small increase. Last year was the first time since 1982, during the last recession, that income growth fell behind inflation.
The failure of income growth to keep up with inflation is expected to be one of the economic statistics the Democrats seize on in the Presidential campaign.
Personal income is measured before taxes but after Social Security deductions. It includes income from all sources, including wages, investment earnings and government payments like welfare and farm subsidies. The per capita figure is derived by dividing total income in 1991 -- $4.81 trillion -- by the total population, 252 million.
Adjusted for inflation, incomes declined 1.9 percent last year, the worst on record going back to 1970, the first year for which comparable inflation-adjusted numbers are available.
And it was the third year in a row that the figure was worse than the year before. Inflation-adjusted per capita incomes were unchanged in 1990, rose 1.4 percent in 1989 and 1.9 percent in 1988.
"One reason why the public is in such an ornery mood is that the pain has been building for several years," Mr. Getman said. "Income growth has been sliding for a while and it's not going to turn around very soon."
 
Revised Figures
 Today's figures represent a revision of an earlier report released in April.
Differences among rich and poor states narrowed last year, although Connecticut retained its 1990 ranking as the richest state, with average income of $26,022. Mississippi remained the poorest, with average income of $13,328.
After Connecticut, the highest incomes were in New Jersey, $25,066; Massachusetts, $23,003; New York, $22,471, and Maryland, $22,189.
The low-income states, after Mississippi, were West Virginia, $14,301; Utah, $14,625; Arkansas, $14,629, and New Mexico, $14,644.
Most of the slowest-growing states were on or near the East or West Coasts. That was the opposite of the "bicoastal economy" of the mid-1980's, in which low-income inland states lagged behind the boom in richer coastal states.
Montana had the fastest income growth last year, at 7 percent, followed by Louisiana, 5.4 percent; Mississippi, 4.9 percent, and Arkansas, Kentucky and West Virginia, all 4.4 percent. State figures were not adjusted for inflation.
Incomes grew slowest in Nevada, up five-tenths of 1 percent, followed by California, up 1.3 percent, and Alaska, Delaware and Idaho, all up 1.5 percent.
Despite the relative differences in growth, 48 states had one thing in common: They all had slower growth than the year before. Growth rates picked up only in Montana and New Hampshire.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Vice President;
Quayle Tries to Separate Family Values and 'Murphy Brown'

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 2

 BODY:
Vice President Dan Quayle sought today to rein in a political debate on family values that seems to have spun out of his control since he opened it last May with an attack on the television show "Murphy Brown."
In a speech to community leaders here, Mr. Quayle defiantly rejected the view that the Republicans have used "family values" as an issue to inflame prejudices against homosexuals, welfare recipients and feminists. He said he also dismissed the notion that family values is an empty subject. 
 "I especially reject the notion that discussing this issue is intended to divide Americans from one another, or to imply that some families are superior to others," Mr. Quayle told about 500 people at a luncheon organized by the Kansas City Chamber of Commerce. "Family values is neither meaningless nor mean-spirited."
But it was the increasingly hostile tone of the family values debate, at the Republican National Convention and in Hollywood's response to Mr. Quayle's "Murphy Brown speech," that led the Vice President to address the issue today. Although Mr. Quayle did not say so, his top aides said the speech was aimed at reclaiming an issue they felt had been misrepresented.
Strategists at the White House and the Bush-Quayle campaign have expressed concern in recent weeks that some swing voters were alienated by the judgmental tone of recent speeches on family values by Patrick J. Buchanan, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, and even Marilyn Quayle.
Any poisoning of the family values debate could prove particularly lethal for Mr. Quayle because he has become so closely associated with it. The Vice President has used the issue not only to appeal to wayward conservatives but to try to rebuild his own image as a politican of toughness and resilience.
Mr. Quayle took pains today not to back away from his assault on what he refers to as the "cultural elite." Indeed, he reaffirmed his belief that Hollywood, the news media and liberal Democrats have undermined the Midwestern values he says he learned from family, church and school.
"Many powerful non-governmental institutions have been heavily influenced by the views of an adversary culture," he said. "This is a culture that flinches when it hears the word 'morality' and lashes out when it is challenged to discuss values.
"Hollywood is a stronghold of the adversary culture. It is on the other side of the cultural divide from Huntington, and they don't like it when someone from Huntington, with Midwestern values, challenges their so-called moral authority."
Responding to those who saw his "Murphy Brown" speech as an assault on single mothers, Mr. Quayle noted that his sister is a divorced mother, as was his maternal grandmother. And in what appeared to be a reflection on Mrs. Quayle's comment at the Republican convention that "most women do not wish to be liberated from their essential natures as women," Mr. Quayle praised the women's movement:
"Some changes have been for the good. Women have gained economic opportunities they deserve. This is both just and good for the country. We are still working out solutions to the new arrangements in our workplaces and in our domestic lives. And I have the greatest respect for the women who face these challenges and meet the demands of work and family."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Countering Dollar's Plunge

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
When the dollar plunged to new lows against the German mark in late August, the bond market went with it, giving up much of the gains it made in July and early August. And there was concern that a continued fall in the dollar would pull the bond market even lower.
But while that could still be the case, a look at the recent performance of the dollar and the 30-year bonds shows the opposite: 
 This year, when the dollar has been rising (and, consequently, the German mark has been falling) the price of the 30-year bond has dropped. And when the dollar has fallen and the mark has risen, as has happened since late spring, the price of the 30-year bond has been on the rise and yields have plunged to their lowest level in five and half years.
"They were all screaming that the market is going down because of the dollar," said Terrence Crowe, a vice president at Nikko Securities Inc. "Are they correct? Who Knows?
"But the line," he said, referring to a computer-generated graph, "is telling you that the correlation of the mark going up and the bond going up is what is happening."
The correlation can be seen in a comparison of the performance of the dollar this year to the performance of the December futures contract for the 30-year bond. It is not a perfect correlation because the dollar was rising as the 30-year bonds reached a high in January.
But since then, the bond fell to its lowest price of the year on March 17, while the dollar hit its peak on March 16. The the bond began a steady, but not alway straight, rise toward its present levels on April 28 and the dollar began its relatively steady fall to its current all-time lows against the German mark on April 20. The only real break in this pattern came in the week after Aug. 20, when the dollar's plunge accelerated despite intervention by the Federal Reserve and a host of Europen central banks to support the dollar.
This correlation has something to do with the fact that the reasons for the dollar's rise early in the year were reasons that also worried the bond market. At that time, economists expected an economic recovery with some punch that would draw foreign investment, which would support the dollar. At the same time, that raised the possibility of an upward move in interest rates and some concern about inflation.
Now the dollar is weak, in part because the economic recovery has barely materialized. There is no draw for foreigners. Rather, investors prefer the much higher interest rates they can get in Europe compared with America. but the weak economy is good for the bond market because there is no fear of interest rates going up or inflation reigniting.
So a mild decline in the dollar is not likely to have a strong downward pull on the dollar, as long as this correlation holds and as long as the decline does not appear to be getting out of hand.
 
Treasury Market
 Bonds and notes had a volatile day in thin trading yesterday. By late in the afternoon, much of the gains from earlier in the day had been lost, in part because of some remarks of unnamed Federal Reserve officials reported by the Market News Service.
According to the report, the two officials seemed to indicate the Fed would move to ease interest rates further if necessary, even if the dollar remains weak.
It was fairly clear from the timing of the report that the prices of bonds and notes, especially the 30-year bond, began to fall after the report. But it is not exactly clear why. This is because the indication of another easing by the Fed would support the market.
The discount rates on three-month and six-month Treasury bills did decline one basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point, each. But the 7.25 percent 30-year bond, which was up 10/32 earlier in the day, finished at an offered price of 98 16/32 up just 1/32 , to yield 7.37 percent, the same as Tuesday.
The shorter-maturity notes, which have outperformed the long bond recently, also fared better yesterday. The 10-year note was up 5/32 , to yield 6.53 percent, down from 6.54 percent Tuesday, and the five-year note was up 3/32 , to yield 5.50 percent, the same as the day before.
Matthew Alexy, the government trading strategist at the First Boston Corporation, said it was not clear why bonds and notes fell at the end of the day. But the cautious nature of the market just ahead of the release of the unemployment report for August on tomorrow was to be expected.
The Treasury will announce today when it will begin its testing of a new auction technique. The test will be for a sealed bid auction where all the securities are awarded at a single price even though the winning bids may be at several different prices. The current system awards the securities at several prices, beginning at the highest bid and moving down until all the auctioned securities are sold.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Rising Challenger In Tough Market

BYLINE: By Adam Bryant

 BODY:
THE consumer electronics business in and around Manhattan is not for the faint of heart or small of ego.
The bazaar atmosphere that preys on unwary tourists, the bustling gray market of this port city and razor-thin margins have cut deeply into the ranks of companies that have tried to make it here. Although some retailers -- the Wiz, for example -- are surviving and expanding in the market, casualties include Newmark & Lewis, Lafayette and Crazy Eddie. Even 47th Street Photo, which long appeared to have made a success of organized chaos, is operating under bankruptcy protection. 
 "It's the most competitive market in the country," said Edwin L. Underwood, an analyst with Scott & Stringfellow.
Enter Leslie S. Turchin, a one-time Sears salesman bristling with confidence, brandishing an ambitious plan to expand his newly public Tops Appliance City chain into New York from his current four-store chain in New Jersey.
Mr. Turchin is competitive. After Newmark & Lewis left the market, a trade publication quoted Mr. Turchin as saying, "Anybody else comes here, we'll send them home in a body bag, too."
If nothing else, Tops Appliance City, which sells a broad range of appliances and consumer electronics, is an example of an entrepreneurial drive to test a clearly marked hazardous road.
As an investment, however, the Tops story grows more complex. Industry analysts cite many reasons that Mr. Turchin, who started his company in 1970, might succeed where others have failed. But investors clearly have their doubts, reflected in the company's stock, which has dropped 14 percent in the three weeks since it went public at $14 a share. It closed at $12 a share yesterday in over-the-counter trading, up 62.5 cents.
"Investors should be cautious," Mr. Underwood said of the stock.
Several analysts echoed his comments but declined to be identified for this article because their firms helped underwrite the recent stock offering.
The winnowed ranks of competitors leave Tops much more breathing room to operate and expand outside its home state of New Jersey. In October, Tops plans to open a 68,000-square-foot store in Mount Pleasant in Westchester County. Its future expansion plans call for one new store of more than 60,000 square feet every 12 to 15 months in the New York metropolitan area, and eventually, Mr. Turchin has said, in New England.
Mr. Turchin, 50 years old, who declined to be interviewed because of the stock offering, has carried out a long list of operating procedures, which he monitors from his desk in the Edison, N.J., store. No callers are to wait more than two rings to talk to a store operator. No customers are to wait more than 10 seconds before they are approached by a sales representative.
Analysts note that the large stores -- ranging from 43,000 to 120,000 square feet -- are generally clean, bright and logically laid out. Tops offers free delivery and free removal of old appliances. Tops promises to pay customers $100 if it cannot beat a competitor's price, a promise on which analysts say it rarely has to deliver because so few customers take the time to shop around. The pace of business at the store is swift, and salespeople have license to make deals.
As a result, Tops is the undisputed leader among consumer electronics chains for sales per square foot, at more than $1,700 a year. "The strategy is sound," said Kurt Barnard, president of Retail Marketing Report.
Even so, the company was fined for its aggressive tactics last year by New Jersey's Consumer Affairs Division. Specifically, it was told to change certain practices -- like charging a "restocking fee" for returned items without warning -- and pay the state almost $90,000 in fines and other charges.
As the company has expanded its number of stores, its revenues and profits have increased. Revenues rose to more than $300 million in 1991 from $212 million in 1988. Over the same period, net profits rose to $5.3 million from $1.7 million.
For the first six months of 1992, however, the company reported a net loss of $4.3 million on revenues of $148 million, a loss attributable primarily to a $4.9 million payout to Mr. Turchin, which will be completed in 1994. The bonus, Tops states, is cash compensation due to Mr. Turchin as a result of the Tops recapitalization in 1988 as a limited partnership. Following the offering, Mr. Turchin owned 36.6 percent of the stock.
An additional $1.56 million was charged against second-quarter earnings to transfer equity interests worth 3 percent to Mr. Turchin's top three lieutenants.
After absorbing these costs, the company's profit-and-loss statement may impress more investors when third-quarter results are reported.
But for the long term, Mr. Barnard and others said, opportunities may be limited for the chain. The Tops name is well known in New Jersey, but the company may have difficulties in quickly building the recognition and traffic it needs to sustain its high-volume operations.
In addition, the economy will no doubt prove challenging for Tops, as consumers continue to be slow and cautious in buying electronics and appliances. "We are in an economic climate that is somewhat averse to big-ticket expenditures," Mr. Barnard said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Revives on Quiet Day Ahead of the Jobless Report

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar recovered slightly against most major currencies in quiet trading yesterday as traders took profits ahead of Washington's monthly unemployment report.
Early yesterday, the dollar fell to a low against the German mark, at one point reaching 1.3860, down from Tuesday's record-low close of 1.3900. But it soon recovered to close at 1.3935 marks. 
 The dollar traded in narrow ranges yesterday, and Mike Faust, senior currency strategist with MMS International in New York, said, "The underlying position of the dollar is still one of weakness."
Investors were selling marks and buying dollars to milk profits ahead of tomorrow's scheduled release of August jobless figures, Kevin Lawrie, the Bank of Boston's director of foreign exchange, said.
There is uncertainty among economists about what those numbers will show, he said, but if they are weak, the Federal Reserve could ease interest rates further, which could lead to further declines in the dollar. United States interest rates are already far lower than Germany's, making mark-denominated investments more attractive.
Gold prices fell. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $338.50 an ounce, down $2.30 from late Tuesday. Later, the Republic National Bank quoted a price of $338.70, off $2.20.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 122.63 yen, down 0.42 yen from Tuesday's finish. It was the dollar's lowest closing in Tokyo since Dec. 9, 1988, when the currency finished at 122.43 yen. Later, in London the dollar closed higher at 122.93 yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 123.10 yen, up from 122.84 Tuesday.
In Europe, the dollar hit 1.3870 marks twice yesterday before firming to trade late in the session at 1.3905 marks.
Also in Europe, the dollar fell to a record low 1.2300 Swiss francs and was trading late in the day at 1.2385 francs, down from 1.2400 francs Tuesday. The previous low for the dollar was 1.2305 Swiss francs, set Feb. 7, 1991. In New York the dollar closed at 1.2425 Swiss francs, up from 1.2360 Tuesday.
The pound traded late in Europe at $2.0035, up from $1.9970 Tuesday. Bank of England figures show the pound last closed in Europe above $2 on June 23, 1981, when it traded at $2.0014. In New York, the pound closed at $2.0005, down from $2.0025 late Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday, included: 4.7505 French francs, up from 4.7385; 1,066.00 Italian lire, up from 1,063.00, and 1.19695 Canadian dollars, up from 1.19465.

HEADLINE: Partisan Air Clouds a Trenton Hearing on the Loss of Medicaid Funds

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Sept. 2

 BODY:
Despite the vow of its chairman that no "witch hunt" is in store, a legislative committee began hearings today on the apparent loss of nearly a half-billion dollars in Medicaid money, with Republicans pointing fingers directly at Gov. Jim Florio.
The lone Democrat on the committee responded in kind, blaming Republicans for both a downgrade of the state's bond rating and a budget that will require sharp cutbacks in services and layoffs of some 2,700 state employees. 
 Republicans say everything would have turned out all right if Governor Florio had not announced that the state would be getting $450 million from the Federal Government in Medicaid reimbursements for psychiatric care. Then, in the midst of the budget-making process, he said the payment was in peril -- an announcement that sent the Republicans scrambling to balance the budget.
Governor Florio and the Democrats said that it was not the Medicaid money that caused the budget problems, but rather the Republican move cutting the sales tax by a penny, eliminating $608 million in revenues.
 
No 'Witch Hunt'
 Senator Richard J. LaRossa, a Trenton Republican who is chairman of the Joint Select Committee on Medicaid Reimbursement, which held its first meeting today, said last week, "The committee will not conduct a witch hunt, but instead will gather information to determine, once and for all, the circumstance surrounding the loss of $454 million in anticipated Medicaid reimbursement funds."
Washington has indicated that the state will get only $74 million of the money it is seeking. But aides to Governor Florio continue to insist that it may get the full $454 million, which includes about $380 million in retroactive claims Washington is disputing.
Mr. LaRossa restated his pledge today not to politicize the issue, saying, "Sensationalism is not the guiding principle of the factual review process."
He said the committee would examine documents relating to the reimbursement request, call witnesses from the administration -- and subpoena them if they are recalcitrant -- and request input from the Federal Government, holding a hearing in Washington if necessary.
 
Invisible Revenues
 The committee's Republican vice chairman, Assemblyman Richard H. Bagger of Westfield, said today that the panel was "not convened to randomly point fingers of blame." But he then went on to maintain that Governor Florio had "brought the budget process to a new low."
"We must not allow another budget blunder to wreak havoc with the lives of state employees, the health of the state's economy and the confidence of our citizens," he said.
Another Republican, Senator Harriet Derman of Edison, said, "It was as if the revenue estimates were written with disappearing ink."
With that, the lone Democrat on the committee, Assemblyman Bernard F. Kenny Jr. of Hoboken, suggested that "there may be a drift toward partisanship as we go along" and warned that "the minute we go off track and begin to point partisan finger, I will point partisan fingers as well."
He then pointed to one, saying, "There is a lot of blame to be thrown around," and accused the Republican majority of ignoring warnings that a tax cut could jeopardize the state's bond rating by cutting revenues below a level Wall Street considers optimum.
That happened just last week, when Moody's Investors Service dropped the rating a notch from the top level, Aaa, to its second-highest rating, Aa1. The downgrade means the state will have to pay more interest on the money it borrows.

HEADLINE: Assembly Speaker Pressed To Help Stop Car Thefts

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, Sept. 2

 BODY:
The Speaker of the New Jersey Assembly told a group of black clergymen today that the Legislature must respond to the increasingly violent car-theft problem in the Newark area, but he said an effective response requires more discussion between community leaders and lawmakers.
"We're not at a point yet for legislation," said the Speaker, Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, a Republican, "although it will not be delayed forever. It can't be." 
 Several bills that would increase penalties for car theft and create military-style boot camps for offenders have been introduced in the Legislature but have remained bottled up in committee. Differing versions of a measure allowing municipalities to declare a 10 P.M. curfew for children under the age of 18 have passed in the Senate and Assembly, but no bill has passed in its final form.
Members of some community organizations have said that simply strengthening law enforcement will not solve the car-theft problem. They maintain that a successful response must also address high unemployment, poor educational achievement and the aimlessness of young people in the inner cities.
Mr. Haytaian said today that the Legislature would heed a plea for help made by Mayor Sharpe James of Newark, where in recent months confrontations between car thieves and the police have resulted in the fatal shootings of four young people riding in stolen vehicles and the wounding of three others. At the same time, police officers have become the target of car thieves who try to run them down or ram their vehicles.
In the latest incident, a Harrison police officer fired two shots at a stolen van Tuesday after the driver tried to run him down at an intersection in Harrison, the police said. The officer, Kevin Murphy, fired at the van's tires, hitting one, according to the police. The van, with its flat tire, was found abandoned a short time later about two miles away in Newark.
 
Subject Wasn't on Agenda
 The car-theft problem was not on the agenda of the breakfast meeting today between Mr. Haytaian and about two dozen members of the Newark-North Jersey Committee of Black Churchmen at St. James A.M.E. Church on Martin Luther King Boulevard. The meeting was scheduled weeks ago to deal chiefly with the religious leaders' concerns about school funding and the impact of budget cuts on programs affecting the cities.
But as the 90-minute session was winding down, the Rev. Robert H. Johnson, pastor of the First Hopewell Baptist Church, asked Mr. Haytaian what the Legislature was prepared to do about car theft. "Kids are getting shot; cars are getting stolen," he said, eliciting Mr. Haytaian's promise of some action after consultation with community leaders.
The Rev. Perry Simmons, pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church and president of the Newark Board of Education, said after the meeting that the car-theft problem "is very serious" and will require the cooperation of law-enforcement agencies, elected officials and community leaders.
He said that repeat offenders should face certain jail sentences, something not assured now because of overcrowded juvenile-detention centers and the low priority often given car theft.
"We must untie the hands of the judiciary," Mr. Simmons said. "If you have a cancer you don't try to treat it with a lotion. When anyone tries to run people down with a car, it becomes a weapon."
Mr. Simmons and other clergymen told Mr. Haytaian that they did not believe the Legislature was sincere about meeting the New Jersey Supreme Court's mandate to bring spending on education in poor urban districts up to parity with that in the suburbs. They said recent statements by some Republican legislative leaders that school aid should be shifted away from the cities to the suburbs had heightened their concern.
Mr. Haytaian said the Legislature supported bringing suburban and city districts to parity, but he said the court had allowed that to be done gradually, and he urged the ministers to withold judgment on the Republican-controlled Legislature's spending on education for another year.

HEADLINE: SCARSDALE JOURNAL;
In Fight Over Tennis Courts, a Village Examines Its Priorities

DATELINE: SCARSDALE, N.Y.

 BODY:
THE opinions are flying as fast here as the tennis balls at Flushing Meadows. Would it be unseemly for this village to build more tennis courts, given the tough economic climate?
The question has bounced around the village this summer, becoming a rallying point for a debate about values and local priorities. 
 Leading the opposition to new courts is the Scarsdale League of Women Voters.
Speaking for the league's 725 members, its president, Ann Rose Simon, told the Scarsdale board of trustees: "This is an inappropriate time to build new tennis courts in the village. We are in an economic recession, with cutbacks and cost-saving measures being instituted at every level of government."
Building courts after school budgets had been cut would set a bad example for children, Mrs. Simon said, noting that despite the village's reputation for affluence, many residents had lost their jobs or seen their incomes reduced during the recession.
Supporters of the effort to build new courts say they are baffled by the opposition because only those who play would have to pay.
The board of trustees is expected to vote on Sept. 8 on whether to add two new public courts to the 25 existing ones in this village of 17,000. The $70,000 project would be financed with surcharges on tennis permits of $5 for adults and $3 for children. About 3,000 permits are now issued each year. The money would be borrowed from a developers' fund that is held in escrow for recreation, and would be repaid over six years.
Opponents of the new courts raise questions about what will happen if the charges do not cover all the construction and maintenance costs of new courts. Mrs. Simon points out that the number of people using the town's once popular paddle tennis courts had dropped sharply, and warned that the number of tennis permits issued could also decline.
Robert H. Harrison, director of the Scarsdale branch of the New York Junior Tennis League, said the courts are needed to ease the frustrations of young players and those who volunteer to coach them, because rules favoring adults kept the 600 youths in the league from playing during peak after-school and weekend hours in the spring.
In response to suggestions that youth matches be moved to the fall to relieve crowding on the courts, Mr. Harrison replied: "Tennis is a spring sport and that's when it should be played. It gets dark soon after 6 P.M. in the fall. Let the League of Women Voters play in October and November if they think that's a good time to play."
Letters to The Scarsdale Inquirer, the village newspaper, have been vocal on the subject, both pro and con. In the editorial and opinion columns, the paper is solidly pro courts. A columnist ridiculed what he called the League of Women Voters' "message of doom and gloom" and advised the group to "lighten up." And an editorial took the view that tennis was especially appropriate in difficult times because "people have more time to play and a greater need to relieve stress."
Alan R. Morse, a parent volunteer in the elementary- and middle-school tennis program run by the village recreation department, said new courts could only enhance Scarsdale's desirability as a place to live. "Our fine recreational facilities are one more thing which help to distinguish Scarsdale from many of our neighbors in Westchester," he wrote to The Inquirer. He called tennis courts a "substantial asset."
But Matthew Taubin, another resident who has been active in youth recreation programs, thinks the village should hold on to its money, and called the building of more tennis courts in Scarsdale an overindulgence.
"There are so many courts in our little town that it's mind-boggling," he said. "I'd rather spend money on something that would help the whole village, like suspending parking fees for an hour each day to help our retail merchants."
Mrs. Simon said she feared that the debate would make Scarsdale "seem flighty," when, in fact, it was strongly civic-minded, with many volunteers serving in village government and on advisory boards.
"I don't know of another place that gives so much time, effort and heart to community service," Mrs. Simon said. "The village is special, not because it is affluent but because it is a community of socially responsible people."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ascii of Japan Says It Has Lined Up Lenders

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 2

 BODY:
Kazuhiko Nishi, the entrepreneur who helped create Japan's personal computer industry, has rescued his company from the threat of bankruptcy.
Mr. Nishi, 36 years old, announced Tuesday that six banks had agreed in principle to lend his company, the Ascii Corporation, 16.4 billion yen, or about $130 million, which will allow Ascii to pay off a huge bond that must be redeemed next March. 
 In exchange, Ascii (pronounced AS-key) has promised to cut back sharply on hiring, to sell or close unprofitable subsidiaries and to take other steps to cut expenses. A manager from the Industrial Bank of Japan, the lead bank in the bailout effort, will join Ascii's management in an as-yet undetermined position, although Mr. Nishi is expected to remain president.
"They have not requested, as part of this deal, that I should resign or step back," Mr. Nishi said in an interview Tuesday.
 
The Plight of 'Kay'
 The plight of Mr. Nishi, known by the nickname Kay, has been closely watched here because he is a rare example of a self-made man in a nation notoriously short of successful entrepreneurs. Mr. Nishi started Ascii when he was a college student in 1977 and has nurtured it into a $270 million company centered on software and computer magazine publishing. And in a nation that shuns flamboyance, he has attracted attention by flying around in helicopters and owning several luxurious cars.
But Mr. Nishi, who has no shortage of visions, took advantage of the easy money available during the boom years in Japan's stock and real estate markets to borrow heavily and move Ascii into new businesses, including movie production and distribution, semiconductors, satellite communications and even helicopter chartering. While Ascii remains profitable, the company could not raise money to pay its debts once Japan's boom ended, requiring it to seek the loan from the six banks.
 
'We're Not in Crisis'
 Since news reports about Ascii's problems appeared in the United States last week, Ascii has been besieged by offers from American companies interested in buying all or part of it. Mr. Nishi said Ascii might eventually need a partner and would listen to offers, especially for minority stakes. But, he added, "For the time being, we're not in a crisis."
Mr. Nishi was vague about which operations Ascii would cut, other than its helicopter service and its Japanese satellite communications business.
He said Ascii would retain its movie business, which it formed by acquiring the Japanese operations of Vestron Inc., a videocassette distributor, and a one-third stake in the Edward R. Pressman Film Company, an independent film maker. The film operations have been buoyed recently because Ascii helped finance the production of the hit movie "Fried Green Tomatoes."
 
To Sell Some U.S. Stakes
 Ascii will also sell its stakes in some of the more than 20 small American technology companies in which it has invested.
But Mr. Nishi said he had great hopes for two Silicon Valley companies in which Ascii holds stakes -- Crosspoint Solutions, which makes user-programmable computer chips, and Nexgen Microsystems, which is developing powerful microprocessors to compete with those of Intel. Mr. Nishi said that if these and other investments paid off Ascii would thrive again in the future.
Asked if he had any regrets, Mr. Nishi paused and closed his eyes. "My regret," he finally answered, "is I had optimistic optimism. I should have had optimistic pessimism or pessimistic optimism."

HEADLINE: De Beers May Be Losing Grip on Diamond Market

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 2

 BODY:
Less than a month ago De Beers Consolidated Mines, the secretive South African company that dominates the world diamond trade through a cartel that controls 80 percent of the world's uncut diamonds, seemed to have coasted miraculously through a recession that had rattled other luxury industries.
But in the last few weeks the industry has admitted that it is suffering its worst swoon in a decade, provoking speculation, once unthinkable, that the cartel is losing its grip. 
 One source of the disarray is a flood of Angolan diamonds that have begun to pour onto the normally orderly world market.
Now that Angola's civil war has ended, some 50,000 prospectors are digging for gems, mainly along the diamond-rich Cuango River. As the African drought has dried up the rivers, alluvial diamond deposits in the riverbeds and riverbanks have become more accessible to the wildcat miners, who smuggle them out to buyers in Antwerp.
The Angolan Government normally cooperates with the cartel, but the war has left large portions of the country virtually ungoverned. The illicit diamonds are hitting a market that, it turns out, is not as immune to the world recession as it seemed. Consumers in the world's two largest diamond-buying countries, America and Japan, have been cutting back or trading down to cheaper stones.
Adding to the industry's gloom are charges that De Beers, which speaks for the diamond establishment, misled investors about the wobbly state of the industry by glossing over evidence of falling demand and ignoring the Angolan problem.
"The diamond market was already going badly last year, and they tried to give it a lift by pretending sales were better than they actually were," said James Picton, a Cape Town analyst who forecast the industry's problems well before De Beers did. "The diamond trade is a very sentimental animal. If it seems to be doing well it sort of feeds on that."
Julian Ogilvie Thompson, chairman of De Beers, insists that the company was not unduly optimistic. De Beers, he said, could not have foreseen the crash of the stock market in Japan, which cast a chill over the diamond market in that country, or the explosion of diamonds from Angola.
 
Chairman Denies Allegations
 "The allegations that De Beers has lost credibility are unfair and ill founded, and the facts support me," he declared with the regal assurance for which the company is famous.
The cartel is scrambling to hold retail prices stable by buying up the oversupply. But for now, the big industrial economies show no signs of returning to the bauble-buying euphoria of the 1980's, and there seems to be little immediate prospect of arresting the flow of gems from Angola.
"It might have been easy at the beginning to control it," said Richard Stuart of Martin & Company, a Johannesburg brokerage. "But now you've got 5,000 demobilized soldiers running wild. If you fly a patrol over the province you can get shot down by a missile. And it's a 100-mile river. You can't put a fence around it."
To keep prices from collapsing, the cartel may be forced to buy up $500 million worth of illicit diamonds from Angola this year -- twice as much as Angola's official production, and far more than De Beers anticipated.
As recently as Aug. 10, De Beers seemed to be a lustrous exception to the world economic slump. The cartel had secured new five-year contracts with its stable of collaborating producers, now enhanced by the addition of Russia. A new Japanese taste for baubles seemed to have buoyed the industry through a sales slump in America. The new De Beers diamond mine at Venetia in the northern Transvaal, which opened in August, was set to yield gems worth $400 million a year.
Diamonds were forever, as the cartel's ad agency is spending $160 million this year to remind the world, and so, it appeared, was De Beers.
 
Some Noticed Danger Signs
 While some analysts noticed danger signals in the persistent world recession and the Angolan diamond rush, many were lulled by the bullish assurances of De Beers's patrician chairman, Mr. Ogilvie Thompson.
Then on Aug. 11, Mr. Ogilvie Thompson broke the news: De Beers was slashing its dividend for the second time in its postwar history and ordering its contractors to hold back production. The mining giant's stock plunged from 75 rands ($28) a share to the low 50's, taking with it much of the Johannesburg Stock Exchange and the company's credibility.
For the first time since the diamond market collapsed in 1981, investors wondered openly whether the De Beers cartel could continue to dominate the gem trade.
"When this question arose 10 years ago, I said, 'Of course De Beers can hold the line,' " said Mr. Picton, the Cape Town analyst, who forecast the dividend cut. "This time, I don't think there's any 'of course' about it. I do think they will hold the line. But at what price?"
De Beers has worked hard to create stability in an industry that in effect sells caprice. After all, no one really needs diamonds. Even the gems used in industry now have synthetic alternatives. Like luxury tours and sable coats, gem diamonds have the makings of a cyclical business that should flutter with economic trends. But it does not, largely because De Beers has kept tight controls on the supply.
Through its corporate Siamese twin, De Beers Centenary A.G. -- a Swiss-based concern created to insulate the diamond trade from international sanctions against South Africa's apartheid system -- De Beers runs the marketing organ called the Central Selling Organization, which grades, distributes and promotes most of the world's rough diamonds.
When demand grows, as it did in the 1980's, the selling organization releases more stones to keep price from soaring. When supply threatens to outstrip demand, the cartel buys the surplus and stockpiles it.
By preventing sharp fluctuations in price, De Beers argues, the manipulations protect the jobs of miners, cutters, traders and jewelers, and secure the value of what consumers buy.
The diamond industry generally plays along with the cartel because it trusts De Beers to foresee trends and act accordingly.
Secrecy is an essential ingredient in the De Beers mystique, but Mr. Picton offers the following stark calculations to illustrate the magnitude of De Beers's predicament:
The Central Selling Organization, he estimates, was obliged to buy uncut diamonds worth $4.8 billion -- $4.3 billion from its contractors, plus the Angolan stones. It could expect to sell consumers less than $3.5 billion, by Mr. Picton's reckoning. The difference was a huge volume of diamonds.
The company moved quickly to restore the balance, ordering cartel members to hold back 25 percent of the diamonds they were contracted to market through the cartel.
But some producers, desperate for cash, will be strongly tempted to evade the cutbacks and sneak their diamonds onto the market.
One analyst, Kevin G. Kartun of Frankel Kruger Vinerine Inc. in Johannesburg, speculates that De Beers is shrewdly exaggerating the Angolan problem to frighten wayward producers like the Russians into hewing closer to the cartel.
"In the meantime De Beers is increasing their share of production," Mr. Kartun said. "Their Venetia mine will be at full production by 1993, and they are putting a huge emphasis on marine diamonds" mined from oceangoing platforms. Owning a greater share of the rough stones, Mr. Kartun said, would give De Beers more muscle to cow other producers into line.
But Mr. Kartun's theory is a contrarian view among brokers, who tend to think the company's woes are genuine and, if anything, likely to get worse. Much worse, if a big producer like Russia breaks ranks.
That worry may explain why Harry Oppenheimer, the 83-year-old scion of the mining dynasty that built De Beers, is in Russia this week, ostensibly on vacation.
 
How Much Have Times Changed?
 Mr. Picton, for one, wonders if the diamond industry will ever fully recover its luster. "There are concerns that overt displays of wealth are a thing of the past," he said.
While few suggest that De Beers and the cartel are in mortal danger, many analysts predict that regaining its grip will cost De Beers heavily.
Aside from the expense of mopping up the diamond surplus, some analysts say De Beers may have to loosen its autocratic hold on the industry.
Sharing power in the cartel would undermine De Beers's secrecy, nibble into its profits and violate its old-boys-club corporate culture.
