HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Tax-Exempt Yields Gain but Taxables Slip

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The yields offered by money market funds were mixed in the latest week, as the supply of municipal debt remained heavy and money markets regained composure after last week's decline in the dollar, according to The IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report, which surveyed 857 funds.
The assets of tax-exempt money funds were down $1.3 billion for the week, to $95 billion, as the average number of days left to maturity of securities held in fund portfolios increased a day, to 65. 
 Walter S. Frank, IBC/Donoghue's chief economist, said the flow of cash from the tax-exempt funds reflected the rise in long-term yields that is affecting the short end.
 
'Upward Pressure on Yields'
 "The more attractive yields of the longer maturities brought on by higher borrowing costs and the increased supply of tax-exempt issues have combined to exert upward pressure on yields in the short paper that funds invest in," Mr. Frank said.
The seven-day average for both compounded and simple yields of tax-exempt funds rose by 11 basis points, to 2.32 percent and 2.30 percent, respectively. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point. Over 30 days, the average was 2.20 percent for a simple yield and 2.22 percent for a compounded yield.
For investors in the 28 percent tax bracket, the taxable equivalent of the current seven-day compounded tax-free yield is 3.22 percent, while the equivalent for investors in the 31 percent tax bracket is 3.36 percent.
In its weekly survey of tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million, IBC/Donoghue's said the Dreyfus Basic Municipal fund was the best performer with a return of 3.14 percent, or 17 basis points higher than the top fund of the previous week.
 
Taxable Funds
 The yields of taxable money market funds slipped, meanwhile, as assets were down $15.8 billion, to $489.9 billion. As in the previous week, most of the outflow came from institutional funds. In the latest period, the institutionals were down $11.4 billion, to $173.1 billion.
The average seven-day compounded yield for taxable money market funds was 3.05 percent, down 2 basis points, with the simple yield down a similar amount to 3.01 percent. For the 30-day average, the compounded and simple yields were both down 3 basis points, to 3.09 percent and 3.04 percent, respectively.
Analysts said the average days left to maturity of securities in portfolios rose a day, to 64.
The Standby Reserve Fund, distributed by Cowen & Company of New York, maintained the top return among general-purpose funds with a yield of 3.82 percent.
With government funds and funds with assets under $100 million included, however, the best yield was the United Services Government Securities Savings fund, distributed by United Services of San Antonio.
By comparison, the average bank money market account slipped 2 basis points in the latest week, to yield 3 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
One Currency: Pain or Gain?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
THE fall of the dollar is yesterday's news in America, a mere digression from enduring issues like witchcraft and family values. But the rise of the German mark -- the flip side of the dollar's humbling -- is not about to be brushed aside in Europe.
Even in ordinary times, currency turmoil would be greater cause for alarm in relatively small, open economies that live or die by trade. And with France poised to vote this month on monetary union with the rest of the European Community, these are hardly ordinary times. 
 The community, on what was supposed to be a deliberate march toward a single currency, has been jolted by the discovery that getting there is much less than half the fun. Indeed, the shock of being caught in the turbulence of the jet-propelled mark is raising basic questions about whether it is worth getting there at all.
Stripped to essentials, the appeal of a common European currency is the attraction of surrendering economic sovereignty to a benevolent despot -- one bent on assuring German-style price stability for the entire community. Or, as Shafiqul Islam, an economist at the Council on Foreign Relations, bluntly puts it, the idea is "to import the credibility of the Bundesbank."
A first taste of the benefits is already being enjoyed under the existing monetary arrangements, in which the major European currencies are linked in a narrow exchange band. British borrowers, for example, no longer pay a significant interest premium over their German counterparts because private lenders have become convinced that London will do whatever is necessary to keep the pound locked to German currency -- and thus immune from locally driven inflation. But as recent events suggest, traveling with the mark can mean a bumpy ride.
The origins of the current problem lie in domestic German politics. To prevent unemployed or low-paid eastern Germans from seeking western German jobs, Chancellor Helmut Kohl agreed in 1990 to bribe them to stay home. This year, Bonn will spend 160 billion marks -- about $11,000 for every eastern German -- to subsidize living standards in the former socialist paradise. But Chancellor Kohl never consented to raise taxes sufficiently to cover the bill. And rather than allow government spending to spill into inflation, the Bundesbank has tightened the monetary screws.
The resulting sky-high German interest rates have sucked in a torrent of foreign capital, permitting Bonn to finance reunification now and pay later. But the rest of Europe has been buffeted by the storm.
Robert Z. Lawrence, an economist at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government, sees striking parallels to Ronald Reagan's fiscal policy of the early 1980's. Then, America financed big budget deficits with foreign capital attracted by high short-term interest rates. That suited the Administration, which thereby escaped the dire capital crunch predicted by most economists. But it proved a double whammy for Rust Belt manufacturers, who were forced to pay more for credit and were priced out of foreign markets by the overvalued dollar.
Unlike Michigan and Ohio, Britain and Italy could devalue their currencies, ending pressure to raise interest rates and making their exports more competitive abroad. But that would undercut the credibility of the current exchange-rate system and raise further doubts about the workability of a true currency union.
The best solution, Mr. Lawrence argues, would be for Germany to prove its loyalty to the community by raising taxes and lowering interest rates. But he is not holding his breath.
An alternative, suggested months ago by Alberto Giovannini of Columbia University, would be to end the convergence dance and go directly to monetary union. An accelerated commitment to a common money would eliminate speculation against weaker European currencies that is simply a byproduct of the surge toward the mark. Some currency union supporters in France are now arguing that it would also give all of Europe a say over policies now effectively controlled by Germany.
But all this begs the core question: Is the potential gain from monetary union worth the pain?
Certainly most European leaders think so, if only because it would bury nascent German nationalism under a blanket of collective responsibility for the economic welfare of the community. But some economists, including one pillar of the American academic establishment, Martin Feldstein, have serious doubts.
Mr. Feldstein, the director of the National Bureau of Economic Research and a former adviser to President Reagan, argues that Europe can enjoy most of the benefits of economic integration without the strains that go with the surrender of independent fiscal, monetary and exchange-rate policies. That view, little heard in Europe until very recently, could prove decisive in the French referendum on Sept. 20, which polls suggest is too close to call.

HEADLINE: The Cartoon's Characters Squish And Twist? It Must Be a Plympton

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
When the cartoonist Bill Plympton looks at a face, all sorts of things cross his mind. Weird things, like pulling both ears until they stretch a couple of feet, and then tying them in a knot. Or winding a face up like the rubber band for a model-airplane propeller. Or expanding the nostril until the nose inhales the entire head.
"I think the human body is the ultimate cliche, so that's why I like tearing it apart, smooshing it and kneading it like dough," Mr. Plympton said in a recent interview in his studio in Chelsea. By way of example, he reached for a prop, a latex-rubber model of an actor, and planted his fist right in the middle of its face, which quietly imploded. Mr. Plympton seemed pleased with the result. A boyish-looking 46 years old, in big shorts, an oversize short-sleeved white shirt, Top-Siders and socks, he looked like a large version of Tintin. 
 Among animation buffs, surreal physical humor that Mr. Plympton has made his stock in trade in eight animated short subjects over the last decade carries an admiring adjective: "Plymptonesque." That quality is on full view in "The Tune," an animated feature-length musical that opens in New York tomorrow at the Quad Cinema.
The film, whose 10 songs and 1 instrumental are written by Maureen McElheron, follows the adventures of Del, a struggling songwriter, as he searches for the perfect song, which he must present to the evil Mr. Mega of Mega Music. If he fails, he risks losing his sweetheart, Didi. An unfamiliar exit on the highway puts Del in a bizarre town called Flooby Nooby, where a series of Plymptonesque encounters unfold.
The musical and visual styles change from scene to scene. In one sequence, Del watches a realistically rendered couple doing the tango. Each time the music calls for a dip, the man leans over his partner and tells a profoundly bad joke. When a blowsy diner waitress sings "Good Again," a country song about reunited couples getting back together, Looney Tunes images appear on the screen, including a hamburger that sits in a living-room chair, pining for the french fry whose framed picture he holds in his hand.
"The Tune" is a monument to persistence. Mr. Plympton drew all 30,000 cels for the film himself, over a period of about two years. His assistant, Jessica Wolk-Stanley, used a $10 set of Pelikan watercolors to add color, with Mr. Plympton putting on the final details with colored pencil, a technique that accounts for the characteristic shimmer of his images. He worked at a small drawing table, wearing a fingerless cotton glove on his right hand to keep oils from his skin away from the paper, with a mirror propped up in front of him so that he could make faces.
To finance the film, which cost about $175,000, he sold segments of it to Expanded Entertainment for the "Tournee of Animation," an annual touring festival of short subjects, and to MTV, which had featured his Microtoons in the past. One segment, "Push Comes to Shove," won the jury prize at the Cannes International Film Festival in 1991. His big breakthrough came when Grey Advertising hired him to make two commercials for Trivial Pursuit.
 
Once Was Quite Enough
 "I'll probably never animate another film by myself," said Mr. Plympton, whose bland, placid manner seems entirely at odds with his work. "It was fun and an adventure, but the joy is gone for me. Next time, I'm hiring animators."
Mr. Plympton said he approached a few large studios, without success. "They wanted nothing to do with it," he said. "A gag in which a rock goes through a guy's head was something they weren't used to." The film was picked up by October Films, a small art-film distributor.
Like most other Americans of his generation, Mr. Plympton, a native of Oregon, grew up on Disney animation, the most important early influence on his art, along with the Warner Brothers cartoons of Tex Avery and Bob Clampett, who animated Daffy Duck and early Bugs Bunny cartoons, and Chuck Jones in his Road Runner period. As a child, he would draw for hours on used butcher paper that his mother gave him, working the bloodstains into story lines. At 14, he sent his work to Disney Studios, which told him he was too young for a job.
Although he studied graphic design at Portland State University, he is self-taught as a cartoonist and animator. While at college he discovered the work of Rene Magritte, the Belgian Surrealist, and Roland Topor, whom he describes as "Magritte on drugs -- actually, Magritte on bad drugs." Another influence is A. B. Frost, a turn-of-the-century American illustrator best known for his drawings for the Uncle Remus tales.
 
'I Was Treated Like a God'
 After moving to New York in 1969, Mr. Plympton worked as an illustrator and cartoonist for newspapers and magazines. For a time he turned out a syndicated political cartoon strip, "Plympton," carried in about 20 newspapers in the United States. In 1985 he animated "Boomtown," a song by Jules Feiffer, and, as the cartoon made its way from festival to festival, got his first taste of fame.
"That was an eye-opener," he said. "Basically, I was treated like a god, with limos picking me up, the whole works, and I thought, 'Why am I wasting my time illustrating?' "
Mr. Plympton turned to animation full time, making such films as "25 Ways to Quit Smoking," "How to Kiss" and "Your Face," which was nominated for an Academy Award for best animation in 1987. All of them are conceptually quirky and rough around the edges, in part out of economic necessity, in part because Mr. Plympton prefers the look. "We're the garage band of animation compared to the symphony orchestra of Disney," he said. "I like the raw quality. It's a counter to the glossy, airbrushed quality of 'Beauty and the Beast.' "
Mr. Plympton's short films also reflect a fascination with the oddities of the human body, whose bizarre metamorphoses he executes with great facility. "The hard part for me is the sound effects," he said. "I don't know what it would sound like if a boulder passed through somebody's nose."
 
Physical, Please, Not Cerebral
 Mr. Plympton recoiled at the suggestion that his work, for all its idiosyncrasy, might be described as intellectual. If the mild-mannered Mr. Plympton can be said to despise anything, it is cerebral cartoonists and the government grants that support them. "A lot of films are supported by grants from the National Endowment for the Arts and others," he said, "and as a rule they are the most unbearable to watch."
Mr. Plympton says he does not care to share their company. "My work is physical humor," he said. "I'm more visceral and unself-conscious."
This is literally true. His next feature, a combination of live action and animation, includes a sequence in which a character's brain, heart, lung and spleen jump up on his shoulder and sing a number called "It Takes Guts."
The singing, dancing organs are the kind of twist that fans of Mr. Plympton look for, like the sumo wrestler who drops from the sky to extinguish a cigarette in "25 Ways to Quit Smoking," hitting the ground with a satisfying splat. He is the first of 25 increasingly bizarre variations on a theme, which returns, triumphantly, to the sumo wrestler, the final, weighty exclamation point to the film.
"The ideal cartoon should build, hit a plateau, ease off and then build again, until the people are in such a frenzy they can't stand it, and then the credits roll," Mr. Plympton said. "Really, it's the same with food or sex."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bill Plympton, a cartoonist, whose animated feature-length musical, "The Tune," opens tomorrow. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

LENGTH: 364 words

HEADLINE: Harmful Politicking in California

 BODY:
Despite a serious recession, California remains wealthier than many nations. Yet for two months it has had to pay some employees and many bills with i.o.u.'s, and its credit rating has plummeted. The episode has embarrassed California's politicians. It also challenges them to a higher order of statesmanship the next time around.
Yesterday's $57.4 billion budget agreement may well improve the state's credit rating and its investment climate. It may also be sufficient to finance hard-pressed schools, health clinics and other public programs. But the margin for error is slim. If the revenue projections are too optimistic, California will face some tough choices next year. Budget planners assume that personal income will rise by 7.8 percent by 1993; but economists expect less. 
 California's problems are threefold. Its huge population is accustomed to generous public services. Its economy has been battered by recession and cuts in defense spending. And its politicians -- a Republican administration and a Democratic Legislature -- usually seem more interested in looking good for their constituencies than in doing good for the state as a whole.
The Legislature, embittered by voter-mandated term limits and deep staff cuts, has been running scared. And Gov. Pete Wilson, whose popularity dropped when he imposed modest tax increases last year, wasn't eager to take the same risk again.
There was also a genuinely difficult division over funds for education. Democrats insisted on honoring a voter-approved law that guarantees a minimum of 40 percent of general funds for education. Governor Wilson argued that the schools were overpaid last year and that in hard times they had to take their fair share of budget cuts.
In the end, Mr. Wilson got most of what he wanted, though the Legislature managed to spare some items. But little was changed from a budget proposal that could have been adopted in the spring.
Economic health may not return to California in time to prevent more budgetary pain next year. Even so, there's time for Californians to ask their officials whether they can't do a little bit more for their state with a lot less posturing.

HEADLINE: China Flunks a Freedom Test

 BODY:
China would like Americans to applaud its economic reforms while averting their eyes from abuses like arbitrary arrest, torture and slave labor. But such selective vision now becomes much harder after two disturbing events.
A report was smuggled out of China documenting the harsh torture of political prisoners. And Chinese police, striking at night, arrested a peaceful democracy campaigner, Shen Tong, and two young associates. The disposition of their case remains unclear. 
 The United States does not have to stand idly by while human rights are so outrageously violated. The best way to encourage a long-overdue political thaw in China is for the Senate to approve a House-passed trade bill that would penalize China for human rights abuses.
Shen Tong, a leader of the 1989 democracy movement in Tiananmen Square, returned to China a month ago following three years of exile in the United States. He was arrested just hours before he was to address a press conference to inaugurate the first Chinese chapter of the Democracy for China Fund, the movement Mr. Shen helped launch from the U.S.
Shen Tong's brave plans challenged Beijing to clarify its attitude toward freedom of association. While China remains a Communist police state, its leaders brag that political stability has been restored. They recently invited student exiles to return home without fear of retribution.
But when confronted with the prospect of public criticism, Chinese authorities spectacularly failed the test. Along with Shen Tong, they seized Qi Dafeng and Qian Liyun, and expelled Ross Terrill, a scholar from Boston accompanying them. The police also confiscated notebooks and computer disks, placing at risk all Chinese who may have spoken with Mr. Shen or his friends.
Yesterday the Times Op-Ed page published a plea by Shen Tong for peaceful change, along with a document smuggled out of Lingyuan prison detailing barbaric tortures now being inflicted on the imprisoned democrats of Tiananmen Square. International pressure is needed to protect Shen Tong and his colleagues from a similar fate.
Americans have a ready vehicle for demanding an early end to China's outrageous treatment of those who dare to call for democracy and civil rights. The Senate will soon be voting on President Bush's request to exempt China from the high tariffs it would otherwise face because of its Communist system and its failure to permit free emigration.
The House has wisely ignored the President, approving a bill to impose selective tariffs if abuses continue. This bill carefully protects the reform-minded private sector of China's coastal enclaves, reserving penalties only for state industries and only if they persist in defying internationally recognized human rights for another year.
Enacting that legislation, by the necessary veto-proof margin, would place America on the side of political as well as economic reform. That, not the side of torture and repression, is where America belongs.

HEADLINE: Essay;
I Am a Pencil

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: ROCKVILLE, Md.

 BODY:
One sign, up near the stage in the amphitheater, reads "Stills," inviting not moonshiners but still photographers.
Another, near good seats in the center, proclaims "Cameras," for the TV medium. 
 Behind them, the view largely blocked, is the designation "Radio and Pencils," which was where I took a seat at yesterday's Clinton rally at Montgomery College in Maryland.
What a deliciously archaic synecdoche: pencils, to stand for "the writing press," much as head is the part used for the whole of "cattle." Most of the pencils around me take notes with laser-point pens or hand-held recorders or laptop computers and would not know a lead pencil from an antique quill, but the figure of speech is apt and original to this campaign.
I am a pencil. So is the 10-year-old boy sitting in the row below, laboriously writing an essay while we await the arrival of the candidate. I can make out the large block letters at the top of the page on his composition pad: "A Saga of Carnage," presumably about Hurricane Andrew; it is unlikely his topic is the plight of the Bosnians or Somalis.
The school chosen to be the setting for the day's public campaign event is the two-year community college in Montgomery County, Maryland, a wealthy area in a Democratic state. It has good facilities and teachers, superb jewelry-making and crafts courses, and is close enough to Washington D.C. to provide a useful suburban backdrop for a stump speech with emphasis on education during a day of political huddles.
The crowd is a couple of thousand nice people on a pleasant day. Many are bedecked in badges, festooned in ribbons of momentary authority.
Governor Clinton ambles in. I remember Richard Nixon explaining how a political leader should make an entrance, striding into a room or onto a stage briskly and authoritatively, taking charge -- but that's not the Clinton style. He eases his way to the platform, almost sleepily listens to the introductions, and embarks on his speech in a folksy way.
What's good about his stump speech is this: Clinton speaks from notes but does not read at an audience, in contrast to President Bush, who is chained to his ever-changing text. The repeated Democratic mes- sage is health care, education, the new economy -- positive themes, delivered in a non-threatening way. He scored a mild point by deriding last year's 23 percent bloating of the White House staff.
The general impression is that this guy means well and is not likely to do much harm, which befits a front-runner's strategy of playing not to lose.
What's not so good about the Clinton stump speech is this: He won't win by playing not to lose. He must sharpen and toughen his assault on the present deadness in the water, and stop calling it the status quo. He has to learn to bring people out of their seats.
Unlike President Bush, who knows how to capitalize on current events, Mr. Clinton does not use a new fact to work himself into some passion. He briefly cited that day's economic news -- that personal income in real dollars had declined last year -- but with quicker staff work, could have made that shocker the centerpiece of his speech and made the network news with his most effective message: Times are tough.
The unwary Clinton, pleased that the Bush family-values balloon has failed to rise, may be stepping into a generational trap. Mr. Bush charges that Democrats will raise taxes, striking fear into wage-earners; Mr. Clinton is counter-charging that Republicans will cut services, frightening retirees. Workers outnumber retirees; if these are the battle lines, Bush will win.
Here in the amphitheater, candidate Clinton is wrapping up, charging wonkily that the country is "undereducated, underorganized, underinvested and underled."
I'm underwhelmed. So is the kid doing his homework, who has made good progress with "A Saga of Carnage."
But the campaign is just getting started; the opposing candidates are sparring, not yet slugging; we undecideds are in no rush to make a decision; and the political carnage lies ahead. It's a great time to be a pencil.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Don't Pity Japan's Part-Time Rice Farmers;
Rejecting Profligacy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Japan's Broken Pledge of Change Comes Back to Haunt Its Economy" (front page, Aug. 15): From the 1970's, the United States has admonished Germany and Japan to jump-start a lagging world economy by importing and consuming with American abandon.
In the early 1980's, the Reagan Administration showed the way with munificent tax cuts and military expenditures, turning the country into the world's largest debtor nation. The demise of the cold war nullified most of the investment in military hardware, and research and development programs like "Star Wars"; massive deficits also prolong the recession. 
 Japan, fortunately for its economy and the world's, would have none of this profligacy. Its federal budget shows a rare surplus among the richest countries, enabling it to finance an increased public-works program of $48 billion to bolster a slowing economy. The slowdown has adversely affected corporate profits, leading not to massive layoffs, as in America, but to less private capital spending.
Meanwhile, Japanese foreign aid (grown to United States levels) and corporate direct investments have helped turn East and Southeast Asia into one of the most dynamic regions in the world. Germany is attempting a similar transformation in Eastern Europe, so far without much support from a highly indebted Washington.
In a capital-starved world with actual starvation in parts of Africa and Asia, it borders on the barbaric to advocate that a major dispenser of foreign aid and investment funds like Japan should instead switch to consuming the output of other wealthy nations.
 
LESLIE S. HIRAOKA
Professor of Management Science
Kean College of New Jersey
Union, N.J. Aug. 18, 1992

HEADLINE: 3 Haitians With H.I.V. Are Allowed to Enter U.S.

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2

 BODY:
Waiving regulations that bar foreigners with the virus that causes AIDS from entering the United States, the Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization has allowed three infected Haitians held at the United States Navy base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, to come to American hospitals for treatment.
The decision to grant the Haitians "humanitarian parole" is the first breach in a wall of rules, policies and court decisions that have combined to trap nearly 300 Haitians at Guantanamo because either they or a family member on whom they depend has tested positive for H.I.V. 
 All these Haitians were initially determined to be eligible to enter the United States to apply for asylum because they had demonstrated a plausible fear of persecution in immigration interviews. Haitian refugees who could not demonstrate such a threat have been returned.
But because these Haitians tested H.I.V. positive, they were left behind when others were moved to Miami to apply for asylum.
The Haitians at Guantanamo are becoming increasingly restive. They have staged three demonstrations since mid-July, two of them violent. In the most recent one on Saturday, buildings were destroyed by a mob trying to free fellow refugees who had been detained and quarantined for earlier acts of violence.
A 1987 rule that bars entry into the United States to foreigners who have tested positive for H.I.V. has drawn wide criticism and recently led to the shift of a conference on AIDS to Amsterdam from Boston when some participants were not granted visas.
The three Haitians for whom the rule was waived include a man sent to Bethesda Naval Hospital for the treatment of an eye fungus about 10 days ago and a mother and baby evacuated to a children's hospital in Norfolk, Va., on Tuesday night because the child had pneumonia and needed a respirator. They are expected to remain in the United States. Once on American soil, they have the right to legal counsel.
More than 37,000 Haitians were intercepted at sea by the Coast Guard as they fled Haiti after the September 1991 coup that overthrew the elected Government of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide. More than a quarter of them, 10,736 people, were able to convince immigration officials who interviewed them aboard ships at sea or at Guantanamo that they could face persecution if returned.
This extremely high proportion of Haitians qualifying for formal asylum hearings, which must take place on United States territory, was widely seen as a contradiction of arguments by the Bush Administration that most were economic migrants looking for a better life.
Some Administration officials apparently accused the Immigration service of being too lenient.
On May 24, President Bush directed that all Haitians picked up at sea be sent back to Port-au-Prince, the capital, without a hearing.
The first parole order issued on humanitarian grounds by the I.N.S. Commissioner, Gene McNary, was for Rigaud Milenette, 26 years old. The request to move him was made several weeks ago by the Navy, which sought specialist treatment for his eye condition.
Mr. Milenette was treated at Bethesda Naval Hospital, then moved to the Varick Street immigration detention center in Manhattan, where he is expected to apply for asylum. The still-unidentified woman and child are at the Children's Hospital of the King's Daughters in Norfolk, Va.
Arthur C. Helton, refugee project director for the Lawyers' Committee for Human Rights, which is trying to arrange legal counsel for Mr. Milenette, said: "While it may be politically awkward for the Administration, the decision to parole the H.I.V. Haitians is an appropriate humanitarian response It perhaps signals a willingness by the I.N.S. to respond to the plight of these Haitians in a humane fashion."
The Milenette case is seen as a test by lawyers who believe that other Haitians who are H.I.V. positive may develop full-scale AIDS or may have other medical problems for which they need treatment in American hospitals.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 5, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Thursday about an Immigration and Naturalization Service decision to grant visas to three Haitian refugees with the virus that causes AIDS misstated the reason why a recent international conference on the disease was moved from Boston to Amsterdam. It was because the United States had rejected a blanket request from conference organizers to change its policy barring H.I.V.-positive people from entering the country, not because some conference participants were denied visas.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Sales rose 9.2 percent for domestically built cars and light trucks in late August. Analysts said demand for cars was flat, but purchases of mini-vans, sport utility vehicles and other light trucks for personal transportation sent that category up 24.2 percent. [D1.]
Small businesses were the hardest hit by Hurricane Andrew, said I.B.M.'s general manager in South Florida, whose own home was devastated. But the damage will take weeks to assess. [D1.] 
 Retail sales meandered up slightly in August, with discounters and value merchants attracting the most shoppers. [D1.]
New claims for jobless benefits held near a two-year low in mid-August for the second consecutive week, the Labor Department said, offering hope that the job market is perking up. [D2.]
An expected plea bargain was aborted in the Southampton insider securities trading scandal, by a judge's vacation. [D12.]
 
Markets
The Treasury will award securities at a single price and yield in a year-long test of a new auction technique. The new process, to begin later this month, follows last summer's Treasury bidding scandal at Salomon Brothers. [D1.] With California's $57.4 billion budget signed, the state entered the market with $3.3 billion of one-month notes to pay past-due bills and salaries. [D12.]
Stocks closed slightly higher, but well below the day's peak as traders turned cautious ahead of the August employment report. The Dow industrials closed up 1.89 points at 3,292.20. Japanese stocks soared. [D6.]
Natural gas prices rose sharply, following Government reports of serious hurricane damage to gas-producing fields in the Gulf of Mexico. [D13.] The dollar and gold both rose. [D13.]
 
Companies
Chrylser, finding a minor defect in its crucial L/H sedan, tried to recall the first 4,000 cars quietly, lest a public announcement jeopardize sales. Then a reporter found out. [D3.]
G.M. said there would be no bonuses for its 95,000 salaried workers in North America. Separately, the automaker and a U.A.W. local in Lordstown, Ohio, agreed that future layoffs because of sluggish demand would hit workers in Ramos, Mexico, first. [D3.]
A $21 million settlement was agreed to by Sandoz and Baxter International's Caremark. They were sued by 33 states because of annual charges of $8,944 for clozapine, a schizophrenia drug. [D3.]
Ames Stores cut second-quarter losses to $36.2 million from $46.5 million a year earlier by slashing expenses and reducing interest before filing for bankruptcy protection. [D3.]
Victor Posner agreed to sell half of his shares in DWG, a soft drink, restaurant, textile and propane company, to Trian Group L.P. for $71.8 million. He will exchange the remainder into nonvoting preferred stock, and resign as chairman. [D3.]
GTE plans to sell nearly $1 billion of newly issued shares to the public. It is the nation's largest local-telephone company. [D3.]
Boeing will scale back 757 jetliner production, making seven of the mid-size aircraft a month, down from eight and a half. [D4.]
Kevin Maxwell was declared bankrupt by a British court, as part of an effort to recover hundreds of millions of dollars that he is accused of helping his father, the late Robert Maxwell, loot from the Maxwell media empire's pension funds. [D4.]
 
Today's Columns
Bargain hunters in European bond markets are betting that the dream of European monetary union will survive when France goes to the polls in two weeks and bidding up prices of E.C.U. bonds. With rates still at 9.65 percent, buy-and-hold investors could benefit regardless. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D6.]
In Florida, banks, insurance companies and other service marketers are using informative ads in the wake of Hurricane Andrew, rather than the self-congratulatory warm and fuzzy spots that followed previous disasters. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D6.]

HEADLINE: Sewer Districts Are Faulted on Pollution

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 3

 BODY:
Warning that rising levels of nitrogen are killing marine life in Long Island Sound, environmentalists gathered here this morning and accused shoreline sewer districts of stalling on an agreement with Connecticut to reduce nitrogen pollution from sewage-treatment plants.
While praising Connecticut for meeting the standards set in a pact with New York State a year ago, the environmentalists said sewer districts in New York, from Westchester to Suffolk County, were dragging their feet by calling for more hearings and more costly studies. 
 "Long Island Sound is dying," said Jeffrey Fullmer of the Citizens Campaign for the Environment. "This unmatched natural and economic resource has been slowly degraded and abused to the point where much of the life that inhabits its waters is now, quite literally, gasping for breath due to severe hypoxia."
 
End to Opposition Urged
 Nitrogen from sewage-treatment plants has been identified by marine biologists as a primary contributor to hypoxia, a condition in which low levels of oxygen kills bottom-dwelling marine life. Nitrogen levels can be reduced they said, by storing the effluent for a longer period before discharging it. For most plants, however, such action requires building additional storage tanks.
Mr. Fullmer urged local officials to drop their opposition to cleanup measures and join in seeking state and Federal funds to improve sewage-treatment plants.
His remarks were applauded by other environmentalists and several baymen at the small gathering near the boat ramps here in Roosevelt Park. But at least one man standing at the fringe was not pleased.
David Layton, one of three commissioners of the Oyster Bay Sewer District, objected to the group holding its meeting in the park, with Oyster Bay Harbor in the background.
He described the demand for a cap on the release of nitrogen as "environmental glitz" and said it was "not fair to ask local taxpayers to pay for something that had yet to be proved was totally necessary." Besides, he said, the Oyster Bay sewer district is meeting its 1990 nitrogen cap.
Discharge permits for each sewage district are issued by the State Department of Environmental Conservation. The state sets the effluent limitations and requires compliance. But a district can request hearings on matters concerning discharge permits, a procedure the environmentalists fear will be used to delay the capping of nitrogen levels.
In Albany, Robert Bendick, the department's Deputy Commissioner for Natural Resources, said he had sent letters to all nine districts seeking hearings, offering to negotiate settlements, which he said would avoid "further costly delays." So far, he said he had received no replies.
He said the state was able to help a district in Westchester secure a Federal grant to upgrade its plant. He said that other districts could apply for funds, at 3 percent interest, made available under a program recently signed into law by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. In addition, he said the Governor's economic development bond act would make funds available if it is approved by voters in November.

HEADLINE: Businesses Reeling From Storm

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CORAL GABLES, Fla., Sept. 3

 BODY:
For Tony Romero, the general manager of I.B.M.'s operations in South Florida, Hurricane Andrew was as much a personal hardship as a business challenge. His spacious white-stucco house overlooking Biscayne Bay, several miles south of I.B.M.'s regional office here, is now a battered, mud-caked wreck.
The surge from the storm shattered the bolts on his front door. The living room furniture lies broken like kindling against one wall. The hurricane ripped down his ceilings, toppled walls and spread a thick layer of mud everywhere. "As you can see, I've lost everything here," Mr. Romero said. 
 But this week, Mr. Romero was back on the job, helping I.B.M. families recover and working with hundreds of I.B.M. customers, from large corporations to tiny companies, whose businesses were hit by Hurricane Andrew. And during an afternoon stint on the road with Mr. Romero, surveying the damage, he offered a judgment of the hurricane's impact on his customers and the danger it poses to South Florida's $85 billion-a-year economy that echoes the consensus heard in the last few days from business people and government officials.
 
Burger King Hit
 Some big companies, like the Burger King Corporation, were hit hard. Yet large corporations are the ones with deep pockets, ample manpower and backup disaster programs that should enable them to make it through without lasting damage to their business.
But, Mr. Romero says, it is the small businesses whose fortunes are most in doubt now. "It will be in the next few weeks that we really know how badly some of our small-business customers were hurt," he said, driving past a strip of boarded-up commercial buildings. "A lot of them are still struggling to find shelter for their families. They haven't gone back to their offices, shops and stores yet."
The Beacon Council, the economic development agency for Dade County, estimates that up to 7,800 small companies, employing more than 50,000 workers, are in danger of going out of business in the next couple of months unless they receive emergency funds and logistical help to get up and running quickly. "The greatest risk to this economy is that we will lose huge numbers of small businesses," said John Anderson, president of Beacon Council, a government-business partnership.
The concern is well founded. In South Florida, it is mainly small companies in service industries -- wholesalers, retailers, financial and business services -- that generate most of the economic activity and jobs. Nearly 95 percent of the 60,000 companies in Dade County employ 50 or fewer workers, and 75 percent of the total have 10 or fewer. Sixty-five percent of the 840,000 workers in the county are employed in wholesale and retail trade and business and financial services, according to John Godfrey, chief economist of Barnett Banks Inc., the state's largest bank.
To help small businesses, especially in south Dade County, the area hit hardest, the state announced today that the Beacon Council would be granted $10 million in state funds to provide interest-free, six-month emergency loans of up to $25,000 each. The council says that many of the loans could be for as little as $5,000 to $10,000. Most important, council officials say, is to have an expedited procedure for disbursing the funds in a few days rather than the weeks or longer it can take to go through the paperwork for Federal disaster relief.
A business will qualify for quick cash if it can show it was a going enterprise before the hurricane. "We're trying to break the rules to help save businesses," Mr. Anderson explained. "Time is short for many of these firms -- they can't wait 60 to 120 days."
 
Teetering on the Edge
 Ursula Vaccaro, the president of Tops Plus Inc., a three-person specialty advertising company that supplies big companies with everything from coffee mugs bearing the corporate logo to sales awards, is one of the small companies teetering on the edge. The roof was blown off her warehouse and office in Kendall, a town a few miles north of Homestead, and the rains destroyed more than $10,000 worth of inventory and office equipment.
For now, Ms. Vaccaro is trying to keep her business going, working by telephone from the bedroom of her storm-damaged house, redirecting shipments and getting in touch with customers nationwide. A single mother who supports two children, she has a slender savings account that will not support the business without emergency funds and a temporary location, until her business is repaired. "This is not the kind of business where you have a lot of working capital," she said. "We live from week to week."
Nearby, Tony Mears runs a bigger business, but has similar problems. He is the president of the Sharon Lawrence Company, a nine-employee enterprise that supplies bathroom accessories, from toilet seats to shower curtains, to specialty retailers. The company did both light manufacturing and marketing from the 5,000-square-foot building it leased. The company had sales of more than $300,000 a year, but Mr. Mears estimates the storm damage at more than $50,000.
Mr. Mears needs to get his building repaired and power restored quickly if the business is to survive. Meanwhile, his nine employees are not being paid. "I'd like to, but I can't," he said.
At big companies, Hurricane Andrew has been more a manageable hardship than a struggle for economic survival. Particularly, the companies that supply the infrastructure of business, like I.B.M. or the Atlanta-based BellSouth Corporation, moved almost as soon as the winds eased, to dispatch people, food, trucks and cash to their local employees and to attend to customers' problems.
Linda Isenhour, for example, is the network manager for BellSouth, the regional telephone company providing service in Dade County. She is in charge of restoring the phones here and managing nearly four times the normal load of calls while working nearly round-the-clock even though she lost her home to Hurricane Andrew. "I've been working most days from 5 A.M. to 11 P.M. to try to keep up," she said.
At I.B.M., the company has all but set up its own privately stocked economy. Food has been brought in and a tractor-trailer with 40,000 pounds of scarce ice is parked behind the office in Coral Gables. Teams of volunteers found new housing for suddenly homeless I.B.M. families. Mr. Romero and his family are now residing in a company-provided house in Fort Lauderdale. "I.B.M. took care of my wife and two children while I went back to work," Mr. Romero explained.
One job Mr. Romero has tackled is helping to get Burger King's worldwide computer network up and running again. The fast-food company's headquarters overlooking Biscayne Bay, near the town of Perrine, was gutted by the hurricane. The company's data processing center, where four I.B.M. mainframes churn away, is in a separate building about six miles inland from the headquarters. It lost its roof and suffered water damage.
 
Temporary Offices
 Burger King's 16-member support staff for personal computers and point-of-sale equipment, which helps the outlets with computer questions, has moved from the headquarters to temporary office space at I.B.M.'s building in Coral Gables. And about 80 people from Burger King's data center, software maintenance engineers and systems specialists, are about to move into a floor in the I.B.M. building temporarily.
Though scattered, the Burger King data center staff should be operating pretty much normally by next week. "I'm surprised we're getting back up so quickly," said Robert Ramsden, Burger King's vice president for information systems.
I.B.M. could make room for the Burger King staff partly because its own local work force has been sliced by 18 percent in a little more than a year, to 630, as part of the computer giant's sharp cutbacks worldwide. And for his part, the 42-year-old Mr. Romero sees an intangible payoff for the company resulting from the hurricane as people worked in pickup teams to help each other and customers.
"For the past two weeks there have been no individual agendas around here, only a corporate agenda and I.B.M. family agenda," he said. "It sounds strange but I think this experience has been terrific for I.B.M. here."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
9.2% Rise In Sales Of Vehicles

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 3

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks rose 9.2 percent in late August. Analysts said automotive demand, although still on the sluggish side, was influenced more than ever by consumers who chose mini-vans, sport utility vehicles and other light trucks instead of cars for personal use.
In late August car sales were flat, while light-truck sales rose 24.2 percent. The seasonally adjusted annual rate of car sales was 5.9 million for the Aug. 21-31 period, compared with 6.2 million last year and 6.2 million in the middle of August. 
 But automotive analysts noted that sales of light trucks, imported and domestic, were up 17.9 percent, to 397,884, for the entire month, while car sales dropped 3 percent, to 648,664, in the corresponding period. Over all, vehicle sales for the month of August rose 4 percent, to 1,046,548.
"Demand weakened in July," said Harvey Heinbach, automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch in New York. "It's not getting any worse; it's not getting any better. It just looks a lot worse if you concentrate on cars only."
John Casesa, automotive analyst for Wertheim Schroder & Company, said light trucks were slightly more than 20 percent of total automotive purchases in 1981. Last month, light trucks were more than 38 percent of vehicles purchased.
For the last few months, retail car dealers have said they have not been able to discern a demand pattern. Nor have sales developed momentum: A few weeks of strong sales suddenly are followed by few buyers, or vice versa. "We just scratch our heads and wonder if everybody gets together and says let's buy a car, or, as we say here, maybe it's the full moon," said Dick LaGruth, who sells General Motors brands in Pine City, Minn.
The Big Three continued to take market share from Japanese brands in August. G.M., the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation cumulatively captured 68 percent of car and light-truck sales, up from 64.2 percent last August. Japanese brands, meanwhile, captured 26.8 percent, down from 29 percent a year ago. Other import brands dropped to 5.2 percent of the market, from 6.8 percent last year.
 
Market Shares Shift
 In the car market, including imports and domestics, G.M.'s share of the market slipped, while Chrysler and Ford gained. G.M.'s sales dropped 7.1 percent from a year earlier to 198,172, while Ford's car sales increased 8.1 percent, to 139,964. Chrysler car sales rose 7.7 percent, to 52,763.
Robert L. Rewey, Ford's vice president-sales operations, said because interest rates on car loans were the lowest since Ford began that business in 1959, "our dealers remain optimistic about their potential for further sales and share improvement in the months ahead." He singled out the Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable, among car lines, for particularly strong sales.
Among Japanese auto makers, the Honda Motor Company's car sales slipped 7.6 percent, to 72,045; the Toyota Motor Corporation's car sales slipped 4.6 percent, to 66,278, and the Nissan Motor Company's car sales rose 1.8 percent, to 39,821. All Honda's models, except the Honda Prelude and Acura Integra, were below last August. Japanese auto makers have been hurt by price increases taken partly in response to the weak dollar.
In light trucks, Ford gained market share, while G.M. and Chrysler lost slightly.

HEADLINE: Officials Seek More Ferries To Manhattan

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
In a vision of hydrofoils and catamarans whisking commuters across New York's waterways, officials said yesterday that they were asking private companies to provide new high-speed commuter ferry lines between Manhattan and eight terminals across the city and suburbs.
Under the plan, announced jointly by the Dinkins and Cuomo administrations, the ferries would provide commuter service to communities including Oyster Bay, L.I., Nyack in Rockland County and Yonkers and Rye in Westchester. 
 Since the mid-1980's, private ferry operators have made large investments in new service from docks in Manhattan to La Guardia Airport in Queens, Bay Ridge in Brooklyn and the New Jersey shore of the Hudson River. Yesterday's announcement represents the first concerted effort by the city and state to expand service elsewhere in the region.
Under the proposal, the city and state would designate routes and provide piers and terminals at little or no cost to ferry operators. But government "is not contemplating operating subsidies," according to a formal request for proposals, which is being distributed among shipping companies and ferry operators.
 
A Question of Affordable Fares
 How much of the ambitious plan will become reality remains to be seen. The key question is whether, without government subsidies, ferry operators can offer service at a price commuters will pay.
One new private ferry line, linking the St. George terminal on Staten Island to Pier 84 on the West Side of midtown Manhattan, is clearly the most likely to succeed because $12 million in Federal financing has already been committed to the project.
Without public subsidy, ferry services have proven risky ventures. Unless they can lure a high volume of passengers and justify frequent trips, they must charge unattractively high prices. Of a dozen private services that have started serving New York City since 1990, four have failed.
One success has been the Port Imperial Ferrybus line, serving downtown Manhattan for $5 one way, and midtown Manhattan for $4 one way, from Weehawken since 1986. It has more than 8,000 riders a day.
Vince Baglivo, a spokesman for the line's owner, Arthur E. Imperatore, said yesterday, "Our system continues to grow, and that speaks well for the potential of other new service." He said Mr. Imperatore might consider submitting a proposal to operate one or more of the new routes.
 
Sixteenfold Increase in 6 Years
 Proponents of the plan can point to a rapid increase in ridership on private ferry services started over the last eight years, particularly those plying the Hudson River between Manhattan and New Jersey. From 1986, when the ferries carried less than 1,000 passengers a day, New York State officials said ridership grew to over 16,000 people a day in July.
The plan was created by the High Speed Ferry Task Force, an advisory panel formed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo a year ago. The group said 70 ferry operators and shipbuilding concerns attended a conference on an early version of the plan in April at the World Trade Center.
The officials said they would set a November deadline for private proposals, and select routes and operators early next year. Some of the new ferry services could begin by the fall of 1993, according to the announcement.
If it succeeds, the plan could help alleviate some of the region's most vexing environmental and economic problems. Any increase in commuting by ferry would reduce traffic congestion and auto emissions, and make better use of long-abandoned piers that have blighted the region's waterfront for decades.
"We must move forward with transportation systems that are environmentally sound," said Mayor David N. Dinkins in a prepared statement.
The plan could also revive some of the maritime activity that has long been lost in New York Harbor, the Hudson River and the East River. When ferry service in the region peaked soon after 1900, it included 125 separate lines.
Ultimately, officials said, the plan may also stimulate a revival of the long-dormant shipbuilding that once thrived in the Brooklyn Navy Yard and elsewhere in Brooklyn and Queens. The state's Urban Development Corporation said it would provide $1.5 million in low-interest loans and other incentives to shipbuilders who start new operations in the city.
If it appears a throwback, the new plan also depends on advanced technology. Officials said they would leave it to private companies to determine what type of ferries work best, but one requirement is speed.
The city and state said they would only consider proposals for ferries that routinely operate at a minimum of 23 miles an hour, and would prefer faster boats that command 34.5 miles an hour. By comparison, the stalwart of New York ferry service, the Staten Island Ferry, chugs to St. George from lower Manhattan at a maximum of 18.4 miles an hour.
Among the sites designated for service outside Manhattan are the Tappan Beach Marina in Oyster Bay; Rye Playland, an amusement park in Westchester; Hunters Point in Queens, the Yonkers Recreational Pier; a site adjacent to the Tappan Zee Bridge in Rockland County; Ferry Point Park in the Bronx; and the Brooklyn Army Terminal or the 69th Street Pier in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.

HEADLINE: In Israel, Cuomo Stresses Economics Over Defense

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Sept. 3

 BODY:
Taking his first look at Israel, both on the ground and from the air, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today that although no one doubts the legitimacy of Israel's security concerns, Israeli leaders may find that solving their economic problems is a more formidable task than protecting themselves from military threat.
To underline that point, the Governor flew by helicopter to the Golan Heights, captured from Syria in the 1967 Middle East War, to see a highly fortified territory that Israel annexed 11 years ago and that most Israelis say they cannot return without undermining their safety. 
 He was aware of the Golan's military significance, he said, "But even if you know the words, knowing the music is something else. I want to stand there and look at it myself." Mr. Cuomo and his wife, Matilda, were on the first full day of a trip that is to last through Saturday.
 
Meeting With Rabin
 The Governor also offered some advice on getting one's fiscal house in order. On that score, he got no argument from Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, with whom he held an hourlong meeting. Mr. Rabin has often said that generating jobs and rebuilding Israel's infrastructure are priorities of his seven-week-old Government.
"Finding work in the private sector for people -- that's Israel's big problem in the long range, probably an even more formidable problem than finding appropriate military security arrangements," Mr. Cuomo said.
In meetings with the country's leaders, Mr. Cuomo focused on economic cooperation between New York State, with its $54 billion annual budget and Israel, whose annual budget is about $40 billion.
Israel's importance to New York State cannot be overstated, he said. Israel buys more than $800 million a year in goods produced in New York, a figure that does not include services like banking and law. With the Israeli Finance Ministry, the Governor announced a new "task force for economic progress" to explore ways of expanding the cooperation.
Mr. Cuomo visited a subsidiary of the AVX Company, a New York designer and manufacturer of electronic components. He also went to Hebrew University to see a demonstration of the New York State Education and Research Network, a high-speed communications system that links researchers in New York, Israel and Germany.

HEADLINE: Jobless-Benefit Claims Stay Near 2-Year Low

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3

 BODY:
New claims for unemployment benefits in mid-August held near a two-year low for the second consecutive week, the Government said yesterday, offering hope that the nation's job market is perking up.
The number of claims increased a less-than-expected 3,000, to 386,000, during the week ended Aug. 22, the Labor Department said. Before the previous week, the claims number had not dipped below 400,000 since October 1990, early in the recession. 
 "We're gradually crawling up from the bottom," said David Wyss, an economist with DRI-McGraw Hill, a forecasting firm in Lexington, Mass.
Two reports on the second quarter -- one on Americans' productivity, the other on mortgage delinquencies -- showed that the economy was struggling.
The productivity of nonfarm workers increased at a healthy seasonally adjusted annual rate of 2 percent, building on an even bigger gain in the first quarter, the Labor Department said.
But economists said the figure largely reflected employers' decisions to defer hiring in a soft economy and to work their existing people harder.
The Mortgage Bankers Association of America said the percentage of homeowners 30 or more days behind on their mortgage payments jumped to 4.77 percent in the second quarter from 4.52 percent in the first three months of the year.
When claims fell to 383,000 during the week ended Aug. 15 from 474,000 the week before, many analysts were skeptical. They said the big swing might have simply been a rebound from a surge caused by a temporary shutdown at General Motors factories. But they were reassured that the improvement held during the latest week.
"It's an important number and if we get one or two more weeks of it, it will confirm that the labor market is stabilizing at the minimum and perhaps moving in the direction of acceleration," said Thomas Carpenter, an economist with ASB Capital Management in Washington.
A moving four-week average of claims, which smooths out the weekly fluctuations, fell to 411,500, from 432,250. It was the lowest in five weeks.
Economists warn, however, that claims will probably surge temporarily after employees working for hurricane-destroyed businesses in Florida and Louisiana file for benefits.

HEADLINE: The Secret Night Life of Wall St.;
After Hours, a Surprising Mix of Work, Noise and Solitude

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER

 BODY:
From the portals of Trinity Church on lower Broadway, you can look down the grand alley of Wall Street and see across the East River to the rooftops in Brooklyn. That's the high sightline, a lovely slice of New York.
But at 5 P.M. no one is looking down Wall Street because everyone is walking up, thousands of people and briefcases, two sidewalks' worth, a purposeful, slightly bedraggled mass of bankers and brokers and lawyers sending as single-minded a message as New Yorkers ever send: Let's get out of here. Let's go home. 
 And in an hour, more or less, all of them are gone, from Wall Street, from the World Trade Center, from Financial Square, leaving behind them the manmade caverns that, according to popular belief, echo with emptiness till dawn.
That was a myth belied this week by the burst water main at South and Broad Streets, which at 1:30 on Tuesday morning forced the evacuation of two buildings, 55 Water and 125 Broad, where -- surprise! -- hundreds of people happened to be at work.
 
People Even Live There
 The Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics keeps no figures on the number of people who work at night in the financial district, but in addition to the white collars working overtime, they include data entry clerks for the financial firms, legal assistants, building maintenance and security people. There is a handful of bartenders and deli workers and a phalanx of limo drivers. And according to the 1990 census, there are 2,215 people actually living there, in the triangle south of Fulton and Vesey Streets, but not including the development at Battery Park City.
Whatever the exact dimensions of the population, a sundown-to-sunup ramble through the area two nights after the water-main break turned up a whole idiosyncratic pocket of street culture. It's very uncitylike, where all the traffic is limousines and garbage trucks (even in deepest night, it's never quiet), where you encounter people one at a time and everyone says hello and will more than likely stop to chat if you ask them to. To judge from a night of such conversations, they tend to be loquacious and amiable and a little melancholy, and, like people in a small town, they seem to share a secret they're proud of.
"It's nice to come out here at 3 A.M.," said Tad Davis, a 27-year-old legal proofreader who was strolling the vast Austin J. Tobin Plaza in the middle of his shift, a lone speck at the base of the twin World Trade towers. "There's a sense of owning the World Trade Center."
A portly, bespectacled man with a long ponytail, Mr. Davis arrived in New York seven years ago from Austin, Tex., he said, with aspirations to be an opera singer.
"But somewhere along the line the reality of making a living hits you," he said, "and you end up doing something ridiculous like this."
 
Working Without Windows
 He works three nights a week from 7 P.M. to 7 A.M., on the 57th floor of One World Trade Center, but in a room without windows. That's why he was taking his break outside. Solitude in such a spectacular setting, he agreed, is a rare and valuable thing.
"By the time we leave in the morning, we're like salmon swimming upstream," he said.
Mr. Davis said things had grown steadily grimmer in the last few years; the decline of prosperity on Wall Street has meant cutbacks in his co-workers, fewer perks. And that was a refrain repeated all night long.
At 1 A.M. yesterday in front of the Broad Gourmet Deli on the corner of Beaver and Broad, a fleet of white limousines -- maybe a dozen -- idled empty and their drivers sat on the street playing cards. They were waiting around for the lawyers or brokers, dozens of stories above them, who would need rides home to Nassau County or New Jersey. But with the mergers and acquisitions market dried up -- the drivers use the jargon -- there aren't as many late-night deals as there once were.
It wasn't all gloom and doom. Before the lights were doused at midnight on the statue of George Washington at 26 Wall (it's where Washington took his Presidential oath in 1789, and where Jon Bon Jovi filmed a rock video at dusk), four young people who described themselves as tourists from Bayside, Queens, pulled up in their car and took pictures of themselves dancing around the statue.
"We heard Bon Jovi was here," said Joel Goldenburg, getting back behind the wheel. "He owes me money."
One of his companions, Pamela Soskin, added: "This is our mission, to harass New York." And they sped off to locations unknown.
"Tourists," said a security guard coming off duty nearby who would give his name only as Ken. The building he works in, 40 Wall, is 71 stories tall and has a prominent spire. "Three times a day people come in thinking it's the Empire State Building."
A few blocks away in front of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, Frank Sherry was just beginning his nightly exercise routine, which features acrobatic stretches and sit-ups on the memorial plaza, among other things. Mr. Sherry, who runs a courier company and works 10 P.M. to 5 A.M., takes an hour and a half every night to work out.
"I've kind of made my own gymnasium out of the neighborhood," he said. "I do my sit-ups here, wherever there's construction I can find a bar to do pull-ups. And I run steps over at the seaport."
Mr. Sherry, 40 years old, lives in Montclair, N.J., but he thinks of this neighborhood as a second home and of himself, apparently, as kind of a small town police chief. "I should tell you about my relentless pursuit of people who urinate in doorways," he said, before jogging into the darkness. "That's my pet peeve."
And one man, Richard Condello, who lives at 3 Hanover Square, was just heading off to a party on the Upper East Side at 2 A.M. He said he relished living in the neighborhood mainly because of its quietude and privacy, but he obviously hadn't met Mr. Sherry. "I could have sex right now, right over there on that bench, and nobody would care," he said. "They might look, but they wouldn't care."
As the night waned, back at 40 Wall, Tony Cestare put it all in some kind of order. Mr. Cestare, for three and a half years the security man from midnight to 8 A.M., has committed the nocturnal flow of events to memory. Surveying the empty street sometime after 3 A.M., he said, without irony, "Wall Street is becoming a ghost town, really." And when a garbage truck stopped to pick up the trash in front of the building, he recalled better days, before 40 Wall lost half its tenants.
"They used to have two trucks stop here," he said.
Mr. Cestare is a former transit policeman with the haircut and compact swagger that recall the actor James Caan -- "Yeah, I've heard that before," he said. He said he prefers night work, "because I'm not into people too much, to tell you the truth."
To all appearances, however, this isn't true. It was he who explained that the flurry of activity between midnight and 12:30 was the cleaning crews getting off work. And it was he who explained the chain of events that takes place nightly beginning at 4 A.M., and signaling the dawn.
It happened just as he said. First the vans arrive, a battalion of them, each towing a coffee cart which is dropped off on a sidewalk. Then the trucks begin -- the milk trucks, the bread trucks, the newspaper trucks. Then the daytime maintenance workers begin to trickle in off the subway.
"The first briefcases," Mr. Cestare said, "show up about 5:30."
Indeed, at 5:35, a gray-haired woman carrying a briefcase, wearing a blazer and a skirt and walking sneakers, got off the subway at Nassau and Wall and headed down the block. It was still pitch dark.
Headed in the door at 60 Wall, the J. P. Morgan building, she wouldn't give her name, nor comment on what it was like to work on Wall Street at night.
"Thank God I don't work at night," she said. "I work during the day."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Higher as Traders Await August Jobless Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against other major currencies yesterday as traders took positions ahead of the unemployment data due today. Gold prices rose.
An announcement by Britain's Treasury that it was borrowing billions to strenghten the pound also brought the dollar higher, said John McCarthy, chief currency trader at ABN-Amro Bank N.V. in New York. 
 "The announcement started traders selling off the German mark," Mr. McCarthy said. The pound and the dollar rose in afternoon European trading after the British announcement.
The mark had been rising against other currencies, pushing the dollar to record lows this week, mostly because German interest rates are several percentage points higher than those in other nations.
Higher rates, along with concern that a planned European monetary union will fall apart and send the mark even higher, have made investors sell other currencies and buy marks.
Traders were waiting for the Labor Department's unemployment figures for August. Mr. McCarthy said a positive report would likely move the dollar slightly higher.
In New York, the dollar closed at 1.4135 German marks, up from 1.3935 late Wednesday. Earlier in Europe, the dollar was quoted at 1.4130 marks, up from 1.3906 late Wednesday.
In New York, the dollar rose to 123.80 Japanese yen, up from 123.10 yen late Wednesday. Earlier in London, the dollar was quoted at 124.05 yen. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 123.03 yen, up 0.40 yen from Wednesday's close, which was the lowest in nearly four years.
In New York, the British pound fell to $1.9835, from $2.0015 late Wednesday. In London, the British pound fell to $1.9825, from $2.0035 late Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Wednesday, included: 1.2635 Swiss francs, up from 1.2425; 4.8120 French francs, up from 4.7500; 1,083 Italian lire, up from 1,066.
On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $340.80 an ounce, up from $338.50 on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
California Gets Back in the Market Quickly

 BODY:
With California's new $57.4 billion budget now signed, the state quickly entered the debt market yesterday to price $3.3 billion of one-month notes that will be used to pay bills and i.o.u.'s to its employees, businesses and local governments not paid since July 1.
The budget crisis lasted 63 days, the longest period ever that the state had been without a budget. 
 Initially, Lehman Brothers priced the California notes due on Oct. 8 at par to yield 3.50 percent, but because of good investor demand the firm was able to reprice the issue to offer a lower yield of 3.40 percent.
According to state officials, the one-month note sale will serve as a bridge loan until the state can sell about $4 billion in notes that will mature next June, the end of the 1993 fiscal year.
Yesterday's note sale was not rated by either Moody's Investors Service or the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
The state will also be seeking a bank letter of credit to back part of the proposed $4 billion note sale, which will be managed by Lehman Brothers as well.
Traders said investors had been kind to California throughout its fiscal crisis, with the state's bonds actually increasing in value in the last few sessions.
For example, California's 6.25 percent general obligation bonds due in 2012 trade at $1,000.40 per $1,000 of bonds, for a yield of 6.213 percent, according to a Bloomberg Fair Value analysis.
While the state's recession has sliced into tax revenues and precipitated the budget crisis, investors still assume that California, with a diverse economy, will always make good on its debts.
Currently the state's long-term debt ratings are under close scrutiny by the rating agencies. They have been lowered twice in the last year. In July, Standard & Poor's downgraded the rating of the general obligation bonds two notches, to A+ from AA. Moody's cut California to Aa from Aa-1.
