HEADLINE: A District That May Not Be Forever

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
A few years ago, the scent of cheese blintzes and the buzz of shop talk and schmoozing filled Berger's Delicatessen and Restaurant long before the first rays of sunlight glinted down West 47th Street. No more. Now, only during normal Manhattan breakfast hours do the counter stools and stackable chairs begin to fill up at this narrow hangout in the diamond district.
This block, the prime distribution center for a nation that buys more diamonds than any other, has suffered its sharpest decline since the trade migrated from Canal Street to midtown after World War II. 
 Falling worldwide demand and the collapse of the country's largest jewelry store chains have left fewer buyers and dealers searching the diamond district's cramped booths and high-security offices for glittering emblems of love.
 
A Suffering Industry
 These sullen economic times have treated few industries as meanly as this secretive enclave, long populated by Orthodox Jews but now increasingly by Asians. Hundreds of cutters and dealers have closed their doors.
Sales of diamond jewelry in the United States, which rose sharply during the 1980's, have declined for the last two years, falling by $600 million, to $10.8 billion, in 1991. The industry foresees no improvement this year.
In the last two decades, the diamond business, buoyed by the newly rich, the hopelessly smitten and the Westernized Japanese, annexed West 46th and 48th Streets. Rents soared past $50 a square foot in the late 1980's, almost to the levels that space sold for a decade before.
Now the district has shriveled back to its original boundaries, West 47th Street between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas. Rents have plummeted, more steeply than elsewhere, to $25 or $30 a square foot, and landlords forbear when tenants fall a month or two behind.
At the diamond district branch of the Merchants Bank of New York, lines used to stretch out past the swinging glass doors on Thursday and Friday paydays. Late last week, the worn velvet ropes inside dangled listlessly; the lone half-dozen customers in line at lunchtime had to wait only a couple of minutes for their turns.
In his 46 years with the bank, Rudolf H. Hertz, the vice chairman, has seen as many downturns in the diamond business as anyone. "This," he said, hunching over his desk as if for protection, "is the most serious one since the 1930's. It's never been like this since the Depression."
Mr. Hertz is one of the people De Beers -- the South African mining giant that rules the diamond cartel -- calls regularly in calibrating its own purchases and sales. Demand is so weak, Mr. Hertz says, that De Beers's 25 percent cutback in purchases of rough diamonds is essential to support prices.
The diamond business is painfully cyclical, he says. In the early 1980's, the price for a perfect 1-carat diamond peaked at about $65,000, only to plunge to $10,000 a couple of years later. Said Michael D. Altman, the branch's chief loan officer and a 28-year veteran himself, "We're talking about a luxury item that in a recession is the first to be hurt and the last to recover."
The industry's loan demand is now so slack, Mr. Hertz said, that the bank's investment portfolio, mostly treasury securities, has grown to $320 million, while loans have fallen to $280 million. Bank credit is essential for dealers to buy rough stones from De Beers and stay afloat while waiting for retailers to make payment.
Sometimes that payment never comes. Mr. Hertz spread the National Jeweler bimonthly on his desk and began reading in a funereal tone: "Zale, Barry's, Birks, Rauch . . ." he said as he started down a list of the retail chains that had filed for bankruptcy protection, closing hundreds of stores. "Our customers don't know who to sell to. They are afraid. They don't want to lose money."
"Especially," Mr. Altman said, "when they owe money to a bank."
When a Zale, with 2,000 stores, closes about 500, that means fewer outlets, fewer salespeople, less advertising to move the stones. Meanwhile, even the healthy chains keep fewer diamonds in inventory, and take longer to pay.
Which is all playing out on 47th Street. "Previous downturns were very, absolutely, totally different," said Martin Rapaport, the rapid-fire publisher of the weekly Rapaport Diamond Report and a diamond broker. "No comparison."
Past slumps came from a weak economy, or speculative booms that pushed a segment of the market -- high-priced investment stones in the early 1980's -- to unreasonable levels.
Now, the decline of the jewelry store chains is compounding the effects of the stagnant economy and the luxury tax, Mr. Rapaport said in a telephone interview, all the while aiming commands at his assistants.
"You are seeing unparalleled change in how the industry is adapting itself to new economic realities," he said. "The mall stores were saying that access to the customer guaranteed sales and high markups. ('Don't even think about what they're offering,' he yelled to a helper. 'It's junk, but try to steal it.') If you opened a thousand stores, you sold a thousand rings. If you opened 2,000 stores, you sold 2,000 rings. The key factor was availability and convenience."
The debt-backed growth binge is now over. "There's less use of credit," Mr. Rapaport said. "The dealer is more conservative, more careful. You pay today, you get the goods."
The diamond district that most shoppers visit -- the sidewalk-level diamond district, with its mazes of stalls the size of diamond chips -- is only the equivalent of a walk-in brokerage office down the street from the New York Stock Exchange.
The real business in this Byzantine industry goes on upstairs, behind triple steel doors, down tight hallways surveyed by closed-circuit cameras. There, billions of dollars worth of diamonds are cut and traded and graded and traded and certified and often set in platinum or gold and finally sold to a retailer. Or shipped abroad, where the cycle can continue.
New York is the funnel through which most of the nation's diamonds pass. Some 98 percent of the nation's diamond cutting takes place here.
On the 10th floor of a nearly anonymous building is the district's nexis, the Diamond Dealers Club. It presents a monochromatic tableau. Bearded men in dark gray knee-length coats sit under gray fluorescent lights at rows of gray tables on gray carpets. They unfold pocket-size paper packets, then gather around to eye the jewels within. In these surroundings, the stones glisten all the more brightly.
Stones are scrutinized, deals made and prices set for the entire industry, all on the basis of handshakes and a Hebrew blessing repeated even by the growing numbers of Indians, Koreans and Thais.
To a visitor, a dealer is likely to repeat a version of the diamond industry's mantra. "As long as there is love . . ." Meyer Herz, a diamond dealer, began, rising from one of the tables as if about to break into song. He stopped in midsentence, then decided to put it more bluntly: "You still have to cut a girl's finger off to get the diamond off."
This year, love at the wholesale level will flicker perhaps 15 percent less brightly. In the club's offices one floor up, Eli Izhakoff, president of both the New York club and the World Federation of Diamond Bourses, says diamond imports will fall from their high of about $4 billion, in 1989, to about $3.5 billion. An aide later calls to say that Mr. Izhakoff meant to be more optimistic: maybe the decline will be slight.
 
Diamond Cutting Goes Abroad
 More and more diamond cutting has gone abroad, to low-wage locales like India, while only the most expensive stones are cut in the United States. Mr. Rapaport estimates that the diamond district had 2,000 cutters in the late 1970's, only 300 today. Last year, only $527 million, or 13 percent, of this country's diamond imports were rough stones.
As in other industries, the merchants and managers blame tight-fisted bankers for their troubles, even as the bankers blame the borrowers.
"Our industry is not overleveraged; it's not overinventoried," said Eli Haas, the secretary of the Diamond Dealers Club. "As I told my banker lately, you have to lend money somewhere, or you're out of business."
With few retail customers still able or willing to buy some bauble on a whim, the diamond district's merchants say they are sustained by the soon-to-be-married.
However they got engaged, the shoppers leaning against the counters, squinting at the rings, are in no passionate rush to buy. They comparison-shop, they hem, they haw, until salespeople feel like jumping out from behind their counters and shaking them.
Yamasheta Wilson recently spent three months shopping for a 1.7-carat engagement ring. "I shopped on Canal Street, on Fordham Road, and in the diamond district," he said. He bought in Atlanta.
Now that he's looking for wedding bands, the diamond district, in the person of Victoria Krugleck, desperately wants him back.
She showed him and his fiancee wide rings and narrow rings, rings with diamond chips and rings with engagement-size stones, rings contemporary and rings traditional.
"They don't have to match," Mr. Wilson assured Ms. Krugleck. "The only things that have to match are the kids."
The fiancee, "Patricia I-go-by-Wilson," lowered her voice when she said she's a lawyer, for fear that the scent of disposable income might tempt Ms. Krugleck to drive a harder bargain.
As the couple admired rings set with tiny diamonds, $250 each, Ms. Krugleck made her offer: "$450 total for both rings."
"I still have to think about it," Ms. Wilson said.
"$425," Ms. Krugleck said.
More hesitation. Ms. Krugleck rushed out from behind the counter, grabbed their hands and told them she was taking them to a nearby factory. "I'm not trying to be difficult," Ms. Wilson said, meekly following.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
Clinton Predicts Bush Will Trim Social Security

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOMESTEAD, Fla., Sept. 3

 BODY:
Pushing his new class-oriented attack that President Bush secretly plans to "devastate America's middle class and its workers" to pay for tax cuts favoring the rich, Bill Clinton today accused the President of pursuing economic policies that would force him to gut Social Security.
The accusation was not based on any known plans by the Bush Administration but rather on an edifice of inductive and political reasoning: a series of mathematical assumptions worked out by the Democratic Presidential nominee's advisers, based in turn on Mr. Bush's promise to cut taxes while also achieving a savings in Federal spending.
 
Clinton Tours Dade County
 "Two weeks ago at the Republican convention Mr. Bush addressed an anxious people who looked for real answers to our economic problems," Mr. Clinton told leaders of an A.F.L.-C.I.O. meeting in Washington. "But instead of a credible plan, he gave us more incredible promises. In the face of a $400 billion deficit this year he made a promise of another tax cut for the wealthy, then promised everybody else an across-the-board tax cut. He said 'We're going to pay for it with spending cuts and I'll tell you about it later.' " 
 After spending the morning deep into the politics of attack, Mr. Clinton spent the afternoon and evening on the politics of compassion, touring this city and other areas devastated by last week's hurricane in Dade County. Mr. Clinton was punctilious in his care to avoid criticizing President Bush for his response to Hurricane Andrew, while matching Mr. Bush in promising help for the people and places hurt by the storm.
"I did not come here for any political purpose," Mr. Clinton told reporters in Miami. "I do not believe there is a partisan element to this disaster." He barely hinted at criticism, saying at one point, "There may be things we could do, there may be ways we could be better prepared for the next one."
Asked if he would match Mr. Bush in the President's pledge that the Federal Government would finance 100 percent -- as opposed to 75 percent, the normal amount the Government provides -- of the recovery effort for the public infrastructure in South Florida, Mr. Clinton said, "Given the scope of the disaster and the total destruction of the infrastructure, I think it would be appropriate to fulfill the 100 percent requirement." The Federal Government's liability, at 100 percent financing, is estimated at $5 billion to $15 billion.
Likewise, Mr. Clinton strongly suggested that as President, he would repair and reopen the nearly destroyed Homestead Air Force Base, which would cost $500 million to $1 billion. Some military analysts and Congressional Democrats have criticized the President for promising to do this, arguing that the base serves no useful military purpose.
 
'He'll be Forced to Cut'
 In Washington earlier in the day, Mr. Clinton said Mr. Bush's universal tax cut, combined with other Administration proposals like a capital-gains tax cut and allowing parents tax credits for private school tuition, would cost the Federal Government $1 trillion over five years.
To offset this, Mr. Clinton said, Mr. Bush would eliminate farm price supports, tax Medicare benefits, freeze discretionary Federal spending and freeze cost-of-living increases in spending.
"But even if he gets rid of all of it, he'll still need another $324 billion to cut," Mr. Clinton said. He concluded with the triumph of a man who has, at last, pulled a rabbit from the hat: "And then, he'll have no choice. He'll be forced to cut -- even to gut -- Medicare and Social Security."
Judy Smith, a White House spokeswoman, called Mr. Clinton's accusations "absolutely false -- another example of double speak."
"The President said in his address that he's not going to cut Medicaid and Medicare," she said. "He said he was not going to touch Social Security."
In his acceptance speech at the Republican National Convention, Mr. Bush called only for ceilings on the growth of such benefits.
Mr. Clinton wove his Social Security charge into a speech before the cheering and hooting labor leaders in an elaborate bid to turn Mr. Bush's favorite question -- "Can Bill Clinton be trusted?" -- against him.
"Mr. Bush says the election should be about trust, and I believe that's right," Mr. Clinton said, beginning the assault. "But for George Bush to say the election should be about trust is like me saying it should be about short speeches."
Mr. Clinton's appearance before the leaders of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. was a conspicuous, if expected, success for a candidate who was never a favorite of labor groups. Recognizing obvious realities, the delegates offered Mr. Clinton an overwhelming and perfunctory endorsement, cheered Mr. Clinton's applause lines, and did not make impolite noises when he walked the careful line he has made for himself on a subject hardly popular in labor quarters, free trade.
"I want a policy that expands trade in terms fair to the United States," Mr. Clinton said, in explaining his neither-for-nor-against position on the North American Free Trade Act recently negotiated by the Bush Administration. "I hope we can sign the right kind of agreement with Mexico." But he was, he said, just not sure if Mr. Bush's agreement was the right one; keeping to his theme, he sought to turn the question of his ambivalence into a referendum on Mr. Bush's.
"The President has accused me of waffling because I wouldn't support an agreement I hadn't read," he said. "Well, he taught me four years ago I can't read his lips. I'm going to have to read the paper."
Mr. Clinton has been flirting with the issue of "trust" for weeks, but today's speech, in which he incorporated his accusation that Mr. Bush is the plutocrat's President into a larger theme that he is inherently untrustworthy, was his most forceful and coherent exposition of the idea.
The theme of trust seems designed to function both offensively and defensively. Offensively, it addresses the greatest vulnerability of an opponent unforgiven by some voters for breaking his explicit 1988 promise to not raise taxes. Defensively, it addresses, if only in implicit terms, Mr. Clinton's worst problem, the suspicion -- much encouraged by Republicans -- that he is too slick for his own, and the nation's, good.
It is notable that the unveiling of this theme followed immediately one of Mr. Clinton's worst days on the trust front in some time, with the broadcasting of news reports on Wednesday that focused fresh attention on the Democrat's extensive efforts to avoid the draft in the Vietnam War, and on the incomplete explanations he offered of his behavior concerning the draft earlier in the campaign.

Editorials/Op-Ed A20-21

HEADLINE: Fighter vs. Peacemaker As 2 Blacks Seek Seat

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 3

 BODY:
On paper, Diane E. Watson and Yvonne Brathwaite Burke have a lot in common. Born two blocks and less than a year apart in South-Central Los Angeles, both graduated from the University of California at Los Angeles, where they were sorority sisters. Both are black, both are liberal Democrats and both are political fixtures in Los Angeles.
This year, the two longtime friends have become adversaries. In what is viewed as an epochal contest for the region's black voters, Ms. Watson, a 58-year-old state Senator, and Ms. Burke, 59, who was a member of Congress in the mid-1970's, are opponents in a November runoff election for a seat on the powerful Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors. 
 The winner will become the first elected black supervisor in county history. Ms. Burke, who gave up her seat in the House of Representatives in 1978 in an unsuccessful race for State Attorney General, sat on the board in 1979 and 1980 as the appointed successor to a supervisor who had died in office.
Despite the parallels in their resumes, the public personas of the two rivals could scarcely be more different. Ms. Burke, a partner at the staid law firm of Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue, seems better suited to the corporate board room than the hustings. She stresses her ability to work with colleagues and to massage a recalcitrant bureaucracy into compliance. "I'm more interested in effectiveness than in being a firebrand," she said.
Ms. Watson, who relishes a fight, promises "nothing short of revolution in county government." During the Los Angeles riots last spring, she gave voice to the anger felt by many blacks over perceived injustices and accused Police Chief Daryl F. Gates of allowing civil unrest to explode in an attempt to make blacks look bad.
"It's the politics of accommodation versus the politics of confrontation," said Lorn S. Foster, a professor of politics at Pomona College.
Despite their closeness in age, the candidates personify a fairly abrupt generational shift under way in Los Angeles politics, as the cautious black leaders who gained prominence in the 1950's and 1960's give way to a more aggressive, less conciliatory and younger wave of elected officials. "Higher income and older blacks tend to be much more comfortable with Yvonne Burke," Mr. Foster said. "Diane Watson clearly speaks for those, particularly the young, who feel more estranged from politics and from the economic system."
Political scientists believe the riots strengthened the hand of those black politicians who insisted that blacks had been shortchanged by government, continued to suffer from discrimination and must demand to be heard.
"A lot of young black voters turned to leaders, like Diane Watson, who seem as angry as they are," said H. Eric Schockman, a political scientist at the University of Southern California in Los Angeles.
The changes in Los Angeles mirror what is happening around the country, said David A. Bositis of the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies in Washington, a research center devoted to racial issues. "A lot of younger black political activists and leaders look at older black leaders as just sort of blending into the political wallpaper, being part of the power structure, being out of touch," Mr. Bositis said.
He cited the victories this year of Bobby Rush, a former Black Panther leader who unseated a veteran black lawmaker, Representative Charles A. Hayes, Democrat of Illinois, and "a whole crop of new members" in the state legislatures of the South.
 
The Bradley Generation
 The transformation is most pronounced in the Los Angeles area, analysts say, in part because blacks, who account for 14 percent of the population in the city and 11 percent in Los Angeles County, have always been a smaller minority here than in New York and many other major cities. In the 1950's and early 1960's, those demographics fostered a generation of black politicians, including Mayor Thomas Bradley, who tended to keep a low profile and work behind the scenes.
"Tom Bradley and his generation always felt they couldn't afford to alienate white voters," Mr. Schockman said. "They always had to get along with the white power structure, and now, that accommodation looks suspect to a lot of younger blacks. I think what we're seeing with this group of Young Turks is a reaction against that."
For many years, the ambitions of young and middle-aged black politicians in Los Angeles were stifled by the remarkable longevity of their elders. But Representative Augustus F. Hawkins retired in 1991 at the age of 83; Representative Mervyn M. Dymally, 66, who has spent three decades in elective office, decided not to run for re-election this year, and several local officials have either stepped aside or died.
The most visible symbol of the older generation, Mr. Bradley, 74, is the subject of speculation that he may retire after 20 years as Mayor when his term expires next year.
Ms. Watson and Ms. Burke are running for the seat being vacated by Supervisor Kenneth L. Hahn, 72, a white man who has represented most of the county's predominantly black areas since 1952.
Beginning with an angry fist-waving address on the night the riots began, Ms. Watson turned up repeatedly on television, saying the rage felt by rioters was justified.
Ms. Burke insists that she was just as active, just as vocal, but was ignored by reporters. "The press was looking for somebody who was incendiary, not someone who said we've got to solve problems and get along," she said.
The power wielded by the Board of Supervisors will catapult whoever wins the race to the top ranks of black elected officials in California. The five-member board functions as both the legislative and executive branches of an $11 billion-a-year government with nine million constituents and responsibility for services ranging from health care for the poor to law enforcement, sanitation and mass transit.
Both Ms. Burke and Ms. Watson promise to devote more of the county's resources to health care, creation of inner-city jobs and aid to the homeless. Each pledges to wrest power from entrenched bureaucrats. Since being elected last year, Gloria Molina, the first Hispanic supervisor in more than a century, has made confrontation a way of life. Ms. Molina, whose election ended conservative domination of the board, has embarrassed the board into re-examining many of its practices. The election of Ms. Watson would produce more of the same, analysts say. But there is no consensus as to whether her performance would differ much in substance from Ms. Burke's, in light of the similarity in their positions and current fiscal constraints.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Diane E. Watson, right, is running against Yvonne Brathwaite Burke, an old friend and sorority sister from the University of California at Los Angeles, for a seat on the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors. Ms. Watson greeted supporters at a fund-raising event in East Los Angeles. (Theodora Litsios for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: RANKS OF U.S. POOR REACH 35.7 MILLION, THE MOST SINCE '64

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3

 BODY:
The number of Americans living in poverty soared last year by 2.1 million, to a total of 35.7 million, and the poverty rate rose for the second consecutive year, to 14.2 percent, the Government reported today.
The new rate is the highest since the peak caused by the recession of the early 1980's. The actual number of poor people is the highest since 1964, when President Lyndon B. Johnson declared his war on poverty. 
 In a disclosure that may be even more politically damaging to President Bush and his re-election campaign, the Census Bureau also said the purchasing power of the typical American household shrank last year by nearly $1,100. The report provides statistical evidence of the hardship experienced by millions of potential voters.
 
Household Income Dips
 The Census Bureau, in its annual report on income and poverty, said the decline in the purchasing power of Americans was also the second straight as median household income, after adjusting for inflation, fell by $1,077, to $30,126. The number of households above the median is the same as the number below it.
A family of four was classified as poor if it had cash income of less than $13,924 in 1991. The poverty level is updated each year to reflect changes in the Consumer Price Index. While the whole concept of poverty reflects political and social judgments about the amount of money needed for subsistence, the process of calculating each year's poverty levels is a statistical, nonpolitical operation.
The poverty rate tends to move in tandem with the unemployment rate and with the number of people receiving food stamps. Since those indicators have risen sharply in 1992, economists say it is likely that poverty has continued to spread this year.
 
Harsh Words From Clinton
 Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the Democratic candidate for President, cited the new poverty figures in a speech to leaders of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., meeting here today. "This Administration has compiled the worst economic record in 50 years, since Herbert Hoover was President," Mr. Clinton said, "and at Houston we saw what their promise for the next four years is: more of the same."
Mr. Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said the increase in poverty was understandable. "Certainly, I think we have to expect that the recession would have a significant and serious impact on income and on poverty levels," Mr. Fitzwater said. "We have tried to target a number of programs in the last couple of years particularly to those problems, knowing that the recession would have a deleterious effect."
Economists say the recession began in July 1990. Since mid-1991, the economy has shown some signs of growth, but not enough for the official arbiters to declare the recession ended.
In the last two years, the Census Bureau said, the number of poor people increased by 4.2 million, while the proportion of people living in poverty climbed steadily, to 14.2 percent in 1991, from 13.5 percent in 1990 and 12.8 percent in 1989. The data do not include homeless people.
Both the number of poor people and the poverty rate declined from 1983 to 1989.
 
The Toll on Families
 After adjustment for inflation, median household income has declined 5.1 percent since 1989. Household purchasing power is lower now than in 1979, the Census Bureau said.
The report suggests there is ample reason for the concern about the welfare of American families being expressed by politicians of both parties. The number of poor families increased to 7.7 million in 1991, from 7.1 million in 1990, it said. The proportion of families living below the official poverty level rose to 11.5 percent last year, from 10.7 percent in 1990.
Many Republicans have criticized the official statistics on the ground that they do not reflect the value of food stamps, Medicaid, housing subsidies and other noncash benefits. But when the Census Bureau used alternative definitions of income that include the value of such aid, it still found that poverty rose sharply from 1989 to 1991. The data do not show the effects of capital gains, 92 percent of which go to the most affluent fifth of all households.
The Census Bureau report made these points:
*The poverty rate for white people rose to 11.3 percent last year, from 10.7 percent in 1990. The rate rose even for white married couples, considered the most economically secure of all families. For black people, the poverty rate rose to 32.7 percent last year, from 31.9 percent in 1990. For Hispanic people, it rose to 28.7 percent, from 28.1 percent. (Hispanic people may be of any race.) For Asian Americans, the poverty rate rose to 13.8 percent last year, from 12.2 percent in 1990.
*In the last two years, household purchasing power declined 5.5 percent for whites, 5.3 percent for blacks, 8.1 percent for Asian Americans and 5.8 percent for Hispanic people.
*The South still has the highest poverty rate (16 percent), but it is the only region where there was not a significant increase in poverty in 1991. The poverty rate rose last year in seven of the 10 most populous states, including such likely battlegrounds of the Presidential election as California, Florida, New Jersey, New York and Texas.
*In the New York metropolitan area, the poverty rate rose to 14.8 percent in 1991, from 14.3 percent in 1990 and 12.1 percent in 1989. In the Los Angeles area, it went up to 16.6 percent from 15 percent in 1990 and 13.8 percent in 1989.
*While the gap between rich and poor did not widen in 1991, there is a clear long-term trend toward increasing inequality of income. The most affluent fifth of all households got 46.5 percent of all household income in 1991, up from 43.5 percent in 1971 and 44.4 percent in 1981. By contrast, the poorest fifth got 3.8 percent of all income last year, down from 4.1 percent in 1971 and 1981.
The Census Bureau also reported that 35.4 million Americans had no health insurance in 1991, an increase from 34.7 million in 1990. About 29 percent of all poor people said they had no medical insurance of any kind at any time in 1991. By contrast, 11.7 percent of people above the poverty level and 14.1 percent of all Americans said they were uninsured.
One of the most significant measures of economic well-being, real per capita income, declined in 1991 for the second consecutive year, to $14,617, after increasing for seven consecutive years, from 1983 to 1989. This figure measures the average income of all men, women and children in the United States, adjusted for inflation.
Democrats seized the data to support their criticism of President Bush's economic policies. Representative Thomas J. Downey of Long Island, acting chairman of the House Ways and Means subcommittee responsible for many welfare programs, said, "The data underscore the worsening plight of American children."
The poverty rate for children under 18 reached 21.8 percent last year, up from 20.6 percent in 1990 and 19.6 percent in 1989. Poverty is more common among children than among other age groups like the elderly, who had a poverty rate of 12.4 percent last year.
 
Looking Beyond Recession
 Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, the Maryland Democrat who heads the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, said the high rate of poverty could not be completely explained as a result of the recession. "Many people were facing economic distress even before the recession began," said Mr. Sarbanes. "The economic expansion of the 1980's left the poverty rate higher than it had been at the end of the expansion of the 1970's."
Robert Greenstein, director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal research institute, said "a further substantial jump in poverty is virtually certain in 1992" because unemployment is well above 1991 levels.
But Representative Dick Armey, Republican of Texas, said the official data "systematically exaggerate the extent of income inequity and poverty by ignoring almost 75 percent of all government assistance to the poor." He said the Census Bureau had done nothing to adjust its poverty statistics for a huge increase in the number of one-parent families over the last two decades.
The increase in the number of poor families headed by women accounted for nearly two-thirds of the net increase in the number of poor families last year, the Census Bureau said.
If noncash benefits like food stamps and Medicaid were counted as income, the poverty rate would have been 11.4 percent last year, rather than the reported 14.2 percent, the bureau said.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Al Gore;
Gore Lashes Out at Bush On His Iran-Contra Role

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 3

 BODY:
In his sharpest and most personal attack on President Bush since being selected as the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, Senator Al Gore today questioned the President's explanation of his role in the Iran-contra affair, stopping just short of calling him a liar.
In remarks inserted into his basic campaign speech, Mr. Gore repeatedly referred to the President's "credibility canyon" in his handling of the economy and foreign affairs. More significantly, Mr. Gore, for the first time, used the phrase to belittle Mr. Bush's oft-repeated explanation about his part in the Iran-contra affair. 
 Mr. Bush has long asserted that when he was Vice President, he was unaware of the details of efforts undertaken under President Ronald Reagan to secure the release of American hostages in Lebanon by selling arms to Iran and the use of the profits from those sales to finance anti-Communist guerrillas in Nicaragua.
To underscore the personal nature of Mr. Gore's broadside against the President, the Democrat failed to utter his customary line in which he says he does not believe Mr. Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle are "bad people" but are merely following erroneous policies.
 
Doubts by 2 Reagan Aides
 Mr. Gore suggested that the central piece of evidence to question the President's credibility was a recent report that two top Reagan aides who opposed the arms-for-hostages deal did not believe Mr. Bush's statements that he had been kept in the dark about the policy.
"George Bush is still saying he didn't know anything about one of the most controversial policies of the Reagan Administration," Senator Gore said in a speech to the 26th constitutional convention of the United Steelworkers of America here. "Now we have some reasons to wonder about the story George Bush has told."
In addition, the Tennessee Senator criticized Mr. Bush for the decision by Attorney General William P. Barr not to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate charges that Administration officials hampered efforts to prosecute people who helped the Iraqi Government illegally use American agricultural credits to purchase arms.
"The similarities between the two crises are overwhelming," Mr. Gore said after his speech, referring to the Iran-contra affair and the illegal methods that were used to allow Iraq to purchase weapons. "If he refuses to answers questions about the first and refuses to comply with the law and establish a special prosecutor in the second, then it raises extremely serious questions of credibility."
Mr. Gore is raising questions about Mr. Bush's veracity, and, in effect, his character, at a time when new questions have been raised about the explanations by Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic Presidential nominee, of how he was able to avoid being drafted during the Vietnam War. Mr. Gore told reporters that his remarks were not an attempt to deflect the character issue away from Mr. Clinton.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Al Gore addressing the United Steelworkers convention yesterday in Pittsburgh. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Plan to Allow Cuts n Investment Taxes Is Dropped by Bush

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3

 BODY:
The White House today abandoned a proposal, popular among conservative Republicans, to reduce the taxes on profits from investments without consulting Congress. Government lawyers said the plan was unconstitutional.
President Bush had been considering the proposal, which was favored by his new chief of staff, James A. Baker 3d, as part of his search for ways to fill out his economic-policy portfolio for the November election. 
 Under the plan, Mr. Bush would have used his executive powers to reduce the taxes on capital gains by whatever amount that inflation has reduced the gain. Republican strategists hoped such a move would spur the economy and satisfy conservative Republican lawmakers, business executives and columnists who have been increasing pressure on Mr. Bush to take such action.
This morning, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said the proposal was "on the front burner."
But Administration officials said the Justice Department told the White House two days ago that the idea was unconstitutional, an opinion that supported earlier ones by Mr. Bush's chief counsel, C. Boyden Gray, and Treasury Department attorneys.
Mr. Fitzwater later issued a written statement saying that Mr. Bush was no longer pursuing the idea and would seek instead to have the change enacted in legislation.

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Roberta Smith

 BODY:
Behind the summer lull, it's been a tense, tumultuous few months for contemporary-art galleries in New York City. As if enduring its own version of the London blitz, the art world seems to be holding its breath, waiting to see which galleries will still be operating when the dust settles and Labor Day is past.
Although some dealers say they think the art market is stabilizing and perhaps beginning a slow recovery, others are less optimistic. But all of the nearly dozen people interviewed tend to agree that galleries are having widespread difficulties as they struggle to bring 1980's overhead -- especially rents -- into line with the contracted art market of the 90's. 
 Recent months have brought more gallery closings, and certainly more rumors of closings, than any other summer in memory. At least six galleries have closed, most of them relative newcomers in SoHo that concentrated on showing younger or less established artists.
In addition, more galleries than usual have moved over the summer, often lured by lower rents, smaller spaces or more central locations. In a seeming contradiction, some galleries have moved to buildings that other galleries had left: in the soft real-estate market, the new tenants negotiated lower rents. Other galleries have cut back on the amount of space they rent, reduced staff or scheduled fewer but longer-running exhibitions for the new season.
Consolidation and lease renegotiation seem to abound on all fronts. For dealers whose leases were signed during the art- and real-estate booms of the 1980's, negotiating a rent adjustment has become a primary goal. At least one reputable operation, the Jack Tilton Gallery, has broken its lease on West 57th Street to move out and look for more favorable terms. Many more have been embroiled in lease renegotiations for up to a year.
But there are some bright spots. Several galleries report successful rent reductions. The Marlborough Gallery has expanded and renovated its gallery at 40 West 57th Street and is opening a branch in Madrid, an undertaking on which its publicity agent says the gallery "has spent a staggering $4 million, without help from the bank." And the Matthew Marks Gallery, a young gallery that shows a successful mix of blue-chip and new art, has expanded its space at 1018 Madison Avenue, at 78th Street, taking over the second floor, previously occupied by Wittenborn Art Books, which closed. Michel Kohn, a French contemporary-art dealer who has worked privately on the West Coast for several years, is also opening a gallery in that building.
 
Showdown at Fuller
 The Fuller Building, at 41 East 57th Street, for several decades one of Manhattan's most prestigious gallery addresses, is the site of the largest and most intense renegotiation effort. The building, an Art Deco landmark on the northeast corner of Madison Avenue, is home to more than 20 galleries. More than a dozen have banded together and hired a lawyer to try to renegotiate rents that they describe as exorbitant. The group is also looking at other buildings on 57th Street that might be more accommodating.
Interviews with several gallery tenants showed widespread unhappiness with both rents and services in the building, which has been managed by Cushman & Wakefield since 1990. The dealers assert that the building has changed hands so many times in the last decade that they no longer know who owns it. They also say the repeated sales have increased real estate taxes, which are passed on to the tenants on top of rent increases specified in the leases.
"This all started a year ago, when we were charged a $10,000 real estate tax increment," said Diana Burroughs, who with her husband, Jason McCoy, owns the Jason McCoy Gallery, which moved to the building from East 71st Street three years ago. "I know someone in the building who was charged $30,000."
 
Magic vs. Money
 Ms. Burroughs, a member of the tenant group's executive committee, said most galleries in the building were paying "from $42 or $48 a square foot to as high as $60, and the going rate on the street for new tenants is closer to $25 or $30." She went on: "We've lowered our prices on our art; our suppliers have lowered theirs. The Fuller Building is the Fuller Building because we're there. It's got its magic because it's got a bunch of great galleries in it. We may have to do something like the Designers and Decorators building on Third Avenue: find a building and open up a gallery center."
James Goodman, who has had a gallery in the Fuller Building since 1986, said: "If people don't get relief, they are going to move out when their leases are up. We're trying very hard to do this in a professional way, but we're making very little progress."
Andre Emmerich, who has had a gallery in the building for nearly 30 years, called the building and its management "short-sighted in not being more accommodating with art-gallery tenants, many of whom face real economic pressures." He continued: "The building's attitude was very much more cooperative under previous owners. The present landlord, whoever he is, seems to take his role model out of Dickens."
Although none of these dealers would verify it, people outside the group have said that the Crown Building at 730 Fifth Avenue, on the southwest corner of 57th Street, is among the buildings to which the dealers are considering moving. When asked about the Crown Building, Mr. Emmerich would say only: "It certainly is an interesting building with a fine location and a good management, all of which is very inviting. The wonderful thing is there's competition in this world."
Reached by telephone, Christopher Kraus, a leasing agent at Cushman & Wakefield, and Frank Freda, who oversees the Fuller Building's management for the firm, responded that the building had had the same owner for six years and that, as far as they knew, there had been only one other owner in the 1980's.
Mr. Freda also said: "The truth is that the building is providing the same services it has provided for years, and we are in the process of modernizing all our elevators and we've added a security guard. The landlord continues to pursue relief through tax certiorari proceedings every year. It's not the landlord's fault as to the amount of taxes that the city chooses to levy on commercial real estate. We are victims as much as the tenants.
"We met with the group's legal representative and requested financial information with respect to the galleries, which they have failed to supply. They have not requested any further meetings."
Mr. Freda also added that "$25 to $30 a square foot is well below what's being asked for a first-class building like the Fuller Building."
Mr. Goodman responded: "As to services, the security in the building has not been good and they haven't addressed that. The same owner can't have owned it for six years: we got tax increases three years ago because the building was sold. As for financial information, they want an accountant's record of just how painful this is. To divulge that kind of information makes everyone feel very vulnerable."
 
Moving In, and Out
 Despite the Fuller Building's troubles, the Barbara Mathes Gallery recently moved in, taking the third-floor corner space previously occupied by Kent Fine Art. And Joan Washburn, another gallery, has moved out. Mrs. Mathes said that her gallery had been at 851 Madison Avenue for 10 years and that her landlord was "not too accommodating" when her lease came up for renewal. She acknowledged that her rent at the Fuller Building was "'no bargain" but said that "it's less than I was paying uptown, and it's lower than people who signed leases here five years ago, naturally."
She continued: "This is the time for a buyer to buy pictures and the time for a tenant to write a lease. If the art market is going to be tighter and smaller, then it's more important than ever to be centrally located."
Joan Washburn, whose 21-year-old gallery specializing in modern and contemporary American art had been in the Fuller Building since 1986, has moved to a smaller, less expensive space on the eighth floor of 20 West 57th Street. Mrs. Washburn declined to discuss her sudden move other than to describe herself as "a good tenant." She also would not elaborate on the name Lindsay & Thomas, which appears on her new gallery stationery, along with the name Washburn, other than to say that she has found financial backers but is still in complete control of the program.
"This is not a good time for anybody," she said. "There's nothing in the news that indicates that this is going to be an easy year. People have to feel good about themselves to buy art."
Until very recently, Mrs. Washburn's new space was occupied by the Blum Helman Gallery, whose main gallery is still on the building's second floor. Rumors of Blum Helman's demise were rampant this summer, but Irving Blum, who owns the gallery with Joseph Helman, said they were greatly exaggerated. "We have given up the eighth floor," Mr. Blum said by telephone. "But we're simply doing what every other gallery in New York is doing, which is to cut back as radically as we can because things are so shaky. I don't find any growth yet, but I do see some signs of stabilization. However, I think something dramatic will have to happen -- a new style from the artists, a new generation of collectors -- before things can turn around in a big way."
 
On West 57th Street
 A similar pattern of musical galleries can be found at 24 West 57th Street, another important gallery building. One of the oldest contemporary gallery spaces closed when the rent could not be renegotiated, and another gallery moved into the building under extremely favorable circumstances.
From 1961 to 1983, the first one, the third-floor front space with high ceilings, round-cornered rooms and big French windows, was the Betty Parsons Gallery, the dealer of many Abstract Expressionists; in 1983, it became the gallery of Jack Tilton, who was Mrs. Parsons's director from 1976 until her death in 1982. Mr. Tilton moved out suddenly last month after trying to persuade his landlord, the Ronesto Corporation, to reduce his rent from $60 a square foot to $30 for the three years remaining on his 12-year lease. Mr. Tilton said he stopped paying rent eight months ago as a form of leverage on the advice of his lawyer, after he heard that new tenants moving into the building were paying $25 a square foot with a year's free rent and construction costs paid by the building.
While Mr. Tilton said other tenants in the building were able to renegotiate leases at about $30 a square foot, he said the landlord's offer to him never went below $35, probably because he withheld rent.
Speaking for Ronesto, Jay D. Lisnow, executive vice president of Gafisa (USA) Inc., which is Ronesto's managing director in this country, said by telephone yesterday: "Certainly those tenants who thought that withholding rent would be a means of leverage were tenants that we stopped negotiating with."
Does Mr. Tilton regret trying such an aggressive tactic? "Not really," he said. "It took a big part out of me to leave that space. I loved it, but leaving has also opened a whole new life for me and the gallery. And what I can get elsewhere on 57th Street or in SoHo is much cheaper than what they were offering."
Mr. Tilton has moved to an office in the Cable Building, at 611 Broadway, at Houston Street, where he is dealing privately. He is looking at spaces and says he plans to reopen in late fall.
Mr. Tilton and his landlord are in court, but negotiations continue. Mr. Tilton said he had offered to pay a portion of his back rent to Ronesto, which seized some office equipment after he informed it of his intention to move out.
 
A New Tenant
 The new tenant in the building is the Mary Ryan Gallery, which concentrates on contemporary prints and drawings. Last month, after 10 years on the Upper West Side, Mrs. Ryan opened her gallery on the building's second floor with a retrospective of Lucian Freud's prints (review on page C17). She denied that her new landlord had paid any of her considerable construction costs. Her rent, she said, is about $25 a square foot, but that figure does not include real estate taxes and yearly increases. She said she had received a year's free rent. "Business is tough," she said, "but this is a great time to expand. I'll be paying about the same for four times as much space, and I'm much more centrally located."
Commenting on both Mr. Tilton's and Ms. Ryan's statements, Cid Keller, chief executive of the Promenade Real Estate Corporation, which manages the building for Ronesto, said: "It's very difficult to make comparisons when you have completely different spaces. Mary Ryan has no windows and is on the second floor. Another gallery, Sherry French, has the front space on the second floor and a lease signed in April 1991, and they pay much more than $25 a square foot. And there's another important issue: when the market goes up, can I go back to the tenant and say 'Your space is worth more now, so you have to pay more rent'?"
 
SoHo: A Toll on Youth
 The gallery situation in SoHo, traditionally the haven of younger artists and dealers, seems especially volatile this summer. Several galleries have closed, but some have moved and there are even a couple of new arrivals.
For example, Hirschl & Adler Modern, which, like Barbara Mathes, was a tenant at 851 Madison Avenue, has moved downtown to 420 West Broadway, the area's oldest gallery building, which is near Spring Street. The gallery took over the fourth floor, recently vacated by the 49th Parallel, an alternative gallery supported largely by the Canadian Government. Donald McKinney, Hirschl & Adler Modern's director, says he has doubled his space for "basically the same rent I paid uptown."
Paul Kasmin, who has had a small gallery at 580 Broadway, near Prince Street, for three years, is moving to a larger ground-floor space at 74 Grand Street. He said he will be paying "one-third more rent for twice the gallery space, plus a basement and my own entrance," a situation that he describes as "definitely more interesting."
The Daniel Newburg Gallery, next door to Mr. Kasmin at 580 Broadway, has closed and may reopen near him on Grand Street, Mr. Kasmin and others in the art world said. Mr. Newburg did not return telephone calls, but one of the owners of 580 Broadway, Richard Feldman, confirmed that Mr. Newburg had moved out and that his former gallery has been rented to Achim Kubinski, a contemporary-art gallery from Stuttgart, Germany.
The Christine Burgin Gallery, at 130 Prince Street, one of SoHo's most expensive buildings, has closed. Ms. Burgin said she was thwarted less by high rents than by shipping costs, since she shows mainly European artists. "For the last two years, I've thought only about business and not about art," she said. "I'm going to try to organize shows for the artists I work with, without having a formal gallery, by using different spaces around the city."
The Diane Brown Gallery, which only last year moved to 23 Watts Street, has also closed. Ms. Brown said she had "a dream landlord" but that "overhead and revenues were not consistent."
"I intend to stay involved and am considering several options," she said.
 
A Slogan Is Coined
 Other closings include the Jamison-Thomas Gallery at 588 Broadway and the Berland-Hall Gallery at 579 Broadway, both near Prince Street. Reached for comment, one of Berland-Hall's owners, Sue Berland, said: "People are really not supporting younger artists right now. Yet it still costs just as much to show them as more mature artists."
The Bess Cutler Gallery, previously on Mercer Street, has relocated to a less expensive space on the third floor of 379 West Broadway, near Broome Street.
And the Pat Hearn Gallery has successfully renegotiated its lease on the three-story building at 39 Wooster Street, which it has occupied since 1988, relinquishing the top two floors. "It would have been difficult to proceed otherwise in that space," Ms. Hearn said. "I think as long as one can figure out how to cut back, you can keep going. It's absolutely possible."
She added that one of her friends, another dealer, had coined what may be the gallery slogan of the season: "Stay Alive 'Til '95."

HEADLINE: Review/Film: Bob Roberts;
A Singing Candidate, A Happy Trail of Hait

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY

 BODY:
"BOB ROBERTS," written and directed by Tim Robbins, who also plays the title role, is a very funny, sometimes prescient satire of American politics, and of the comparatively small, voting portion of the electorate that makes a Bob Roberts phenomenon possible. Recent events haven't completely overtaken the movie, but they do indicate just how wild a satire must be these days to remain on the cutting edge of the outrageous.
In the person of Mr. Robbins, whose performance is a career-defining achievement, Bob Roberts is a smoothly ingratiating, guitar-playing businessman, a self-made millionaire who wants to be the next United States Senator from Pennsylvania. He's good-looking, but in the way of a familiar television personality, not of a major movie star. His charisma doesn't intimidate. 
 He's young, healthy and sincere. More important, he appropriates gestures and language associated with 1960's protest movements and uses them in the cause of his own brand of 1990's right-wing rabble-rousing. He calls himself a "rebel conservative." He's the kind of guy who answers a young fan's letter by cautioning her not to do crack, adding, "It's a ghetto drug."
When Bob strums his guitar and sings such upbeat numbers as "My Land," "Times Are Changin' Back" and "Wall Street Rap," he is selling family values and patriotism and assuring his supporters that, in effect, it's their duty to "take, make and win by any means," even if they can't. Among other things, Bob understands the appeal of an ultra-conservative political and economic policy even to those who have nothing: anticipating the day when they do have it all, they want to make sure they will be able to keep it.
"Bob Roberts" takes the form of a documentary being made about the candidate's campaign from its opening days until its eventful close, through the election itself and its aftermath. Driving through the state in his caravan called the Pride, he speaks and sings at fund-raisers and rallies and attends a beauty contest where the young woman with a ribbon identifying her as Miss Three Mile Island becomes one of the film's sight gags. He's fawned on by some of the news media, insulted by others, called a savior by his supporters and a crypto-fascist by the disenchanted.
Interviewed from time to time in the course of Bob's campaign, and seen on one occasion attempting to debate the issues with him, is the liberal incumbent whose seat Bob covets. Senator Brickley Paiste is a patrician fellow whose breeding, wit and political intelligence are tested by Bob's money, razzle-dazzle public shows, dirty tricks and supermarket charm.
As played by Gore Vidal, the novelist, essayist, political commentator and sometime aspirant to political office, Brickley Paiste is the film's conscience and most articulate voice. Mr. Vidal performs on-screen much as he does in print. His manner is one of detached amusement combined with feigned shock that the world has somehow come to this ghastly pass. Without him "Bob Roberts" would be no more than an exceptionally clever, feature-length revue sketch.
The film's mock-documentary form, which echoes two classic comedies, Woody Allen's "Take the Money and Run" and Rob Reiner's "This Is Spinal Tap," can't easily accommodate the sort of melodrama and conspiracies with which Mr. Robbins begins to load the movie toward the end. It's not only because the melodrama and the conspiracies are a little far-fetched. It's also because no documentary film maker who was privy to such explosive information could have kept it under wraps for very long. If he had, he certainly wouldn't have finished his movie quite as gently as Terry Manchester (Brian Murray), the director of the film-within, finishes this one.
It can be argued that the documentary form is not to be taken too seriously, that it's only a narrative device, but Mr. Robbins can't decently enjoy all the advantages of the form without acknowledging the limitations.
A documentary is the record of the way people and events look and sound. It is a collection of surfaces that can reveal interior truths. Almost everything one needs to know about this candidate can be found in the mundane details Terry Manchester records for his film. Bob is so charming and plausible that his supporters probably couldn't care less that he did not work his way through college, as he says, but, as his mother says, forged her name to a check to pay his tuition.
"Bob Roberts" works best when it is most documentary-like. Jean Lepine's use of the hand-held camera is wizardly, creating a sense of mounting hysteria as it captures the candidate and his handlers at public functions and in those small private moments that no film maker can ever anticipate.
The movie is terrific when it attends to reportorial detail, to the behavior of people, to the found incident, to campaign decisions relating to print and television commercials, and especially to Bob's repertory of campaign songs. These are alternately foot-stomping battle cries for fat-cats or cautionary, lunatic-fringe dirges, all written, in fact, by Mr. Robbins and his older brother David.
Mr. Robbins has learned a lot from Robert Altman, who directed him in "The Player" and whose "Nashville" and "Tanner '88" would seem to have influenced both the spirit and the style of "Bob Roberts." The new film's soundtrack is layered with as much information as the images.
With one exception, the movie is beautifully cast, from the featured roles (Giancarlo Esposito, Ray Wise) to the bits in which Susan Sarandon, James Spader, Pamela Reed, Fred Ward and John Cusack, among others, appear as some of the television anchors and hosts who deal with the Bob Roberts phenomenon.
The exception is Alan Rickman as Lukas Hart 3d, the chief architect of Bob's campaign. Mr. Rickman is not a subtle actor. The minute he comes on the screen, he is so arrogant, shifty and Mephistophelean that it seems likely someone would have checked out his connections before it actually happens.
With "Bob Roberts," Mr. Robbins emerges as a formidable triple-threat man. There's a big imagination at work here. The movie sometimes overstates its case, but the music-making, success-oriented Bob represents an authentic American political tradition. Our politics has always been entertainment. Think of the crowds that came out for the Lincoln-Douglas debates. It's just that the entertainment has declined a bit in quality and, with television, become pervasive in ways to numb the thought processes.
"Bob Roberts," which has been rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian), has vulgar language and some violence.

HEADLINE: Reviews/Art;
The Psychologically Revealing Etchings of Lucian Freud

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER

 BODY:
The British artist Lucian Freud has received belated but fascinated attention in America in the past five years, thanks to successive traveling shows of his paintings and works on paper. Now the Mary Ryan Gallery is offering an absorbing survey of the artist's complete etchings, a body of work never shown before in the United States, and one that helps round out the picture of a half-centurylong career.
Mr. Freud is a figurative painter who works in the vein of highly stylized realism that became a British specialty after World War II. Most of his subjects are portraits and studio nudes, male and female, rendered with both an Expressionist's feel for his materials and an attention to intimate naturalistic details. In Mr. Freud's hands the figure is neither idealized nor truly objectified; it looks like a product of well-schooled academic painting turned slightly freakish, as if filtered through the distorting lens of an intense disquietude. 
 Much that is true of the artist's paintings is also true of his etchings, though as a group the prints give a greater overall sense of stylistic cohesiveness. This is due to a quirk of chronology. Although the artist made his first few etchings in Paris in the late 1940's, he quickly abandoned the medium and didn't pick it up again until 1982. As a result, fully three dozen of the 40 prints shown here were executed in the past decade, and reflect his mature style.
It's just as well they do, since the earliest works are undistinguished. Two tiny etchings done in Paris in 1946 are sweet but slight, and a 1948 portrait of Mr. Freud's first wife looking out half-hidden from behind a large fig leaf has the self-conscious whimsy of children's book illustration. Another likeness of the same woman from the same year is, however, more interesting. Titled "Ill in Paris," it shows her in bed, staring up from her pillow with a look of unfocused apprehension. In the foreground is a single upright rose, its thorned stem bisecting the picture, its sharp leaves and layered blossom carrying unmistakable sexual connotations.
Certain characteristics of Mr. Freud's later etchings are already in place at this point: a formal facility that he later elaborated; a tendency to view his often reclining models from odd angles, and a gift, sometimes used, sometimes not, for psychological acuity. The last quality is best demonstrated in two very different portrait etchings from 1982. In one, titled "Lord Goodman in His Yellow Pajamas," the sitter, with his massive neck and flat features viewed from slightly below eye level, looks like an alert and agreeably disheveled old animal; in the other, the artist's mother, her frowning visage a thick knot of dark, snaking gestural lines, radiates a fierce existential disapproval.
Not all of the portraits are so successful. Some display a heavy-lidded, all-purpose angst, as ineffectual in its way as the unvarying expressions of mild good humor on the faces of Alex Katz's figures. And the portraits printed in developmental stages usually start out well but end up looking overworked. In the first state of a likeness of Sir Lawrence Gowing, the scholar's bespectacled face is economically drawn against a white ground; in the second state the same face has, inexplicably, been covered with a dark, netlike fabric, under which the features lie all but obscured.
Among the most striking images in the show are the nudes. Some emerge straight from a classical studio tradition. A woman sits placidly staring down at her feet; a man lies on his stomach as if sleeping, his hand held protectively under his chest. Yet most often the figure is oddly placed within the picture space. In "Girl Sitting" (1987), for example, the figure is pushed to the top of the composition, so that the artist is looking down at her from a wide expanse of empty foreground. The play of domination and submission Mr. Freud sets up here and elsewhere is surely -- and successfully -- calculated to give otherwise ordinary figure studies a provocative psychic tension.
That tension is also present in the large male nudes, though for somewhat different reasons. Even reclining on a bed the men fill and dominate their space and look straight at the viewer, blank-faced but unintimidated. They are the only figures in the show given the realistic detail and the technical finish of Mr. Freud's paintings; in fact, one etching of a male nude has the face fully worked up in pastel. In "Man Posing," from 1985, the subject lies flat on a couch, his legs spread so that his genitals are at the picture's center. The room around him is as minutely observed as the skin and hair of the body itself. All of Mr. Freud's virtuosic command of the etched line comes into play here, from the varieties of cross hatching used for floor, walls and couch to the carefully rendered books that the man uses as a footrest, as if symbolically asserting the sensual rather than intellectual import of the picture.
It's a strong, claustrophobic image. To find its like, one has to go back to Egon Schiele in turn-of-the-century Vienna (interestingly, a time and place associated with Mr. Freud's grandfather Sigmund Freud). And like much of the artist's work, it is remarkable less for sheer originality than for the way it enlivens an existing pictorial genre often thought to be exhausted. It is a tribute to the power of these etchings that were they the only work of Mr. Freud's to survive, they would confirm him to be an artist of unusual interest. That is certainly the impression left by this fine show.
"Lucian Freud: The Complete Etchings, 1946-1992" remains at the Mary Ryan Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, mid-Manhattan, through Sept. 26.

HEADLINE: TV Weekend;
America's Pint-Size Philosophers

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
As appealing a cast as you are likely to come across in this or any other television season is on show tonight in "Age 7 in America." Nineteen children from New York, Chicago, Los Angeles, Lincoln, Neb., and Dublin, Ga., offer their thoughts on life as they know it and would like to know it.
The hourlong documentary, directed by Phil Joanou, is an American version of "7 Up." That 1963 program opened a notable British series directed by Michael Apted, who is producing "Age 7 in America." Every seven years after that, the British team revisited its 14 subjects to ask how life was living up to their expectations. At the most recent encounter, shown this year, the group had turned 35. 
The American children -- 10 boys and 9 girls, black and white, urban, suburban and rural, from public schools, prep schools and parochial schools -- can be glimpsed at work and play before being brought together for a party. They come from both sides of the economic divide: one boy in a Chicago suburb is busy at his computer; another, in a Chicago project, rides his bicycle around what passes for a seventh-floor terrace instead of on the street "so nobody won't take it from me."
The conversational off-screen interviewer asks about school, money, race, drugs, dreams, religion. (God is taken seriously. One boy, seen soliciting for Jehovah's Witnesses, says entering Paradise is high on his wish list, and a girl confesses earnestly, "I never had a religious experience.") The answers are not readily summarized, but they leave no doubt that grimmer aspects of urban America have already been impressed on the less fortunate youngsters. Julio, who was born in El Salvador and now lives in Los Angeles, says, "In El Salvador they kill people with big guns, here with small guns."
The claim relayed by Meryl Streep, who narrates, that the children are "mirrors and crystal balls of our society" does not seem far-fetched. A Japanese-American boy says black people are treated badly in America. A Chinese-American girl says she is frightened of black people.
Money is on many minds. Both rich and poor children seem to believe that a poor person could become a rich person, as one puts it, "if he works harder and gets smarter." Parental injunctions may be discerned in avowals of a desire to share with the poor, but one prep school girl declares that she wants to be rich because then "I won't run out of money." Such forthright phrasings keep the hour bubbling.
A hint of melancholy links children wherever they live who are seen playing alone or just hanging around, like the girl who says thoughtfully that she has no friends. Joey, the polite and reserved Jehovah's Witness, lives in a rural Georgia town. Asked what he would like to be when he grows up, he replies soberly, a comedian. Maybe it is the influence of television, or maybe some 7-year-olds could use more laughs. Louis, who lives at the moment in a shelter for the homeless on New York City's Lower East Side with an extended family that does not include his father, also wants to be a comedian.
Perhaps the evening's saddest line comes from a girl whose one wish is: "Be an adult right away."
Along with the similarities of age and the divisions of class, there are signs of developing personalities that, if the British series is any guide, will have taken surprising forms when the producers return to the group at age 14.
For now, choose your favorites. The camera understandably keeps coming back to pint-size, practical Louis, who likes to talk and has a lot to say. He provides a motto for the program with this self-description: "I'm bad, I'm good. I'm friendly, I'm not friendly. I'm American."
 
Scared Silent
Exposing and Ending
Child Abuse
CBS, NBC, PBS, tonight at 10 (Channels 2, 4, 13 and 49 in New York)
ABC, Sunday at 10 P.M. (Channel 7 in New York)
Oprah Winfrey, in person and in spirit, makes a big visit to prime-time this weekend. She is the host of "Scared Silent: Exposing and Ending Child Abuse," an hourlong documentary that occupies CBS, NBC and PBS simultaneously tonight and will be repeated on Sunday on ABC. The announced purpose is to alert the nation to what Ms. Winfrey calls a "national epidemic" of sexual, physical and psychological abuse of children, usually by other family members, especially Dad.
Despite the title, which refers to the victims' fear of speaking up, child abuse is no secret to television viewers. It has been a staple of afternoon talk shows for several years, for reasons tonight's program make evident. Ingredients like sexual taboos, vulnerable children, brutal parents and pop psychology have proved irresistible. Earlier this week, for example, CNN carried "Breaking the Silence: Survivors of Incest," complete with victims, experts and call-ins.
"Scared Silent" focuses on six accounts of abuse: a church usher who spent a year in jail for sexually molesting his two daughters; a teen-ager who says she was molested by her brother and, in turn, molested a younger cousin; a grown brother and sister who tell of frequent beatings by their father; a mother whose conviction for killing her young son was overturned on appeal but who still feels guilty; a man described as "a lecturer and consultant" who says he suffered from being constantly criticized by his mother, and a man who served a jail term for sexually molesting his young daughter.
Everyone involved seems to have passed through therapy, as evidenced by the lingo that slips into the meetings, evidently arranged for the program, between abusers and abused. "Some shattered families can turn tragedy into healing," says Ms. Winfrey, who periodically provides an "800" number where help is said to be available. The language is explicit and the usual visual and musical effects are laid on for dramatic impact.
Although the intentions are no doubt righteous, the reporting leaves something to be desired and no responsibility is taken by network news departments. The script given to Ms. Winfrey, who begins by once again announcing she was raped by other members of her family beginning when she was 9 years old, relays a catch-all figure of 2.7 million cases of child abuse and neglect reported in 1991 without pausing to sort out what might be included.
Is the emphasis on sexual abuse in this hour and on the afternoon shows it emulates a reflection of reality or merely of television's partiality to the sensational? What constitutes violent abuse and does it occur more commonly among some groups than among others? The category of psychological abuse seems spacious enough to accommodate any family problem anyone cares to drop in. The question raised in recent child-abuse trials of the power therapists can exert on children's memories is not addressed.
But reporting is too much to ask of this sort of exercise. Viewers in need can dial the "800" number. Others may wish to dial "20/20."

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Tampa Bay Is Ready for the Zamboni

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla.

 BODY:
Outside Expo Hall, the temperature was in the low 80's and so was the humidity. Palm trees shaded the bright morning sun. Inside the dark arena, the air felt much cooler and drier as a few players glided across the playing surface in an unofficial workout before training camp.
Doug Smith, in charge of air-conditioning and ice for the only National Hockey League team in the subtropics, stood next to the glass and boards and promised suitable playing conditions in the temporary home of the Tampa Bay Lightning. 
 "It's a matter of trial and error," said Smith, the building superintendent. "We're not going to have ice problems, I guarantee you that, no doubt in my mind. We could create snow in here."
 
Process of Trial and Error
 Artificial winter could be the least of the challenges for the Lightning, one of two expansion teams entering the league this season. The entire founding of the franchise has been a process of trial and error as the Lightning, along with the Ottawa Senators, bring the league's total membership to 24 teams.
After the N.H.L. approved a franchise bid led by Phil Esposito, the Lightning's financing flickered and the team got behind on payments of its $50 million entry fee. After first announcing that it would play in the Florida Suncoast Dome in St. Petersburg, the Lightning abruptly moved to a smaller arena east of Tampa, on the state fair grounds, with livestock barns nearby.
Despite N.H.L. guidelines urging 18,500-seat arenas and 10,000 season tickets, the Lightning will play in a 10,500-seat arena and has so far sold only about 5,000 season-tickets. Plans for a big, new arena have been announced, but financing is incomplete and no ground-breaking date has been set.
Expressway billboards announce "Kick Ice" and "We Are the Lightning, You Are the Thunder," but much preseason light and sound here has been stolen by baseball because the San Francisco Giants may move to the Tampa Bay area next season.
Considering that much of the market is made up of senior citizens and that the economy is still in recession and that baseball may provide competition for customers and that Florida is closer to Cuba than it is to Canada, can major league hockey survive and thrive in a place like this?
Certainly, according to David LeFevre, the Manhattan lawyer who runs the team for the Japanese companies that paid the $50 million.
"There are more Canadians in Tampa than there are in Ottawa," LeFevre said after the first day of ticket sales for individual games. "We've sold out four of the games entirely. People now understand it really is going to happen. To have an ice-cold building and a game with the excitement of hockey in the middle of Tampa is a pretty exciting event."
 
Fan Interest on Rise
 "It's been a big turnabout over the last two or three months," LeFevre said of fan interest. "It's been a long struggle, but now we are having a little bit of success and you sort of say 'How do you deal with that?' instead of putting out fires."
Hundreds of fans stood in line Tuesday and were greeted by Esposito, the team president, who shook hands, signed autographs and posed for pictures like a presidential candidate. Ticket prices range from $12 to $50. Next to the arena, the team is constructing a big tent as a private club for season-ticket holders.
As was the case when he was general manager of the Rangers, Esposito has hired several friends. His brother, Tony, is the director of hockey operations. Don Murdoch, a former Ranger teammate, is a scout. Wayne Cashman, who played with Phil on the Boston Bruins, is an assistant coach to Terry Crisp. Esposito is no longer the general partner of the team, losing the position when Japanese investors became distressed at his dealings. LeFevre now holds the position.
 
Female Goaltender Invited
 Perhaps to generate publicity during training camp, Esposito invited goaltender Manon Rheaume, a woman who played one period of junior hockey last season in Three Rivers, Quebec. (She will have a private dressing room.)
A third-round draft choice with a chance to stick is Brent Gretzky, one of Wayne's brothers. A veteran trying out is Ron Duguay, one of Esposito's old pals from his playing days with the Rangers. At age 35, Duguay may have lost some of his playing skills, but he still retains the facial features and long, flowing locks that helped make him popular on his previous tours of various teams. Rob Zamuner was signed as a free-agent from the Rangers and Rob DiMaio was drafted from the Islanders.
Another former Islander is Joe Reekie, a defenseman who says Florida takes some getting used to.
So is the progress on a new arena. If the private group can't raise the funds in the next few months, the Lightning can get out of its lease. Marc Ganis, spokesman for Tampa Coliseum Inc., said that the new $114 million arena "is going to get done" right next to the football stadium despite "the tough banking climate these days."
