SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 467 words

HEADLINE: Worse Than a Lie

 BODY:
When President Bush keeps insisting that Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas has raised taxes and fees 128 times, he knows he is falsifying the record. He seems so eager to smear his opponent as a big taxer that he's willing to trash the truth over trivia. But he jeopardizes more than credibility.
In a time of economic pain newly documented by the Census Bureau's report of soaring poverty, one would think the President would wish to ask voters for a mandate endorsing a sensible economic program. But his program so far remains incoherent, and meanwhile he keeps flailing at his opponent with this silly list. When will Mr. Bush get serious? 
 The number of tax increases during a governor's administration simply doesn't matter. What matters is the reason for any increases or cuts and, at bottom, the burden on taxpayers. Arkansas was a relatively low-tax state when Mr. Clinton became Governor 12 years ago, and still is.
Mr. Bush has seized on a gimmick that has a ring of truth to it but is, in fact, a misrepresentation. Exactly 128 tax and fee increases, he says, brandishing an amazingly sloppy list his staff asserts came from official Arkansas legislative records.
The list is endlessly misleading. It includes dozens of fee increases, not usually counted as tax increases, and it ignores tax reductions. But that's the very nature of this shabby tactic. In this case, the idea seems to be to plant in voters' minds the impression of many increases. If critics cavil, arguing over whether it was 128 or 138 or 59 or something else, so much the better; that keeps the issue alive.
Governor Clinton's record on taxes is, not surprisingly, by no means the horror that is thereby implied. There have been two increases in the state sales tax during the Clinton years, both earmarked for education, and three increases in the tax on gasoline, earmarked for highways.
The Legislature has rejected several Clinton proposals for higher personal and corporate income taxes, which would make the tax structure more progressive and more open to growth. The State Constitution requires three-fourths majorities to raise income taxes, but only simple majorities to raise the sales tax. When Mr. Clinton sought repeal of the three-fourths requirement, he lost.
In a larger perspective, the overall tax burden in Arkansas has hardly changed at all in the Clinton years. Revenue from state and local taxes equaled 9.5 percent of total personal income in 1980, and 9.6 percent in 1990, the latest figure available. The national average is almost 11.5 percent.
 The President would be wise to forget his list of 128 and turn instead to newer, truer numbers, starting with those just released by the Census Bureau: In the last year, 2.1 million more people have sunk below the poverty line.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The European Danger

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL; Anthony Lewis is on vacation.

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
The question about Europe now is what is more dangerous the eruptions of the same old murderous hatreds or the eruptions of the same old attempts to explain, rationalize or excuse them.
Sooner or later, Americans will have to pay attention. European nastinesses have a way of involving the U.S. and so do European evasions of the truth. Sooner would be better -- say before Election Day. 
 Take Germany, please. In a half-dozen cities, Nazis -- plain Nazis, there is no such thing as a neo-Nazi -- smash and burn in riot against foreign refugees and job-seekers.
Now, no decent European, German or otherwise, actually justifies the Nazi violence. How could you think such a thing? But a lot of them, German and otherwise, thoughtfully explain that Germany has taken in more than 250,000 refugees, and that even in their powerful economy Germans resent foreign competition for jobs and welfare, naturally.
Naturally. This is said as if refugees had not existed before -- nor history. It was not long ago that on any productive month the German Army created more refugees than Germany has taken in all together -- to say nothing about corpses.
Other countries handled refugees without rioting and hate. Poverty-ridden Pakistan accepted millions of Afghans. Israel is happy to gather in as many refugees from Arab or former Communist countries as can get there. And the U.S. has not done too badly either.
Of course, we all know, don't we, that Nazis no longer represent the German nation. Still, I was a bit surprised to discover in comments by the European representative of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, no less, that Germans who "wavered in their commitment to democracy" and voted for the right wing were not Nazis but just trying to say how angry and frightened they were, and that what Jews should do was converse more with Germans about fighting discrimination.
Myself, I had thought that message must have gotten across to Germans by now, some time since the end of World War II.
No -- what is happening in those German towns is not for lack of Jews "reaching out" to comfort and educate "mainstream" Germans, but because of Nazi race-mongering used as a political weapon, as usual. Now it is used against Muslims and other foreigners. German Jews are in low supply, thus available neither for purposes of conversation nor slaughter.
In the Balkans, Europe could not bring itself to take meaningful action until thousands of Europeans had been murdered, dozens of towns blown apart. Then, despite its armies and alliances it did not really bestir itself until the U.S. was set to get in.
Czechoslovakia. It was the former Soviet colony with the best chance of success. Now it prepares for its own burial. Europe takes it for granted that since Czechs and Slovaks had differences, they had to divorce.
Why? Why was it so inevitable that Czech and Slovak could not live together in the unified freedom they had before Western European appeasement of Hitler, the German Army and the Soviet Union incarcerated them?
Has Europe noticed that countries like India, Indonesia, Brazil and, yes, the United States stay in one piece despite mixtures of religions and races and histories of racial and cultural tensions?
I live under and rejoice in the philosophies of political and intellectual freedom that came from Europe. But it is sinful delusion to forget the truth that for centuries religious and national hatreds were encouraged to fester in Europe -- and still are used by some Europeans to dominate, conquer or kill other Europeans.
Until that is recognized and fought intellectually and politically by today's Europe, the Continent cannot become a union no matter how many treaties are signed. A trading and travel bloc, maybe -- a union of nations and peoples, no.
The U.S. cannot bring that about. The best it can and should do is to help those who suffer from racism and despotism, whether European, Asian or African. And in Europe, as everywhere including their own country and hemisphere, Americans can refuse to wear the dangerous blindfold of rationalization or excuse. It hides from them the difference between perpetrator and victim, thus preventing the defeat of one and the succor of the other.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 498 words

HEADLINE: If Government Protected Us, We'd Sue Less

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The latest demonstration of the unfortunate popular practice of lawyer-bashing came from both President Bush and Vice President Quayle in accepting their party's renominations on the last night of the Republican National Convention (speech transcripts, Aug. 21). 
 While the habit of blaming lawyers for many of society's ills has been practiced by both political parties, it has never received such prominent, nationwide, prime-time exposure.
Vice President Quayle asserted that the nation's financial woes and overloaded court calendars were the fault of the legal profession. He declared: "The explosion of frivolous lawsuits burdens our economy and weakens our system of justice."
The Vice President, a lawyer himself, then presented, as prima facie evidence, that "America has 5 percent of the world's population and 70 percent of the world's lawyers."
One can assume he will soon announce that the reason Americans are annoyed with the Federal Government and the Administration is that we have more newspapers, radio and television stations, reporters and editors per capita than the world's population average.
Mr. Bush's denunciation of the legal profession was peppered with phrases like "sharp lawyers," "crazy lawsuits" and "every trial lawyer who ever wore a tasseled loafer."
There are, however, many causes for the high level of litigation initiated by citizens against physicians, hospitals, manufacturers and government.
America has the best protections of an individual's rights and ability to seek recourse for damages of any nation. Our Federal and state constitutions, laws and court decisions wisely place great emphasis on an individual's prerogatives and ability to seek justice in the courts.
This is a blessing, not a curse. Curtailing this freedom would violate a basic principle of our society.
Better and continued evaluation of doctors and hospitals, and quicker actions when warranted, are the means to reduce malpractice litigation and lower insurance costs.
Weak product liability legislation or none at all, with almost meaningless government testing of a product's claims, safety and reliability, are the basis for much of today's civil actions against merchandise, drugs and goods.
The overburdened court calendars are due, in great measure, to the lack of sufficient numbers of judges and constant underfunding of our courts.
But the majority of civil suits against manufacturers, physicians and hospitals would not be initiated, entertained by the courts and supported by decision of juries if government agencies responsible for pro
tecting the public lived up to their legal and moral obligations.
Government, to a large extent, still follows a "let the buyer beware" policy, which leaves seeking justice in the courts as the only means of gaining protection and safety in the marketplace.
 
JOSEPH A. BAUM
Flushing, Queens, Aug. 25, 1992
 
The writer is president of the Queens County Bar Association.

HEADLINE: New York Risks Losing Lucrative Film and TV Production

 BODY:
To the Editor:
More than a year ago the Directors Guild suggested to the New York City Council that the film, television and commercial production business -- the business that creates and depicts New York's reputation to the rest of the world -- was leaving the city and taking with it the pool of talent that drives New York's cultural and creative community. The Directors Guild represents the directors, assistant directors and unit production managers who create American theatrical motion pictures. 
 From that day until this, our analysis is that the city has done nothing to prevent the death of the industry. Deputy Mayor Barry F. Sullivan has failed to fill the top slot at the Mayor's Office of Film and Broadcasting. Without someone to provide leadership, focus and direction, the office has become little more than a granter of filming permits.
The Mayor and his administration still fail to comprehend the need to treat the entertainment industry as an economic asset that needs nurturing and development. Their failure undermines our efforts to refocus the spotlight on New York City as a producer-friendly center of production, rather than a hassle-filled location.
The Directors Guild, with the other unions representing creative talent (the Writers Guild East, the New York Local of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists and the Screen Actors Guild), has commissioned an economic-impact study to help demonstrate to the city's bureaucracy the high-stakes issues involved.
Worse than the disastrous economic significance of a loss of the film and television business is the city government's failure fully to understand the threat to the city's reputation and the way it is portrayed to and perceived by the rest of the world.
The administration must remember that while the talent we represent can move elsewhere to follow the work, the city will be hard pressed to recover from the loss of this central business. Perhaps the time has come for the City Council to create an office of its own to act on behalf of the film industry.
 
ALAN S. GORDON
New York, Aug. 26, 1992
 
The writer, Eastern executive secretary of the Directors Guild, is a member of the Mayor's Film and Television Advisory Council.

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 237 words

HEADLINE: If Government Protected Us, We'd Sue Less;
A Noble Calling

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a lifelong conservative Republican who also happens to be a plaintiffs' lawyer, I am compelled to respond to the attacks on trial lawyers by both President Bush and Vice President Quayle in their acceptance speeches at the Republican National Convention. 
 We have safer highways, automobiles and other products, higher standards of health care and a more humane workplace in the United States because of trial lawyers. This profession was once esteemed by the public as a noble calling.
Our greatest political leaders (for example, Daniel Webster, Abraham Lincoln and William Jennings Bryan) were trial lawyers.
It is my experience from 20 years of trying cases that it is extremely difficult to persuade a jury to award damages to an undeserving plaintiff. Indeed, roughly half of all civil cases are successfully defended. Generally, jurors make a conscientious effort to reach just and truthful verdicts.
According to a 1991 Rand Corporation study there are fewer lawsuits today as a percentage of the general population than there were in Colonial times. Such mechanisms as post-trial motions and appellate review protect against occasional excessive or unwarranted jury awards.
The one group dedicated to protecting and preserving individual rights in this country does not deserve to be made scapegoats by our nation's leaders.
 
WILLIAM M. CROSBY
Irvine, Calif., Aug. 27, 1992

UNEXPECTED DIP IN EMPLOYMENT
In a stunningly grim reflection of the midsummer economy, the Government reported that 167,000 private-sector jobs were lost in August as factory employment skidded to its lowest level since April 1983. The unemployment rate edged down, to 7.6 percent, but that drop resulted from a decline in the number of people seeking work. The new figures led to another interest-rate cut by the Fed, a move that was intended to spur economic growth but could hurt the dollar. 1

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Some 167,000 private-sector jobs were lost in August as factory employment skidded to its lowest level since April 1983, stunningly grim Government figures showed, even though the unemployment rate edged down one-tenth of a point, to 7.6 percent. The figures promptly led to another cut in interest rates by the Federal Reserve Board, which pushed the Federal funds rate down to 3 percent. The Administration called the decline in the jobless rate encouraging, while the Clinton camp hammered at the Administration. [Page 1.]
 
International
 A liberal aviation pact was agreed to by the U.S. and the Netherlands. The agreement could allow KLM Royal Dutch Airlines and Northwest to operate as a single airline. [1.]U.S. airlines are offering incentives to frequent fliers.[33.] 
 Japanese companies, angered by "patent wars," as some call American companies' demands for large royalties from Japanese companies for the use of patented technology, are fighting back. [1.]
The Administration released part of the free-trade pact struck by the United States, Mexico and Canada on Aug. 12 -- a three-inch-thick computer printout. [31.]
Although Lloyd's of London faces more potential losses, there seems to be growing confidence among the institution's management and the "names," as its financial backers are known, that Lloyd's, after a most tumultuous period, is stabilizing. [31.]
 
Markets
The bond market was stunned by the surprisingly steep decline in employment in August. Prices soared and yields tumbled. [31.]
Stock prices sagged in the slowest trading of the year, with the Dow off 10.27, to 3,281.93. [35.]
The Amex was closed after a half hour by a fire nearby. Four hundred workers were evacuated by 10 A.M. [32.]
The dollar fell against most other currencies, and gold rose. [41.] Soybeans and corn futures prices posted moderate gains as traders rolled the dice on forecasts of frost. [41.]
 
Companies
Allstate Insurance said it expected $1.2 billion in claims from Hurricane Andrew, more than four times what it paid out for Hurricane Hugo in 1989. [31.]
A Lockheed-led team won a $689 million contract to develop an anti-missile system to replace the Patriot missile. Other companies involved are Honeywell, Rockwell International, Westinghouse Electric and United Technologies. [31.]
G.M. prepared to close two more assembly plants in Wilmington, Del., and Lansing, Mich., as negotiations continued on ending the eight-day-old strike at its Lordstown parts plant. [33.]
Carl Karcher Enterprises said a buyout of the company had been discussed by its chairman and chief executive. [43.]
Merck has created a new division to make a generic version of an anti-inflammatory drug. [43.]
 
Today's Columns
The I.R.S. can provide relief to some of Hurricane Andrew's victims. Taxpayers who file an amended 1991 tax return claiming a casualty loss can expect a refund check within weeks if they qualify for deductions -- many may not. Jan M. Rosen: Your Taxes. [32.]
Raymond V. Damadian is seeking patent royalties for the revolutionary medical diagnostic technology known as magnetic resonance imaging that he is generally credited with inventing. Edmund L. Andrews: Patents. [32.]

WATCHING THE MEDICINE GO DOWN
Lenora Alston is one of about 50 workers in New York City whose sole job is to see, visit or find tuberculosis patients to insure that they take their medication. Her seemingly tedious job has become one of the most important in public health care. Page 1.

ELECTRONIC MONITORS FOUND FAULTY
In a policy shift, Federal prosecutors in Manhattan said yesterday that they would oppose the use of electronic monitoring devices to keep track of criminal defendants out on bail, because the prosecutors believed the devices did not deter defendants from fleeing the country or committing other crimes. Page 23.

Before an old post office building on the Upper West Side of Manhattan partly collapsed on Thursday, the contractor demolishing it was cited by city inspectors 10 times for safety violations during the last three weeks, city officials said yesterday. Page 23.
TWO EXPLOSIONS IN MIDTOWN
Two explosions, ignited by sparks from a Consolidated Edison cable, rocked a midtown Manhattan street yesterday morning, terrifying pedestrians, shattering windows and hurling manhole covers "into the air like pizzas," a Fire Department official said. Page 23.
City wants a new lead-paint policy. Page 23.

NASSAU CLERK MAY RETIRE
The Nassau County Clerk has taken steps to retire, ending his 45-year career in the County Clerk's office under an avalanche of criticism for logjams in its operations. "This is not the way I wanted to go out," Harold W. McConnell said. "I thought I would go out after serving my full term, but the problems got to be too much. I'm not 30 years old anymore." Page 24.
ACKERMAN INVESTIGATION SOUGHT
Congress should investigate allegations that Representative Gary Ackerman, the Queens Democrat, evaded House limits on outside income, his opponent for the Democratic nomination for Congress said. The allegations were raised in a Newsday article that said Mr. Ackerman negotiated a $45,000-a-year consulting contract for his wife, Rita, when he sold his newspaper and advertising company in 1989. Page 24.
TORNADO? NO, A MICROBURST
Meteorological sleuths attributed the damage of Thursday's fierce thunderstorms in southwestern Connecticut not to a tornado, but to an equally rare marauder known as a microburst, a sudden violent downdraft of a kind that has caused plane crashes and carried away buildings. But the National Weather Service confirmed that two small tornadoes had touched down in Scarsdale and in Endicott, 150 miles northwest of New York City. Page 24.
AN AMUSEMENT PARK'S SPECIAL WEEKEND
After a sorry, silent season, the roller coaster at Lake Compounce Festival Park in Bristol, Conn., was again clattering. A corps of volunteers overcame squabbling owners and creeping neglect to reopen just for the holiday weekend what is said to be America's longest continuously operating amusement park. Page 24.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Bush Courts Small Businesses by Offering Loans

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FREDERICKSBURG, Va., Sept. 4

 BODY:
Campaigning as a skeptical outsider while behaving as a Washington insider, President Bush today sharply attacked Congress for rejecting most of his legislation and then praised and signed a bill promoting small business loans.
In a street-corner campaign speech here that was billed as an endorsement of small business, Mr. Bush described himself as a former businessman who got ulcers meeting payrolls and felt disgust for too many regulations and high taxes. He also spoke of his contempt for a "gridlocked Congress" that routinely dismissed his proposals. 
 Mr. Bush then rolled up his sleeves and made a ceremony out of signing a bill that the House and Senate approved last month. It increased the amount of small business loan guarantees to $8 billion in 1994, from $6 billion in 1992. The actual Federal outlays for such loan guarantees are about 5 percent of the loans, which is $300 million in 1992 and $400 million by 1994.
 
'They Create Jobs'
 The bill-signing ended a week of barnstorming across the nation during which the President announced approval of new foreign arms sales and military spending, an increase in Federal agricultural subsidies and authorization for large-scale Federal spending in South Florida in the aftermath of Hurricane Andrew.
Mr. Bush brushed off questions about whether all the Federal largesse was an effort to buy votes. "These are good, sound proposals," he said. "They create jobs. So I take nothing but great pride in them."
Arriving at this city by helicopter from the White House 55 miles away, Mr. Bush briefly visited the Fredericksburg Hardware store before being whisked in his black limousine a few blocks to Goolrick's Pharmacy.
In front of the pharmacy, he reiterated his intention to cut taxes and regulation on small businesses but offered no new specifics on how he would do that. He also criticized Gov. Bill Clinton's economic plan, saying it would raise taxes for most Americans, increase the deficit and cause the elimination of 2.6 million jobs.
 
Response From Clinton Camp
 "Our differences couldn't be sharper," Mr. Bush said. "I see small business as the backbone of the American economy. He sees a golden-egg-laying goose that ought to pay more in taxes."
Aides to Mr. Clinton noted that Mr. Bush had avoided mentioning the grim new employment figures announced today, and they challenged Mr. Bush's economic policies.
The Labor Department said today that the August jobless rate fell to 7.6 percent, from 7.7 percent in July. But the department said 167,000 jobs were lost last month despite a new Government program that hired 100,000 people.
"If George Bush is so good for business, how come there's been three times more bankruptcies than new private-sector jobs," said George Stephanopoulos, the Clinton campaign's communications director.
While Mr. Bush was warmly received by most of the crowd, the appearance was not without dissenting voices. One sign asked, "If recession's over, where's my job?," while another said, "Our Family Values Jobs."

LENGTH: 620 words

HEADLINE: Downed Plane: Serbs and Bosnians Trade Charges

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 4

 BODY:
Leaders of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the country's rebel Serbs today accused each other of responsibility for the downing Thursday of an Italian relief plane in the mountains outside Sarajevo.
Although the plane was downed in territory held by Croatian forces loyal to Bosnia, troops from various Muslim, Croatian and Serbian factions are said to operate in the area. United Nations officials said they had still not determined which group might have fired at the plane. Nor was it clear which faction fired at two United States helicopters that were searching for the wreckage, forcing them to withdraw. 
 Gen. Ratko Mladic, the top army commander of the so-called Serbian Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, asserted that Croatian and Muslim fighters had downed the cargo plane. He denied any connection between Serbian forces and the downing of the plane. He made his accusation in a letter to Gen. Satish Nambiar of India, the commander of the United Nations peacekeeping forces.
But President Alija Izetbegovic of Bosnia said the plane had been hit by missiles that came from an area controlled by Serbs.
Neither General Mladic nor President Izetbegovic offered evidence for their statements.
Italian Air Force and United Nations investigators arrived at the crash site today to inspect the wreckage of the G-222 twin-propeller airplane, which crashed in Jasenik, 20 miles west of the capital. All four crew members died.
Witnesses told journalists and United Nations officials that at least one missile had hit the plane, but a spokesman for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in Geneva, Fernando del Mundo, said United Nations personnel had not yet found hard evidence to support these accounts.
"The wreckage of the plane is strewn around an area of about 1.5 kilometers, which indicates there was some sort of explosion before impact," said Peter Kessler, a United Nations spokesman in Zagreb, the Croatian capital.
Fighting between all the factions in Bosnia continued today, and diplomats said it was too early to tell whether there was progress in fulfilling commitments made last week at a London peace conference.
 
Parliament Backs Premier
 In Belgrade, factions on the Serbian side that favor a conciliatory stance achieved a victory when the federal Parliament voted to endorse the policies of Prime Minister Milan Panic. But Serbian forces in the field are believed to pay far more attention to the Serbian Government, which is led by President Slobodan Milosevic. Serbia and Montenegro are the only two republics remaining in Yugoslavia.
Mr. Panic, a Serbian-American millionaire, was appointed Prime Minister to improve Yugoslavia's image and help persuade the United States and European countries to lift economic sanctions, and he appears to have achieved a measure of support among people weary of the hardships caused by the sanctions.
Mr. Panic favors adherence to Serbian promises to dismantle detention camps and turn over heavy weapons to United Nations forces. But negotiators express doubt that Mr. Milosevic will let these steps be carried out in full.
Mr. Panic, for instance, has angered nationalist Serbs by advocating the recognition of Croatia and Bosnia within the borders that existed before the fighting began, in effect supporting withdrawal of Serbian forces from large areas of the republics.
In London, representatives of all the factions agreed to end their sieges of various towns and cities and bring irregular militias under central control. The Serbs have also lifted their four-month siege of the mostly Muslim Bosnian town of Gorazde and allowed United Nations observers access to gun emplacements above Sarajevo, one diplomat said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Leaders of the Government of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the country's rebel Serbs are accusing each other in the downing of an Italian relief plane on Thursday. Yesterday, a French doctor sifted through the wreckage of the crash, which killed four Italian airmen. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Deal With Russia Is Said to Involve More Uranium Than Believed

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
Federal officials say an East-West deal in which the United States would buy Russian uranium from scrapped nuclear arms involves far greater amounts than generally reported, at least 500 metric tons of highly enriched uranium. The purchased uranium is to be diluted for sale as commercial reactor fuel.
The agreement was announced by the White House late on Monday, but its complete terms were not spelled out, leading to differing interpretations of its meaning. 
 The New York Times said the deal involved at least 80 metric tons of bomb-grade uranium, while some other publications stated proposed yearly rates of purchases without giving a time period or total quantity to be bought, implying that it might be relatively small.
In interviews, officials at the Energy and State Departments said the agreement was a 20-year arrangement and that no less than 10 metric tons of highly enriched uranium would be bought annually for the first five years and no less than 30 metric tons annually for the next 15 years. In other words, 50 tons would be bought during the first period and 450 tons in the second period, for a total of 500 metric tons.
"These are target numbers," said Philip G. Sewell, the Energy Department's deputy assistant secretary for uranium enrichment. "If we can do it faster and in higher quantities, we will."
Administration officials said the agreement is confidential and declined to make it public. Details of the overall deal remain to be worked out, and the final agreement requires the formal approval of both Moscow and Washington. The American aim is to bolster the shaky Russian economy and to reduce the risks of nuclear accidents and theft.
Private experts once considered 500 metric tons to be the total inventory of Russian uranium bomb fuel, but they are now raising their estimates because it seems unlikely that Moscow would sell its entire supply.
It is unclear whether the vagueness and the lateness of the White House announcement was by accident or design. A State Department official said the news was played down out of worry that it might embarrass the Russian military, elements of which are angered by the dismantling of large parts of Russia's nuclear arsenal.
But a private analyst, Marvin S. Fertel, vice president of the Council for Energy Awareness, the communications arm of the nuclear power industry, suggested the deal was slighted by general White House fumbling and foreign-policy defensiveness in an election year dominated by domestic issues.
The nature of the White House announcement, Mr. Fertel said, was "indicative of the ineptitude" of the Bush Administration in recent months.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Airlines Fight for Frequent Fliers

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The airlines' battle for passengers took a new turn yesterday when carriers announced special travel awards for frequent fliers.
"The airlines have bled themselves dry with the fare wars," said Randy Petersen, editor and publisher of Inside Flyer, a newsletter covering frequent-flier programs. "This is an effort to stop costing themselves real money." 
 The carriers have not used frequent-flier programs recently to stimulate business, Mr. Peterson said. Now, they are making up for lost time.
United Airlines announced a new program on Thursday that offers two free "connoisseur class" round-the-world tickets to passengers who make 25 round-trip flights on the airline in the next two months.
Through Dec. 18, passengers earn credits for round-trip tickets -- one credit for each economy fare and two for a first- or connoisseur-class ticket.
Four bonus credits earn one free economy round trip within the continental United States or four 1,000-mile upgrade certificates.
Seven bonus credits earn one free economy-class round trip between the continental United States and Hawaii, Europe, the Caribbean or Latin America, or eight 1,000-mile upgrade certificates.
Eleven bonus credits count toward one free economy-class round-trip between the United States and Asia or the South Pacific, or 12 1,000-mile upgrade certificates.
Yesterday, American Airlines, Delta Air Lines and USAir all announced award programs of their own. Like United's, their awards are in addition to regular miles earned through airline frequent-flier programs.
Continental said it announced a similar program to members of its frequent-flier program, One Pass, in August. Trans World Airlines and Northwest Airlines said they were studying the offers.
American will award one certificate good for one free coach-class ticket for travel within or between the continental United States, Canada, Mexico and the Caribbean for every 10 flight segments or 12,000 miles flown.
Two award certificates can be redeemd for one round-trip coach class ticket to Hawaii, Europe, Latin America or Japan. All the special awards must be used between Feb. 1, 1993, and May 31, 1993.
USAir's bonus awards are similar to American's, although they are good for travel between Jan. 15 and May 15. They are also subject to blackout dates and capacity controls, the airline said.
Under Delta's program, two award certificates will be given for eight segments traveled. One will be good for a domestic upgrade, two for one free coach ticket in North America or an upgrade to Europe or Asia.
With four certificates, a passenger earns a coach ticket to Hawaii, Europe or Asia, with six, a business-class ticket to Europe or Asia, and with eight, a first-class ticket to Europe or Asia.
Like American's, Delta's award tickets are valid February through May next year.
Fall is traditionally the slowest for the airlines, which have lost billions of dollars in the last two years of recession.
And airlines have said they expect this summer's fare wars will mean large losses in the third quarter, usually their best.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Strategy;
Discipline, Message and Good Luck: How Clinton's Campaign Came Back

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 4

 BODY:
In the last three months, Gov. Bill Clinton has transformed the Presidential campaign from a referendum on his character into one on George Bush's Presidency by sticking to a disciplined plan, and the tactic has salvaged the Democrats' hopes of regaining the White House.
The process of burnishing Mr. Clinton's tarnished image began shortly after the June 2 California primary. Top advisers, including James Carville, Mandy Grunwald, Stan Greenberg and George Stephanopoulos, formed a working group to plan their candidate's rehabilitation. 
 They developed a carefully honed message and organized a campaign of taut, centralized discipline. But beyond that, the process has relied on some major strokes of good luck as well.
"If anybody tells you they knew what was going to happen, they're lying," Mr. Greenberg said.
 
The Economy and Perot
 Indeed, nobody could say for sure in the early spring that the nation's economy would remain sour into the fall. And the Clinton strategists could scarcely have known that President Bush would fail to address it in a convincing way at the Republican National Convention.
Moreover, the independent candidacy of Ross Perot proved valuable. It was a distraction for the press and voters at the time Mr. Clinton was regrouping, and when the Perot campaign collapsed it was a source of support, with its backers turning to Mr. Clinton as the only remaining alternative to the incumbent.
Still, it has not all been luck. Mr. Clinton and his top advisers have missed few chances to take advantage of circumstances and events.
Crucial to the resurrection of the Clinton candidacy was Mr. Greenberg's discovery, through voter surveys, that there were many people who knew little of substance about Mr. Clinton but were receptive to learning more.
 
Showing His Favorable Side
 He also discovered that voters' minds could be changed about the Arkansas Governor once they were presented with favorable information about his family background, his wife and their daughter.
Setting aside the personal issues that had come to define the campaign and might yet derail it -- Mr. Clinton's draft record, his belated admission that he had smoked, but not inhaled, marijuana and accusations of marital infidelity -- the strategists determined to use late-night television shows, televised "town meetings" and pop culture magazines to reach voters directly. This way, they could pierce the veil of conventional, and more critical, news reporting.
The results are best shown in the poll-takers' measurements. In June, when Mr. Perot was still in the race and after Mr. Clinton had clinched the Democratic nomination, more than twice as many voters responding to a New York Times/CBS News survey viewed him unfavorably, 40 percent, as did favorably, 16 percent.
By last week, the Times/CBS poll showed that 36 percent viewed Mr. Clinton favorably, while 28 percent had unfavorable impressions.
In the six weeks between the California primary and the Democratic National Convention, Mr. Clinton appeared on Arsenio Hall, MTV, morning talk shows and the cover of People Magazine.
 
Image of a Family Man
 His strategists were so determined to play up the image of Mr. Clinton as a family man that it rejected People's plan to feature only Mrs. Clinton on the cover. Instead, shoppers at checkout stands across the country saw the whole Clinton family pictured.
Talk show hosts and their viewers learned about the house Mr. Clinton lived in -- briefly, it turns out -- that lacked indoor plumbing, and the jobs he held to put himself through school. They learned he was born to a single mother and battled an abusive and alcoholic stepfather.
"Some of it was smart," Mr. Greenberg said of the series of events that led to the Clinton comeback. "Some of it was accident."
One accident was that Mr. Clinton introduced his economic plan in a period when voters were being alienated by the static of the feud between Mr. Bush and Mr. Perot.
"They learned in vague ways that he had an economic plan," Mr. Greenberg said, "but the most important thing they learned was that he worked for what he got in life. The same set of facts look very different if it's a working-class kid instead of a rich kid."
 
'A Strategic Dictator'
 The plan to begin a grass-roots media assault was, by most accounts, the brainchild of Ms. Grunwald. Mr. Greenberg used his surveys to expose the soft spots in the psyche of the electorate. And Mr. Carville took over the strategic end of the campaign, emphasizing discipline above all else.
"It's not like we're flying blind anymore," one Clinton strategist said. "Campaigns demand benevolent dictatorships, and this one has it. James has become a strategic dictator."
The campaign moved to a new headquarters here in Little Rock, where top officials work 18-hour days, eat hearty lunches at a restaurant named "Your Mama's" that specializes in mashed potatoes and meatloaf, and plot a hungry strategy.
Unlike typical Presidential campaigns, the Clinton effort is run entirely from the headquarters, not from a peripatetic campaign plane. What the candidate does on the plane and on the bus, from scheduling to message, is driven by decisions made at the 7 A.M. meetings here led by Mr. Carville.
 
Changing Personalities
 As the strategic plan hardened, personalities rose and fell. Mickey Kantor, the campaign chairman, returned to the strategic periphery, planning for debates and acting as liaison to party leaders. David Wilhelm's role evolved into that of a political director who runs the state operations. And Susan Thomases, the New York lawyer who is close to the Clintons, took over scheduling, a pivotal position that touches many areas of the campaign. Overseeing the communications, polling and media strategy was Mr. Stephanopoulos.
Once this structure was in place the campaign was poised to take advantage of circumstance. The best day of the campaign was July 16, when Mr. Perot dropped out of the race on the last day of the Democratic convention.
Another potent lift materialized when Mr. Clinton selected Senator Al Gore of Tennessee as his running mate. Strategists naturally planned for Mr. Gore to help the ticket, but not to the degree that polls now show he did.
"Gore was reinforcing," Mr. Greenberg said of the addition of the Senator and his family. "If you assume that the primary process did not allow Bill Clinton to be known, the Vice-Presidential process, rather than to balance him, needed to reinforce him."
 
Joint Appearances
 Campaign officials suggest this was a happy accident, one they were quick to exploit with bus tours and joint appearances at every opportunity.
"If we do only a competent job of keeping the campaign focused on the economy, we're prepared to let the chips fall where they may," said another top adviser, Eli Segal. "As long as we keep the debate on the issues, George Bush has nothing to say."
The Democratic nominee has now rebuilt his campaign from the bottom up, from the nuts and bolts of installing an efficient phone system at the headquarters here to the creation of a strategic hierarchy that has spent the week making a series of aggressive attacks on Mr. Bush.
From Michael S. Dukakis's campaign in 1988 the leaders have learned the value of speedy response. And from last winter's bouts with "character" questions they have learned the value of pre-emptive strikes.
 
Running a Close Race
 Mr. Clinton's strategists have concluded from the experience of 1988 that this year's race will be won narrowly if it is to be won at all.
"Two months ago, whenever I made a speech to fund-raising group, I would say, 'We can win, so stick with us,' " said Mr. Segal, the Boston businessman and veteran Democratic party worker who is the campaign's chief of staff. "Now I say, 'We can lose, so stick with us.' "
For Clinton partisans, the difference is that they now believe they can fight for the Presidency on their own terms. They are not yet cocky, but nearly so.
"For the last couple of months we were running against ourselves," Mr. Greenberg said recently. "We're running against George Bush now. It's a different campaign now."

HEADLINE: 167,000 JOBS LOST IN U.S. BUSINESSES; FED CUTS INTEREST

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4

 BODY:
In a stunningly grim portrayal of the midsummer economy, Government figures showed today that American business and industry lost 167,000 jobs in August as factory employment skidded to its lowest level since April 1983.
The job losses shown in today's labor-market report, the next to last reading before Election Day, were almost completely unexpected by private analysts. The release of the figures promptly led to another cut in interest rates by the Federal Reserve Board. The action was intended to spur economic growth, but it could also help push the already weak dollar lower against foreign currencies. 
 The unemployment rate edged down one-tenth of a point, to 7.6 percent, but this resulted from fewer people seeking work, perhaps because they saw little prospect of finding any.
The Bush camp put on a brave face. The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, called the one-tenth of a point decline in the jobless rate "an encouraging sign that the economy is improving," even though the Labor Department considers it statistically insignificant.
 
Tax Incentives Urged
 Michael J. Boskin, the President's top economic adviser, added, "While the decline in the unemployment rate and the increases in the workweek and hourly earnings were welcome, the employment numbers reiterate the need for the Congress to pass the President's proposed tax incentives to spur growth and create jobs now."
But Congressional Democrats and Bill Clinton's Presidential campaign seized on the figures to disparage the country's economic performance of recent years.
When the Federal Reserve injected money into the banking system just before noon, it was clear that the central bank had established a new 3 percent level for Federal funds, the overnight lending rate among commercial banks. The rate had been 3 1/4 percent.
Analysts said that this, in turn, could mean lower rates on certificates of deposit and money market funds but that the 6 percent prime rate would likely remain.
 
Central Bank Is Inhibited
 But a more aggressive move by the Federal Reserve is not considered likely. In early July, after a comparably dismal jobs report, the central bank cut the discount rate, which is the rate it charges on loans to banks, as well as the Federal funds rate. But now the Fed would be inhibited by the dollar's weakness on international currency markets in recent months and by a lack of evidence that some of the lowest rates in decades are actually spurring economic recovery.
"It's a real jolt," said Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company, referring to the Labor Department's report and its psychological, as well as economic, impact. "Even if you haven't lost your job, you've got to be pretty nervous."
The figures, said Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, head of the Joint Economic Committee, "are striking evidence that the frail condition of the American economy continued into August," with the jobless rate above 7 percent for the ninth straight month. "Despite more than a year of reported growth in the gross domestic product, there are still 1.8 million fewer jobs in the American economy now than there were when this recession started more than two years ago," he said.
Governor Clinton, who has been hammering at President Bush's economic record all week, was quick to work the new unemployment figures into a speech at Pinnacle Mountain, Ark., where he accepted the endorsement of the Sierra Club.
He noted that "there was an actual reduction of 167,000 people employed in the private sector," and said, "If it weren't for summer jobs programs, this country's unemployment would have gone up again this last month." Mr. Clinton then suggested the nation's economic woes were linked to the Bush Administration's environmental policies, saying that unlike the Governments of Japan and Germany, the Administration did not recognize the job-creating potential in industries related to environmental cleanup programs.
Among the 11 large states for which individual data were published today, New York posted a nine-tenths of a point decline in its jobless rate, to 8.5 percent, while the Illinois rate dropped 1.9 points, to 6.5 percent. In California, however, which has been hit by cutbacks in military spending, the riot in Los Angeles in the spring and the state's protracted budget crisis, unemployment surged nine-tenths of a point, to 9.8 percent.
The huge improvement for Illinois, an important political battleground, brought joblessness there eight-tenths of a point below the August 1991 level.
Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., noted in a statement that the jobless rate for adults actually rose in August -- to 6.3 percent from 6.2 for people 25 and over.
Mr. Kirkland, referring to those who could find only part-time jobs and those who have given up the job search, contended that if these people were included, nearly 18 million would be unemployed, a rate of 14 percent.
Today's glum job news prompted some economists to question whether the recession -- which began in July 1990 and probably ended sometime last year, although no formal designation that it is over has been made -- may resume. As measured by gross domestic product, the economy has expanded modestly in the five most recent quarters after contracting in the final three months of 1990 and the first three months of 1991.
Although he did not necessarily foresee a so-called triple dip, Edward F. McKelvey, senior economist for Goldman, Sachs & Company, said there was considerable cause for concern.
Over all, employment was down 83,000 in August, according to the department's survey of payrolls. The decline reflects the 167,000 drop in private-sector employment and a gain of 84,000 government jobs, nearly all of which opened up at the local level with the help of a Federal jobs program established in the wake of the Los Angeles riots.
Manufacturing was particularly weak. In all, 97,000 factory jobs disappeared last month, the second decline in three months after a short period of stability, the department noted. And the weakness was widespread, with losses appearing for 16 of the 20 industries specified, including industrial machinery and transportation equipment.
Jobs in retail trade grew far less than usual in August, declining 71,000 after seasonal adjustment. Construction jobs also fell, with summer losses now having offset increases during the spring.
The department's survey of households, on which the unemployment rate is based, showed 35,000 fewer jobs, along with a 95,000 decline in the labor force. Together, this cut meant that the number of unemployed fell by 60,000, to 9.7 million.
 
Rate Among Teen-Agers
 The one-tenth of a point decline in the unemployment rate followed a similar drop in July. In June it jumped three-tenths of a point, to an eight-year peak. The decline has been largely confined, however, to teen-agers, whose rate fell 1.2 points in August to 19.8 percent.
Without seasonal adjustment, there were 119,082,000 people with jobs last month, the department reported, down from 119,754,000 in July but up from 117,859,000 in August 1991.
William G. Barron Jr., Deputy Commissioner of Labor Statistics, pointed today to what he called a striking pattern over the past year in which the unemployment rate has been governed by growth in the labor force.
For most of the second half of 1991, he told the Joint Economic Committee, there was no labor force growth and the jobless rate held at just under 7 percent. Then, beginning in November, growth became rapid, jobs could not keep up, and the unemployment rate rose nearly a point to June's 7.8 percent. The jobless rate has eased for two months because growth of the labor force has halted without significant job growth.

HEADLINE: Religion Notes

BYLINE: By Ari L. Goldman

 BODY:

Scriptures to Floridians
Along with the hot meals, clothing and bottles of water that have been moving briskly at the emergency distribution centers in Florida and Louisiana has been one other commodity: Bibles.
The American Bible Society in New York reported yesterday that it had shipped more than 31,000 copies of the Scriptures to victims of Hurricane Andrew. English, Spanish and French Bibles were sent. 
 Most of the Bibles were distributed in cooperation with the Salvation Army, which stacked them on their mobile food vans.
"We have 13, soon to be 16, mobile kitchens that are going every day to Dade County, distributing meals," said Capt. Ron Busroe of the Salvation Army office in Fort Lauderdale. "We can use as many Bibles as you can send."
The Rev. Doyle L. Wetherington, executive director of the Miami Baptist Association, said many families had lost their Bibles in the devastation. And whether they had Bibles before or not, he added, reading the Scriptures in a crisis "provides comfort and a sense of stability."
Dr. Wetherington said 16 of the 100 churches in his association were so severely damaged in the hurricane that they could not be used.
Dozens of others religious structures, including a handful of synagogues, also suffered serious damage. Worshipers have been gathering in temporary chapels, parking lots and tents near their churches.
Rabbi David H. Auerbach of Bet Shira Congregation said his goal was to get his badly damaged sanctuary in working order for Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish new year, which begins the evening of Sept. 27. As he spoke, workers were replacing a glass wall that had been smashed by the winds with a new concrete wall. "It's not going to be pretty," he said, "but we are determined to hold services."
The Lubavitch Hasidic group, which has 40 centers in southern Florida, combined its relief efforts in the area with a spiritual message. Rabbi Zalman Schmotkin, a Lubavitch spokesman in New York, said yesterday that the group had distributed 65,000 sandwiches -- tuna, egg salad and cold cuts -- to people who suffered from the hurricane. The sandwiches, which were kosher, were distributed to Jews and non-Jews.
"We also spoke to people about the miracles they experienced," Rabbi Schmotkin said. "Given the wrath of the hurricane, we have to be thankful that there were comparatively few casualties."
 
Inflation Rose Faster
 Contributions to nine major Protestant denominations rose 4.4 percent in 1990 but failed to keep pace with the consumer price index rise of 5.4 percent, according to the recently released 1992 Yearbook of American and Canadian Churches.
The yearbook, published by the National Council of Churches, uses the nine denominations as a bellwether of overall church economic vitality because they are large bodies that regularly report their income from contributions.
Of the nine, the Episcopal Church reported the highest per-capita giving, rising to $811 in 1990 form $763 in 1989, an increase of 6.2 percent.
The largest percentage increase was reported by the United Church of Christ, which showed a 7.1 percent rise to $374 in 1990 from $350 in 1989.
 
Clerics Protest in Israel
 The effort by Ethiopian Jewish clerics in Israel to be treated as officially recognized rabbis took a more aggressive turn this week when 16 of the clerics broke through police barricades in front of the office of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin in Jerusalem and were arrested.
"We requested and begged," said Daniel Adgah, a spokesmen for the clerics, known as kessim, told the Religious News Service. "This apartheid is growing."
Israeli rabbis are authorized by law to wed and divorce Jews and officiate at burials. Similar authority is given to Muslim and Christian clerics. Israel's chief rabbinate, which is responsible for Jewish clerics, has acknowledged the status of the kessim. But the chief rabbis said the Ethiopian clerics must study modern Judaism as practiced in Israel if they want authority.
Although some Ethiopians have been trained in modern Orthodox Judaism, many have not. Ethiopian Jewry is said to date from the time of King Solomon nearly 3,000 years ago. Almost from that time, the Ethiopians had been cut off from Jewish community in Israel and therefore had little knowledge of the Talmud and medieval commentaries that shaped rabbinic Judaism.
Uzi Baram, the Religious Affairs Minister, and Yair Tsaban, the Absorption Minister, called on the police to release the Ethiopian kessim, who represent a community that was largely airlifted by Israel from Ethiopia. The ministers also called on Israel's chief rabbinate to treat the kessim no differently than rabbis.
"It's a shame that there was violence and there were these arrests," Mr. Tsaban said. "This is a quiet community that has gone through a lot."

HEADLINE: Bonds Surge on Poor Jobs Report

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The surprisingly steep decline reported yesterday for employment in August, including a loss of 167,000 private-sector jobs, stunned the bond market, where investors and analysts were expecting a modest increase.
The decidedly bad economic news sent prices soaring and yields tumbling across the board, from the three-month bill to the 30-year bond. 
 The discount rate on three- and six-month bills fell below 3 percent for the first time since 1963. The yield on the two-year note is at its lowest ever, having dipped below 4 percent. The yield on the 30-year bond fell briefly to its lowest level since September 1986 and ended at 7.28 percent, the yield it touched briefly in August and matching the lowest since January 1987.
 
The Fed Makes a Move
 And the Federal Reserve, by injecting money into the financial system after the employment report, indicated that it had lowered its benchmark short-term interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point, to 3 percent, the lowest level in almost 30 years.
The declines in rates for bills, notes and bonds happened in a matter of minutes just after the release of the employment data on a trading day that was cut in half because of the Labor Day weekend. The price of the 30-year bond was up over a point and the increases for notes were similar. The prices came off just a bit after the Fed acted, apparently because some investors and traders had hoped the central bank would go further in bringing down rates.
But all of these new lows in interest rates only emphasized the economy's trouble, because bad economic news is what drives the bond market higher.
These sharp declines and the Fed's 23 previous cuts in short-term interest rates since 1989 have apparently failed to get the economy moving, so the central bank's cautious reduction yesterday was judged by several economists and traders to be far short of what was needed.
They acknowledged that concerns about a weak dollar, which has plunged to a string of lows recently against the German mark, are probably hemming the Fed in. But, they said that given the weakness uncovered by the unexpected jobs data, the Fed must act more emphatically.
"The Fed should say the dollar be damned and lower interest rates," said Robert A. Brusca, the chief economist at Nikko Securities Inc. in New York.
 
Urging That More Be Done
 Neal M. Soss, the chief economist at the First Boston Corporation, said the failure of the Fed to reduce its closely watched discount rate, as it did in December and again in July, left its performance yesterday without the theatrics necessary to get convey the message that the Fed cared about the workers who have lost jobs and about those who are worried that their jobs will be the next to go.
"If the central bank is trying to reach out to Main Street, they should be more declarative," Mr. Soss said.
Now that the Fed has moved to push interest rates lower again, the immediate question is: Will the central bank cut any further? After recent reductions in the Federal funds rate, which the Federal Reserve controls and is a benchmark for other short-term rates, the immediate conclusion has generally been that the Fed was finished. Then new, pessimistic economic data would prompt speculation that the Fed would move again.
Yesterday, analysts were generally convinced that this was not the Fed's last move, although there was no consensus on whether the Fed would act again soon or would wait until the September employment report is released on Oct. 2. That report will be the last monthly jobs data released before the Presidential election on Nov. 3.
For the bond market, this could mean a continuation of the spectacular rally that began in July after the last Fed interest rate cut. Yields on the 30-year bond could even dip below 7 percent soon.
 
Fears About the Deficit
 But at the same time, the bad employment numbers make it more likely that whoever is elected President in November will try to stimulate the economy with a program of new spending and perhaps tax cuts, moves that would increase the record Federal budget deficit. Worries about that could soon begin to trouble the bond market, slowing the decline in long-term interest rates.
For the economy, a sharp decline in long-term interest rates now is more crucial than the fall in shorter-term rates. Many economists have joined the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, in bemoaning the sluggish decline in long-term rates, which are crucial to stimulating the growth in housing and construction that could lead an economic recovery.
"It is possible to have the market trade down and get close to 7 percent on the 30-year bond," said James S. Fralick, the senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. "But as we get closer to the election, political anxiety will push yields back up again."

HEADLINE: Slowest Trading of Year As the Dow Drops 10.27

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Stock prices sagged yesterday in the slowest trading of the year, registering a wary response to unexpected new evidence of weakness in the economy.
Activity tapered off to a near standstill in the afternoon as investors got an early start on the long Labor Day weekend. 
 The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 10.27, to 3,281.93, finishing the week with a net gain of 14.32 points.
Declining issues held a slight edge on advances in the daily tally on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Very Light Volume
 Big Board volume came to 124.3 million shares, down from 212.5 million Thursday and the lightest total since 76.82 million were traded in a post-Thanksgiving session last Nov. 29.
The Labor Department reported yesterday morning that nonfarm payroll employment fell by 83,000 last month, rather than posting the sharp increase economists had been expecting.
Without a temporary surge from a Government summer jobs program, analysts said the drop in employment would have been even bigger.
The news was taken as a strong sign that the economy was still struggling to gather momentum as summer draws toward a close.
It sent interest rates tumbling in the credit markets as traders concluded that the Federal Reserve was moving to ease credit conditions further.
Rates on short-term Treasury bills fell more than 20 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, in some cases to below 3 percent. Prices of long-term Government bonds rose almost $10 for each $1,000 in face value, lowering their yields to around 7.28 percent.
But brokers said stock-market investors' response was more equivocal, influenced by worries about economic growth prospects.
Among actively traded blue chips, Merck rose 3/4, to 49; General Motors gained 3/8, to 35 1/8; Philip Morris slipped 1/4, to 84 3/4, and I.B.M. lost 5/8, to 86.
Glaxo Holdings climbed 3/8, to 29 5/8. A Food and Drug Administration advisory panel recommended approval of the company's drug Zofran for use against post-operative nausea.
Digital Communications Associates, which warned late Thursday that its earnings for the current quarter would fall short of analysts' estimates, tumbled 3 1/2, to 15 3/4.
Bank stocks managed only a mixed showing on the drop in interest rates. J. P. Morgan rose 5/8, to 60 1/4, and Chemical Banking added 1/2, to 33 1/4, but BankAmerica lost 1/8, to 43 7/8, and Citicorp dropped 1/8, to 16 3/8.
Federal National Mortgage, or Fannie Mae, rose 1, to 66 1/2, and Federal Home Loan Mortgage, or Freddie Mac, was up 1/8 at 42 7/8.
Amerada Hess, subject of a rating downwgrade by a brokerage firm, dropped 1, to 47 3/4.
The Nasdaq composite index for the over-the-counter market slipped 1.44, to 573.44. At the American Stock Exchange, which had an abbreviated session because of a fire at a nearby building, the market value fell 0.25, to 384.85.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
U.S. Unemployment Report Sends the Dollar Skidding

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most other currencies yesterday after the Labor Department released surprisingly gloomy news on unemployment and traders anticipated a cut in interest rates. Gold prices rose.
"Today's economic news was enough to make the dollar give up all the steam it got in the previous session," said Hillel Waxman, chief currency trader at the Bank Leumi Trust Company in New York. 
 The Labor Department said that the nation's unemployment rate fell slightly in August, to 7.6 percent, but that employers cut 83,000 nonfarm jobs from their payrolls. A temporary summer jobs program for teen-agers helped the August unemployment rate ease, but adult joblessness worsened slightly and the economy lost thousands of key manufacturing jobs.
 
Fed Cuts Funds Rate
 In response to the report, the Federal Reserve cut its target for the Federal funds rate -- the fee commerical banks charge each other on overnight loans -- to 3 percent from 3.25 percent. The move caused little reaction in currency markets because investors had expected it after the unemployment report, traders said.
Italy raised its discount rate 1.75 points, to 15 percent, and dealers said that both the German Bundesbank and the Bank of Italy had intervened in currency markets to support the lira.
In New York, the dollar fell to 1.4015 German marks, from 1.4135 late Thursday. In Europe, the dollar was quoted at 1.4040 marks, down from 1.4130 late Thursday. Before the Federal unemployment report, the dollar had been trading at around 1.4300 marks in Europe.
In New York, the dollar was quoted at 123.15 Japanese yen, down from 123.80 late Thursday. In London, the dollar was quoted at 123.20 yen. Earlier, in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 124.15 yen, up 1.12 yen from Thursday's close.
In New York, the British pound was quoted at $1.9960, up from $1.9835 late Thursday. In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9945, up from $1.9825 late Thursday.
Other dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday, were: 1.25075 Swiss francs, down from 1.2635; 4.7685 French francs, down from 4.8120; 1.19875 Canadian dollars, up from 1.19695; 1,071.50 Italian lire, down from 1,083.
Gold prices rose worldwide.
On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $341.30 a troy ounce, up from $340.80 on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Your Taxes;
I.R.S. May Help Storm Victims

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
One source of relief for some of Hurricane Andrew's victims is the Internal Revenue Service.
Taxpayers who file an amended 1991 tax return claiming a casualty loss can expect a refund check within four to six weeks because President Bush declared the hard-hit sites of Florida and Louisiana a disaster area. That designation means that people who suffered losses do not have to wait until they file 1992 returns to claim them. However, many taxpayers will be severely disappointed by the size of the losses they can claim, if any. 
 "Many people presume they can take a casualty loss, but the rules eliminate 90 percent of the people I see," said Doug Stives, a member of the Federal tax division of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants and a partner in Curchin & Company, Red Bank, N.J. But the hurricane's devastation was so complete, he added, some people could get "money in their pockets right away if they go back and amend the '91 return."
For personal property, including a home, furnishings, car and clothing, losses can be claimed only to the extent they exceed 10 percent of adjusted gross income plus $100 per occurrence. The loss itself is the lower of the taxpayer's cost basis or current market value less any reimbursement from insurance.
Jerry S. Williford of Houston, chairman of the real estate tax committee of Grant Thornton, a national accounting firm, said, "Each taxpayer's situation is going to be different," under those rules. He discussed three examples of neighbors who had homes worth $200,000 apiece before the hurricane; afterward they had only the land, valued at $40,000, and a pile of rubble.
The first neighbor bought his house in 1970 for $40,000 and had it insured for $150,000, having failed to keep pace with inflation. Although he is going to have to come up with additional money to rebuild, he has no loss for tax purposes since the insurance recovery is more than his cost basis.
The second neighbor bought her house in 1987 for $250,000 and carried replacement-cost insurance. She also has no loss for tax purposes since her insurance carrier will pay her and the mortgage holder enough to rebuild the house. The fact that the house has gone down in value is not at issue. Even if she should sell the rebuilt house for $200,000, capital losses on a personal residence are not deductible.
The third neighbor, like the second, paid $250,000, but like the first is underinsured and collects only $120,000, or $40,000 less than the loss, based on the house's pre-hurricane market value, of $160,000. Say the taxpayer's income was $50,000. The loss that can be claimed is $34,900 -- that is, $40,000 minus 10 percent of income minus $100 -- enough that the taxpayer should be able to get a refund for most or all of the taxes paid last year.
In addition to home losses, of course, many hurricane victims have big losses for other personal possessions. "People never have enough insurance," Mr. Stives said, so when they list everything that was destroyed and add up its current market value, many people may qualify for tax refunds.
Yet many who qualify may be timid about claiming refunds, fearful of the I.R.S. or fearful they have no proof because their records were lost along with everything else.
"You don't have to have proof in filing the return," Mr. Williford said. "Just come up with the best possible estimate. Technically, the I.R.S. could disallow it, but generally they're reasonable people."
In fact, he noted, proof should not be attached to the return. Taxpayers should, however, collect and keep any evidence they can like photographs or receipts in case a return is audited. That is most likely when a return claims losses that seem out of line with income or when it may be examined for other reasons like sizable deductions for medical expenses or charitable donations or unreported income.
Taxpayers should use Form 1040X to file an amended return and attach Form 4684 to list the casualty losses plus a signed statement that they are making the choice to file for 1991 because of Hurricane Andrew. Those who have not yet filed 1991 returns because they are on extension can claim the hurricane losses when they do so, Mr. Williford noted. Detailed information on claiming nonbusiness casualty losses is available in I.R.S. publication 547.
Business losses, net of insurance recovery and depreciation already taken, can be claimed in full, without the income restrictions that affect personal losses.
Many people in Florida have offices in their homes, Mr. Williford noted, so they may have both personal and business losses.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Baseball's Two-Party System

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN

 BODY:
During the last three months, pressure from what was originally thought to be a minority of baseball owners has grown into a committed movement to force Fay Vincent's resignation as commissioner of baseball.
On Thursday the first shoe dropped when owners, meeting in Rosemont, Ill., voted by secret ballot to ask for Vincent's immediate resignation. Vincent has already said that he would never resign, so the battle will move to St. Louis on Wednesday, when the owners will reconvene, apparently with the idea of forceably removing Vincent from office. 
 The dispute between Vincent and his employers has sparked debates between fans and division among owners. If neither side gives in, the feud is very likely to instigate a legal battle that could ultimately define the ability of a private sports enterprise to hire and fire as it sees fit.
As intriguing as all of that is, however, something larger than either Vincent or the owners appears to be taking place in our game. I use "our game" not as an expression of emotion or endearment, but as acknowledgement that baseball is a vital historical possession of a country that, in a relative sense, has such a brief history. In a nation without the haunting magnificence of Europe's castles, cathedrals, synagogues and mosques, which stand as monuments to human effort and endurance, even the most mundane of institutions can be precious, and precarious.
Baseball, as it happens, is one of our most cherished cultural, social and political institutions. The history of the game offers an enlightening insight into the complex ethnic, racial and gender dynamics of our society.
When the foundation of the game changes -- as it is may well be doing at this moment with the owners trying to retrieve the power they gave the commissioner -- the shift becomes more important, historically, than whether Vincent stays or goes. A fundamental shift in baseball should prompt people to examine the reasons behind the shift.
The nation appears to have grown more conservative and less tolerant during the last eight years. According to Clifford Alexander, the former Secretary of the Army who works with baseball to improve minority hiring, the three most recent commissioners -- Peter Ueberroth, A. Bartlett Giamatti and Vincent -- have been Republicans. But ironically, they slowly transformed the office from a job primarily concerned with baseball's narrow interests to one that has focused on higher moral and ethical standards.
Of the three, it is Vincent who has most clearly articulated the notion that the commissioner should be the conscience of baseball.
What this essentially means is that the commissioner will intervene on the side of what is right and moral and in what he defines as the best interests of baseball. And that definition may not necessarily be in the owners' or the players' best interests.
Ueberroth ordered clubhouses open to all reporters regardless of gender and began the minority hiring push that exposed and swept out Al Campanis; Giamatti banned Pete Rose from baseball for gambling; Vincent banned George Steinbrenner and has prodded owners to open their front offices by hiring more minorities.
And perhaps because Vincent himself is wealthy, he felt that baseball owners with vast amounts of money needed to be prevented, or at least discouraged, from stampeding to greater riches and ego gratification at the expense of the game. The evidence has already been recorded, from the owners conspiring to avoid paying high salaries, to their locking out players from training camps.
Now the owners have arrived at a crossroads. The majority of them have apparently grown weary of Vincent's moral platform and have decided to attempt to fire him, effectively reducing him to a pitcher with a sore arm who has outlived his usefulness. They have apparently become so disenchanted that the first name mentioned as a possible successor is that of Ron Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee.
Apparently, the national pastime, like the nation itself, is reassessing its direction and priorities. For baseball, as for the country, the bottom line is economic survival. With the collective bargaining agreement between the players and owners expiring at the end of next season and some teams in dire economic straits, a certain strain of owners feels an urgent need for a change.
Meanwhile, Vincent has vowed to fight. The smaller question is whether this is an egocentric struggle to stay in power or whether he is fighting for the right to enforce a higher conscience.
The larger question is whether the foundation of the game is changing, and what the best interests of the game really are.
