HEADLINE: Credit Cards on the Rise in High Schools

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER

 BODY:
When Saskia Herz, a 16-year-old high school student, needed to buy some expensive supplies this summer for a photography class, she didn't bring along her mother. She brought along a credit card.
"I don't use it that much," said Ms. Herz, who has had a credit card since she was 13. "Because when I do, I have to pay it back out of my allowance." 
 As millions of high school students start a new year, many of them are carrying something besides driver's permits in their wallets. A recent study by Mastercard International suggested that about 10 percent of high school juniors and seniors, or about 640,000 teen-agers, had regular access to a credit card either in their own name or that of an adult, said Gary Flood, a company spokesman.
The Mastercard study appears to be the first effort by a large issuer to determine the extent to which the credit-card culture has penetrated high schools. But there is little doubt that credit-card use by those under 18 is growing and that issuers are increasingly focusing their marketing efforts toward high schools.
"It used to be that college was the big free-for-all for new customers," said Marian Salzman, president of BKG Youth, a New York City marketing concern. "But now, the big push is to get them between 16 and 18."
 
New Programs, New Criticism
 A person under 18 cannot legally get a credit card unless a parent or other adult agrees to take financial responsibility for it. Still, over the last two years, large credit-card issuers like Mastercard, Visa and Discover have started educational programs about personal finance in thousands of high schools nationwide. Some of the programs also include mention or advertisements for their sponsors.
The new programs have attracted criticism from some consumer advocates, who argue that in trying to line up a new generation of customers, credit-card issuers are creating a new generation of debtors. About 65 percent of those who get a credit card stay with their first brand for 15 years or more, Mastercard says.
"It is outrageous for companies to go after kids in high school," said Paul Richards, education director of the National Center for Financial Education, a San Francisco advocacy group. "Young people today are being indoctrinated to spend, not save."
Spokesmen for companies like Mastercard, Visa and Discover said they were not trying to promote credit cards for those under 18 but rather to give them a grounding in basic financial management. Many college freshmen fall into serious debt soon after getting their first credit card, and ruin their credit ratings.
"We are trying to make kids more financially responsible," said Beth Metzler, a spokeswoman for Discover Card Services Inc., a unit of Sears, Roebuck & Company.
The growing debate comes amid both changing economic mores and broad gaps in the type of financial information young people receive. While many teen-agers are still encouraged to save, they are increasingly the targets of marketers beseeching them to spend. And few high schools have programs that teach young people financial management.
"There is certainly a need for this type of education as there is for other life skills like how to get a job," said Lew Armistead, a spokesman for the National Association of Secondary School Principals, a professional group in Reston, Va. "But we have to balance all needs against how many minutes there are in the school day."
The programs developed by credit-card issuers have taken different forms. For the last two years, for example, Discover has sponsored an annual supplement in several magazines produced by Scholastic Inc., a high-school publisher. A recent issue of the supplement called Extra Credit included articles on holding down a part-time job, how credit works and complusive shopping by teen-agers.
The back of the supplement carried a full-page advertisement showing students in a classroom and a picture of a Discover card with the headline: "Go Ahead, We're Behind You."
 
'Choices and Decisions'
 Ernest Fleishman, the director of education for Scholastic, said that the Discover-sponsored supplements had been well received both by teachers and students. "We are very comfortable with this approach, which doesn't encourage students to purchase or not purchase credit cards," Mr. Fleishman said.
By contrast, Visa has developed a classroom teaching program about personal finance called "Choices and Decisions." Visa sells it to banks at a nominal cost, and they, in turn, distribute it to schools. The program, which does not identify Visa as its sponsor, is being used in more than 2,800 schools, said Brad Hennig, a spokesman for Visa International. Mastercard is also developing a teaching program, Mr. Flood said.
Mary Beth Butler, a spokeswoman for Bankcard Holders of America, a consumer-advocacy group in Herndon, Va., said that the group had supported educational efforts about personal finance, but she added that she feared that leaving the effort solely to card issuers might give children the wrong ideas about lenders.
"They need to know that credit-card companies are not doing them a favor but are in business to make money off them," Ms. Butler said.
 
Safer Than Cash?
 Elizabeth Herz, a Manhattan real estate broker and Saskia's mother, said she believed that credit cards were a fact of modern life and that teen-agers should learn how to use them properly. She said they were helpful in emergencies and safer for a young child than carrying cash.
"Do you want a kid walking around with $100?" Ms. Herz asked.
But some parents in smaller cities were shocked by the notion of credit-card-toting high schoolers. "My son hardly spends any money," said Nancy Seldin, a licensed school counselor in Missoula, Mont. "The things he wants to consume, like a big car, are so expensive he knows it is nuts, so he doesn't think about it."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
49 PART-TIME JOBS TO BE CUT BY DELTA AIR

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
Delta Air Lines plans to lay off 49 part-time employees this month at the Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky International Airport as part of a systemwide plan to cut costs. The airline has told the employees their last day of work will be Sept. 15, Frances Conner, Delta spokeswoman, said. The workers stock airplanes with supplies, take tickets and handle baggage. 
In addition, an additional 300 part-time, temporary employees might be laid off at the airport, although Delta said it has not made a final decision. Delta announced in July that it would lay off temporary workers, cut benefits and freeze wages in an effort to reduce annual costs $700 million by 1995.

HEADLINE: Contrasts Mark Republican Primary for Senate

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 4

 BODY:
Connecticut's southwestern corner has produced a pair of Republican candidates for the United States Senate this year whose styles highlight contradictions within Fairfield County and, indeed, the rest of the state.
One of the candidates, Brook Johnson, makes his home in a Greenwich subdivision where the lots are sprawling and residents enter through an electronically monitored security gate. The other, Chris Burnham, lives in Stamford, a city that borders Greenwich to the east and where neighborhoods range from rows of shabby tenements to elaborate estates tucked behind stone walls. 
 For years, the ultimate insult in Stamford has been to characterize someone as being from Greenwich; at the same time, Greenwich youngsters have been known to make snide comments about "Stamford" and "welfare" in the same breath.
Mr. Johnson, a self-proclaimed "self-made man," moved to Fairfield fairly recently. He was born in Willimantic, a hardscrabble mill town in eastern Connecticut, the son of a textile worker who eventually became an executive. A graduate of public high schools and North Carolina State University, he joined the Army after college. He now plays polo in his spare time and belongs to a yacht club.
Mr. Burnham's life went in an opposite direction. Born into a middle-class family in Stamford, he graduated from the Kent School, a private boarding school in northwestern Connecticut. After college (Washington and Lee), he joined the Marines and saw active duty during the Persian Gulf war. He has said that his only asset is his golden retriever, although he does own a nonfunctioning Saab automobile that is sitting in someone else's driveway, he said.
 
Tenfold Difference in Money
 The two candidates, who will face off in a primary Sept. 15, both have business experience: Mr. Burnham, 35, is an investment banker, on leave from First Boston, and Mr. Johnson, 45, owns and runs a towel and bedding concern called C. S. Brooks, although he says he is divesting.
But otherwise their backgrounds are as different as their campaign styles. Mr. Burnham has logged two terms as a state representative and worked for a year as an intern for Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., then a Republican Senator from Connecticut. Mr. Johnson has no political experience but says that is the kind of refreshing change the state needs in a senator.
Perhaps the most obvious contrast in the race is their money. Mr. Burnham has raised about $400,000 and spent slightly more than that, while Mr. Johnson has said he thinks his primary race may cost as much as $4 million and has used mostly his own money so far, aides say.
Mr. Burnham says he is running a classic grass-roots campaign, which has included walking some 150 miles through the state to talk with voters. Mr. Johnson seems to prefer meeting with groups at homes for the elderly or at factories and has spent about $400,000 on television and radio ads.
"It's a close race," said Richard Foley, Connecticut's Republican Party chairman, who, in his capacity as a state representative, voted for Mr. Johnson when the businessman won the party's endorsement at its convention in July.
 
Wooing Fickle Republicans
 Both candidates claim to be underdogs in the primary, and both insist that their efforts are aimed at a bigger goal -- unseating Christopher J. Dodd, the state's senior Senator and a two-term Democrat.
The most recent poll of Connecticut voters by the University of Connecticut Institute for Social Inquiry, conducted in late June and released in July, found that few voters had heard of either Republican candidate.
The poll reported that only one in eight people surveyed were willing to state an impression of Mr. Burnham, with roughly the same results for Mr. Johnson. About 57 percent said they would like to see Mr. Dodd re-elected.
The poll, a survey of 500 adult state residents selected at random, has a margin of error of plus or minus 5 percentage points.
A Quinnipiac College poll of 667 registered voters released today showed similar support for Mr. Dodd, with him getting about three-fifths of the vote compared to about one-fifth for either of the Republicans.
In the primary race, the two candidates are vying for the loyalties of the state's 461,000 registered Republicans, traditionally a fickle bunch, who are deeply worried this year.
They include people like Lynn Helfer of Newtown, a mother of two who was stopped on her way into a grocery store this week by Mr. Burnham, whose name and mission were news to her. He pumped her hand and explained he was running for the Senate.
"I'm having a lot of trouble with the Republican Party's stance on issues," Mrs. Helfer, a registered Republican, said afterward, citing the opposition to abortion and the emphasis on "family values" in the national platform. "I'm worried about the state of the economy also," she added. "I know people who have been hit pretty hard by this."
 
Focus on the Economy
 The two Republicans have made turning the economy around a priority. Mr. Burnham advocates reducing the Federal deficit first, by trimming away government programs he considers unnecessary. With the savings on debt financing that such a move would mean, he says, the country would soon be on the mend.
Late last month, Mr. Johnson released a booklet titled "Blueprint for an Economic Renaissance," featuring an architect's blueprint for a residence, complete with service entrance, on the cover. He calls for enterprise zones to be set up in faltering cities like Bridgeport, New Haven, Waterbury and New Britain, as well as across New England. He supports additional deregulation of business in the manner of Ronald Reagan.
Today, as the candidates met for their first debate, to be televised Sunday, Mr. Burnham heatedly accused Mr. Johnson of plagiarizing his economic plan from a book on fiscal issues by the Heritage Foundation, a conservative think-tank.
"You said that you wrote that plan. I'd challenge you to show one original idea," Mr. Burnham said.
Mr. Johnson responded, "I find it interesting that you've been in this race for over a year, as you keep telling people, and you've yet to produce any plan for anyone to read."
Both Mr. Johnson and Mr. Burnham favor giving investment tax credits to businesses, indexing capital gains tax rates and finding alternatives for workers in the defense industry -- long the linchpin of Connecticut's economy.
To get the state's economy moving, Mr. Johnson's ideas range from improving ports like Bridgeport and New Haven to pushing Connecticut as a home for both another minor-league baseball team (New Britain already has one, the Red Sox) and an amusement park based on Lego toys.
 
An Exchange of Charges
 Like Mr. Burnham, Mr. Johnson supports deficit reduction, beginning with a 4 percent cap on annual spending increases. He also supports the proposed Deficit Reduction Act, which would allow taxpayers to designate 10 percent of income-tax payments for debt retirement.
Both candidates support abortion rights, as does Mr. Dodd.
While the campaigns have spared voters televised mudslinging, neither Republican shrinks from a chance to take potshots at his rival.
Here is Mark Rivers, Mr. Johnson's campaign director, discussing Mr. Burnham's walk last month through parts of Connecticut: "Chris Burnham's walk across Connecticut was a sophomoric publicity stunt. The only issue he raised was which candidate had better shoes or a better pair of feet. While he was walking down the shoulder of I-95, we were visiting factories and senior-citizens homes."
And here is Mr. Burnham, on the differences between him and his opponent: "I'm very optimistic, although the race has come down to money versus message." He adds: "He has a campaign based on slick commercials. I have a campaign based on the grass roots. I believe that the people of this state will make a decision based on my message, rather than his money."

HEADLINE: 2 Women Defy History in New Hampshire Governor Race

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOOKSETT, N.H., Sept. 3

 BODY:
For many people in New Hampshire, the primary next Tuesday in the race for governor has become a tale of two women.
New Hampshire is one of only two states that have never elected a woman to either a statewide office or to Congress; Alaska is the other. But the front-runner in the Democratic primary is Deborah (Arnie) Arnesen, a 38-year-old State Representative, while in the Republican race another State Representative, Elizabeth Hager, 47, is given a chance of an upset victory. 
 Even more surprising, in a fiercely conservative state where candidates for years have taken what is known as "the pledge" not to impose a state income or sales tax, both Ms. Arnesen and Ms. Hager have made calls for a state income tax a major part of their campaigns.
Moreover, both women are advocates of the right to choose abortion. But Ms. Hager's chief opponent in the Republican primary, Steven Merrill, a former State Attorney General, has said he would propose criminal penalties for doctors who perform abortions except in cases of rape or incest or to preserve a pregnant woman's health.
 
'An Absolute Watershed'
 "It's an astonishing turn of events for New Hampshire," said Richard Winters, a professor of government at Dartmouth College, speaking of the two women's emergence and their position on taxes.
Thomas Rath, a lawyer and treasurer of the state Republican Party, said, "The governor's race has the potential to be an absolute watershed in terms of the direction of public policy in New Hampshire."
Even if both women are defeated in the primary, he said, "I don't think we can go back to the way it was before."
The race for the governorship opened up when Senator Warren B. Rudman decided not to run for re-election this fall. That opened the door for Gov. Judd Gregg, a conservative Republican, to start a campaign for his party's nomination to succeed Mr. Rudman. Mr. Gregg has repeatedly denounced attempts to institute any state income or sales tax.
 
The Recession Factor
 In large measure what has allowed Ms. Arnesen and Ms. Hager to become popular candidates in the face of the state's conservative tradition has been the recession.
For most of the 1980's New Hampshire was the fastest growing state east of the Mississippi except for Florida. But since New England's economy slumped in 1989, New Hampshire has lost nearly 10 percent of its jobs, and it has had one of the highest percentage increases in bankruptcies and welfare caseloads of any state.
These troubles have been exacerbated by New Hampshire's singular tax structure, which relies on the property tax for almost 70 percent of government revenue, three times the national average, according to state figures. Property taxes have doubled in the last four years, becoming the highest in the country, Ms. Arnesen says.
The high real estate taxes have been particularly hard on the elderly, who have homes but little income. The escalating property taxes have also touched off a crisis in the state's public schools, which get only 7 percent of their funds from the state, by far the lowest amount in the nation, making each school district almost entirely dependent on the property base of its community.
 
Tax Structure Faulted
 Enter Ms. Arnesen, a native of Brooklyn who settled in a small town near Hanover, the seat of Dartmouth College, after earning a law degree at the University of Vermont Law School. An impassioned, articulate candidate who speaks at machine-gun pace, she says she decided to run for governor because she believes the tax structure is undermining the state.
"Let's remember that in taking 'the pledge' we are not pledging not to have taxes," she told a small audience at a candidate's forum here in Hooksett, a town of 2,500 people in southern New Hampshire. "We are just pledging not to have certain taxes."
The state's current tax system, she said, "is not only bad tax policy; it is bad economic policy," penalizing elderly people and schoolchildren, making housing unaffordable and hurting some businesses, which are subject to a business profits tax.
Ms. Hager, the chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, offers much the same argument from the Republican side. "It's time for people in New Hampshire to face up to the facts," she said at the same forum.
 
Aid to Public Education
 She said the state budget for the current fiscal year, which began July 1, would have had a deficit of 21 percent if New Hampshire had not received a special one-time bailout from the Federal Government in reimbursements for Medicaid payments. That, Ms. Hager believes, constitutes a structural deficit that cannot be made up by the patchwork of taxes and fees the state levies on items like beer, cigarettes, hotel rooms and restaurant meals.
As remedies, Ms. Arnesen and Ms. Hager have proposed similar plans that would establish a state income tax but guarantee that 75 percent of the new revenue would be channeled back to the towns for public education, reducing property taxes in the process.
Mr. Merrill, who is strongly supported by The Manchester Union Leader, for many years the state's most influential editorial voice, has promised not to introduce an income or a sales tax. He has not indicated where he would get the money to make up the deficit, except by cutting spending.
Ms. Arnesen's strongest challenger, Norman D'Amours, a former Congressman, has also vowed to resist new taxes. A third Democratic candidate, Ned Helms, a former commissioner of the State Department of Health and Human Services, supports tax reform.
A third major Republican challenger, Edward DuPont, the president of the State Senate, is against new taxes.
There have been no published scientific polls on the governor's contests, and the candidates' private polls show that large numbers of voters are still undecided. The private polls tend to show Ms. Arnesen leading in the Democratic race and Mr. Merrill ahead in the Republican race. Some private polls indicate that Ms. Hager has been rapidly overtaking Mr. Merrill, but others put her well behind.
After listening to the candidates in Hooksett, Carl Lindblade, manager of the Red Jacket Mountainview Motor Inn, a resort hotel in North Conway, said he was impressed by both Ms. Arnesen and Ms. Hager but was still skeptical of their proposals.
"Having this debate is healthy," he said. "The tourist industry is being killed by hidden fees, which we pretend are not taxes. But I don't think the people of New Hampshire are ready for a broad-based tax. Steve Merrill taking the pledge makes people comfortable."
Still, Ms. Hager is optimistic. At another forum, she said, a man in the audience repeatedly confronted her about taxes, but after the session he approached her and said: "I'm really angry at you. I don't want an income tax in this state. But it's so clear that you're right that I'm going to support you."
Ms. Arnesen acknowledged that in the past few months the growing interest nationwide in female candidates has probably helped her and Ms. Hager. But when she began running more than a year ago, she said, "being a woman was a liability."
"Everyone felt sorry for me," she continued. "They said, 'It's too bad Arnie's not a guy -- she's so bright and articulate.' Now it's helping us."

It was the Vermont Law School in South Royalton. It is not affiliated with the University of Vermont.

PUB-DATE: September 6, 1992

SECTION: Section 7; Page 24; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 897 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy

BYLINE: By LAUREL GRAEBER

 BODY:
THE NIGHT TRAVELLERS, by Elizabeth Spencer. (Penguin, $10.) This novel takes place during the Vietnam War, but its conflicts are personal as well as political. Mary, a former dance student, is torn between the cold rationalism of her scientist mother and the romantic idealism of her husband, an activist and fugitive. Last year our reviewer, Edward Hower, found the book more "about relationships than about historical events, and this is one of its greatest strengths."
DEN OF THIEVES, by James B. Stewart. (Touchstone/ Simon & Schuster, $12.) There is street crime and there is Wall Street crime, and as different as the latter is from the former, James B. Stewart shows that it has no less power to threaten society. This book, which examines the insider-trading scandals of the 1980's, reveals how brokerage-house bad guys manipulated not only money but fundamental free-market principles in their quest -- staggering in its scope -- for ever-increasing wealth. " 'Den of Thieves' should, must be read by every American who gives a damn about this country," Michael M. Thomas said in The Book Review last year, calling it "as good a book on Wall Street as I have ever read." 
 WILL YOU PLEASE BE QUIET, PLEASE? by Raymond Carver. (Vintage Contemporaries, $10.) This edition brings back into print Raymond Carver's first short-story collection, consisting of 22 of his spare, desperate odes to working-class life. "They have been carefully shaped, shorn of ornamentation and directed away from anything that might mislead," our reviewer, Geoffrey Wolff, said in 1976. Also new in paperback is . . . WHEN WE TALK ABOUT RAYMOND CARVER, edited by Sam Halpert (Peregrine Smith/Gibbs Smith, $11.95), a series of interviews with the late author's intimates, including his first wife, Maryann, Richard Ford and Jay McInerney.
BROTHERLY LOVE, by Pete Dexter. (Penguin, $10.) In a poor neighborhood in South Philadelphia, a tragedy unfolds that our reviewer, Robert Stone, found nearly Jacobean. Peter Flood, a man indirectly responsible for the childhood death of his sister, grows up to assume the mantle of violence that grief and guilt have cast upon him. "Few writers are better at describing the ways in which bad men do evil things and forgive themselves, while good men do nothing and suffer agonies of remorse," Mr. Stone said last year.
THE STARCHED BLUE SKY OF SPAIN: And Other Memoirs, by Josephine Herbst. (Harper Perennial, $10.) Josephine Herbst (1892-1969), an author and radical, had her roots in Sioux City, Iowa, but her travels and her imagination ranged all over the world. Last year our reviewer, Alfred Kazin, described this book as her best, a "startling personal document."
STRANGE FRUIT, by Lillian Smith. (Harvest/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $10.95.) This 1944 novel, a best seller that was banned in some cities, focuses on a love affair between a black woman and a white man in 1920's Georgia. "The tragedy of the South is explicit in every line," said our reviewer, William Du Bois.
CHAIN REACTION: The Impact of Race, Rights, and Taxes on American Politics, by Thomas Byrne Edsall with Mary D. Edsall. (Norton, $10.95.) The Edsalls scrutinize America's political parties and find them both guilty: the Republicans of exploiting white middle- and working-class racial and economic fears, the Democrats of letting an activist agenda take them too far from their constituents' concerns. In The Book Review last year, David Oshinsky said that "Chain Reaction," now with a new afterword, "should be read by anyone with an interest in American politics, but it should be required reading for Democratic leaders who dream of someday winning another national election."
CITY OF THE MIND, by Penelope Lively. (Harper Perennial, $10.) Cities are the sum total not only of concrete and brick, but of the memories and impressions they leave with their citizens. Last year our reviewer, Gary Krist, compared this novel about a London architect and the crumbling edifice of his marriage to a "Proustian Baedeker, an effortless blending of geography and free association."
ALVA MYRDAL: A Daughter's Memoir, by Sissela Bok. (Merloyd Lawrence/Addison Wesley, $12.95.) Alva Myrdal (1902-86) was a wife, mother and a Nobel Peace Prize winner in an era in which it was difficult for a woman to combine family and work, much less high achievement. "Accurate, compassionate and honorable, the book itself is a record of spiritual courage," Ursula K. Le Guin said here last year.
A SCANDAL IN BELGRAVIA, by Robert Barnard. (Dell, $4.99.) Peter Proctor, as proper as his name sounds, uses his retirement from the British Government to unravel the decades-old murder of a colleague. Last year our reviewer, Marilyn Stasio, said, "Mr. Barnard never loses control of his polished form, even as he does his pretty hatchet job on the last half-century of Conservative Party politics in England."
REMEMBERING HEAVEN'S FACE: A Moral Witness in Vietnam, by John Balaban. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $11.) Mr. Balaban, a conscientious objector, recalls his own tour in Vietnam as a member of International Voluntary Services, a group he joined as an alternative to military duty. Not surprisingly, he found the experience as scarring as that of his battlefield peers. Last year our reviewer, Doug Anderson, called this an "important book" and "a deeply moving memoir."

HEADLINE: The Cologne Challenge: Is New York's Art Monopoly Kaput?

BYLINE: By Deborah Solomon; Deborah Solomon, a frequent contributor to this magazine, is working on a biography of the artist Joseph Cornell.

 BODY:
In Cologne not long ago, a party was held at the Ludwig Museum to celebrate a new exhibition. As the guests milled for an hour or so, there was much smiling and handshaking and a clatter of German. Everyone sipped not wine or Champagne, but the local party fare -- cold drafts of Kolsch beer. Most of the guests were Cologne art collectors who are, as they say, "into contemporary." The exhibition, borrowed from their holdings, was organized as a tribute to their audacious taste.
Everything about the show was designed to provoke, most notably the cover of the catalogue. It featured a photograph by the American Cindy Sherman, a self-portrait in which the artist is posed amid assorted condoms and dildos. Despite its attempt at in-your-face outrageousness, "Art for the Home," as the show was jokingly entitled, included the usual fashionable names, and in the end seemed less to buck prevailing taste than to endorse it. 
 Like the exhibition, the Ludwig Museum itself is a reminder of the fluidity of cultural power. It was built by the city in 1986 to house the collection of Peter Ludwig, a local chocolate magnate with a hankering for America's Pop Art confections. Wandering the museum's vast, sparsely hung rooms, one finds signed soup cans and sculptured Brillo boxes and jumbo-size cartoon girls, a parade of Pop hits assembled by Ludwig in the 1960's, when American culture was king. But that moment seemed like so much lost history at the opening last May. Of the 32 artists in "Art for the Home," about half were American and half were German, a ratio that reflects as well as anything the recent upsurge of German assurance in its own art as against New York's.
The guests, too, that evening, were measuring themselves against their American counterparts. Among them was Eberhard Garnatz, a prominent collector who is also the director of Cologne's Chamber of Commerce. A large, friendly man who was wearing a loud tie designed by the artist Jean Tinguely, Garnatz shares the widespread German view that American taste is befouled by the pursuit of wealth and status. As he toured the exhibition, he observed: "In America, Frank Stella is like a Frigidaire. No collector is without one!"
WELCOME TO COLOGNE, THE city that has unexpectedly emerged as the European capital of contemporary art and, in the process, busted up the New York monopoly on painting. It isn't only Cologne art collectors who are inclined to inveigh against America; the city's art scene as a whole is consumed by a desire to surpass New York -- and the ecstatic suspicion that perhaps it already has. The rumblings first began in the early 1980's, when a group of German painters stepped into the international limelight under the rubric of Neo-Expressionism. What started as a sensation in slick Manhattan galleries went on to create a new canon in American museums, where artists like Anselm Kiefer, Georg Baselitz and Gerhard Richter have become an abiding presence. Those who keep up with contemporary art in Manhattan can sometimes feel they're viewing a skewed world map on which the only countries that exist are Germany and America.
It's hard to think of a less probable art center than Cologne, a grimy industrial metropolis on the Rhine with a population of about a million. Its previous cultural heyday was in the Middle Ages, and since the 18th century its renown has rested mainly on the perfumy water called eau de Cologne. Heavily bombed during World War II, the city was rebuilt in the 1950's with block after block of Bauhaus knockoffs that resemble nothing so much as airport hotels. Yet it is here in this architectural wasteland that the German art scene is headquartered, with its shining legends (like Richter and Sigmar Polke), cluster of young stars (like Rosemarie Trockel and Martin Kippenberger) and inevitable troupe of the merely hopeful.
It is here, too, that the German galleries are concentrated, pumping out images and ideas that have had a pivotal influence on the rest of the world's post-modernists. Much has been made of the revival of figurative painting that took hold in New York in the early 80's, after a decade of Minimalist rule. This development was spurred in large part by Germans, who since the time of Durer and anonymous Gothic carvers before him, have sought to bring the drama of real life into the cloistered world of art. At the other extreme, "appropriation," art's cynical version of the recycling movement, is also a German specialty: the concept is rooted in a loss of belief in the questing, quixotic adventure of modernism and can have no more meaning anywhere than in Germany, whose history is a monument to the absurdity of enlightened visions.
German artists are hardly unaware of the challenge they have posed to America's cultural hegemony, and they do not lack for confidence. Asked how he viewed the New York art scene, Gerhard Richter, sitting in his sprawling studio in Cologne, paused thoughtfully over his coffee. "Kaput!" he said with a chuckle. "America had such a big and great period, starting with the Abstract Expressionists and then Pop Art and then Minimal and Conceptual. Those were all American things. But you can't expect it goes and goes and goes." He made a circling motion with his hands. "You have to have a break."
Back in New York, few would disagree that American art lost some steam in the 80's. As the Pop artist Roy Lichtenstein observes, "It's hard to say who's ahead -- New York or Cologne -- but you can say that New York isn't as important as it once was." After pointing out that the German art boom might be understood as a belated discovery of artists who came of age in the 1960's, Lichtenstein added in a hopeful tone: "They're having a great period, but it'll fall off eventually."
Art is not the Olympics, and some artists feel it is philistine to keep a running tally on America's artistic standing. Frank Stella, the veteran abstract painter, is among them. "I have no interest in what America does," he told me recently. "What's important is culture and civilization, and we're all in this together." Yet when I mentioned to him that certain Germans felt their country was outpacing ours on the painting front, Stella discarded his lordly detachment. "The best art in the world is still produced in New York," he shouted into the telephone receiver. "German art is O.K. But is O.K. good enough? Vanity plays a big part in their culture. They can't be good. They have to supersede. They have to take over."
IT IS POSSIBLE, ON SOME DAYS, TO find Cologne almost picturesque. Though nearly all its buildings and distinguishing marks were damaged or demolished in bombing raids during the war, the city nonetheless has the hoary, hobbly feel of an age-old village. Its skyline is dominated by the Cologne Cathedral, a masterpiece of the Gothic whose soaring silhouette is the trademark image of the city, beaming from postcard racks and souvenir key chains all over town. The writer Heinrich Boll, a native of Cologne and a Nobel laureate, once bemoaned in an essay that prewar Cologne survives only in photographs -- and that one day "even the actual photographs will become part of a fairy tale." One might add that Cologne's prewar years, paradoxically, seem less real, less imaginable, than the medieval past that produced the cathedral, whose spires guided weary peasants homeward from the fields and beckoned pilgrims to the shrine below.
Cologne still attracts its share of wayfarers: every artist seems to have come from someplace else in Germany. Their turf is the Belgian Quarter, a maze of narrow streets where many of the city's 130 or so galleries occupy the requisite pristine white rooms. Cologne is said to have more galleries per square foot than any other city, a statistic that is difficult to prove but useful in its suggestion of a brash atmosphere. The most prestigious galleries tend to specialize in contemporary German art, and inside their precincts the usual bias against America prevails. Michael Werner, a well-known Cologne dealer who owns a second gallery in New York, insists: "Compared to European artists, American artists are like accountants." How surprising, then, that prices for contemporary German art have remained more stable in the current recession than those for contemporary American art.
The artists of Cologne are apt to practice a studied indifference toward money. There is no place they patronize that qualifies as "haute," or where the food gets much fancier than blood sausage, a ubiquitous local specialty. The city's best-known art critic is an anonymous guerrilla reviewer who voices his appraisals by spray-painting a plump yellow banana outside any gallery he recommends.
IN ITS INSISTENCE ON scruffiness, Cologne's art scene is reminiscent of a college town with everything but the college. The Walther Konig Bookshop has art tomes crammed from floor to ceiling and browsers dressed in bohemian black eternally hunched in the aisles. Across the street is the artists' main hangout, the Broadway Cafe, a smoky little hovel where the art villagers congregate to talk shop. It's no accident that the place takes its name from an American landmark; for all its impudence towards New York, Cologne remains hooked on American culture.
You find reminders on virtually every block of America's contributions to modern civilization, albeit not all of them lofty. On the Hohe strasse, the city's main shopping street, a slender woman sports a gray T-shirt emblazoned with the American television conundrum: "Who killed Laura Palmer?" At an outdoor cafe, a punk in a leather jacket hunches over a paperback copy of a John Irving novel, "Das Hotel New Hampshire." Our junk food is their junk food, down to the last M&M.
American artists fantasize about exhibiting in Cologne, the mark of an auspicious career. One afternoon, I slipped into the hushed elegance of the Jablonka Galerie, whose exhibition consisted in its entirety of five stuffed turkeys displayed on tall pedestals and variously bedecked in a tie, a sport jacket, a blindfold and American Indian headgear. These "Untitled Turkeys" (1992), as the accompanying literature scrupulously identified them, were the work of the New York art star Meyer Vaisman. Standing before them, one stood as well before the legacy of Warhol, for whom nothing was to be taken seriously except the gravely hip joke. Perhaps it was precisely America's pre-eminence in the arts that had allowed for such jesting and wanton banality. Play, after all, is premised on privilege.
How revealing, then, that so many well-known German artists are emigres from East Germany, where their rights were sorely constrained. Is totalitarianism somehow good for art, making the imagination the only safe place to hide? It's a question you can't help but consider in Germany, where most of the prominent older painters -- including Georg Baselitz, Gerhard Richter, Sigmar Polke, A. R. Penck and Markus Lupertz -- are refugees from political oppression. Much has been made of the collective German guilt that produced an artist like Anselm Kiefer, who is famous for his war-haunted confessions. Yet what needs to be said is that many German artists were caught in an additional predicament; long after Hitler was crushed and West Germany emerged as a democratic state with an enlightened cultural life, the Communist party line in East Germany still denounced modern art as a crime against the state.
Penck, for instance, whose large, clamorous canvases explore the modernist obsession with primitive art on a billboard-size scale, was stuck in East Germany until 1980. Unable to show his work publicly, he smuggled it to Cologne in rolled-up newspapers. We arrange to meet one day at a cafe, and I ask Penck, a rotund man with a long, gray beard, how an artist trapped inside a cultural void could create pictures brimming with references to Picasso and Klee. He replies succinctly: "Repression unleashes strong desires."
Gerhard Richter, perhaps the most widely respected painter in Germany, recalls the air of charged mystery surrounding modern art during his student days in Dresden in the 1950's. "Secretly we saw the catalogues and reproductions, but it was forbidden to see any work after French Impressionism," he says. "At the library whole sections were missing from the shelves. When we did look at Cezanne or Cubism, we were attracted to it, but we didn't have the knowledge to understand it."
Such a bleak predicament seems impossibly remote on this shining spring morning in Richter's studio. The place is fastidious, with paintings-in-progress hung in careful rows and the artist's materials hidden away behind labels like Papier, Tesa and Hand schuhe (paper, tape and gloves, he explains; discretion prevents me from asking why he works in gloves). Richter -- a diminutive, dark-eyed man of 60 -- wears an air of general modesty, as if none of his ideas could be of much interest to a visitor. As he sets out coffee and a tin of lacy cookies, he says: "There are two problems with this interview. One is my English. The other is that I'm not very intellectual." He shakes his head. "It's a pity."
Critics writing about Richter's work invariably remark that over the years he has shuttled restlessly between landscape, portraiture and pure abstraction, as if his very inability to settle on a style were somehow the point. Yet all styles are not equal. In defiance of the German tradition of graphic figuration -- Ernst Ludwig Kirchner with his thin, jittery bodies, Max Beckmann with his unhappy urbanites, Baselitz's upside-down men -- it is as an abstract painter that Richter has created some of the most original images of our time and wielded immense influence on other "neo-abstractionists."
A typical Richter abstract painting is easy to recognize. It's composed of shrill reds and yellows that look as if they were smeared by a giant windshield wiper, or rotated on one of those "spin art" machines found at street fairs. The work has a deliberately chilly quality; its streaks and splatters suggest a petrified version of Abstract Expressionism. Perhaps Richter is taking refuge in the post-modern plea that after the darkness of the war, conventional forms can only fail us. When I ask him if he sees his work as German, he replies with characteristic ambivalence: "I'm not interested in a German style and I don't know what it is. But whenever I see my work in another country, I think, ah, it looks a bit German. It has to do with Germany."
It can be unsettling to contemplate the speed with which a nation nowadays rises as an art power, or declines. Like brokers watching the fluctuations of the stock market, the art crowd can confidently tell you the latest -- that Barcelona and London are rapidly gaining, that Italy is fading despite an 80's surge, that French art remains irretrievably dead, entombed by academic theory. Things used to happen more slowly. From the 17th century up until World War II, Paris remained the seat of world culture. Then New York took the lead. No story in American art has been given the Hollywood treatment more than the 1940's ascent of the Abstract Expressionists, starring Jackson Pollock, Willem de Kooning and the rest of the hard-drinking, impecunious gang who set out to topple the supremacy of Paris. Their victory was so stunning it's still prompting sour-grapes grumbling about "How New York Stole the Idea of Modern Art," to borrow the title of the 1983 book by the French art historian Serge Guilbaut.
Today, in an age of mass communication and mass travel, it is sometimes said that the notion of an art capital -- one single, unstoppable fountainhead of new ideas -- is becoming anachronistic. If air travel reduces the distance between countries, it also reduces the cultural differences that constitute a reason for leaving home. More art is like other art than ever before. With German money and political power convening in a united Berlin, it is believed that city will eventually become the next new brazen center of culture. And yet surely its art scene will have the weaknesses of its strengths, the most obvious among them being a trendiness to its art. Already older German painters complain about a bland global esthetic they see overtaking the young. As Markus Lupertz tells me one morning in his dim, cluttered studio in Dusseldorf: "The same way the international food is steak and salad, the German critics, who are the stupidest people, have this idea of an international art style, and that style is conceptual art."
At 40, Rosemarie Trockel is among the celebrated young artists of Cologne who have sworn off painting in favor of a more conceptual approach. She earned her first fame in the late 1980's for "knitted paintings," blunt, rather doctrinaire creations composed from computer-made textiles. Where Trockel rises to eloquence is in her more sculptural works, like the 1989 "Untitled (Eva in Trance with Ectoplasm)," a papier-mache and plaster object depicting a not unsubtle image -- a human head oozing gunk. The piece harks back to the smooth, spare, dreaming heads of Brancusi, while rejecting his formal purity. Trockel's punctured head is a metaphor for a postwar Europe in which everyone is bruised and no one any longer believes that the modernist engagement with abstract forms can save them.
Trockel lives on the outskirts of Cologne, in a rambling red-brick building that was formerly the Edelweiss Laundromat, as a sign hanging outside attests. Stopping by one Saturday afternoon, I find her in the kitchen, a sturdy and soft-spoken blond woman picking limp strands of sauerkraut from a bowl with her fingers. "I've heard that it helps prevent cancer," she explains with a smile, leading me into the well-stocked library that adjoins her studio. There are no conventional art supplies around; the artist needs little beyond the wooden chair where she sits and thinks, since her recent creations have been fabricated in factories.
Trockel may be a lapsed painter, yet her work remains as tethered to a specific time and place as that of any of her older compatriots. Born in 1952, she was reared in the small town of Schwerte and recalls an atmosphere in which children had to live with both the sins of their parents and the uneasy hush of denial. "When I was growing up," Trockel says solemnly, "no one talked about the war. We weren't taught about it at school, and whenever it came up, the nuns would simply cry and run away. My father was in the war. I never asked him if he killed anyone, but it was always in my head: Did he or didn't he? I'd meet my uncle and think: Did he or didn't he?" She pauses, and her mouth twists into a frown. "If you can't believe in your own brother, you have to believe in art."
Fierce words, and yet fierce words are the local dialect of Cologne. Every artist has a story to tell, dolorous tales of hometowns being bombed, of paintings being banished, of life as people knew it crumbling into nothing. To younger artists like Trockel, by contrast, the single most indelible event is not World War II, but the fact that they missed it, and grew up in frustrated ignorance of the incomprehensible deeds of their elders. Listening to the countless fevered stories, it's as if the events of half a century ago had happened half a year ago. And yet what gives Cologne its distinct flavor is less the intrusion of haunting memories than the way the art galleries so prosperously market them. This is a city with inner demons for sale.
Perhaps it has always been that way in Cologne, the transcendental and the commercial existing side by side. One evening, seated at an outdoor cafe beside the cathedral, its arching spires now blue against the dusky sky, the art critic Wilfried Dickhoff explained: "In the Middle Ages, relic dealing was concentrated in Cologne. There were so many bones of holy people that the Pope closed the borders." He relayed the information in an amused tone, the implication being that Cologne has a very long history of turning the ideal into a material deal.
In discussing the rise of German art, cynics tend to dwell on the country's economic "miracle," the implication being that art is an automatic byproduct of wealth. (If this were true, Tokyo would be the Parnassus of the modern world.) However, it is incontestable that German artists have benefited from their Government's prodigious patronage. In the area of public funds for the arts, the country has little competition from the United States, whose per capita budget for cultural affairs is among the lowest in the industrialized world. In 1987, the most recent year for which such comparative statistics were compiled, Germany's arts expenditures came to $39.40 per citizen, while the United States meted out just $3.30.
It is easy to count marks and dollars, yet harder to measure the sense of mission the Germans have brought to their Kulturkampf -- the quest for cultural excellence. In America, as the National Endowment for the Arts continues to be enmeshed in controversies over the financing of sexually explicit artwork, it sometimes seems that our Federal arts officials do little but fret over questions of propriety. Meanwhile, Bonn, Frankfurt, Stuttgart and Dusseldorf can all claim important new art museums, as I learn one morning in the office of Marc Scheps, a genial, sixtyish man who became the director of the Ludwig Museum last year. "Germany has been offering far more than France and Italy and Spain, more than any country in Europe," he tells me, gazing up at the Kenneth Noland painting of a target that hangs on his otherwise bare walls and echoes his invincible tone.
Perhaps nothing demonstrates the Ludwig's eagerness for world standing more than the installment of Scheps himself. The museum's new director was selected from, of all places, Israel, where he was the longtime director of the Tel Aviv Museum.
Germany's culture is notoriously decentralized. In a country where every town seems to have its own opera house, there is no single metropolis like New York where publishing, art, theater and music are all firmly centered. Before the art scene gravitated to Cologne in the early 1980's, nearby Dusseldorf was the place to be. There, Joseph Beuys, the charismatic artist-guru in his signature gray felt hat, enthralled a generation of students at the fabled Dusseldorf Academy and became "the Pied Piper of postwar German aesthetic renewal," as the critic Robert Hughes once dubbed him. Berlin, in the meantime, was the locus of the Neo-Expressionists, who sought to reconnect the thread of German Expressionism severed by the war, often with facile results; undisciplined brushwork was splashed out by the yard.
The Cologne art scene, by contrast, has historically been associated less with high-minded strivings than with simple high jinks. Here, Max Ernst and Hans Arp promulgated the shock tactics of Dadaism after World War I. But yesterday's rascal is today's blue-chip master, and the only voice of dissent nowadays heard in the galleries of Cologne belongs to collectors bemoaning the high cost of the art.
AS MINISTERS OF culture plot their strategy, as new museums rise and existing ones expand, as art dealers and critics rush to discover the latest "ism," the artists of Cologne remain loath to acknowledge any interest in the activity swirling around them. To the contrary, they like to pretend that the attention lavished on them is a miserable burden they wish would instantly evaporate. Their bohemian posturing might be understood as yet another aspect of their rivalry with New York artists, whom they tend to speak of as if they were all Madonna with a paintbrush.
Surely no one relishes his outsider status more than Sigmar Polke; at 51, he's Cologne's most worshiped art legend. He shuns publicity, avoids his own openings and can be so elusive that his friends and benefactors competitively trade ancecdotes about the lengths they have gone to find him. He and Richter were close in the 1960's, when they helped found a movement called Capitalist Realism, a homegrown strain of Pop Art, but even they don't speak anymore. I harbored little hope of meeting Polke during my visit to Cologne, yet telephoned anyway late one afternoon. Had he received my letter? "I don't read my mail," he replied brusquely. Was he willing to be interviewed? "No," he growled. Yet when I suggested a quick cup of coffee, he surprised me by agreeing, providing I could come to his studio right away. Then he added smugly: "You won't be able to find it."
Indeed, a cab ride that should have taken 10 minutes took nearly an hour, during which time it seemed increasingly plausible that the artist's invitation was instead a sardonic joke. Finally, the taxi pulled up at a squat factory building sequestered behind a chain-link fence. Polke, a thickset man in shorts and bare feet, was sitting outside with a clutch of young assistants, a 16-millimeter movie camera in his hand. As I stepped from the cab, he trained the camera on his interloper and shouted with unexpected geniality: "I knew you'd find it! New Yorkers can find anything!"
He led me into his studio, a looming, hangar-like space where a dozen new paintings were stacked up carelessly in a far corner. Though painted on sheets of cheap, see-through vinyl, they evoked an airy rococo dream, complete with vaporous mists and fluttering angels. Polke is a master at marrying images and effects that don't belong together. He was raiding art history for material long before that nervy deed acquired respectability as "appropriation," and his influence on young American artists like David Salle has been considerable.
When I raised the question of whether New York was still the international capital of art, Polke appeared baffled. "What does zis mean, art capital?" he replied. "There are some activities here, and some activities where you are, and we profit each other. Every city treats the problems of art in a special way, whether it's Cologne or New York or the Cote D'Azur in France." As he talked on, the thin light of early evening cast shadows across the gray-carpeted floor of his studio. The question of an art capital seemed suddenly beside the point. Polke's paintings were an affecting reminder that every artist draws on the art of his age to create something that will outlast him, something that stretches beyond the boundaries of time and place.
Then again, art may be larger than nations, but artists are not, as Polke himself demonstrated only minutes later. Combing through his stack of recent paintings, he pulled out a particularly lyrical work and gestured toward a section in which veils of amber pigment twist gently through space. And then taking aim at an American famed for his supple touch, he bellowed as if for all the world to hear: "Never could Willem de Kooning do this!" Clearly the race is on.

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
Family Values

BYLINE: By William Safire

 BODY:
INTEGRITY, COURAGE, strength" -- those were the family values as defined by Barbara Bush at the Republican convention in Houston. She added "sharing, love of God and pride in being an American." Not much controversy in that definition.
But on "family values night," as Marilyn Quayle described the session dominated by Republican women, the values took on an accusatory edge: after recalling that many in the baby boom had not "joined the counterculture" or "dodged the draft," the Vice President's wife made clear to cheering conservatives what she felt was at the center of family values: "Commitment, marriage and fidelity are not just arbitrary arrangements." 
 Pat Robertson, the religious broadcaster who sought the Presidential nomination four years ago, eschewed such innuendo and slammed home the political point: "When Bill and Hillary Clinton talk about family values, they are not talking about either families or values. They are talking about a radical plan to destroy the traditional family."
We have here the G.O.P.'s political attack phrase of the 1992 campaign. When Mario Cuomo stressed the words family and values in his speech to the 1984 Democratic convention, he used them in a warmly positive sense. But this year, packaged in a single phrase, the terms are an assertion of moral traditionalism that carries an implicit charge: the other side seeks to undermine the institution of the family by taking a permissive line on (a) abortion rights, (b) homosexual rights and (c) the "character issue," code words for marital infidelity.
Sometimes pot smoking is included, but sex is most often the common denominator, and the pointing finger includes women who do not center their lives inside the home: the defeated candidate Pat Buchanan includes "radical feminist" in his angry denunciation of those who lack what he considers to be family values.
The use of family as an attributive noun in its modern sense can be traced back to the 18th century, as in Samuel Johnson's 1781 sales pitch for his dictionary: "This Lexicon . . . might become a concomitant to the Family Bible." In that decade, family man was coined, followed a generation later by family circle.
The word family is based on the Latin famulus, "servant"; in 1400, a man's servants included his wife, children and domestic help. "His family," goes a report of a 1621 Star Chamber case, "were himself and his wife and daughters, two mayds, and a man." You do not have to be a radical feminist to know that this sense has been lost. The poet John Milton first used family in the sense of "parents and children" in "Paradise Lost" in 1667, with Jesus as the head of the family of Man: "As Father of his Familie he clad/ Thir nakedness."
The family being used as the attributive, or modifying, noun today is the traditional family, by which is usually meant a father and mother (of opposite sexes), legally married, with children under 18 living at home. According to the Census Bureau, 26 percent of American households now meet these criteria.
This group is also known as the nuclear family, a coinage of the anthropologist George P. Murdock in 1949 -- "a married man and woman with their offspring" -- perhaps taken from the 1913 "nucleus-complex" discussed by the psychoanalyst Carl Jung, combining the lust of sons for mothers and lust of daughters for fathers. (How did we get here? Back to politics.) In 1966, Daniel T. Jenkins wrote of "the extended, as distinct from the nuclear, family," and Barbara Bush in 1992 used that term to expand her meaning of family: "When we speak of families, we include extended families. We mean the neighbors, even the community itself."
The earlier term for something similar to family values was social issue, a 1970 coinage by Richard M. Scammon and Ben J. Wattenberg in their seminal work, "The Real Majority." The authors argued that rather than being primarily concerned with the old bread-and-butter issue of economics, the voters were turning their attention to the drug culture, angry dissenters and changing moral standards.
Like the social issue, the term family values calls attention to a cultural rather than an economic interest, as Republicans are especially eager to do this year; the difference is that the use of family values focuses more sharply on abortion, gay rights and the pre- and extramarital activities that go under the name of playing around or hanky-panky. (Another sexual issue, harassment, is not included in most definitions of family values, presumably because it usually takes place at the office and not within plain sight of the family; besides, opposition to sexual harassment is a cause more associated with feminists and libertarians than with traditionalists.)
And now, for etymologists at least, to the jackpot question: Who is the coiner of family values in its current sense? The earliest use of the phrase I can find is in "The Education of Catholic Americans," a 1966 book by the Rev. Andrew M. Greeley and Peter H. Rossi: "Marriage and family values do show some relationship with Catholic education; however, the relationship is in most instances not a strong one." (Greeley, now also a well-known novelist, has just published "Wages of Sin," its title taken from a grammatically disagreeable line in the Book of Romans: "For the wages of sin is death.")
The first official political use of family values was in the 1976 Republican Party platform: "Divorce rates, threatened neighborhoods and schools and public scandal all create a hostile atmosphere that erodes family structures and family values."
Lexicographic Irregulars are invited to submit earlier citations; more to the point, however, is the search for the modern political operative who first sent his principal a memo about how the public can be distracted from slow economic growth by a concentration on family values. Even the most confidential White House interoffice memorandums will be accepted in this purely lexicographic quest.
The campaign theme is powerful, but it can backfire. At the Houston convention, as a score of the members of the Bush family gathered around the President and Barbara Bush to display family values in all their solidarity, the background music inexplicably chosen for this moving moment in the Astrodome was "The Best of Times" from "La Cage aux Folles," a Broadway musical that broke new ground in the straights' acceptance of homosexuality.

HEADLINE: LITHUANIAN INDEPENDENCE

 BODY:
Budris's article raises an important question: Why does the West come to the aid of Russia and ignore the brave Baltic republics -- particularly Lithuania -- who faced Soviet tanks and economic blockades alone and now must contend with their renegade army, some 70,000 strong? Lithuania should be rewarded for the billions saved as a consequence of helping to end the cold war and the arms race; instead, it is being ignored at a time in its history when its hard-won independence is still so precarious. When will the West realize that the interests of these small democracies are our interests as well?
 
E. K. BURDEN

HEADLINE: How the New Charter Affects Land Use

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
DESPITE a dearth of construction in New York City, communities are feeling the impact of land-use review procedures that went into effect two years ago under the 1989 City Charter revision.
The new rules have stirred up greater land-use planning activity at the borough level. And many community board officials say they are better informed now than they were in the past about prospective changes in their neighborhoods. 
 But others complain that, without the Board of Estimate and its calendar of meetings, they can no longer be sure they will find out about important issues in time to prepare a coherent position statement.
For the most part, local leaders who felt that Charter reform would help them keep unwanted city facilities from their neighborhoods have been disappointed.
"The Charter held out false hope to communities," said Rosina K. Abramson, executive director of the Department of City Planning. "They thought they were getting a better balance of power with city government. What they got was lawyer-like amendments that complicated the process."
Under the Charter revision, all comprehensive land-use proposals, as well as changes in the city zoning law or in urban-renewal plans, must go to the City Council after a lengthy public hearing process.
Community boards must be included early in the process, when developers are "scoping out" their proposals with the Department of City Planning.
And there is a process for making the City Council the final arbiter when the City Planning Commission approves a land-use project over the opposition of a community board and a Borough President.
Moreover, the Charter requires each Borough President's office to publish a plan that incorporates the needs of each community. And under its so-called fair-share doctrine, the city government must at least consider whether communities are overburdened or underserved when city facilities are sited.
Still, the new process is in many ways less indulgent of narrow neighborhood interests than the old. Last month, the City Council approved a new incinerator to be built in the former Brooklyn Navy Yard over strong local objections.
In the Bronx, Community Board 8 can't persuade the City Planning Department to let it downzone parts of Riverdale unless it allows higher-density building on Bailey Avenue in Kingsbridge. And in the Douglaston section of Queens, civic associations are suing to overturn zoning variations that were granted to developers.
"It was a lot easier when we could appeal to the Board of Estimate," said Bernard Haber, chairman of Community Board 11, which includes Douglaston.
Land-use officials offer quite different views of the new Charter's impact. "Land use is now a much more central part of what the Borough President's office does," said Marla Simpson, Manhattan's director of land-use planning.
That idea gets a chuckle out of Marilyn Gelber, Ms. Simpson's Brooklyn counterpart, who has the title of executive assistant to the Borough President. "It's the people who favored Charter revision who perpetrate this myth that planning has increased dramatically," she said.
A ZONING squabble in which Ms. Gelber is involved underscores the rivalries that procedural revisions cannot paper over. She and Frederick Gross, the director of planning and development for Queens, have filed diametrically opposed texts for a proposed zoning revision that would restrict where the city can put future garbage-transfer stations.
His would forbid siting any noxious activities -- including garbage-transfer stations -- in any area zoned for light manufacturing. Hers would allow them on a case-by-case basis in most areas, provided they met specific performance standards.
Subsequently, Ms. Gelber withdrew her text in favor of yet a third one, put forth by Bernd Zimmermann, director of the bureau of planning and development in the Bronx. His text also stresses operational rather than locational restrictions.
"Fred's zoning text would effectively ban garbage-transfer stations in Queens and site them squarely in Brooklyn and Bronx," Ms. Gelber insists. Mr. Gross, who recently laid out a plan for making Queens a region-wide railway hub, counters: "Zoning is a development tool. You can't attract clean industry to an area with garbage stations."
Since shelters for the homeless and other often-unwanted facilites have been dropped from the city's construction plans, the practical effect of the new planning rules is seen most vividly in the way the Borough Presidents are setting priorities and spending their new, bigger budgets.
The Bronx, for example, has set up a land-use staff of nine professionals and a salary budget of about $350,000 and is trying to promote more moderate-income housing and viable businesses. Mr. Zimmermann recently got all 12 Bronx boards to petition the Mayor to move the Police Academy to Bronx Center and to approve Melrose Commons, a large-scale housing proposal.
Borough President Fernando Ferrer allocated about a quarter of his capital budget of $18 million in fiscal 1992, which ended last June 30, to subsidize thousands of new housing units, thus making housing affordable to a wider income band of the Bronx population.
The Queens office is operated with eight people and a payroll of $340,000. Queens Borough President Claire Shulman has a capital budget of $32 million this fiscal year, of which $3.25 million is earmarked for housing. Zoning is a primary focus in Queens, where a 40-person task force, with a shifting complement of community members, has been re-examining existing zoning in each neighborhood, with an eye toward lowering allowable densities in many so that their one-family character is preserved.
WITH just two people and a salary budget of about $154,000, Paul Bonfilio, Staten Island's land-use director, can do little more than keep residents apprised of their rights and of relevant projects, and try to snag the occasional lucrative project for his borough. Borough President Guy V. Molinari spent $600,000 of his $8 million capital budget on housing the elderly in fiscal 1992.
Manhattan Borough President Ruth W. Messinger has far and away the most imposing planning apparatus, with a staff of 12 and a payroll of $475,000. One of its main priorities is to alert communities early enough so that disputes over land-use projects can be resolved without suits.
The planners recently warned a Central Harlem community about a scheduled auction of six parcels of city-owned land in time for them to get use restrictions put on them. They are helping Community Board 8 on the Upper East Side put together a proposal to restrict the depth of new buildings.
And they helped get a planned shelter for people with AIDS moved from West 44th Street, where theater owners and other prominent Times Square business people opposed it, to 10th Avenue in the 20's, where the community welcomed it.
"In the old days we might not have known about the project until too late to do anything about it," said Paul Libin, producing director for Jujamcyn Theaters, which led the push for alternative siting of the shelter. Warrie L. Price, an official of Community Board 8, added: "I feel the community really gets more help and more of a voice now."
In Brooklyn, Borough President Howard Goldin, who opposed the Charter revision, has hired a land-use director, John Benguiat, and given him an assistant. But because Borough Hall's old system of specialists in education, economic policy and the like remains intact, it is difficult to cite dollars spent specifically for land- use review activities.
But some $10.3 million of the Borough President's $38 million capital budget for fiscal 1993 is allocated to such development projects as refurbishing the waterfront and industrial parks, and $4.6 million is committed to new housing.
Despite her skepticism about the new procedures, Brooklyn's Ms. Gelber is talking about running planning shows on public access stations, and videotaping a master plan for the borough. She also said that, symbolically at least, it was good that hearings on developing the site of Brighton Beach Baths -- a project that was approved in July -- were held at the Borough President's office.
"At least people are now realizing that they no longer have to run to City Hall to be heard," she said.
