HEADLINE: Making the Choice: A Co-op or a Condo

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
WHEN they started looking around their Greenwich Village neighborhood for an apartment to buy last spring, Jeffrey and Victoria Connell thought they had a handle on the distinctions between co-ops and condominiums. But early in their search, an apartment they liked and could afford was scratched from their list when they discovered that the co-op had a 40 percent cash requirement.
"We were about to make a bid," said Mr. Connell, "when we found out about the 40 percent down payment requirement. We could have done it, but it would not have left us much cash for other things, like closing costs, the move or improvements in the apartment." 
 If the apartment had been in a condominium, only the Connells' mortgage lender could have dictated the cash portion of their down payment.
But co-op boards have the right to require buyers to put any amount -- even all of the purchase price -- down.
Buyers like the Connells, many of them new to the market, find the choices before them go beyond matters of price and personal taste. Before buying they must grapple with distinctions between co-ops and condominiums on matters involving monthly carrying costs, building finances and the owner's relationship to his neighbors.
While a condominium unit, for example, may carry a higher price tag than the same size co-op apartment, the difference may be illusory. Most co-op buyers take on two debts when they buy -- their own mortgage on the unit and their share of any mortgage the co-op has on its building.
There can be differences in financing the co-op or condominium purchase too. Some co-ops ask high cash payments by buyers, but it is the lender who determines the down payment in a condominium. And the cost of closing on a loan for a condominium is normally higher than for a co-op. Another distinction, which to some buyers is the most significant of all, is the control that co-op boards have over such matters as who buys in the building and whether subletting is allowed. Some co-ops charge shareholders a fee, known as the flip tax, when they sell their apartments. Although this cost, which for most co-ops is between 2 and 4 percent of the sale price, is the seller's responsibility, it does factor into the price. It is a cost most condominium sellers do not pay.
And co-op and condominium apartments in the same size category can vary widely. A two-bedroom co-op in a luxury-level prewar building is often a six-room residence and includes a formal dining room and full foyer. By contrast, only the most luxuriously spacious two-bedroom apartments in new condominium towers have full dining rooms. Many lack full foyers or entry halls.
ROSE EDWARDS, a real estate broker in Manhattan, said the new wave of buyers is carefully scrutinizing the purchase process. While the market's skid has given buyers a break in prices, it has also made for more cautious consumers.
"The difference is that buyers are much more conscious of what they need to know before they buy," said Ms. Edwards, whose real estate brokerage company, Walscott Company, specializes in Greenwich Village, Chelsea and SoHo listings.
"They know that they must buy for the long-term," she said. "They don't have the crutch of being able to sell easily if the financial burden is too great or their apartment is not what they wanted."
Realtors say this is a stark contrast to the mid-80's, when many buyers just wanted to know how much an apartment cost and, if it was in a co-op building, whether the board was going to let them in.
The drop in prices and the market slide of the late 80's, which took some converted co-op buildings to the brink of failure, left an impression on many buyers.
John and Lisa Bendik, for example, said they didn't avoid co-ops but they carefully scrutinized the finances of the buildings they considered.
"I had some ideas about wanting things like lots of windows and a building where I didn't have to depend on an elevator," said Lisa Bendik. "But what was most important to us when we looked at co-ops was the level of risk in the ownership."
The Bendiks said each apartment they considered passed or failed on such matters as the building's tax status, the age and amount of any temporary tax benefits, the condition of the mechanical components and the size of the building's mortgage in proportion to the number of units, and the proportion of shares held by owner-occupants as opposed to non-occupying owners, including the conversion sponsor.
They settled on an East Village co-op that is 100 percent owner-occupied.
"It was important for us that everyone in the building be owners," Mrs. Bendik said. "With only 20 apartments there is not much room for financial problems."
If the Connells do buy an apartment, they will join about 480,000 co-op or 80,000 condominium owners in New York City. Apartment ownership became an option for many of those owners only in the 70's, when large-scale conversion of rental buildings began.
Until then the vast majority of New Yorkers were renters. The few co-op apartment buildings were either luxury-level prewar buildings, mostly on Fifth and Park Avenues, or limited-equity co-ops built for middle-income residents under the state's Mitchell-Lama program or the earlier Section 213 Federal program after World War II.
The co-op movement gathered speed when landlords, weary of the restriction of the rent regulation system, started selling their buildings to the tenants or to conversion specialists. Another boost came in 1971 when the state Legislature allowed banks and other lenders to offer co-op loans.
Before 1982, landlords were required by law to have sales agreements with the tenants in 35 percent of the apartments before a conversion from rental could take place. Under these so-called eviction plans, the sponsors were not required to offer lease renewals to stabilized tenants after the conversion.
In 1982, the co-op and condominium conversion laws were revised and non-eviction plans came into widespread use. They allowed sponsors to convert buildings with as few as 15 percent of the units sold, but nonbuying tenants were assured of the right to a lease renewal under rent stabilization.
The new rules also increased the percentage of required sales for eviction plans to become effective -- to 51 percent of the units in the building from 35 percent. Noneviction plans made the conversion process easier for owners and became the conversion method of choice for most sponsors.
The first high-rise condominium in New York, the St. Tropez at 340 East 64th Street, was built in 1964. For years it stood alone. But at about the same time the conversion movement was taking root, the pace of development of new high-rise residential buildings quickened. By the early 80's, most of the new construction of luxury-level housing was for condominium ownership.
Co-op housing is an arrangement in which members hold shares in a single ownership corporation rather than a deed to an individual unit, as in a condominium. The shares are proportional to the size and other characteristics of their apartment.
The shareholders also hold a proprietary lease from the corporation for the use of their apartment. As the name implies, the co-op was originally looked upon as a cooperative living arrangement, and the original ones were formed by people who had something in common, perhaps membership in a union that set up the corporation and ran the property from the start.
Every owner pays his share of the operating costs for building upkeep, services, staff salaries, management fees, taxes and any mortgage on the building -- through monthly charges known as the maintenance fee. Each apartment owner's monthly maintenance fee is based how many shares are assigned to the apartment he or she occupies.
A large chunk of the expense for many co-ops is the building's mortgage. Co-op shareholders are entitled to take tax deductions for their share of the interest portion of their building's underlying mortgages.
A co-op's business and management chores are handled by a board of directors elected by the shareholders. Co-op boards have the right to reject applicants without giving reasons as long as discrimination is not based on race, creed, color, age, sexual orientation, marital status, national origin or because of a disability. Real estate brokers and boards are reluctant to discuss it, but discrimination in housing is still widely considered to be a factor in the New York City co-op market.
Co-op board members, who are also residents of the building, serve in a voluntary capacity, so all but very small co-ops hire professional management companies to handle the day-to-day responsibilities.
Co-op ownership is a more comfortable fit for owners willing to take on shared responsibility of maintaining their buildings. It is an ownership style that appeals to the Connells.
"I realize that it limits you on things like subletting and what you can do with your own space," said Mr. Connell. "But I like the idea of shared responsibility that comes with owning a co-op. I would rather own in a building where people can't come and go as they please."
While the Connells would prefer to live in a prewar, co-op building, they have broadened their search to include apartments for sale in buildings like 299 west 12th Street, among the few prewar buildings converted to condominium rather than a co-op.
Owners of condominiums have more in common with homeowners than they do with co-op shareholders. Unlike co-op owners, they hold titles to their individual apartments and pay their own real estate taxes.
IN general, a condominium unit owner is free to rent or sell without approval of the board. A board of managers can block a sale only by exercising its right of first refusal to buy the apartment.
While condominium owners have the right to rent out their apartments, condominium managements can charge the owner a fee for the privilege. Sometimes the fees are so high that owners find the right is not worth the economic burden it carries.
Ms. Rothman, of the Council of New York Cooperatives, a 17-year-old nonprofit advocacy organization for co-op and condominium buildings, said that in some respects the lines between co-ops and condominiums are blurring.
"Some people originally chose condominiums over co-ops because of the greater freedom that they offer," said Ms. Rothman. "But in recent years, many condominiums have tightened their rules in order to have more control over the comings and goings of residents.
"At the same time, the tough economic times have made some co-ops re-examine and in some cases liberalize their policies on things like subletting in order to accommodate owners in a difficult market."
Some condominiums have taken a firmer hand in controlling residency in their buildings by screening subtenants.
The common charges for a unit owner covers the cost of building maintenance of common spaces like lobby, corridors and driveways, systems and services and land. Monthly carrying charges can be lower than they are for owners of co-op apartments of comparable size because there is no building mortgage to pay.
But not owning property in common does have its drawbacks. When a condominium building needs cash for repairs, there is no property to borrow against. If the building's reserve fund cannot cover the costs, each unit owner must be assessed for the expense.
Georgia Asher, a broker with Wells & Gay Stribling & Associates, a brokerage company in Manhattan, said that the common charges and fees in some condominium are beginning to catch up to co-op maintenance charges, which in the past were usually higher than condominium fees.
"Some condominiums built in the late 70's and early 80's are beginning to require expensive maintenance work," she said. "These repairs must come out of the pockets of unit owners, because condominiums cannot take out mortgages to cover theses kinds of costs."
Most buyers of brand new condominium apartments got substantial breaks in their taxes in the early years of ownership because of the tax benefits granted to the developers of their buildings. But tax bills on newly built condominiums have increased in the past few years as those benefits have gradually expired.
The condominium's business is handled by a board of managers, also elected by the unit owners. But this body has less control and authority over the individual unit owners than do the boards in co-op buildings.
Even though local lenders have been giving both condominium and co-op loans since 1971, mortgage brokers say most banks would still rather see condominium buyers than applicants seeking co-op loans.
"Condominium loans are viewed as less risky," said Margaret Scott, president of Mortgage Advisory Services, a mortgage brokerage company based in Manhattan. "They are a more securable asset than co-op shares. Because of the trouble in some buildings a few years ago, some lenders have withdrawn from the co-op market entirely."
Haunted by a wave of financial troubles that washed over some of the city's converted co-op in the late 80's, and uneasy over slow sales at the low end of the market, many lenders are declining to take the risk of writing mortgages on some types of co-op apartments.
Even though widespread default and failures never occurred, lenders have remained timid.
The turnoff for banks remains apartments in co-ops where fewer than 50 or 60 percent of the residents own their apartments as well as small apartments like studios, units in walk-up buildings and residence in buildings with fewer than 10 apartments.
Mrs. Scott said that some banks are getting finicky about the level of investment owners in condominiums.
"It is the same nervousness they have about lending to people who have second homes," said Mrs. Scott. "If the owners of investment properties get into trouble, they usually payoff their own mortgages and let the mortgage on the investment property go. If too many investment owners in a condominium fall behind, it could weaken the value of other owners in the building."
Many co-op have down payment requirements that go well beyond the 20 percent that lenders require. It is not unusual for a co-op to expect buyers to pay 40 to 50 percent of the purchase price in cash. There are some buildings, mostly on the Upper East Side, that require buyers to pay for their new homes in cash.
BUYERS, even those with the resources to pay cash, sometimes circumvent the requirement by taking out personal loans, rather than mortgages. When this is done it is not the co-op shares, but other assets that are used as collateral for the loans.
But while condominium buyers may have an easier time getting a loan, they usually need more cash up front for closing costs.
Co-op buyers escape such closing expenses as the cost of the title search, which insures that an owner has the right to sell a property and that there are no judgments against or liens against the property. In New York City the mortgage recording tax is 2 percent of the loan value. Of that, the buyer pays 87.5 percent and the bank pays the rest.
Rather than paying for a title search, co-op buyers pay what is known as a U.C.C. fee. It refers to the search, required by the Uniform Commercial Code, which validates the ownership of stock certificates. The cost is ususally less than $100.
Another closing cost for condominium buyers can be the prepayment of the property tax that some lenders require.
Both co-op and condominium owners are at risk when a significant number of other owners in their buildings fall behind in maintenance payments or common fees.
"It is even more important that a condominium keep a tight rein on arrearages," said Ms. Rothman of the Council of New York Cooperatives. "Because in a condominium if an owner fails to pay common fees and the mortgage, the bank's rights have priority over the condominium's in any claim to the unit."
In a co-op, a corporation's rights to back maintenance would come before a bank's claim.

HEADLINE: Talking: Parental Aid;
Lenders Relaxing The Rules

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
ALONG with a college education, parents are increasingly providing their children with the down payment, and sometimes the closing costs, on a first home.
A Chicago Title and Trust survey released this year suggests that up to 12 percent of first-time buyers get this benefit, up from 8.8 percent in 1989. Even with the decline in home prices generally, meeting the cash requirements of a purchase is still difficult for many young people. 
 The customary 20 percent down payment on a $100,000 home, plus closing costs, would normally require $26,000 in cash just to get through the door.
So it is hardly surprising that even among families with modest incomes "parents have become a significant factor," said Diane Campbell, director of one-family programs at the New Jersey Housing Finance Agency, which helps first-time buyers. It is not unusual, she said, for parents to put up $30,000.
The lenders themselves have often made it easier for parents to participate. Some find ways to let the children borrow 100 percent of the price by accepting a guarantee from the parent, instead of cash, for the down payment. And they are no longer so concerned when down-payment cash comes from parents rather than the children, the borrowers. Until about two years ago, said Mercy Valles, assistant branch manager at the Hackensack, N.J., headquarters of Globe Mortgage, lenders were more insistent that the buyers contribute some of their personal savings.
The new "Parent Power" program of Merrill Lynch Credit Corporation, available since May in five states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, lets a first-time buyer finance 100 percent of the purchase price if the parents or other close relatives guarantee 30 percent of that amount.
They can do so in two ways. One is to open a brokerage account with any Merrill Lynch office, placing stocks, bonds or mutual funds into the account to equal the 30 percent. A further 30 percent of the 30 percent must also be deposited to allow for fluctuations in the portfolio's value. The total, for example, would be $39,000 on a $100,000 home.
This was the route chosen this spring by Philip and Dorothy Brown, retired educators of Pioneer, Calif., who were eager to help a daughter and son-in-law.
"What I liked was that it wasn't costing me anything," said Mr. Brown. "All I had to do was take a portion of my existing portfolio and put it into a special account. I could still trade. I can even withdraw any profits. And as they've both got good jobs I didn't even see it as much of a risk."
Alternatively, the parents could have collateralized the amount by opening a home equity line of credit and pledging an amount equal to the 30 percent, which would not be drawn upon unless the child defaulted.
But once again, the line of credit would have had to be taken out with Merrill Lynch (although other companies may soon offer the same sort of plans). In addition, a further 10 percent of the 30 percent -- for a grand total of $33,000 for a $100,000 home -- would have been required to provide a cushion against any adverse dip in the home's value. Under the Merrill Lynch plan the parents must also pay an annual maintenance fee of 2 percent on the pledged amount.
The guarantee is lifted when the loan has been paid down to 70 percent of value, upon sale or after seven years if a new appraisal shows the loan then represents no more than 70 percent of current value.
Michael Johnston, chairman of Merrill Lynch Credit Corporation, headquartered in Sarasota, Fla., said the program was devised because the company's securities brokers had been watching with concern as an increasing number of clients like the Browns were being forced to liquidate their assets to provide their children with a down payment, thereby diluting their own asset base.
SINCE late 1990 the Dime Savings Bank of New York and some other banks have let first-time buyers finance 100 percent of the price if a relative or employer puts 20 percent of the total on deposit in a certificate of deposit at any branch.
The amount may not include funds already set aside in a retirement plan, like a Keogh or an I.R.A., because Federal law prohibits such use. And it cannot be removed until the loan has been paid down to 80 percent of value, or a new appraisal shows that the outstanding balance has fallen to under 80 percent.
"I felt better because my parents were not actually giving me the money," recalled Barry Driesman, a 31-year-old lawyer who bought his first home -- a $30,000 studio apartment in Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn -- last year, using this formula.
But a word of caution. William Selsberg, a real estate lawyer in Stamford, Conn., says too many parents take the guarantees too lightly. They don't consider, he said, that such a guarantee could limit their own future borrowing. Nor do they truly believe the young people might default or have to get out at a loss, thus having to draw upon the pledged sum.
"Anything can happen in an economy like this," he warned.
A further push to make first-time mortgage loans more parent-friendly has come from the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae), the Government-chartered organization that buys loans from local lenders and sets lending standards.
In April 1991, the agency started what it calls its Community Home Buyers' Program. Serving 13,000 purchasers to date, it lets first-time buyers whose household earnings fall below 115 percent of median area income have an outsider -- not necessarily a relative -- contribute two-fifths of the 5 percent minimum needed for the down payment.
Formerly, anyone using its 5 percent-down program had to provide the full 5 percent himself. And the source of that 5 percent was scrutinized to make sure it was indeed the young person's money.
The fear was that unless the buyers contributed at least some of their own earnings they would be more likely to default, said Bonnie O'Dell, director of consumer information at Fannie Mae. This concern has now given way to a more pressing fear that people in lower income brackets might not otherwise own a home.
Finally, some general tips can be gleaned from walking into any office of Weichert Realtors -- they operate in eight states along the Eastern Seaboard including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut -- and picking up a free copy of their booklet "How to Help Your Kids Buy a Home."

HEADLINE: Q AND A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Refinancing for a Co-op
Question: My owner-occupied, five-unit brownstone co-op is facing a balloon payment on the mortgage next January. The underlying mortgage is $115,000. We would like to refinance the loan for a 15-year term. 
 Although the building is worth at least 10 times the mortgage amount, we are having a hard time finding a bank willing to finance our mortgage. Are there any institutions that will extend mortgages to buildings like ours? . . . Benjamin Hamilton, Manhattan
 Answer: Yes, but not many. It is often difficult for small co-ops to find lenders willing to refinance their underlying mortgages when they are less than $500,000 because banks do not find them profitable.
The National Cooperative Bank is one lender that will make loans to small co-ops like yours, but it offers only 10-year loans to buildings your size.
According to Paulette Bonanno, vice president of the National Cooperative Bank, its minimum loan for co-op buildings is $100,000, and it will consider mortgages for co-ops with five or more units. Ms. Bonanno said key factors in the consideration of any application would be the co-op's owner-occupancy level, the building's condition and value and the corporation's financial viability.
Ms. Bonanno said that a 15-year loan for a building your size would not only be hard to get, but may also not offer the best flexibility. A 15-year loan would probably come with prepayment prohibitions, Ms. Bonanno said, and a long mortgage commitment could be a problem if the building needed to raise cash for something like a major improvement or repair job.
The number of the National Cooperative Bank's New York office is (212) 08-0880.
 
Co-op Rent Pass-Alongs
 Question: I own a rent-controlled co-op apartment in Manhattan. The rent charged to my tenant has always been within the guidelines established for rent-controlled tenants.
For the last several years, the co-op board has made assessments for building improvements. Can I pass these costs along to my tenant? . . . Michael Drexler Manhattan
Answer: Maybe. There is a mechanism that allows investor-owners of co-op or condominium apartments with rent-regulated tenants to pass the costs of major capital improvements along to the tenants under certain circumstances. According to Joseph D'Agosta, acting deputy commissioner of rent administration for the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal, any assessment costs passed on to tenants can only be for improvements that qualify as major capital improvements as determined by his agency. The improvements would have to be for a new installation as opposed to a repair of old equipment or building feature. Among the improvements where an increase would be justified would be a new boiler, roof or windows.
Any increase would have to be approved by the housing agency. You would not be able to make the application on your apartment alone. The application for the M.C.I. increase would have to be made by either by the sponsor or the co-op's board of directors or jointly by the shareholders.
 
Garbage-Truck Noise
Question: I live in a neighborhood that is both residential and commercial. After business hours the neighborhood is very quiet until 10 or 11 P.M., when garbage trucks arrive to collect refuse from private businesses. The noise is disturbingly loud. Do I have any recourse in stopping this nuisance? . . . Joshua Kimerling, Manhattan.
Answer: No. there are no city regulations restricting the time that garbage may be collected. Not all collections are made in the middle of the night. But city sanitation trucks and private carters need to make pickups at times when there is little traffic congestion.
The city does have standards that limit the level of persistent noise, such as loud music or construction equipment. If the garbage collectors play music, yell or toss cans around, you might bring it to the attention of the carting company or the Department of Environmental Protection.

LENGTH: 2196 words

HEADLINE: Education Cutbacks Arouse Barrage of Complaints

BYLINE: By PRISCILLA VAN TASSEL

 BODY:
AS the 1992-93 New Jersey public school term opens this week, the focus is not on the classroom but in the courts and the State Legislature, where the fate of New Jersey's new system of financing public education is being determined.
All across the state, in urban, suburban and rural school districts alike, parents and educators are complaining of cutbacks in educational programs. 
 Lawyers representing 30 of the state's poorest districts went to court in July to seek more funds. Dr. Kenneth Hall, Superintendent of the Matawan-Aberdeen Regional School District, says that middle-class districts like his "are really in very deep trouble." And 60 mostly wealthy districts have joined in an effort to lobby for funds.
Last month, the Republican leadership of the Legislature added to the uproar by announcing plans to trim increases to urban school districts while adding an extra $200 million for middle-class districts. The Legislature has determined to dismantle the financing system Gov. Jim Florio created in 1990 and replace it with a version of its own by next year.
This is the second year of implementation of the Quality Education Act, the state's financing formula, and neither school districts nor taxpayers who absorbed the largest tax increase in state history to pay for it are very happy.
 
Criticism From the Start
 The law was the Florio administration's answer to a 1990 New Jersey Supreme Court ruling that held that spending in poor school districts must be raised to the level of wealthier ones. From the start, there has been a frenzy of criticism from educators who say that the financing formula is not generating enough resources and that they are being squeezed by increasing costs over which they have no control, and from taxpayers outraged by what they perceive to be out-of-control education costs.
Taxpayers point out that New Jersey leads the nation in education spending: an average of $9,940 a student in 1991-92, compared with $5,452 nationally, according to the National Education Association's most recent statistics. This year a record $4.6 billion in state aid -- more than 30 percent of the entire state budget -- is earmarked for education, and 455 of New Jersey's 593 operating school districts will be seeing increases in aid.
But last month, the Center for Government Services at Rutgers University issued a report suggesting that New Jersey could spend much more on education. Based upon its residents' per capita income, the report said, New Jersey ranks 39th among the 50 states.
The lawsuit filed by the 30 urban school districts challenged the Quality Education Act in New Jersey Superior Court, arguing that poor districts will still be hundreds of millions of dollars behind wealthier ones in three years.
In one of the districts, Jersey City, school officials say a $25 million increase in state aid this year will finance expansion of early childhood education and computer programs and the introduction of an accelerated elementary school art and science program, but not two new school buildings, a summer school program or a reduction in elementary school class size, as had been hoped. Elementary classes now average 25 students.
Trenton's $17 million increase will permit the district to begin an after-school program for disruptive students, but plans for a separate school building for them have been at least temporarily scrapped, and a program to place experienced teachers in each of its 18 elementary schools to serve as mentors for other teachers has been scaled back. Instead, six teachers will rotate among the schools.
The education act was intended to go beyond the Supreme Court mandate by increasing state aid to middle-class communities as well. But a number of these districts have found that they are coming up short this year.
"Three years ago, 42 percent of the money to support our schools came from the state," said Dr. Hall of the Matawan-Aberdeen district. "Next year it will be less than 20 percent. That's a tremendous shift in burden."
With a property tax rate that is now 63 percent above the state average, Matawan-Aberdeen has still had to cut its staff by more than 10 percent, increase class sizes and eliminate one-quarter of its high school's electives in the last two years, Dr. Hall said.
 
Bill Is Introduced
 A legislative bill has been introduced to increase school aid to high-taxing middle-class districts, but Dr. Hall said it was "highly unlikely" any help would come before next year.
"These districts are really in very deep trouble," he said. "A lot of them had to reduce budgets, cut staff and budget under their cap for spending, which means they are going to be hurt next year by a reduction in cap. Next year will be a disaster."
As part of the education act, the state has imposed local school budget caps to control the growth of education costs in an effort to limit local property tax increases. The law also calls for the phase-out of state support for regular education programs in wealthy districts over four years beginning this year.
More so than the loss of this aid, though, it is the budget caps that are causing problems for school officials in these areas. Districts can receive waivers on caps, but voters have to approve the action first, and they often view such expenditures as excessive. In April, more than half of the requests for cap waivers were rejected.
 
Cuts Made in Madison Programs Eliminated
 In wealthy Madison, a 5.6 percent cap on budget growth, in addition to the gradual elimination of $300,000 yearly in state aid, has forced school officials to cut staff positions, increase class sizes and eliminate home economics and behind-the-wheel driver's education.
"It's the first time in anyone's memory that we've had to cut programs within the Madison schools," said Dr. Lawrence Feinsod, the Superintendent. "You may say, well, inflation is 4.5 percent, but then I'll say to you, do something about special education costs that are going up about 10 percent a year, and insurance costs that are going up 18 percent a year, and a whole lot of other areas over which we have no control."
Once largely above the political fray, New Jersey's wealthy school districts are beginning to lobby, both collectively and individually, for changes in the act. In one such effort, 60 mostly wealthy districts have formed the Garden State Coalition of Schools and are paying $500 dues for an administrator who will also serve as a lobbyist.
"This is my 18th year as a Superintendent, and I've never seen my colleagues so involved in the political arena," Dr. Feinsod said. "We believe that equity should be achieved by improving poor education and not by diminishing quality educational opportunities for kids by eliminating programs."
 
Spending Tied to Programs
 The Quality Education Act was signed into law by Governor Florio within 20 days of its introduction in the spring of 1990. This month Republican legislative leaders are expected to reveal the specifics of a new plan that would distribute more of the aid on the basis of programs, rather than in lump sums of money for school districts to spend as they see fit.
Under that plan, aid to urban school districts would be reduced while middle-class districts would see a $200 million increase.
"We can't keep in place the present formula because it will bankrupt the schools first, and then eventually the state," said State Senator John H. Ewing, Republican of Bedminster and chairman of the Senate Education Committee. "It's never been proven that money does the job, and therefore to say parity in funding is just not right. There should be parity in terms of what is offered to the child."
It was to get around the Supreme Court mandate of equal spending that Mr. Ewing co-sponsored legislation last spring that would remove language from the State Constitution that formed the foundation of the court's opinion. The possible elimination of the constitutional guarantee of a "thorough and efficient" education for all New Jersey schoolchildren, in place for more than 100 years, ran into such fierce opposition from educational organizations that the bill has been dropped, although Mr. Ewing said it might be reintroduced with some changes later this year.
"People seem to be yelling and screaming and kicking their feet about the words 'thorough' and 'efficient,' " he said, "although no one has ever defined it, and I don't think any one of the judges could define it."
 
Teacher Pension Costs
 Republican legislators have also promised amendments to overturn a provision in the education act that would shift teacher pension and Social Security costs from the state to local districts. As the law stands now, districts will start having to assume the $693 million responsibility for the next school year.
But that possibility seems to be increasingly remote, as support for the transfer erodes. In a significant defection, Marilyn Morheuser, lawyer for the 30 districts that are challenging the education act in court, said in July that she was dropping the contention that state payment of pension costs was unconstitutional since wealthy districts received more aid than poorer ones in that they had more teachers and higher salaries. In explaining her change of mind, she said it was more important for various education interest groups, most of whom oppose the switch, to stay united.
Proponents of a locally based pension system say school boards would have more incentive to keep salary increases to a minimum. The weak economy may be doing that anyway, as recent salary increases have been averaging less than 7 percent, down from a high of more than 9 percent in the 1980's.
 
Issue of Regionalization
 In another effort to ward off judicial interference in school affairs, State Senator Gerald Cardinale, Republican of Demarest, has introduced a constitutional amendment that would prohibit forced regionalization under any circumstance, including a court order. The bill, which has been attacked by civil rights groups as racist, is in response to a recent effort by the Englewood Board of Education to merge its predominantly black Dwight Morrow High School with Tenafly High School, where 2 percent of the students are black or Hispanic.
There are other calls to consolidate New Jersey's 593 school districts as a way to cut down on administrative costs and strengthen educational programs. In February, the Quality Education Commission, a group appointed by Governor Florio to study the education act, recommended that there be fewer than 100 school districts by the year 2000, a move that is considered unlikely given New Jersey's strong allegiance to home rule. The chief targets would be the 65 percent of the state's school districts without a kindergarten to 12th grade curriculum, or those enrolling fewer than 2,500 students.
In more moderate positions, the State Department of Education and the Assembly minority leader, Joseph V. Doria Jr., Democrat of Bayonne, are each proposing to encourage voluntary regionalization through financial incentives. Despite decades of discussion on the advantages of regionalization and dozens of studies commissioned by school districts to consolidate, only two, Chatham Township and Chatham Borough, have merged in the last 10 years.
 
Teacher Tenure
 In another area, there are signs that teachers' staunch resistance to changes in the tenure laws may be softening. While the New Jersey Education Association, the state's largest teachers' union, refuses to endorse any specific proposal at this point, association officials concede that their attitude is more open.
"Yes, it probably is," said Karen Joseph, spokeswoman for the union. "So much has changed. It doesn't mean that we'll come out in agreement when all is said and done, but we're open to discussions."
It is unlikely, though, that the union would go so far as to embrace the elimination of tenure altogether and substitution of renewable contracts in much the same way superintendents are now hired, as the New Jersey School Boards Association is advocating.
 
Commissioner's Agenda
 Last year the State Commissioner of Education, Dr. John Ellis, was calling for a longer school year and tougher curriculums, but there is little talk of such things these days in the midst of New Jersey's preoccupation with revision of the education act.
Dr. Ellis said he, too, would like to modify the act, particularly to end districts' uncertainty as to how much aid they receive, and also to see that the law doesn't diminish the quality of education in wealthier districts. As a start, he said, he would like to stretch out the time that general education aid to these districts is phased out, and also to expand what is known as categorical aid, which is distributed on a per-pupil basis regardless of a district's wealth.
"We can do some small changes that will be helpful," he said, "but it's going to take a year or more of thorough study and involvement with the Legislature to really rework the formula to be politically acceptable and pass muster with the courts."

HEADLINE: New Jersey Q & A: Eugene M. Haring;
How the Practice of Law Has Changed

 BODY:
IN his small 14th-floor office in the Gateway Center, behind a barren, polished leather-topped desk, sat Eugene M. Haring, 65 years old, looking more like a mischievous, crackly-eyed grandfather than the senior partner of New Jersey's oldest and largest law firm.
Mr. Haring has silver hair, a deep, soothing voice and a genial smile that seems to involve nearly every line and muscle in his face. He has worked for the Newark law firm of McCarter & English since 1953, when he was hired as a summer clerk. 
 The firm had 15 lawyers at the time. It now has 200 lawyers and 300 administrative employees.
 Mr. Haring grew up in Summit. After serving in the Marines just after World War II, he attended Princeton University, graduating summa cum laude, in 1949, and went on to the Harvard Law School. McCarter & English was his first job thereafter, and he has never looked back.
Mr. Haring lives in Princeton with his wife, Janet.
In an interview, he discussed the changes that have swept through the practice of law over the last four decades, not all of which have been to his liking.
Q. Why doesn't the senior partner of the state's largest law firm have a bigger office? And how come your desk is so clean?
A. When we moved here four years ago, we decided we didn't need any offices bigger than this. Lawyers don't really need big offices. But we do have lots and lots of conference rooms.
My desk is clean because I like a clean desk. And because I knew you were coming.
Q. Why did you take a job with McCarter & English when they were only paying $50 a month?
A. To be paid $50 a month as a clerk was good -- a lot of firms weren't paying anything. And I was impressed with the firm because even though I only wanted a job as a summer law clerk, every partner interviewed me. When I got out of law school, they started me at $4,000 a year.
Q. What do the highest-paid partners at the firm now get paid for their time?
A. Around $285 to $300 an hour.
Q. Has the recession hurt your firm?
A. Not really. Our practice is very diverse and spread over a spectrum of different kinds of problems and different kinds of clients. Our clients are not only from New Jersey, they're from all over the country, and with that kind of diversity we have not felt the effects of the recession all that much. Actually, it increases your bankruptcy work.
Q. What do you do as senior partner?
A. What I do is preside at meetings of the executive committee, which occur once a week, and I preside at meetings of the firm. I deal with our administrative people and with the other partners.
Q. Do you do any lawyering?
A. Yes, but not to the degree I used to. If there's a case that I'm expected to argue in court or on appeal, I'm involved in it day to day. But most times I'm only involved at points in a case when decisions have to be made.
Q. What about paralegals?
A. In the 60's we had maybe one or two; now we have 40 or 50. Paralegals do work that requires intelligence and some expertise but that does not require a law degree or experience in the courtroom. We also have other professionals such as nurses and a psychologist on staff.
Q. How do they fit into a law firm?
A. They analyze the vast amount of evidence and documents that are used in some of the cases we have -- like the mass toxic tort cases involving asbestos or pharmaceuticals.
Q. What is the biggest difference you've seen in the practice of law since you started?
A. When I started, most lawyers were generalists. In fact, the one test of whether we wanted to make somebody a partner or not was whether they could handle just about any kind of legal problem that came along. Since then we've become more a profession of specialists than we were 35 years ago.
Q. Anything else?
A. Yes, cases are more complicated now; they're more document-intensive than they used to be. A lot of what we do now requires an elaborate computer infrastructure and a huge administrative staff.
Q. Has the practice of law itself become more of a business?
A. It was easier 35 or 40 years ago to keep the practice of law as a profession than it is today, when there are more business considerations. A profession is a calling which a person practices in order to perform a service; the monetary rewards are incidental. The primary object of a business, though, is to make money. And the moment a law firm becomes a business, it will become less effective as a law firm.
Q. Have your feelings changed about being a lawyer?
A. Well, in some respects it was more fun 35 years ago. It was less pressured then, a little more relaxed. When you went to court, you knew everybody. Now, you don't have as much contact with other lawyers.
Q. Why is that important?
A. Because a lot of what a lawyer does is assist in resolving disputes. Years ago, lawyers knew each other and treated each other pretty well. And to the extent that lawyers know each other and get along with each other, it is easier to resolve disputes more effectively and you can better serve your client that way.
Q. We hear that the courts are terribly crowded. Have we become more a more litigious society?
A. I think so, yes.
Q. Is it because there are more lawyers?
A. I'm not sure. After all, there have to be clients to ask lawyers to bring lawsuits. I think part of it may be that there are more people; this is a densely populated state. Frankly, it may also be that there is a general feeling that somebody else ought to be responsible for paying for some of the misfortunes that occur to us.
Q. Aren't people suing for the same things they were suing for in the past?
A. No, because 30 years ago you didn't have products liability suits the way we do today. You didn't have the mass tort cases like the asbestos cases or the breast implant cases or the pharmaceutical cases. And you didn't have any environmental litigation to speak of.
Q. How do you feel about lawyers advertising?
A. That's a hard thing. Obviously it reflects an increased competitiveness in the field. You're almost forced to do a little bit of advertising given today's practices. It's contrary to what we would have done 35 years ago. I probably find it a little less attractive than my younger partners do.
Q. Does your firm advertise?
A. Very modestly: small "tombstone" ads in the New Jersey Symphony program and things like that.
Q. What about "pro bono" work -- providing free legal services for people who can't afford lawyers?
A. We're often asked to take on a case or a series of cases by the courts, in which case we always do. Recently, we handled a case of sex discrimination in the state's prisons. The male prisoners were suing the state because they were being watched in the showers by female guards, and the female guards were countersuing, saying that if they weren't allowed to watch the male prisoners, that took away their job opportunities. The case was settled when prison officials agreed to put up modesty screens in the showers. Our best estimate last year was that we spent 4,800 hours on pro bono stuff.
Q. So if lawyers provide services people need, why does it seem that many people just don't like lawyers?
A. I think that over the ages, at least since Shakespeare, lawyers have been fairly unpopular. In many cases, when people need lawyers, they are not in a happy situation to begin with. So as a class, I guess, lawyers are not among the most popular people around. But then again, neither are journalists.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Eugene M. Haring, the senior partner of the state's oldest and largest law firm. (Frank C. Dougherty for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Boom and Bluster at the Merc

BYLINE: By Susan Antilla

 BODY:
BIG shots at the nation's trading exchanges love nothing more than to flex their muscles over the latest record-breaker. Little wonder, then, that they are hooting and hollering out in Chicago.
The price of a membership, or "seat," on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange has been hitting record highs this summer nearly as often as the U.S. dollar has been hitting record lows. Meanwhile, seats on its arch-rival New York Stock Exchange are a shadow of the record $1.15 million set in the headier days of 1987. 
 To hear Chicago advocates tell it, the record $585,000 seat sale on August 17 was yet another example of the Merc's cutting-edge innovation, unmatched liquidity and positively unbeatable marketing of the futures and options that are its bread and butter. If the Merc has a notable institutional shortcoming, it is that it has all the humility of an investment banker circa 1987 -- before the stock market crash.
"I want to say it nicely and not denigrate any other exchange," said Jack Sandner, chairman of the booming Chicago Merc. "If you compare the various institutions and make an objective membership decision, you would probably decide on the Merc."
No doubt the bidders who are paying up for the privilege of trading on the Merc may be getting their money's worth. While the NYSE suffers a slow erosion of market share in its mainstay stock-trading business, the Merc offers all the lure of volume growth that a big trader or investment house salivates for. Volume is up, new Merc derivative products are enjoying instant worldwide popularity, and open interest -- trading positions that are held overnight -- is at an all-time high of 4.1 million contracts.
It doesn't hurt, either, that the Merc twisted arms starting in April 1991 to get leasers to buy seats. It slashed fees from 25 cents a trade to 7 cents for owners of seats, simultaneously hiking charges from 25 cents to 30 cents for anyone who rented.
"One of my friends says it saves him $70,000 a year," said Joel Leonard, a member of the nearby Chicago Board of Trade. "The Merc is very aggressive about getting its seat prices up."
Most important to the Merc's boom, though, are the nail-biting political and financial environments. Merc products such as Eurodollar, interest rate and stock market futures are a tonic to nervous investors looking to hedge in uncertain times, particularly in presidential election years. Mr. Sandner said the increasingly global markets are a boon, too, since "the more global the world gets, the more uncertain it will be."
The Merc also cashes in on the rush by financial institutions to deal in "swaps," the complicated hedging technique in which Bank A cuts a deal to exchange a payment obligation -- say, floating-rate interest payments -- to Bank B. As the number of financial institutions involved in a swap increases, so, too, does the likelihood that one of them will use the Merc to hedge the risk.
(Critics have lambasted the swaps market for its potential to set off a chain reaction of financial disasters if a player in a chain of swaps were to default on an obligation. Mr. Sandner, who said his only sleepless nights come from fear of over-regulation, said he never loses a wink of sleep over swaps. They are "commuter railroads bringing people to our main terminals," he said.)
Worrywarts fret that the flood of money going to the Merc's derivative products could be taking capital away from so-called "primary" markets like the NYSE. If market players are indeed putting money into derivatives that would otherwise have gone to owning old-fashioned stocks, it could result in less liquidity and less reliable pricing of stocks, they say. Sanford Grossman, finance professor at The Wharton School, scoffs at that idea, arguing instead that the proliferation of derivative products brings more money to stocks. Investors have a greater comfort level buying stocks when they know they can hedge in Chicago, he said.
At the New York Stock Exchange, executives make the case that they shouldn't be compared with the Merc because the two exchanges are simply in different businesses. Lewis Horowitz, executive vice president at the NYSE, said Chicago is a "transfer of risk" operation. "Here we are a capital-raising institution," he said of the NYSE.
That's little more than hocus-pocus marketing talk to market-watchers like Mr. Grossman, who said that very little of the NYSE's business derives from the initial public offerings that raise capital. "The NYSE is a place where people trade individual equity risk, and in that sense, it's no different from what's going on in Chicago."
If the two exchanges have anything in common, it is that their executives are given to boast that their market is the biggest, the best and the most liquid. Seat prices at the Merc may be higher than those at the NYSE, where Mr. Horowitz points out that 1,366 members own seats worth $6.3 million in all, surpassing the $3.6 million in current market value of the 625 Merc seats.
"It's tough being No. 1," sniffs Mr. Horowitz. "It's tougher to stay in first place than to get there."
While the debate goes on as to which market is better, bigger or safer, investors increasingly are spending money to buy the security of a hedged position through the Merc. To talk with some, the financial insurance products available today offer such a perfect hedge that no player need ever lose money -- a suspect claim in a trading world that is meant to have risks.
Riskiest of all, though, could be the confidence of Chicago's advocates that, amid the rush of new financial products being introduced, absolutely nothing can go wrong.
But short of the doomsday scenario where a major bank collapse brings the entire financial system down, Mr. Sandner says, "I don't see anything happening," he said. "I just worry about losing product lines to offshore trading."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
The Jobs Are In Government, Not Industry

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
YOU can't sell it if you don't have it, even if you are willing to cut the price. And when it comes to manufactured goods, you have to make them to sell them.
The employment report for August was a disaster from every perspective save that of the bond traders, who figured that the Federal Reserve would push interest rates lower, as it promptly did . Much will be made of the fact that the private sector has 38,000 fewer employees now than in January 1989, when President Bush took office. 
 But it is in manufacturing jobs that the sad story of America's slide as an industrial giant has been written. The number of such jobs has fluctuated within a relatively narrow band for the past two decades. In recessions, lots get laid off. In recoveries, a few get rehired.
Back in 1979, a record 21 million people worked in manufacturing in this country. By the end of 1982, recession had cut that figure to 18 million. During the much vaunted recovery of the 1980's, it was never to get back above 19.5 million. Now it is at 18.15 million, just a couple of ticks from setting a 27-year low.
In his speech to the Republican National Convention, President Bush vowed that the United States would be an "export superpower," but the Administration's strategy, if it has one, is not very clear. It did boost subsidized agricultural exports last week, but in manufactured goods the plan seems to be to let the dollar slide far enough to make prices competitive.
That's where the catch comes in. The low dollar has made it prohibitively expensive for Americans to travel overseas, and it has aided exports for those companies that make internationally traded products. But the worry is that the manufacturing base in this country has shrunken so much that exports can never rise to the levels needed to offset the current levels of imports.
The decline of manufacturing as an employer helps to explain the rise in poverty in this country. Historically, manufacturing offered reasonably good jobs to relatively uneducated workers. Now, a generation has grown up with no expansion in the manufacturing sector.
In sum, the bad news in the employment report is not just cyclical, that the recovery from the recession is hard to find. There is also a secular trend, in which service jobs have increased, particularly in government employment. When President Reagan took office, there were 25 percent more Americans working in manufacturing than in civilian government jobs. Last October, for the first time ever, government employment outstripped manufacturing, and now there are 554,000 more people working for governments.
In this season, of course, much of the world is focused on the political implications. For George Bush, the good news may be that job-creation historically has not been very important to most voters. This Administration has been the worst in recent history in producing private-sector jobs, but the best was Jimmy Carter's. And that fact did not save his job.

LENGTH: 1742 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: August 30 - September 4

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL
 
Failing Pravda Gets a Partner
When Pravda was founded in Moscow by Vladimir Lenin in 1912 as the official organ of the Soviet Communist Party, its purpose was to be the party's "agitator and organizer." But with the Soviet Union dissolved and the Communist Party having fallen on hard times, Pravda has seen its circulation shrink from 10 million in 1987, to less than 1.4 million. And more than once it has found itself on the wrong side of history: when it supported last year's failed coup and when it opposed many of Russian President Boris Yeltsin's economic reforms. Pravda -- it means truth -- also saw its revenues decline. Last March it was forced to shut down for three weeks while it arranged emergency bank loans. Last week, Pravda's editor-in-chief, Gennady Seleznyov, announced he had found a savior for the paper -- and he's certainly no Lenin. For an undisclosed amount, Greek businessman Yannis Yannikos will buy a 55 percent interest in Pravda.
 
The Rights to Fly
Countries guard their airlines jealously against too much competition. But last week, the United States and the Netherlands agreed on broad new aviation pact that could change all that. The agreement will allow airlines in each country the rights to fly anywhere in the other country. "This is a very significant event in international aviation," said Secretary of Transporation Andrew E. Card Jr. "Not only does it cement an extremely close relationship, but it will provide a mood for market-oriented aviation agreements with other countries." The immediate impact of the agreement is to allow KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, which owns 49 percent of Northwest Airlines, and Northwest to operate as a single airline, with antitrust immunity. Previous treaties had prohibited the two airlines from coordinating their pricing, routes and flight schedules. The Department of Transportaton is though to be putting pressure on Britain to negotiate a similar aviation treaty.
 
Cost-Cutting, Japanese Style
Dai Ichi Kangyo, the world's largest bank, is cutting costs Japanese style. Rather than laying off low-level clerks, it is asking its 41 top executives to take 5 percent pay cuts and has asked them to trim 20 percent off their expense accounts. Those executives must certainly do a lot of entertaining. According to Yoshihide Akazawa, a spokesman for the company, the cuts -- along with a few others -- are expected to save an estimated $40 million a year.
 
ECONOMY
 
Politician Bush Has a Little Something for Taiwan and U.S. Farmers
President Bush has been loathe to anger China. He opposed sanctions after the 1989 massacre in Tiananmen Square and fought hard for China to keep its most-favored-nation trade status. But this is an election year and last week -- at a General Dynamics Corporation plant in Fort Worth -- Mr. Bush said he had approved the sale of 150 of the company's F-16 fighters to Taiwan, China's long-time foe. The sale could be worth $6 billion over 10 years to American companies in Texas, California and Connecticut. The same day, in South Dakota, Mr. Bush -- a staunch foe of agricultural subsidies in this year's trade negotiations with Europe -- said he had approved $1 billion to subsidize American wheat sales abroad and another $755 million to aid farmers whose crops were damaged by Hurricane Andrew. "This is pure pork-barrel politics," said Dee Dee Myers, a spokeswoman for Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic challenger.
 
Outlook: Stagnant to Grim
Behind every President there are economists. But George Bush's economic mavens must be feeling a little uneasy. Last week's report from the Commerce Department on the Index of Leading Economic Indicators showed the pace of growth at just 0.1 percent in July after a 0.3 percent decline the month before. The index, which forecasts economic activity six to nine months hence, suggests a slower economy in first quarter of next year. "The economy is essentially dead," said Lawrence Chimerine, of DRI-McGraw Hill Inc.
 
More Poverty for All
Sluggish economic growth? How about plain poverty? The Census Bureau said last week that the number of Americans living in poverty increased by 2.1 million last year to a total of 35.7 million or 14.2 percent of the population. It was the second consecutive annual increase in the poverty rate. What's more, there are now more people living in poverty in America than at any time since 1964. The purchasing power of the average household also shrank last year by $1,100, the bureau said. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater blamed the increase in the poverty rate on Congress's inability to pass the Administration's economic proposals. Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic challenger, blamed it on the Administration saying it has the "worst economic record in 50 years."
 
Handling Hurricane Andrew
Tallying up the damage from a disaster as vast as Hurricane Andrew is no mean feat. But last week estimates began to trickle in. The American Insurance Services Group, a nonprofit research organization, figures Andrew will cost insurance companies about $7.3 billion. But those estimates do not include uninsured losses, losses in Louisiana, damage to the infrastructure and damage to Government-owned installations. Though Andrew is the costliest natural disaster ever, analysts believe the insurance industry -- with $160 billion in capital -- will be able to take the hit. "The one thing this industry is very effective at is spreading risk," said G. Alan Zimermann, an analyst with Prudential Securities.
 
No Glee in Purchasing
If the nation's purchasing managers are the economy's weathervane, they are saying there's hardly a breeze. Last week, the National Association of Purchasing Management said its Purchasing Mangers Index fell to 53.7 from 54.2. A reading above 50 indicates economy is growing, below 50 indicates it is contracting.
 
Fed Acts on Jobless Numbers
Though unemployment fell to 7.6 percent in August, from 7.7 percent in July, it was accompanied by an alarming loss of 83,000 jobs from the nation's nonfarm payrolls and -- if government employment is excluded from the picture -- an even gloomier loss of 167,000 jobs from the nation's private payrolls. The unemployment numbers show "a dramatic deterioration in the job market," said Norman Robertson, chief economist at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. Most of the job losses were concentrated in the transportation, instruments and electronics sectors of the economy. "This news will not be well received in the White House," Mr. Robertson said. In response to the figures, the Federal Reserve lowered its Federal funds rate to 3.0 percent from 3.25 percent, the lowest level since 1963. The move is designed to make it easier for banks to borrow money.
 
COMPANIES
 
Bad Season for Citicorp
It hasn't been the best of summers for Citicorp. First the banking examiners identified problems that forced it to revise downward its second-quarter earnings by $28 million, to $143 million. Then a document leaked out from the Comptroller of the Currency's office that criticized the nation's No. 1 bank for the shoddy way it has run its mortgage subsidiary. The report said Citicorp overcharged customers and exposed the bank to undue risks. It did such a poor job at screening out unqualified mortgage applicants that it was unable to sell its mortgages to other institutions. The report also said Citicorp executives "have neglected their responsibilities to correct identified problems," some of which were first pinpointed in 1988. Citicorp said it could not legally comment on the report but that not everything in it was necessarily true.
 
General Mills's Shredded Wheat
Last week, General Mills, the nation's No. 2 cereal maker after Kellogg, said it planned to add RJR Nabisco's ready-to-eat cereal business to its Wheaties-led lineup. For $450 million, (no boxtops please) General Mills will get mostly shredded wheat -- in the form of Shreddies, Spoon-Sized Shredded Wheat, Frosted Shredded Wheat and the original, 100-year-old Shredded Wheat. The proceeds from the sale will help RJR pay off the $13.6 billion debt remaining from the $25 billion it borrowed in 1988 to finance a leveraged buyout. RJR's market share in cereals has slipped to 3 percent from 5 percent. "Nabisco had been on the slide for a long period of time," said William Leach, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. Because of the increasing concentration in the food business, the deal is expected to be scrutinized by the Government for antitrust violations.
 
Whither Letterman?
It's no secret that late-night TV host David Letterman wanted Johnny Carson's old job. He's said so himself. But NBC replaced Mr. Carson with Jay Leno. If last week's reports in Advertising Age are correct, however, Mr. Letterman is determined to leave the network. Though his contract does not allow him to negotiate with anyone until after he has completed talks with NBC, other suitors -- including syndication companies -- have made "presentations," to Mr. Letterman's agents at the Creative Artists Agency in Los Angeles. A syndicated show could be far more lucrative -- but riskier -- than staying with a network. NBC said in a statement that Mr. Letterman has been "a valuable member of the NBC family for the past 10 years," and that it wants to keep him right where he is. Mr. Letterman has remained silent.
 
Labor Strife at G.M.
The strike at General Motors Corporation's Lordstown complex has spread from a single metal shop to include 30,000 workers, forcing production at its Saturn division to be halted. But this strike is not over wages. Members of the United Automobiles Workers union walked out to protest the replacement of some of G.M.'s tool and die makers with a plan to buy from the outside. To become more competitive, G.M. wants to do more outsourcing; it currently produces 70 percent of all the parts it uses, versus about 40 percent at Toyota. Last week union and management teams met for talks. "G.M. is in a tough economic position," said Harry Katz, professor of labor relations at Cornell University. Both sides are "looking for bargaining leverage.
 
Now It's Canon-I.B.M.
Is there any high-tech company anywhere that hasn't entered an alliance with I.B.M.? Last week the International Business Machines Corporation joined with Canon Inc. to develop a new notebook computer.

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
One View Fits All

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
My oldest kid invited the jock home the other day. The jock's name is, of course, Kyle. He is a nice kid with an awesome arm, the kind who can choose a tree halfway down the road, pick up a stone and -- bing! -- nail it while my son stands open-mouthed.
This is one of the great rituals of growing up, trying to puzzle out who you are by discovering who you are not. Our children bring home familiar strangers, archetypes who will, by contrast, teach them what they're made of. There is something bittersweet about watching this, something that makes you want to give them simple answers instead of time and space. But figuring out who you are is the whole point of the human experience. So we let them be. 
 I couldn't help thinking of this when Pat Buchanan gave his hateful speech at the Republican Convention. You figure when you go on vacation certain events will pass you by. But the Buchanan speech has stayed with me because it was so insulting to the American people and so contrary to everything we value.
The election, he said, "is about more than who gets what. It is about who we are." Here's the catch -- who you are is who Pat Buchanan says you should be. Distrust differences. Revile people who are gay. Dismiss the aspirations of women. Reduce the answers to the problems of our cities to "force, rooted in justice, and backed by moral courage." Let your fears and hatreds be your guide. Invoke God to justify them.
"There is a religious war going on in this country for the soul of America," Mr. Buchanan said. And if you agree with him you are blessed. And if you do not you are damned.
Thus did we learn of a simpler life, life without thought.
Some Republicans were distressed by the us/them tone of Mr. Buchanan's speech. But his hyperpitch does not stand alone. Pat Robertson, who also spoke at the convention, says that the equal rights amendment "encourages women to leave their husbands, kill their children, practice witchcraft, destroy capitalism and become lesbians." (What? No cannibalism?)
Marilyn Quayle, questioned about the wisdom of asking Mr. Buchanan to speak, said tight-lipped that he was the one who had done the asking. But Mrs. Quayle did some polarizing, too, saying liberals were "disappointed because more women do not wish to
be liberated from their essential natures as women."
I don't know what Mrs. Quayle defines as my essential nature; luckily, I worked that one out for myself a long time ago. I know it will probably take my daughter some time and some pain to figure out what being female means to her. Guide her with my beliefs and experiences, sure, but I will not garrote her with them. Maybe it would be a lot less difficult if she followed some all-purpose formula. But then she'd be a lot less human.
In the weeks since the convention the Republicans have figured out what the rest of us were thinking as we sat in front of our televisions. They flogged this package they called family values. And you could almost hear millions of folks saying, "Guys, we'll take care of our values if you take care of the economy."
And that is the point: we do take care of our own values, and it is an insult to have some pol stand up and tell us he has a handy-dandy all-purpose values package, one size fits all. The Republicans have now abandoned this campaign cul-de-sac. It would be nice if this was because they realized it was wrong. The truth is it just didn't play.
The Buchanan speech played least of all. Conscience is not simple; prejudices are not ennobling. The problems of L.A. require much more than automatic weapons. Good people disagree about abortion. Knowledge comes from discussion, not conclusion and exclusion.
It is painful to watch our kids struggle to find themselves in a complicated world. But it would be more painful still to have that growth stunted by the kind of exclusionary and conclusory catechism offered by Mr. Buchanan. He calls himself a traditionalist. I am a traditionalist too. The tradition I cherish is the ideal this country was built upon, the concept of religious pluralism, of a plethora of opinions, of tolerance and not the jihad. Religious war, pooh. The war is between those who trust us to think and those who believe we must merely be led. Demagoguery vs. democracy.

HEADLINE: Ducking the Environment

 BODY:
Senator Al Gore says George Bush has "turned his back" on the environment. The influential Sierra Club says the President has compiled an "anti-environment record that is the equal of Ronald Reagan's." Meanwhile, Republican spokesmen describe Mr. Gore as an extremist whose "hysterical" views would strangle the country in regulation and cost thousands of jobs.
These are caricatures. Mr. Bush's record is mixed, but his efforts to clean the air, protect the ozone layer and preserve Antarctica suggest a level of concern far higher than Mr. Reagan's indifference. 
 For his part, Mr. Gore is capable of hyperventilating on almost any ecological subject. Still, he discovered these issues before they became fashionable and has spent more time worrying about the trade-offs between jobs and a cleaner planet than almost anyone in government.
If the debate stays at this silly level, Election Day will arrive without either party addressing important questions or educating the public on tough choices. The winner will emerge with neither an environmental agenda nor a mandate.
This is not, of course, a convenient time for any politician to talk about the environment. Back in 1988, flush times, Mr. Bush could grandly promise to be the "environment President." No more.
Reeling from recession, and using Vice President Quayle as his point man, Mr. Bush has remade himself into a champion of environmental deregulation -- all in the name of jobs. Republicans accuse the Democrats of caring more about the spotted owl than unemployed loggers, more about fuel efficiency than auto workers.
Even Mr. Gore is feeling the heat. The Tennessee Democrat has long argued that the nation doesn't inevitably have to choose between jobs and a cleaner environment, and in many cases he's right. There's no reason, for example, why the richest country on earth cannot save its old-growth forests and retrain the relatively small number of workers who would lose their jobs.
Yet Bill Clinton's strategists have reportedly asked Mr. Gore to talk less about trees and more about the economy -- another sign that issues badly in need of intelligent discussion won't get it.
What would the candidates do, for example, to reconcile energy needs with environmental protection? Surely a vigorous commitment to energy efficiency could reduce pollution and serve as a hedge against global warming while improving the long-term competitiveness of American industry. The only issues are cost, and how best to do it.
The Democratic platform spends one sentence on the subject; the G.O.P. platform, none.
Nor is there much discussion of problems that are global in nature -- greenhouse warming, for example, or the exploitation of valuable rain forests. The loudest single message from the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro was that the third world wants the West to help pay for the environmental costs of its industrialization.
This is the sort of issue that Mr. Gore and William Reilly, Mr. Bush's environmental chief, think about all the time. But it does not fit conveniently into sound bites.
The electorate needs to know how the candidates would handle a wide range of environmental questions. Yet the recession has both parties running away -- the Republicans from their early achievements, the Democrats from their promise of an even better policy.

HEADLINE: Abolish the Disaster Agency

BYLINE: By Lawrence J. Korb and Robert H. Kupperman; Lawrence J. Korb and Robert H. Kupperman have both served on the Federal Emergency Management Agency's advisory board.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The Federal Emergency Management Agency's lackluster response to Hurricane Andrew makes it painfully clear that the agency should be abolished.
In theory, the management agency is responsible for coordinating the Government's response to domestic emergencies. In reality, it has little practical authority to carry out Presidential priorities -- particularly when it tries to coordinate with much larger entities, like the Pentagon or the Department of Transportation. Moreover, the agency has become a dumping ground for mediocre political appointees with little background or interest in disaster relief. In fact, its ratio of political appointees to career professionals is the highest in the Government. 
 The U.S. used to have an effective crisis-management organization. The Office of Emergency Preparedness was in the White House. Its director, a member of the National Security Council, reported directly to the President. The office handled domestic disasters, as well as national security emergencies (like industrial sabotage) and economic crises (like carrying out a wage and price freeze).
But in 1973 the office was abolished, a victim of a political skirmish in the Nixon Administration. Its national security functions were moved to the General Services Administration, while its disaster management responsibilities were transferred to the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
In 1978, Jimmy Carter put crisis-management responsibilities back under one roof when he created the Federal Emergency Management Agency. But the agency's record has been less than inspiring. Delays plagued its responses to recent disasters -- the San Francisco earthquake in 1989, Hurricane Hugo the same year and Hurricane Bob in 1991. Worse, the rest of the Government doesn't take the agency seriously. Wallace Stickney, its director, was effectively cut out of the decision-making process during Hurricane Andrew.
The emergency agency should be scrapped and replaced with a smaller, highly professional office. The new agency must operate from the White House, and its director must be of Cabinet rank to carry the necessary authority. About 500 professionals (100 in Washington and 400 in the field) would constitute its nucleus, replacing the current staff of 2,600.
Moreover, the military should be given responsibility for planning and logistics, coordinating simulations of disaster conditions much as it conducts military exercises. Bases across the country would serve as centers for water, food and medical supplies and as temporary shelters. A military official of lieutenant general rank should be made director of operations for the agency to strengthen ties with the Pentagon.
During the cold war, it did not make much sense for the military to take on domestic disasters. The Pentagon could not afford to have Army divisions tied down in Florida if the Soviet Union tried to break through NATO defenses in Germany.
But now fewer troops need to be stationed abroad. Giving the military responsibility for disaster relief would not only be good for the country, it would be good for the troops, giving them a meaningful mission to maintain their cutting edge. Our armed forces know how to deal with disasters, as they demonstrated in Somalia and Bangladesh. And they would be particularly adept at responding to the man-made disasters of the future: techno-terrorist attacks that could paralyze the entire country.
If the Administration is really serious about reducing the size of Government, it would replace the Federal Emergency Management Agency with a streamlined crisis-management organization agile enough to provide disaster relief immediately -- and not a few days later.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
