HEADLINE: 'Business as Usual Won't Work'

 BODY:
Articles in the Sunday, Aug. 2 issue ["New Fields Opening Up, Offering Hope for Jobs" and "Retraining Classes Inundated") underscore the reality that business as usual won't work, recent changes seem permanent and our economy will never again be what it was. For high school students close to graduation, for seasoned workers facing a bleak job picture and for the broad community of counseling and educational professionals the challenge is great.
Counselors in L.I. high schools have the task of refocusing students' expectations and goals, helping to guide them into marketable fields of interest and to schools that can meet their needs. Sometimes, that choice is a two-year college first, to help move them more quickly into the job market. At Briarcliffe, more than a third of our graduates eventually go on to a four-year institution (usually on Long Island) to complete a bachelor's degree. Many go for graduate work. 
 As Dr. Pearl Kramer notes, a whole array of new technologies is coming on board and education and retraining is critical. For our experienced work force, many technical skills are transferable, with some updating and focussed effort on new programs and new advances in the high-tech fields. There are student services, including counseling, job preparation and placement, that can make the difference between failure and success.
Finally, the articles clearly mark the need for increased co-operation and partnerships between education and business to give our economy the jump-start and consistent energy it needs to recover and remain strong.
 
RICHARD TURAN
President
Briarcliffe College for Business
Data Systems Institute
Woodbury

HEADLINE: Bush Takes Economics Out Beyond Voodoo

 BODY:
To the Editor:
One of the notable features of the Reagan Administration was its reliance on voodoo economics, the dubious benefits of which are presumably still with us. President Reagan's program was coherent but wrong. President Bush, with the two major tax proposals in his acceptance speech, has given up on coherence as well. 
 The first proposal is that he will cut income taxes by an unspecified amount to the extent that he can find unspecified expenditures to cut. This promise is empty as it stands and incoherent in principle. Even if the spending cuts could be found, as Herbert Stein has pointed out, the President could not afford to reduce taxes if he really supports a balanced budget amendment (or simply a balanced budget), as he says. Balancing the budget requires that any saving in the cost of government be applied to reduce the deficit, not taxes.
The second proposal is to give each taxpayer the option of allocating a fraction of his or her taxes to defraying the cost of government, the rest being used to reduce the deficit or debt. Again, the President would insist on matching, but unspecified, spending cuts. This would be an astonishing way to run a railroad, let alone a government. The standard procedure in a democratic society is for Congress and the executive to assess the needs of the country and its capacity to bear taxes, and to reach a compromise. The Bush proposal would let the public decide how much should be spent, regardless of need. Public finance textbooks will be agog at this innovation.
Leave that aside. The President has committed himself to reducing the deficit some $200 billion over the next five years. The checkoff for debt reduction could, if fully taken up, reduce spendable revenue by about $280 billion over that period, as estimated by the Congressional Budget Office. It is hard to price out an unspecified, across-the-board tax reduction, but cutting rates by 2 percent would cost $250 billion over five years.
Throw in a few of the President's other recommendations, and you are soon close to a trillion dollars. Where could the spending reductions possibly come from, with Social Security exempt as promised? The charitable explanation is that Mr. Bush does not mean a word of it. His program might well be described as out beyond voodoo.
 
FRANCO MODIGLIANI
ROBERT M. SOLOW
Cambridge, Mass., Aug. 31, 1992
 
The writers are professors of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
For Victims Of Hurricane, The Crisis Is Here to Stay

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
More than just the landscape was irremediably altered two weeks ago when Hurricane Andrew smashed and swirled its way across southern Florida, blowing down thousands of houses, stores and offices and leaving 38 people dead. Hundreds of thousands of people have had their lives shattered, and as they labor wearily in the ruins left by the biggest natural disaster in American history, one question looms above all others: how much longer before things return to normal?
The signs are not encouraging. Even for those lucky enough not to be included in the estimated 250,000 homeless, the initial elation that came with survival and the discovery of a home that was merely damaged, not destroyed, has faded into a primitive and numbing routine. By Friday, an estimated 350,000 residents of Miami's southern suburbs remained without electricity and potable water, forced to cook their meals and boil their water over propane stoves or open fires. There are also generators to be filled, mosquitoes to be fought off, and roofing material, glass and plywood to be sought. 
 Army troops and utility repair crews seem to be everywhere, working around the clock, which in an odd way only adds to the frustration and impatience surging throughout the disaster zone. Compared with the great leaps forward in the first days after the storm, progress now seems to come in smaller and smaller increments, and impatience is growing. "The aftermath is the real test," cautioned Kate Hale, Dade County's Director of Emergency Management. "It's going to take a very, very long time to sort this out and clean it up."
Some elements of normal life, of course, have been restored or will be in the next few days. Grocery stores that have reopened are selling fresh meat and fruits as well as the canned goods that were the only source of sustenance in the first days after the storm. The school year is to begin Sept. 14, two weeks later than originally scheduled, and a primary election is even to be held Tuesday, after a court-ordered delay of one week.
Beyond the immediate problems of food and shelter, however, there are concerns about what kind of place Miami will be after the last bit of debris has been carted away and the lights turned back on. In the 1980's, Miami came to be seen as glamorous, cosmopolitan and polyglot -- the kind of place where it was possible to enjoy diving and sailing by day and nightclubs and exotic cuisines by night. Granted, the trend setters have been quick to return to Ocean Drive in Miami Beach, despite a county-wide curfew that remains in effect. But if the damage caused by Hurricane Andrew exceeds $20 billion, and insurance companies anticipate having to pay out $7.3 billion, where is the difference going to come from? President Bush has pledged that the Federal Government will pay virtually all the costs of rebuilding public property and services in Florida, but Federal officials say it will be weeks before they can even estimate the amount of aid that will be needed to fulfill that promise. Already, local officials are talking of tax increases, which, when paired with an abrupt shortage of cheap housing, means a certain loss of allure.
"The fantastic cost that is going to be involved in reconstruction here is far beyond the capabilities of any local or county or state government," Representative Dante B. Fascell, who represents south Dade County in Washington, said last week after touring the disaster zone. "The devastation is just unbelievable."
Spurred by President Bush's visit Tuesday and his televised appeal that night for assistance, people around the country have been sending supplies to the area, some driving from as far away as California and New England to help. But what appears to be lacking is an overall sense of the recovery's direction. Local officials and business leaders have been so overwhelmed with day-to-day details that they have not had time to address long-term needs like jobs and housing.
In addition, a gulf seems to be emerging between those who suffered in the storm and those who did not. Residents north of the disaster zone have begun to complain of round-the-clock local radio and television coverage of the storm's aftermath, wondering when they will again be able to watch their favorite prime-time programs instead of scenes of devastation. People living in devastated areas like Perrine and Richmond Heights, most of them black and many of them poor, are questioning why more affluent neighborhoods got more press attention and, at least initially, more relief supplies.
 
'The City Invincible' Stumbles
 "What took so long?" Caroline Sumpter asked while in line for food in Perrine. "Is it because we are black?"
Some older residents have been wondering aloud if Hurricane Andrew might not be as much a turning point in Miami history as the storm that struck "The City Invincible" in September 1926. That hurricane destroyed thousands of homes and caused huge financial losses. Its greatest impact, however, was on public confidence and the city's image, both of which took a severe beating. Not until the end of World War II did the region's economy really begin to take off again.
Southern Florida today is much larger and its economy much more diversified than it was during that first boom period in the 1920's. But Hurricane Andrew has inflicted damage that will require more than gestures like President Bush's announcement that he wants to rebuild Homestead Air Force Base. The scenes of devastation broadcast around the world can only tarnish Miami's luster as a tourist destination, even though other Florida cities tried to distance themselves from that problem with an advertising campaign reminding people that most of the state was untouched.
 
A Breadbasket Uprooted
 With no significant industries, the Miami area relies heavily on commerce and services, both of which are now severely damaged, as sources of employment. Local business leaders estimate that up to 7,800 small companies employing more that 50,000 workers are in danger of going out of business. Agriculture, already reeling from the impact of the free-trade agreement with Mexico, is another victim. The area around Homestead is one of the prime sources of winter vegetables and tropical fruits for the United States, and many farmers who lost crops say they may have to go out of business.
Some people are wondering, in fact, if it is worth the effort to stay on and try to rebuild. "We were very, very fortunate to survive," Joyce Conjurski, manager of a trailer park in Homestead, said as she and her husband cleared rubble last week. "But everything here is gone, and our friends have all been scattered to the wind. You have to ask yourself if maybe it isn't time to move on."

HEADLINE: As Washington Lives on Credit, States Live on Gruel

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES

 BODY:
While President Bush politicked across the Great Plains early last week, handing farmers some $1.8 billion in Federal largess, Gretchen Tegeler was poring over the Iowa state budget in her Des Moines office, looking for ways to make ends meet. It is a stretch.
Spending on major items like prisons and the state payroll is ballooning. Medicaid alone already consumes one of every 10 state dollars and is pegged to rise by more than 20 percent as far as the eye can see. State revenues, meanwhile, are projected to grow by about 4 percent a year, or barely enough to beat inflation. Ms. Tegeler, the state's top fiscal officer, figures she has about two years before the two lines converge and cross. 
 "It's a difficult time to be governing," she said.
It is, at least in most states. In the latest and most sobering example of belt-tightening, California's government enacted a $57.4 billion budget last week that sharply cuts welfare, higher education and aid to local government, and imposes new restrictions on health-care programs for the poor. Across the country, tax hikes and spending cuts are more the rule than the exception.
But somehow, the message of hard times hasn't stuck in Washington. Last week alone, Mr. Bush pledged billions for disaster relief in hurricane-stricken Florida and to rebuild a wrecked Air Force base that had been, until the storm, a strong candidate for permanent closing. He gave $1 billion in subsidies to wheat farmers locked in a trade war with Europe, and dispensed close to $1 billion more in disaster aid to farms and communities from Arizona to Ohio and beyond. His Democratic rival, Gov. Bill Clinton, has no treasury to dip into, but promptly flew to Florida and matched Mr. Bush's offer of assistance anyway.
 
Spending, the New Virtue
 This is not out of form for either candidate. Mr. Bush claims to be an apostle of small government. But like a lot of politicians, he has turned the ugly necessity of Federal spending into a virtue at election time. He pledged in August to develop the M-1A1 tank, a jobs-creating project for the politically shaky states of Michigan and Ohio that, only months ago, the Pentagon had derided as a huge waste. He has also reversed field to pump foreign money into the economy, changing a decade-old policy last week to allow Taiwan to buy $6 billion in F-16 jets -- and keep a Texas aircraft plant operating.
Mr. Clinton is not to be outdone. In the primaries, he urged building Seawolf nuclear submarines that even Mr. Bush wanted to pinch, and his somewhat sketchy economic platform advocates $220 billion in added "investment" -- once called spending -- in part on such laudable programs as high-tech research, communications, education and roads. The Clinton campaign contends its plans are revenue-neutral, financed by cuts and streamlining elsewhere, but many experts find that claim dubious at best.
Is helping storm victims and factory workers wrong? Hardly; Mr. Clinton and the Democratic Congress, which allotted much of the money Mr. Bush is handing out, seem to agree that it is generally not. So do most voters. The real question, which only is starting to dawn as a political issue, is how long they can keep it up.
Iowa and other states have to balance their books, but the revenue and spending lines for the Federal bureaucracy crossed paths long ago and are now diverging at the rate of $332 billion a year. Among state leaders there is a growing fear that the Federal deficit is not just an abstract number but a genuine threat to their own fiscal health, prolonging economic downturns and gobbling up Federal revenues to which they might otherwise lay claim. (Interest on the national debt, at 14 percent of the budget, this year surpasses the 13 percent allotted to various grants to state and local governments.) There is also is a sense that if Mr. Bush or Mr. Clinton and their Congress do not find a way to control their spending, the painful choices legislatures and governors are making this summer, more than likely, are trial runs for those that Washington soon will be unable to avoid.
What kinds of choices? An April survey of state budget offices concluded that 23 states were proposing cuts in employee benefits in their fiscal 1993 budgets, and state employment would drop by 180,000 full-time positions. Nineteen states wanted to cut Medicaid, Aid to Families with Dependent Children, or both. Fully 36 states are considering a bureaucratic restructuring to cut expenses and deliver services more efficiently.
Nine states have proposed personal income-tax hikes this year, and 14 want to raise sales or corporate income taxes. States raised taxes and fees by a record $25.3 billion in 1991 and 1992, and have raised them another $5.1 billion for fiscal 1993.
"We're trying to communicate that tough choices must be made," said Oregon's budget director, Mike Marsh, who also is busily plotting huge cutbacks in state spending. "There's a perspective out there that you can continue to do more for less ad infinitum. And at some point, there has to be some recognition that that stops, and you have an impact on services."
 
A Shot Across the Bow
 Mr. Marsh was talking in part about citizens, but mostly about politicians who, he said, shy from what he believes is the real task: curbing the public's appetite for more government. The 50 governors fired a shot across the Federal bow on that issue in February when, at the National Governors Association meeting in Washington, they grilled both President Bush and his budget director, Richard Darman, on their plans to reduce the deficit. More recently, Oregon has prepared the public for budget cuts by beaming its Governor by satellite to 20 town meetings for discussions of state spending and taxes. In Iowa, Gov. Terry E. Branstad, a Republican, held the Legislature through two special sessions until it agreed to pass a package of spending cuts and enact a one-cent sales tax.
Even if it wanted to, the Federal Government is hindered in making similarly large changes in the budget anytime soon, because a drastic reduction in spending or a tax increase now would risk turning a slow recovery into a steep recession. On the other hand, says Alice M. Rivlin, a leading expert on Federal spending at the Brookings Institution, some things can be done: "The Federal deficit could be reduced with less agony than the states are going through if the economy revives, and if a new President and a new Congress work out a plan for reducing it over the next five or six years."
None of that seems especially likely today. Ms. Rivlin said she sees no sign of anything but a tepid recovery. Mr. Bush is running on a platform of tax cuts and spending cuts, and Mr. Clinton on a proposal to shift taxes from average people to the rich and big business. In general Mr. Bush proposes to shrink the Government out of the deficit and Mr. Clinton to grow his way out. But neither has a specific proposal to reduce the deficit. "Whoever wins," Ms. Rivlin said, "is going to be in a very tough spot."

HEADLINE: LOOKING FOR WORK;
America Isn't Creating Enough Jobs, And No One Seems to Know Why

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
This is a joyless Labor Day for many people. It is like a May Day without a Maypole or Christmas without gift-giving. It is hard to remember a time when so much was going wrong for the American worker.
Labor Day used to be a celebration of the nation's wage earners -- 20-year employees in factory and office jobs with rising incomes that made tens of millions of Americans, by the early 1970's, solidly middle class. Rarely, if ever, had prosperity been so widely spread through a population. "You could train a person on the job and it was like he had been born into a rich family," said Richard Freeman, a Harvard labor economist. 
 But now the jobs that were the foundation of the American prosperity are dying out, or paying less, or being lost to countries where labor is cheaper.
How to get back to the rich days? People are being told that the route is through education. They must be better at reading and math. Get a college degree. No one explicitly says so, but the message is that corporate America somehow stands ready to generate well-paying jobs for a better-educated, more skilled work force.
But Americans already are highly educated. Nearly 22 percent of the work force has college degrees, almost double the percentage 20 years ago. And 23 percent is going beyond high school today, taking some college courses in their pursuit of the elusive better jobs. The Germans and the Japanese, those benchmarks of industrial prowess and steady jobs, just match the American achievement in higher education.
 
Educated and Frustrated
 The problem, it is turning out, is not so much the lack of education, although clearly many Americans don't read or add as well as they should. The problem is a shortage of good jobs, even for the educated. Across the country, one major industry, health care, is scrambling for skilled workers. Nearly everyone else has applications piling up, particularly if the pay is $8 an hour or more. And increasingly, the Labor Department reports, college graduates are taking lesser jobs -- as sales clerks, for example -- that don't require a college education.
Indeed, on this Labor Day, it is worth considering the paradox that companies in the forefront of the campaign for better public school education to solve the skills problem -- companies like General Motors, Kodak and Xerox -- have nevertheless shed skilled workers by the tens of thousands. Corporate America, in the name of efficiency and survival, has chosen to permanently shrink its employment rolls, and the shrinking process is not over yet.
 
More Bad News
 "The economy is failing nearly every American," Lawrence Mishel, chief economist at the Economic Policy Institute, a Washington research group, told Congress's Joint Economic Committee on Friday. Drawing on recently published Government data, Mr. Mishel calculates that even the wealthiest Americans, the 20 percent of the households with $80,000 a year or more in annual income, have been losing ground to inflation since 1989. Until 1989, they had been the one group bucking the trend toward shrinking real incomes.
Some say that Labor Day 1993 will be happier. By then, they predict, the recession will be over, along with the weak economic growth that has held down the nation for more than three years. The economy will be growing smartly again, these optimists say, and while big corporations might not rehire many workers, new companies will form to hire more workers, and the job machine will once again generate more than 200,000 new jobs a month, the minimum considered necessary to absorb a growing labor force. How far distant this goal is was illustrated on Friday, when the Labor Department reported that 167,000 private sector jobs disappeared in August. The latest unemployment rate is a still very high 7.6 percent.
Such unsettling data, coming week after week, are thinning the ranks of the optimists. Alan Blinder, a Princeton economist, is a recent convert to pessimism. "It is a very glum Labor Day," he says. "We have been unable to recover from recession and no one knows the reason why."
Nevertheless, explanations are emerging. Many are still based more on suspicion than solid evidence. But among other messages, they seem to say that radical, long-term changes in American labor practices and trends are limiting job opportunities and wages -- perhaps helping to cause the weak economic growth, rather than being its result.
"It is hard to establish what is recession and what is trend apart from recession," said Marvin Kosters, director of economic policy studies at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington. Full knowledge will come only in hindsight, he said.
The Presidential candidates, George Bush and Bill Clinton, offer planks to redress labor's decline -- but like corporate leaders, they stress job training more than job creation. More than in his first term, Mr. Bush would focus on Federal grants to retrain job-losers -- for example, auto workers whose operations were moved to Mexico. Mr. Clinton would require companies with 50 or more employees to spend 1.5 percent of their payrolls in constant worker training.
In the Clinton camp, one hope is that the investment will commit companies to their workers, as Germany does through its national apprenticeships for young people not going to college, and large Japanese corporations do with extensive on-the-job training. Another hope, in both camps, is that American companies will somehow immerse themselves, en masse, in new technologies and work practices not easily transferred to other, lower-paid countries. That inclination has not shown itself yet.
"A lot of the skill training can and should be done on the job, and the question is who is going to pay for it," said Paul Ostermann, an expert in job training at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "If you ask companies, many say they are unable to cover the cost."
 
Income Declining
 Whatever the solutions, the problems are piling up. Take household income. Through much of the 1970's and 1980's, more and more household members went to work. But women are no longer entering the labor force in rising numbers, and young people are also having more trouble finding jobs. The result: the wage stagnation among individuals has spread to household income. The Census Bureau, reflecting the trend, reported last week that median household income, adjusted for inflation, had fallen to $30,126 in 1991 from $31,750 in 1989 -- after having risen for six years.
"It is primarily the recession that is doing this, but there are other factors as well," said Daniel Weinberg, a Census Bureau official.
It is mainly the recession that has driven up the number of Americans living in poverty to 14.2 percent of the population, roughly matching the level during the 1981-1982 recession, the Census Bureau reported last week. But other problems are not just a result of the recession and weak economic growth.
Forty percent of the layoffs last year were white-collar workers, double the level in earlier recessions, as manufacturers are not the only ones shrinking staff. Millions of Americans who still hold jobs tell stories of friends or relatives who have lost theirs, or have been forced into lower-paying work, often at smaller companies. Job insecurity has been woven into daily life, making millions of Americans who are burdened with debt from the 1980's reluctant to spend freely again as they work down their debts.
The hardships continue. Layoffs and attrition in the defense industry, shrinking in the post-Cold War era, have accounted for at least 15 percent of the job losses since mid-1990, and these seem permanent. The number of workers without company-sponsored health insurance or pensions, or both, is rising. People on layoff are remaining out of work for longer periods than in the past, suggesting that even companies with rising sales are reluctant to take back employees -- a reluctance that corporate executives often confirm and justify as necessary for efficiency.
Some 6.3 million people who work part-time really want to work full-time, the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics reports, and one million others, listed as neither employed nor unemployed, appear in bureau statistics as wanting to work but too discouraged to go out and look for jobs.
Both figures are rising, and Mr. Mishel, in his Congressional testimony Friday, declared that if one adds up the unemployed, the underemployed and the discouraged, more than 13 percent of the labor force is clearly in pain.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
From Soviet Warheads to U.S. Reactor Fuel

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
Last week a new kind of unthinkable came to pass, marking a milestone in the transformation of nuclear swords into plowshares. The Bush Administration announced it had quietly cut a deal with Russia to buy much of its highly enriched uranium -- the very stuff that for decades was the explosive core of Soviet warheads, prompting Americans to build fallout shelters and a costly military-industrial complex. The agreement marks the first time in the atomic age that large amounts of military uranium are to be diluted into fuel for civilian power plants.
The deal, particulars of which must be ironed out and approved by the two Governments, calls for the United States to buy at least 500 metric tons of highly enriched uranium over 20 years. That amount of material is valued at several billion dollars. The Administration's aim is to bolster the shaky Russian economy, to reduce the risks of nuclear accidents and theft and, less explicitly, to expedite the disarmament of a former foe. 
 Even Federal officials privy to the secretive negotiations said they could hardly believe what had been wrought.
"Instead of lighting up mushroom clouds, this stuff is going to light up homes in the United States with electricity," said Philip G. Sewell, a Department of Energy official who took part in the uranium talks. "It's kind of incredible."
Not all experts were overjoyed. Paul Leventhal, director of the Nuclear Control Institute, a private group based in Washington, worried that the transport of highly enriched uranium to the United States for processing could prove risky. Instead, he said, it should be diluted into harmless reactor fuel in Russia before being shipped. The 500 metric tons of uranium is enough to build more than 30,000 bombs as powerful as the one dropped on Hiroshima.
"We've never moved H.E.U. in those quantities," Mr. Leventhal said, referring to highly enriched uranium. "You have the potential for theft and diversion, which even in relatively small amounts has tremendous potential for blackmail and destruction."
The Administration has pledged that transport of the material will be protected from accidents and theft, and has agreed to buy bomb uranium that has already been diluted from Moscow, if it can produce such material.
Highly enriched uranium is never stockpiled to run civilian reactors, which use a less concentrated material known as low enriched uranium. Traditionally, the two worlds of uranium have been kept far apart since they are so contrary, for peace or war.
After purchase by the Federal Department of Energy, bomb-grade uranium is to be diluted into commercial reactor fuel. Industry experts say the fuel would cover a football field in a 1.5-foot-thick layer and run the 110 nuclear reactors now operating in the United States for a decade or more.
 
A Fraction of Normal Demand
 The Department of Energy is the world's largest enricher of uranium for civil reactors, selling fuel to utilities around the world and the country. Nuclear reactors must be at least partly refueled with fresh uranium every 12 to 18 months. The department plans to use diluted Russian material to meet some fraction of its normal customer demand.
Mr. Sewell of the Energy Department said the agency expects to save up to $200 million a year on its own uranium enrichment operations, freeing that money for Russian purchases and making the deal "budget neutral."
Uranium miners who supply the department have voiced few complaints about the Russian agreement, saying that if it is managed carefully it will have little impact on their business. After all, raw uranium ore will be used to dilute the bomb fuel. "Besides," noted Robert E. Moyer, an official of the Uranium Producers of America, a trade group, "the fundamental idea is of benefit to everybody."
A godfather of the deal was Dr. Thomas L. Neff, a physicist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who argued that the dismantlement of Soviet warheads offered an economic bonanza that could aid Russia's transition to a market economy while helping avoid nuclear misuse and proliferation. His ideas, outlined in an article on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times last Oct. 24, were reviewed favorably in the State Department and other Federal agencies even as the Russians, increasingly desperate for hard currency, became nuclear salesmen.
 
U.S. Companies Saw Potential First
 The Government was also prodded by several American companies, including Allied-Signal Inc., an aerospace and chemicals giant based in Morristown, N.J., that saw the potential for big profits in the resale of Russian bomb fuel and wanted to do the deal themselves. Instead, the Government took the lead.
Months of secret talks culminated in Moscow on Aug. 28 with the initialing of a 20-year agreement. It calls for the Energy Department to buy no less than 10 metric tons annually for the first five years, and no less than 30 metric tons annually for the next 15 years, Federal officials said. A final contract is to be signed within a year. Methods of processing and transport have yet to be determined.
The 500 metric tons is what many experts once considered to be the total Russian inventory, so they are now raising their estimates because it seems unlikely that a nuclear superpower would sell its entire supply.
"This is a pretty significant event in the history of the 20th century," said Marvin S. Fertel, vice president of the U.S. Council for Energy Awareness, the communications arm of the nuclear power industry. Even so, the White House downplayed the deal.
Rather than being presented at the regular noon briefing, where it might have made a splash, the news dribbled out late Monday. A confusing fact sheet seemed to suggest that the deal was for 80 metric tons, which understated it considerably, and gave no time period for the transaction. Late Monday night, a White House spokesman said he knew no details of the accord and was unaware that President Bush had hailed it earlier that day.
A State Department official said the news was downplayed out of concern that it might embarrass the Russian military, elements of which feel betrayed by the dulling of Russia's nuclear edge.
But Mr. Fertel suggested that the deal was slighted because of general White House bumbling and foreign-policy defensiveness during an election year in which domestic issues have so far reigned supreme.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Poland Sets Rough Path In Market Restructuring

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG

 BODY:
Communism left its mark on Eastern Europe, from the polluted landscape to the acres of dilapidated concrete apartment blocks. But perhaps the most politically significant legacy was a human one: the millions of workers who run the heavy industries and were used to being taken care of, after a fashion, by their government.
It is a proletariat fired by an incendiary mixture of anger about the past and fears about the future. 
 In what was once East Germany, the Government has tried, with mixed success, to buy them off with social programs and retraining. In Poland, the more apt model for the impoverished nations of the former Eastern bloc, the Government has recently launched a riskier strategy. It is confronting its own recalcitrant workers, and even threatening to replace strikers from the most radical unions.
Last week, on the 12th anniversary of the founding of the Solidarity movement, dismissal notices were sent to strikers -- a move that neither the last three democratically elected prime ministers or Poland's Communist Governments had dared make.
If this approach succeeds, it is likely to be emulated by other former Soviet bloc countries, all of which have restive workers employed in economically inefficient heavy industries awaiting restructuring.
The conflict between the workers and the expiring free market government is particularly acute in Poland, where the largest state-owned steel mills and shipyards were strongholds of the Solidarity movement.
Because of their size and poor management, most of these factories have been the least able to adapt to the rigors of competition. With wages stagnant and bankruptcy often looming, the employees of these companies find themselves among the losers in the new market economy they helped create.
Still, economists agree that these factories will have to be broken up, their bloated work forces trimmed, and the companies turned private if Poland and other former Communist nations are to revise their economies.
Poles frequently point out that Western governments have found it impossible to administer such bitter medicine in their own countries, and they take note of the European Community's massive farm subsidies and the persistent budget deficits in the United States.
But because their national world is so much smaller, the weak democracies of Eastern Europe paradoxically have less room to maneuver. Their circumstances, and the need to forge agreements with the International Monetary Fund, force them toward hard decisions.
 
Ex-Trailblazer
 Poland's Governments in the last year have managed to postpone tough economic choices, but at a price. Its agreement with the I.M.F. has been suspended since September 1991 and its reputation among Western investors has slipped badly.
From 1990 to 1991, Poland was a trailblazer in the region, and its shock-therapy reforms showed how a Communist-style economy could eliminate shortages virtually overnight by trimming government subsidies and allowing prices to jump to world levels. Leaders of the economic reforms were praised for their courage.
Then politics reared its head. The next step that was planned, the massive restructuring of industries and the closing of inefficient mines and factories, coincided with presidential and then parliamentary elections. Poland found itself with a fragmented Parliament whose members had campaigned on vague popular promises of a better life.
Jan Olszewski, a lawyer with no background in economics, became Prime Minister last December, ushering in six months of gridlock. His Government did manage to produce a slimmer budget but it also effectively froze privatization and seemed to deliberately erect roadblocks to Western investment.
After a Parliamentary vote of no confidence, an interim Prime Minister, Hanna Suchocka (pronounced sue-HOTZ-kuh), emerged in July to head a coalition Government. Immediately she was confronted by strikes, including a wildcat walkout at a car parts factory in the southern Poland city of Tychy.
Although Ms. Suchocka had not provoked this test of wills, her aides quickly saw the possibilities. While many strikes under way stem from legitimate workers' frustrations with bad management or, in the case of the Ursus Tractor Factory near Warsaw, previous Governments' ineptitude in carrying out restructuring plans, the strike at Tychy appeared different -- even one that the Government might win.
It was egregiously ill-timed, and unlikely to generate public sympathy. The factory is part of a nearly $2 billion investment in Poland by Fiat, the Italian auto giant, which meant its success or failure would send an important symbolic signal to other investors.
 
Solidarity Splinter Group
 The union argued that the deal, renegotiated by successive governments, had been overly generous, and said Fiat should have been squeezed harder. In fact, Fiat had already promised stepped wage increases over the next year if the deal was signed.
Nonetheless, even before the final papers were agreed to, workers at Tychy struck, demanding that they be paid 10 percent of the value of the car they were making, the subcompact Cinquecento. Also perhaps helping the Government's public relations position, the strike was led by Solidarity 80, a radical splinter group from the original Solidarity union. Solidarity 80 is now part of an alliance of angry farmers, former Communists and unions that oppose the economic reforms.
After negotiations proved fruitless, strikers began to receive dismissal notices. Late last week, in response, they halved their wage demands and returned to the bargaining table, prompting local managers to suspend the dismissals as a gesture of good faith. But the point had been made, both inside the country and to the foreign investors, and the betting in Warsaw was that Ms. Suchocka would eventually prevail in this strike and several others now under way.
Ms. Suchocka said she was trying to change a mentality that has been rooted in decades of Communist rule. "There exists in society a certain barrier in social consciousness -- society is somehow unable to free itself from the previous way of thinking," she said in an interview last week. "So far, they believe that the losing of a badly paid job in some state company or government office is a defeat for them, instead of realizing that it is a certain challenge to begin new work which will be more satisfying and better paid."

HEADLINE: The World Has a Few Too Many Russian Vodkas

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
Selling vodka in the New World Order has not proved a simple matter.
Ask Kenneth L. Onish. Several years ago, the Connecticut businessman began laying the groundwork to import Soviet vodka to the United States. He hit on the perfect name, one that captured the excitement of the changes in the Communist bloc, and had thousands of labels printed. 
 But by the time Mr. Onish's vodka hit the shelves of American liquor stores this summer, history had marched on, trampling his marketing plan. The vodka was named Raissa, after Raisa Gorbachev. Its advertisements read: "They've Tasted Freedom. Now You Can Too! Raissa, The Taste of Glasnost" and conclude with the curious catch-phrase: "Our thanks to George, Gorby, Boris and CNN."
Raissa vodka has failed to find its way into many gimlets.
While many liquor industry executives and trade experts expected a swarm of imported Eastern bloc vodkas to follow improving international relations, that has not happened. "There is a certain vaguely tacky quality" to the few recent imports that have crossed the Atlantic, said S. Frederick Starr, a Russian scholar who is president of Oberlin College. The exception, he said, is Stolichnaya Cristal, a $26-a-fifth vodka (brand-name American vodkas run $12 and up) that Mr. Starr said has replaced satellites as the new symbol of Russia's ability to make at least one high-quality product.
But even regular Stolichnaya, which at $19 a fifth is by far the most popular Russian vodka in the United States, is encountering problems instead of the huge profits it had expected with the collapse of the Communist bureaucracy. Pepsico Inc., which has the contract to import Stolichnaya in return for cola syrup, is struggling just to get basic supplies. Even bottles are in short supply, forcing Pepsi to import them from other parts of Europe. As a result, Soviet shortages are showing up in American liquor stores.
The disintegration of the Russian economy is also posing uncomfortable marketing problems. Vodka sellers usually rely on photographs of glaciers and icy mountain streams to convey images of purity, but shots of bread lines, dingy factories and outdated nuclear reactors on the evening news project a far different image.
"Until things stabilize, it is hard to believe that informed American consumers are going to pay upscale prices for anything from the Soviet Union that you have to put in your mouth," said Edward Keenan, a professor of history at Harvard University.
Struggling vodka importers admit people seem edgy. "A lot of people are asking about quality," said Everard Marks of Euro Trade Inc. "What they are really asking is: "Is it made in somebody's barn?' "
It could get worse -- and it does. The brew that Euro Trade imports, Tarkhuna, is a "flavored vodka." And it is flavored not with lemon or pepper -- which Americans are just now getting used to -- but with tarragon. It has a pale green tinge and a label of vaguely Stalinist design, but is from the now-independent Soviet republic of Georgia. Its ads read: "Georgia On My Mind."
That may only confuse consumers more. Those who perceive that it is not a peach liqueur from suburban Savannah probably have only one other Georgian image on their minds, thanks to American advertising: a heavily mustachioed people in fur hats who attribute their longevity to yogurt.
Besides, even though vodka is the best-selling liquor in the United States, it's a shrinking market; alcohol sales fell 7 percent last year. "There is no crying need for another imported vodka," said Nicolas Furlotte, editorial director of the Jobson Corporation's annual survey of the liquor industry. He was recently approached by a Czech company eager to export its vodka. "We told them, 'Who needs it?' " he said.
The irony of all this is that Stolichnaya created the "premium vodka" category with its made-in-the-land-that-invented-it image. But because it was a state monopoly, no other Soviet vodkas were exported. So the Swedes, Finns and even the British jumped into the category with Absolut, Finlandia and Tanqueray Sterling and ate up Stolichnaya's market share.
Absolut alone has triple the sales and triple the advertising budget of Stolichnaya. Now a newcomer has to advertise heavily to get into that category -- and those magazine pages and billboards can't be bought with, say, Ukrainian ruble coupons.
 
Invading Afghanistan Hurts Sales
 For Pepsi, supply problems and new competition are simply more hurdles in what has always been a difficult relationship. Stolichnaya's "real Russian" heritage has always proved something of a two-edged sword.
After the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, Americans hunting for a way to protest it seized upon dumping bottles of Stoly. Sales dropped 40 percent. They climbed back up, only to plunge again after Korean Air Lines Flight 007 was shot down by a Russian fighter in 1983.
"Our sales curve has been a barometer of East-West relations," said John Swanhaus, president of Pepsico Wines and Spirits International.
Still, even though history is hardly cooperating with capitalist plans, importers like Mr. Onish are pressing bravely on. He still even defends his appropriation of Mrs. Gorbachev's name (to which he added the extra "s" in case the Gorbachevs objected to the scheme).
"This is the year of the woman," he said. Then he began improvising further: "You know what I like about the name? If you look at 'Raissa' real fast, it looks like 'Russia.' "

HEADLINE: AFTER THE STORM;
SNARL OF RED TAPE KEEPS U.S. CHECKS FROM STORM AREAS

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Sept. 5

 BODY:
The Federal Emergency Management Agency, the Government's lifeline to people caught in disasters, is so understaffed and consumed by paperwork that tens of thousands of victims of Hurricane Andrew are unlikely to get immediate financial help when they need it most.
Few have seen a check yet, and many others have been told that it will be weeks more before they can even apply for aid.
The main problem seems to be red tape that keeps even the most dedicated agency workers from doing more than helping the hurricane victims fill out forms.
 
16 Centers for Thousands
 Of scores of people interviewed over the last week, not one had yet received a Government check, and many others were still trying to apply for one. A major Homestead bank that has been operating since the day after the storm hit on Aug. 24 said it had seen numerous checks from insurance companies but no Federal relief checks.
The emergency management agency has set up 16 temporary Disaster Assistance Centers in Dade County, most in tents, where several hundred registrars help people fill out forms for subsistence and home-repair grants. The registrars also steer people to other workers at the centers who can help, including counselors from the Small Business Administration, which provides loans to qualified businesses and homeowners, and the Internal Revenue Service, the Department of Veterans Affairs, the Red Cross and the Salvation Army.
The management agency also takes information for grant applications by telephone, although working telephones are hard to find in badly battered communities like Homestead, Florida City and Cutler Ridge. And some centers have begun dispatching bilingual aides into neighborhoods where people are clinging to the ruins of their homes.
But many of the estimated 200,000 people left homeless have still not been reached, and when lines build up at the assistance centers, the storm victims are given appointments to come back days and even weeks later.
"What do we do in the meantime?" Juanita Mosely said after she was told to come back between 10 A.M. and noon on Sept. 26.
The agency said that by Wednesday it had paid out $500,000 in several hundred checks to grant applicants in Florida, for an average payment of less than $2,000. The five disaster centers in Louisiana, a state that took less of a hurricane blow than Florida, had dispatched 169 checks totaling $228,000.
"We are writing checks faster than in any other disaster," said Andrea Booher, a spokeswoman for the emergency management agency.
As he rushed off from a quick inspection of an assistance center in Homestead, Antonio Perez, an associate director of the agency, said, "F.E.M.A.'s doing just great despite what your newspaper is reporting."
 
No Checks at a Bank
 Whatever the amounts, it is almost impossible to find anyone who has received a check from either the emergency management agency or the Small Business Administration. Likely people to come across the checks are cashiers at the First National Bank of Homestead, whose main office reopened the day after the storm. Through a week when nearly all other banks remained out of commission, First National cashed checks and took deposits for all comers, customers or not.
"We are not seeing any Government checks," Bob Jensen, a First National vice president, said late this week.
Mr. Jensen said that he was seeing checks only from insurance companies to policyholders and that the first of those to show up were for immediate living expenses, typically $2,500 to $5,000. Lately, he said, he was seeing much larger amounts for the full value of homes that were destroyed.
One day this week, Juanita Mosley, whose Southern Gentleman barber shop in Cutler Ridge is shut down and strewn with the debris of a collapsed ceiling, joined the line of 20 people at the assistance center in the parking lot of Cutler Ridge Mall. Ms. Mosley, who has owned the shop for 22 years, said she could not find her landlord to ask if he would rebuild the barber shop space. She had recently let her insurance expire while she looked at other policies.
"I don't have a business," Ms. Mosley said. "I don't have a home. I don't have an income."
Many people here do not buy insurance other than personal liability coverage for their cars. This is a low-wage economy of clerks and farm workers who typically do not own much personal property or have the disposable income to pay for insurance.
At the center, operating from folding tables and chairs under two candy-cane-striped canopies, 10 counselors worked patiently, most straight through lunch in 90-degree heat filling out the emergency agency's 29-question Disaster Assistance Registration/ Application forms. One of the smaller centers, it is also the most productive in putting through applications quickly, agency figures show.
 
'Mass of People' in Need
 "I'm finding that we have a mass of people that need help now," said Jimmy Wheeler, the center's manager, who stood at his post all day greeting people. "We try to find out what type of assistance they need."
But there is little the counselors can actually do. The center cannot approve applications or shed light on how much money applicants might get, when they will get it or whether they will get any at all.
There was still less the center could do for Ms. Mosley. When she came to the front of the line after a 20-minute wait, Mr. Wheeler gave her an Appointment Information form inviting her back on Sept. 26.
Yet Ms. Mosley was luckier than people who came later. By mid-afternoon, when Margaret McBean, 37, got in line, appointments were backing up, and she was asked to come back on Oct. 2.
"Four kids and they put you on hold," said Ms. McBean, a medical secretary who is separated from her husband.
"I can't go to work," she added. "My car's windshield is broke. We don't have no electricity or water. I need to move somewhere. I don't have savings. I live from paycheck to paycheck, like everybody else.
"You listen to the radio saying the Government is going to help you. Where do they help you? 'Go fill out this application and wait.' I can't wait one month, two months."
Ms. Mosley and Ms. McBean might have been immediately served if they had gone to one of the centers that, because of their remote locations, have been getting little business.
"They're not limited to going to that center in their neighborhood," said Jim Aguirre, a spokesman for the emergency management agency. But at the Cutler Ridge center, no one advised people to try elsewhere.
In general, information of the centers is spread by word of mouth and by radio. But most of the centers are so poorly marked that a person could pass by without realizing they are there. There is little uniformity in appearance or organization.
In addition to location, luck is a factor in getting processed. On a recent day, the counselors at Mr. Wheeler's center were told that if long lines formed appointments were to be given for Oct. 7, but rain cut down on the number of visitors to the center, allowing counselors to meet with all comers.
 
Bureaucratic Caution
 What seems to be involved here is a conflict between compassion and caution, with the emphasis on caution. The emergency management agency and the Small Business Administration want to be alert to fraud and the criticism of taxpayers and Congressmen. "We don't have someone willy-nilly writing checks," Mr. Aguirre said.
But because of the scrutiny given to applications, the agency can violate another of its missions: helping people quickly and making sure that, as an agency flier puts it, "people have a safe place to live until their homes can be prepared."
Both agencies are also under budget constraints that prevent them from sending enough counselors and investigators into the area to speed the work. And as big organizations, they can be slow in responding to the ever-changing needs of people here.
Although F.E.M.A. has dealt with scores of disasters in the 13 years since President Jimmy Carter established it, the agency is learning as it goes in confronting what is proving to be the costliest natural disaster in the nation's history. On Thursday, for example, the agency told its registrars to disregard 14 of the 29 questions on the assistance form.
 
Adapting to Needs
 Typically at the centers here, a hurricane victim approaches the manager, who makes a quick assessment of the person's needs and assigns him to a registrar. If the registrars are backed up, the manager sets up an appointment to return.
The registrar first helps fill out the disaster application form and tries to see if the applicant has enough income to carry an Small Business Administration loan for up to $100,000 for home repairs or up to $500,000 to re-establish his business. If the applicant qualifies, he is sent home with a big manila envelope, addressed to the S.B.A., that contains other forms and requests for documents like tax returns, even though for many people such records blew away with their roofs.
People with little or no income and little insurance can apply for grants of up to $11,500 to repair their homes. And every person with a damaged home, whatever his or her income, can apply for a grant to pay for three or four months rent, based on rental costs in the area and the emergency management agency's determination of the family's housing needs.
Each grant seeker is told that in 8 to 10 days an inspector will contact him to set up a time to visit and verify his claims. The applicant is also given an (800) telephone number with which he can track his application's progress or report a new address. Once an applicant finds a working a phone, however, the (800) number is often busy.
 
Paper, but No Money
 A few people seem fed up with their visits to the assistance centers. An unshaven man who appeared to be in his late 50's bolted from the big center in Homestead, saying, "Yeah, I got help. A lot of paper but no money.
Another man, Jerry Beard, who wanted a small-business loan to replace lost equipment, seemed befuddled by the paper chase the Homestead center was sending him on. "I was here 40 minutes, and I've got enough stuff to keep me busy for a month," said Mr. Beard, who owns Jerry's Pest Control.
David Banks stopped at a center, waited in line for an hour, gave up and then came upon another, in the parking lot of the Naranja Park Baptist Church. That center is one of the more remote ones, and with no one in line, Mr. Banks was able to sit down with a registrar immediately.
Like many people here, Mr. Banks lost both his home and his business, a auto-repair business in which he went to people who would call him or send him a fax. He still has his truck but his home was demolished. He has moved to an apartment in Miami but has not been able to get his phone numbers transferred and so cannot get work. In addition, he said, he has lost a lot of his tools.
Mr. Banks's house was insured, and the insurance company has given him $2,000 in living expenses. He used all but $132 of that to get his temporary apartment -- $619 for a month's rent and the rest for security and a deposit.
The registrar chided him for spending so much of the money, Mr. Banks said, adding, "They know nothing about rents around here. That just got me four walls to live in."
The registrar gave Mr. Banks forms and told him to come back when the insurance company contacted about reimbursing him for the loss of his home. "Then another guy here said, 'Forget that. Come back tomorrow,' " Mr. Banks said. "I'm coming back tomorrow."
"What angers me most," he continued, "is that their favorite answers are, 'Wait a minute,' and 'I don't know.' Nobody has any idea of when the money is going to be available. One guy says seven days. Another guy says two weeks. I expect it to be a long, long time."
 
Getting On With Life
 With the immediate trauma of the hurricane over, many people applying for aid seem worn down but working to reassemble the order of their lives, and many say they get sympathetic hearings at the assistance centers.
"We don't have a check, but at least we have a number now," said Frances Blackwelder, whose home and furniture store were destroyed.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Strategy;
Recasting Bush Isn't Easy, Baker and Aides Discover

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD with THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5

 BODY:
From their State Department perch six blocks west of the West Wing, the Baker team had scoffed and raged for two years about the clumsy attempts of Bush officials to deal with politics and domestic affairs. The foreign affairs "whiz kids," as they liked to think of themselves, could not always hide their contempt for what they saw as a slapstick, slapdash White House operation.
When the country turned inward after the Persian Gulf war, when Los Angeles burned, when Ross Perot tapped into voter disgust, James A. Baker 3d and his band of fortysome thing aides looked over at the White House in wonder. What they saw was President Bush and his advisers squandering record-high approval ratings through their failure to understand the anxiety of Americans in economic pain and to offer a convincing plan to solve their problems.
 
Fixing the Mechanics
 But now that they have commandeered the White House, members of the Baker SWAT team confide that they are coming to grips with the fact that it is not so easy to ride to the rescue. They are, after all, operating within the constraints of a Reagan-Bush legacy that has dismantled important levers of government, especially in the domestic agencies. They are also working with a President who had wasted political capital for four years by scorning the idea that he needed to communicate, or even develop, a coherent theme and long-range strategy for his Presidency. 
 Their initial steps have been largely mechanical: brisker, more focused daily White House meetings; more substantive Presidential speeches tied to specific initiatives and a fresh cordon of trusted aides to manage the President on the road.
 
So Much to Do; So Little Time
 This may be the first Administration in history that is scrambling for its first-100-days plan in its last 60 days before facing the voters. With Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas still leading in the polls and with more bad news in the latest economic figures, the Baker team quickly has to get beyond long-overdue, elementary improvements in organization to a fundamental recasting of the Bush persona and campaign.
One of the reasons George Bush is in trouble is that his image now is of wanting to be President more than of wanting to accomplish things as President. A key to Ronald Reagan's success was that he always managed to convey the impression that he would rather be back in California riding a horse but had to stay in Washington to enact his ideas. Now Mr. Baker and his aides are expected to come up instantly with the ideas that will justify Mr. Bush's urgent desire to stay in Washington.
Like students cramming the night before an exam, the Baker aides are closeted in their offices, steeped in paper, coffee and Diet Cokes, working late into the night to come up with campaign themes and attack lines, driving everyone at the campaign headquarters crazy by calling every few minutes to find out Bill Clinton's position on one thing or another. The group who knew a lot more about the inner workings of the Russian economy is frantically working out economic recovery ideas for America -- which they expect to unveil shortly.
Even as Janet G. Mullins, the new Bush campaign liaison, was still trying to figure out where the White House ladies' room was, and Margaret D. Tutwiler, the new White House communications director, was still asking officials down the hall, "Excuse me, I don't mean to be rude, but who are you and what do you do?" they were hit with Hurricane Andrew, the sour aftertaste of the Republican National Convention and the pungent reality of the mess they had inherited.
 
Mood of Desperados
 While he enjoys polishing his image as a wily court magician, Mr. Baker knows he will be lucky to get out this time with his cape and rabbits intact.
It is one more fascinating twist to the 35-year friendship and rivalry of the Tex-prep friends that, in some ways, the better Mr. Baker does, the worse Mr. Bush will look, because it will underscore the President's Zelig-like tendency to be as clever as his nearest adviser. "If Baker is the great pooh-bah and savior, it makes George Bush look weak, doesn't it?" noted Lyn Nofziger, the White House political director under President Reagan, who regards Mr. Baker as an overrated self-promoter who has put his own interests ahead of those of Mr. Reagan and Mr. Bush.
The mood of the Baker team is a mix of anger at having to move in at this late stage, terror at the prospect of being labeled failures and thrill at the thought of beating the odds. They have been swamped trying to simultaneously figure out everything from who runs the White House fax machines to who can be relied on to get things done in the government agencies.
When they were at the State Department, "We knew who you talk to, how you move things, who you can trust, if you want to establish a no-fly zone over southern Iraq," one Baker aide said privately, because they are all trying to keep low profiles. "But we had to learn about southern Florida. So you go ask people questions, but you don't know who really knows, so you don't know whose answers you can trust. In the State Department, you pull a lever and you have a pretty good idea what is going to happen on the other end, and if it doesn't happen you know just where to kick or jiggle."
Mr. Baker had made it clear over the years that he agreed with critics who charged that the autocratic former chief of staff, John H. Sununu, had surrounded himself with a second-rate staff. But the officials brought in by Mr. Sununu and those brought in by his successor, Samuel K. Skinner -- layers that curl outside Mr. Baker's inner circle like rings on a tree trunk -- seem sincerely relieved at the arrival of the C-Street cleanup crew, even though some were evicted from their coveted West Wing offices.
The only antidote to the ingrained Washington instincts for envy, turf-fighting and backstabbing, it would seem, is the fear of humiliating defeat. As one top Bush campaign official sees it: "At some point the prospect of being hanged in a fortnight focuses you on avoiding the noose. You can worry about the location of your cell later."
It is a measure of the chaos that Bush officials talk gratefully about how James Baker has stripped them of titles and power. They describe themselves as a sort of dysfunctional family craving an authority figure -- a role that the genial Mr. Bush did not want to play or even delegate.
Under Mr. Skinner, officials said, meetings meandered without a clear agenda or a sense of who was responsible for what. "There was no centralized authority or forward motion," said one top White House official. "If you wanted a decision overturned, all you needed to do was wait 30 minutes or call another meeting. Now people play the roles they are designed to play."
 
Genius, in Comparison
 It has not gone unnoticed that Richard G. Darman, the budget director, does not try to use his sharp elbows on Mr. Baker, his former boss in the Reagan White House, and instead goes along tamely. Mr. Baker has also reclaimed White House control over the campaign schedule of Vice President Dan Quayle, a potential rival for the 1996 nomination should both men's careers survive this election.
Although there have been plenty of "White House in disarray" headlines over the past few years, the extent of drift is vividly underlined by the way veteran White House officials rave about some of the basic administrative changes instituted by Mr. Baker. What would look like standard operating procedure is hailed as another example of Mr. Baker's administrative "genius."
For instance, one senior Bush aide gushed over the way Mr. Baker has made sure that the President's speeches "deal with real issues now," have only one theme and are no longer written on Air Force One at the last minute. Speech writers no longer have to come on each trip to cut and paste because speeches are prepared in advance under the direction of Robert B. Zoellick, the brainy deputy chief of staff who makes even the buttoned-down Mr. Baker look like a blithe spirit.
Other proferred examples of Mr. Baker's skill: If someone rambles off the subject at a meeting, the new chief of staff steers him back to the subject at hand, and each meeting is expected to produce solutions.
 
Taming the Meetings
 Mr. Baker and his aides know that this is not rocket science, and they privately reflect some resentment about having to leave the State Department to inject the sort of order and substance that Mr. Bush might easily have had all along.
Before he meets with the President at 8 A.M., Mr. Baker holds a 7:30 meeting, which is attended by the core group that has moved from State -- Mr. Zoellick and his equally well-organized colleagues, Miss Tutwiler, Ms. Mullins and Dennis Ross, the policy planning chief -- as well as Mr. Darman; Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman; Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, and the downsized campaign directors, Frederic V. Malek and Robert M. Teeter. The same group meets at 6 P.M. to see where things stand.
"We had one meeting that lasted 45 minutes," an aide said. "I came out and said to Scowcroft: 'God, that took a long time. Why did it have to take that long?' And he said: "Long? We would have spent four hours on that before.' "
 
Next, the Vision Thing
 Once again, Mr. Baker is directing the campaign from Washington and giving the often unfocused Mr. Bush clear guidance by surrounding him with a trio of aides on the campaign plane: Mr. Fitzwater, who deals with the press; David Q. Bates, a former Bush aide and tennis partner who has returned to keep track of local politics and make certain that Mr. Bush shakes all the right hands and knows the mayor from the governor, and Phillip D. Brady, who makes certain the President stays abreast of his daily duties as chief executive.
But everyone agrees that discipline will only go so far; the content of the President's message must be improved.
Baker aides say privately that, while the convention may have helped consolidate the Republican base, it was in many ways "a wasted opportunity." Mr. Clinton went into the Democratic convention with a major issue hanging over his head -- the "character question." He tried to resolve it as best he could and reaped the benefits in the polls.
Mr. Bush went into his convention with a major issue hanging over his head -- the need to convey that he had an economic plan to deal with restructuring the military industry, jobs, competitiveness, productivity. He did not address it and did not get the kick in the polls.
The Baker aides, insisting that "we get it," say they are drawing up a trellis of speeches, appearances, sound bites and Government initiatives intended to persuade a skeptical public that Mr. Bush actually has a domestic policy.
 
A One-Two-Three Punch
 The President's appearances last Wednesday, one official said, previewed a blueprint for the new three-pronged approach: Speech. Action. Attack.
The President met with farmers in South Dakota and aircraft workers in Texas, and the theme of his remarks was "economic security." The related concrete action was his announcement of disaster relief and $1 billion in export assistance for wheat farmers, as well as the sale of 150 F-16's to Taiwan that would provide jobs for 6,000 Texas aircraft workers. The companion attack on Mr. Clinton charged that he had a wishy-washy position on the North American Free Trade Agreement.
But even some of the most devoted Administration advocates wonder whether it is too late for Mr. Bush to transform himself into the Domestic President.
"The more they come up with now, the more people will ask, 'Where were you before?' " said one old friend of Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker.
Mr. Baker, who spent a generous portion of his time as Mr. Reagan's chief of staff schmoozing with the press, has refused so far to see any reporters since moving to the White House. Disappointed at having to give up his statesman's mantle, disdainful of his "handler" moniker, knowing that this is going to be an ugly race, Mr. Baker is keeping his head down.
The President, by contrast, has a new bounce in his step. As one aide notes, "He likes the new sense of stability."

HEADLINE: Auto Workers End Walkout Against G.M.

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 5

 BODY:
Striking workers at a General Motors parts plant in Lordstown, Ohio, overwhelmingly approved an agreement today to end the nine-day strike that had shut much of the auto maker's domestic production and idled more than 40,000 workers nationwide.
At a meeting in nearby Youngstown, Ohio, 98 percent of the workers voting approved the deal, officials of the United Automobile Workers union said. Union and company spokesmen said they expected workers to begin returning to their jobs tonight. 
 "We've got a skeleton crew in there now getting the plant ready, and we'll be up and running by this evening," David Kimmel, the president of U.A.W. local 1714, told Reuters.
An important issue in the dispute was the General Motors plan to close a tool-and-die shop at the Lordstown plant that employed 240 workers. Under the compromise reached today, G.M. agreed to keep the shop open at least through January 1994. After then, it will be free to close the operation.
Linda Cook, a General Motors spokeswoman, said this schedule was "slower, but not a great deal slower" than what the company had sought. She said G.M. would continue to move tool-and-die work from Lordstown to some of its other 10 shops in four states and Canada, while the workers in the Lordstown shop would have the option of retraining, transfer or early retirement.
General Motors also agreed to shift to the Lordstown plant additional stamping work on the company's 1995 model-year replacement for the Chevrolet Cavalier and Pontiac Sunbird cars. That work, previously planned for other plants, will add about 140 jobs at the plant.
"You never get everything you want, but we feel it's a good agreement," Mr. Kimmel said. "We feel we will be able to offer any one of our members affected by the tool-and-die shop closing the opportunity to stay at Lordstown."
 
Effort to Cut Costs
 G.M., which lost $4.5 billion last year, has embarked on a campaign of shutting plants and trimming 74,000 jobs from its payroll to reduce costs and turn itself into a leaner, more competitive company.
While both sides said they were happy with the agreement, the first reaction from Wall Street was that G.M. is still moving too slowly to cut costs.
"I would certainly characterize this as a victory for the union and a defeat for G.M.," John Casesa, an analyst with Wertheim, Schroeder & Company, told Reuters. "The market feels that G.M. must downsize as quickly as possible, and these types of settlements are slowing down the process."
The 240 jobs in Lordstown that the company proposed to eliminate thus became a symbol of far broader plans, and the negotiations themselves presaged the talks between G.M. and the auto workers next year over a contract for all the assembly plants.
Parts shipments to G.M. assembly plants across the country could be resumed during the holiday weekend, union and company officials said, and Ms. Cook said some but not all of the nine G.M. assembly plants closed by the strike could open on Tuesday,
Labor relations experts, G.M.'s competitors and industry analysts are certain to analyze the dispute to see how resolute G.M.'s new president, John F. Smith Jr., is about reducing costs.
The dispute is also a key test of leadership for Stephen Yokich, vice president of the union's G.M. department, and the leading candidate to succeed Owen Bieber as president three years from now. Mr. Yokich and the union have made job security the union's top priority, but not everyone in the union is sure about his tactics.
Michael Bennett, the head of the U.A.W.'s local at G.M.'s Saturn plant in Spring Hill, Tenn., had publicly questioned the wisdom of crippling the auto maker's overall production for the sake of an issue that affects one plant and relatively few workers. The Saturn plant, whose car models are in great demand, was forced to shut because it lacked parts produced at Lordstown.
 
Fight Over Tool-and-Die Shop
 G.M. had told the union it wished to consolidate tool-and-die operations elsewhere, closing the Lordstown shop. The union countered that G.M. was trying to give tool-and-die work to nonunion suppliers.
Candace Howes, an assistant professor of economics at University of Notre Dame and a former researcher for the auto workers' union, said G.M.'s strategy of reducing labor costs "doesn't gain you much and undermines any opportunity for real cooperation."
Although the union has not said so explicitly, its decision to strike almost certainly was motivated by the campaign to lower G.M.'s costs that is being carried out by J. Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, a Spanish engineer who was named G.M.'s vice president of worldwide purchasing four months ago by Mr. Smith.
Mr. Smith was named president only a month before that after G.M. directors became impatient with the slowness of change under G.M.'s former president, Lloyd E. Reuss, who was demoted.
Only a few months earlier, G.M. management had announced it would close 21 plants and eliminate 74,000 jobs through the mid-1990's.
The shakeup in G.M.'s management ranks and Mr. Lopez's cost-cutting edicts to suppliers have made the union fearful that they soon may be asked to forgo job security, wage and medical benefits, which are the most extensive and costly in American industry.
The strike at Lordstown signaled the U.A.W.'s determination that it would not give up jobs or benefits without a fight. The length of the strike signaled Mr. Smith's determination not to cave in to the union too quickly.
The strike at the metal-stamping plant had halted production of parts needed for 14 G.M. models and idled more than 32,500 workers at seven plants by Friday morning. Two more assembly plants, in Wilmington, Del., and Lansing, Mich., were closed late Friday night because of a lack of parts.
The other affected plants were in Oklahoma City; Wentzville, Mo.; Flint, Mich.; Baltimore; Orion Township, Mich.; Spring Hill, Tenn., and a plant adjacent to the parts plant in Lordstown.
G.M. and the union's Local 1112 settled similar grievances at a second Lordstown operation on Thursday.
