HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Farm Policy;
NO ADDED MONEY IN FARM AID PLAN

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5

 BODY:
Wheat farmers who were promised $1 billion in export subsidies by President Bush on Wednesday will find that sum more than offset by reductions in domestic programs that help them, Bush Administration officials now acknowledge.
The Administration is counting on the increase in exports to result in slightly higher domestic wheat prices. The higher prices in turn would reduce Government payments to farmers under domestic programs by $1.7 billion. 
 The farmers will still come out slightly ahead because of the higher prices. A third of their crop is not covered by Federal price guarantees and farmers actually receive the market price for this wheat. But the largesse will be far less than the impression created by the President.
The net gain for Federal coffers is not just budgetary alchemy. The calculations assume that foreign wheat producers will make up the difference by giving up a part of their share of the international market to American farmers.
 
Communications Breakdown
 Public statements from the Agriculture Department and the White House on Wednesday did not spell out how the Federal Government would pay for the subsidies, and Administration officials did little to counteract the impression this week that the subsidies represented a new bonanza for wheat farmers.
Robert E. Grady, the executive associate director of the Office of Management and Budget and the White House's top expert on export finance, said that the Administration had not tried to mislead anyone and that few journalists had asked him about the budget consequences of the program.
But he added that the Administration's explanations of the program might have been inadequate. "That may be part of our broader communications failure," Mr. Grady said.
Some export subsidies announced by President Bush represent the renewal of dozens of existing programs for foreign countries. These programs have been announced separately each year by the Agriculture Department since the export program began seven years ago, said Stephen L. Censky, the acting administrator of the Agriculture Department's Foreign Agricultural Service.
When told of the Bush Administration's budget calculations for the export subsidies, Gene B. Sperling, the economic director for Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic Presidential candidate, said similar calculations of savings could be made for many programs but were often not justifiable.
Representative Robert T. Matsui, a California Democrat on the House Subcommittee on Trade, said the Administration should have fully disclosed the domestic spending cuts when it announced the export program. "This has been the problem with the Administration's job-training program, the aid to hurricane victims in Florida and now the wheat exports -- they don't tell you where the revenues are coming from," he said.
Mr. Matsui, who was asked to comment, added that he was skeptical of the Administration's planned savings on domestic farm programs and worried that the export subsidies might add to the deficit.
As more American wheat is sold abroad, overseas prices fall. So the main effect of President Bush's spending change is to take away other countries' share of the international wheat market.
Foreign grain-producing countries are predictably furious. The most angry are countries like Australia, which has have few subsidy programs and whose farmers will directly feel the brunt of President Bush's decision.
"We deeply regret that domestic political pressures have overridden a U.S. commitment to the pursuit of a less corrupted international trading environment for farm products," said Prime Minister P. J. Keating of Australia in a statement on Wednesday.
The United States will now subsidize sales in Asian markets where wheat sells for about $3.50 a bushel, compared with $2.90 a bushel in markets where the United States and the European Community are subsidizing exports. For example, President Bush is nearly doubling the tonnage of subsidized sales to China, to 250 million bushels, and is adding India and Pakistan to the program.
With the spread of subsidies to Asian markets, Australian farmers may be forced to lower their export prices.
While the wheat export subsidy program announced by President Bush will cost close to $1 billion, it will save the Federal Government as much as $1.69 billion in domestic spending on wheat farmer assistance, said Mr. Censky of the Agriculture Department.
Under a program that currently covers two-thirds of the nation's two-billion-bushel wheat crop, the Federal Government guarantees farmers a price of at least $4 a bushel for their wheat. Wheat has been selling in the last week for $3.20 to $3.34 a bushel, making farmers eligible for Government payments of 66 to 80 cents a bushel.
By encouraging wheat exports and raising domestic prices, the subsidies announced by President Bush will mean that the deficiency payments will be smaller.
 
Plan Called Budget Neutral
 As a result, the export-subsidy program, "has always been scored by O.M.B. as budget neutral and still is," Mr. Grady said. "By driving the price up, you reduce the cost of our domestic programs."
Mr. Grady and Mr. Censky said the main benefit for farmers would come on the one-third of wheat production that is not eligible for price supports and for which farmers actually receive the prevailing price in the United States. The price of wheat for September delivery rose 5.5 cents to $3.2525 a bushel on Tuesday, when rumors of the export subsidies reached many traders, and climbed another 8.75 cents on Wednesday. On Friday they closed at $3.30.
Wheat can be ineligible for the price support program either because farmers choose not to meet the program's paperwork requirements or because a farmer produces more wheat per acre than the Federal Government allows in its payments program.
The United States subsidized the export of 680 million bushels of wheat during the crop year ended on June 30, 1992, and will subsidize the export of up to 1.1 billion bushels by the end of next June under President Bush's plan.
 
If Other Countries Retaliate
 But private experts cautioned that not all the new subsidies might be used if exports fall short of that level, which could happen if other countries step up their subsidies to avoid losing their shares of the world market to the United States.
The effect of the export subsidies on consumers will be too small to notice, because wheat is mainly used as an ingredient in processed foods and as animal feed, said Daniel A. Sumner, the Assistant Secretary of Agriculture for Economics. He pointed out that wheat accounts for only 2 cents of the cost of a loaf of bread.
"Any consumer effect is very small -- if it's measurable at all, it's negligible," Mr. Sumner said today.

HEADLINE: EUROPEANS RETAIN CURRENCY VALUES

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 5

 BODY:
Faced with the possibility of a major setback to European unification if French voters reject the union treaty, the 12 European Community nations sought today to ease growing economic strains but ended up again confronting their conflicting domestic priorities.
European finance ministers, meeting in Bath, England, amid turmoil in monetary markets, reiterated their commitment to the current European Monetary System, under which their nations have agreed to keep their currencies linked in value within a relatively narrow range. 
 They also discussed how they might respond if a French referendum on Sept. 20 goes against the next stage of European unification. Uncertainty over the outcome of the vote has widened the disparity in the values of key European currencies.
Investors -- nervous about the outlook for economic growth in Europe if the process of unification is slowed or stopped -- have been putting their money into the German mark, which is widely seen as the world's most stable major currency.
But as the value of the mark has gained in relation to other currencies, officials and economists have raised questions about the willingness and ability of nations to maintain even their current level of monetary coordination.
 
Germans Prove Unwilling
 The finance ministers failed to elicit what they most wanted, a signal from Germany that it would cut its interest rates. Instead, they said Germany had indicated only that it would not raise interest rates further under current economic conditions.
High German rates have contributed to the mark's surge, and to a corresponding drop in the value of some other European currencies and of the dollar as investors seeking higher returns put their money in mark-denominated accounts.
Bonn's Finance Minister, Theo Waigel, offered little hope of changes at a news conference today. "Everybody knows that lower interest rates have to be earned," he said, "and can't be ordered at the stroke of a pen."
The turmoil in the monetary markets and the uncertainty over the outcome of the French referendum have emerged as the clearest tests yet of the willingness of European governments to maintain their coordinated approach to economic policy in the face of growing domestic economic pressures.
In Britain, for example, some members of the governing Conservative Party have challenged their leaders to explain why they should remain committed to a European policy rather than concentrating on what is best for the British economy.
 
Accepting Short-Term Pain
 Despite doubts in the currency and stock markets and among some economists and government officials, the finance ministers have repeatedly restated their commitment to coordinate their currency values.
In Britain and Italy, the nations whose money has been most weakened, they have done so in part by taking actions that carry a short-term cost to their domestic economies. These moves include raising or threatening to raise interest rates in hope of reaping long-term benefits like lower inflation. The pain is borne by would-be homeowners seeking mortgages or entrepreneuurs in need of loans.
Italy, for example, raised its benchmark discount rate sharply on Friday -- to 15 percent from 13.25 percent, in an attempt to halt a rapid erosion in the value of the lira. The Government made the decision to increase rates despite a deep recession, suggesting its willingness to risk a domestic political backlash to reap the longer-range benefits of a more stable currency.
Norman Lamont, the British Chancellor of the Exchequer, said today that Britain, too, stood ready to raise rates if necessary. On Thursday, Mr. Lamont said Britain would begin an innovative program to borrow $14.5 billion worth of foreign currencies and use the proceeds to buy sterling in the hopes of bolstering the pound's value.
 
No Revaluation Now
 Mr. Lamont, as the chairman of today's meeting of the finance ministers, said the European Community nations had again rejected the possibility of revaluing their currencies. A revaluation would remove the need for higher interest rates or heavy central bank intervention in those nations with weak currencies. But it could lead to higher inflation and perhaps higher interest rates in the long run.
"We are not in favor of altering exchange-rate parities," the Chancellor said after the meeting, "and it is a very important part of the process of monetary coordination that we see greater stability within the European Monetary System."
But economists and officials question whether the European governments will be able to maintain their resolve if the French vote no on union and other currencies drop further against the mark. They said that ultimately the British pound, the lira and perhaps the French franc might have to be devalued to avoid domestic economic pain, especially if Germany holds its ground on high interest rates.
"I think the probability of the European Monetary System sticking together even in the event of a no vote remains very high," said Peter Spencer, chief economist for Kleinwort Benson Securities in London. "But I think it's also very likely that it will revert to something closer to what it was in the early 80's, when countries under pressure were allowed to devalue."

HEADLINE: Chamorro Dismisses Her Police Chief, a Sandinista

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Sept. 5

 BODY:
President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro removed her Sandinista police chief and 11 of his closest aides today, but the changes may not have met Bush Administration conditions for the renewal of economic aid.
Mrs. Chamorro, trying to juggle the pressures of the United States with the resistance of the opposition Sandinista Front, replaced the police chief, Rene Vivas, with another Sandinista, though of much lower profile. 
 The State Department, in part pressured by Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, was believed to have urged Mrs. Chamorro in recent days to replace both the police and the army leadership with non-Sandinistas. When she defeated the Sandinistas in elections in February 1990, she promised to keep them in those roles.
Daniel Ortega Saavedra, the Sandinista leader Mrs. Chamorro defeated, said he and other top Sandinistas met with aides to Mrs. Chamorro earlier this week and warned that the country would suffer a profound crisis if the Government bent to American pressure.
In a letter to President Bush published today in the Sandinista newspaper Barricada, Mr. Ortega said Washington was "promoting a witch hunt against those citizens who maintain their adhesion to Sandinista thinking."
When President Chamorro swore in her new police leader, Fernando Caldera Azmitia, she made no reference to the United States and insisted that the changes were part of an effort to create a professional civilian police force.
She also swore in a new vice minister for public security, a civilian, who will have direct authority over the police, serving under the Minister of Government, Alfredo Mendieta. The new vice minister, Ronald Aviles, is a cattleman and businessman.
Mr. Mendieta made the only reference to the United States during the announcements, saying in answer to a reporter's question that "we have excellent relations with the United States Government."
When Mrs. Chamorro was elected the United States accepted her reasoning that the Sandinistas might interfere with her Government and that retaining Sandinista leaders was necessary to preserve peace after the civil war.
However, for more than a year, leaders of Mrs. Chamorro's own electoral coalition have been saying it is time to remove the Sandinistas.
Mr. Vivas and a number of regional police chiefs have also been accused of abusive and repressive policies against demobilized members of the Nicaraguan Resistance, or contras, the American-backed force that fought the Sandinistas for a decade.
The Bush Administration, after long, quiet criticism of the Sandinista role, recently made its concerns public. Last spring, at the request of Senator Helms, it suspended the $104 million that remains of a $731-million two-year aid package approved after Mrs. Chamorro's election.
 
Aid Tied to Stabilization
 This week, a State Department delegation led by a deputy assistant secretary, John F. Maisto, met with top officials in Nicaragua, but neither side would release information on the talks.
Nicaragua desperately needs the aid at this point if it is to continue its largely successful currency stabilization program.
There is also concern that the United States might try to block financing from international agencies.
Mr. Caldera, whose title is director-general of police, has been accused in the anti-Sandinista press of repressive actions. Mr. Mendieta blamed the accusations on wartime conditions that were beyond the control of individual police chiefs.
Mr. Caldera, declaring that his conscience was clear, said he considered his responsibility to the Government to take precedence over his political affiliation as a Sandinista.
American diplomats said $5 million in emergency aid granted to Nicaragua this week after giant waves caused destruction along its Pacific coast did not come out of the $104 million in suspended aid but was a separate part of the package, marked for creating jobs, that had been held up by a decision of aid officials.

HEADLINE: Brazilian President Courts His Bureaucracy

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRASILIA, Sept. 2

 BODY:
In one sunlit office of the marble and glass Presidential Palace here, an aide talked confidently today of President Fernando Collor de Mello's battle against impeachment and plans for a visit this month to the United States.
Two flights up, one corridor over, another presidential aide brusquely cut off a visitor who cautiously mentioned Brazil's Vice President. 
 "Not the Vice President -- the future President," the aide snapped, flaunting his hope that Vice President Itamar Franco would soon replace Mr. Collor, whose future has been clouded by an influence-peddling scandal.
Unable to control the loyalty of aides working within yards of his corner office, President Collor faces the larger problem of losing control of Brazil's huge federal bureaucracy. The cooperation of the bureaucracy will be crucial in coming weeks if the President is to succeed with his plan to win congressional loyalties through political patronage.
With an impeachment vote expected for October, the President must win the support of 168 lawmakers in the 502-member Chamber of Deputies. According to one newspaper poll, 31 deputies plan now to vote against impeachment. Using the federal budget, the President must win converts among the 117 listed as undecided or the 354 listed as favoring impeachment.
Complaining of what he called "Trojan horses" in his administration, the President is reportedly planning to shuffle his cabinet next week in three key areas: economy, justice and congressional liaison.
The Economy Minister, Marcilio Marques Moreira, has refused to print and to spend money for the pet projects of congressmen.
The Justice Minister, Celio Borja, has allowed the federal police to continue wide investigations into allegations of multimillion-dollar misappropriations by the Collor family.
The Minister of State, Jorge Bornhausen, has announced that he will not get into "a vote-buying game" with Congress.
But by replacing this group of ministers, called the Eticos, or the ethical ones, by the press, it is not clear that Brazil's President will be able to make the bureaucracy do his bidding.
"The congressmen are going to want the money up front -- they won't go for promises," said Antonio Martins, an aide in the congressional liaison office. "As it is now, the President can't even get a vice minister of economy to return his telephone call."
Indeed, resistance to Mr. Collor's strategy of trying to save his presidency at any cost is believed to be spreading among upper-level bureaucrats.
On the lower levels, the opposition Workers Party controls many public service unions, including the unions of bank employees and accountants. In the 1989 presidential election runoff, Brasilia was one of only a few major cities won by Luis Inacio da Silva, the Workers Party candidate.
Today, the president of Banco du Brasil, Lafaiete Coutinho, is reported to be active in channeling patronage from the federally administered bank to congressmen. But at one bank agency here this week, each worker's desk was decorated with yellow and blue anti-Collor signs saying, "Resign Now."
Just as bank employees cooperated with a congressional corruption inquiry, they are expected to drag their feet in carrying out a congressional vote-buying campaign.
Some may also blow whistles. During the congressional inquiry, depositions by an office secretary and a chauffeur at the presidential palace were crucial in unraveling the multimillion-dollar influence-trafficking ring.
Much of this city's hostility toward Mr. Collor date from his first weeks in office, when he started deriding civil servants and slashing their benefits. Anger deepened in recent months when it became clear that the President was not matching his comments with his own lifestyle.
Testimony and canceled checks indicated that while her husband was introducing a national policy of austerity, Rosane Collor de Mello was receiving a $20,000 monthly spending allowance from the influence-trafficking ring.

HEADLINE: Yugoslav Sanctions Taking High Toll

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAR, Yugoslavia, Sept. 3

 BODY:
With its vast but vacant wharfs, idle cranes and empty warehouses, the largest port in the truncated state of Yugoslavia presents a poignant image of the economic paralysis that is gripping the country and leaves no doubt that United Nations sanctions are causing widespread suffering.
Although port officials and people living close to the nearby Albanian border say some smuggling of cigarettes, liquor and fruit has occurred since the imposition of sanctions three months ago, they describe the quantities as small and portray the overall effect of the United Nations embargo as disastrous. 
 "Largely nothing has come in during the past three months, apart from one or two small boats bringing bananas and other fruit," said Budimir Vukcevic, the deputy director of the port. Gazing out to the Adriatic, where only a solitary vessel with a Greek flag broke a placid view of empty seas, he added, "Usually we would be unloading 15 to 20 boats and have another 15 vessels waiting to come in."
Photographs in the entrance to the port provide an image of such happier times. They showed timber, steel, grain and Yugo automobiles waiting to be loaded for export. Now there is nothing to be seen.
 
U.S. Officials Describe Evasion
 Such desolation contrasts with the measured accounts of the effects of the embargo given by Western diplomats in Belgrade. They described evasion of the sanctions as common and many of Yugoslavia's borders as extremely porous. United States officials, citing the frequent use of the transshipment ruse of labeling goods for delivery to Bosnia and Herzegovina that were actually sent to Serbia, say they favor tightening sanctions on Yugoslavia to bring an end to the war in Bosnia.
"The only alternative to the use of force is the tightening of sanctions," said one United States official in Belgrade, arguing for what he called a "check in, check out" system that would insure that any goods labeled for Bosnia really ended up there. He added that the current price of bribing Albanian border guards to allow merchandise through was 500 German marks, or about $360.
Along the Albanian border, however, a different picture emerges. Some people show off cigarettes that had been smuggled in, and say small items like candy and school notebooks are also entering Yugoslavia. But, said Rizo Muslijevic, a trader from Titograd, "these are not large amounts, just what people can carry."
At the port of Bar -- whose importance for Belgrade has grown since other major ports were lost to the now-independent states of Croatia and Slovenia -- there is no question that activity has ground to a halt. Virtually all the 2,000 workers have been laid off. While many of them could be employed early in the embargo on maintenance and construction, such work has been exhausted.
 
Money Runing Out
 Moreover, while all workers have been receiving a substantial proportion of their wages up to now, money is beginning to run out. "I think for September we may not be able to pay anything," Mr. Vukcevic said.
The problems of this port are widely shared. Crippled by sanctions and also by the dislocating effect of the breakup of Yugoslavia, most major industries have sent their workers home. United States officials estimate that by the end of this month, 50 to 80 percent of workers will be idle.
But up to now the social impact of this disaster has been diluted by the summer vacation period -- when many plants would be closed anyway -- and by the continued payment of wages.
The vacation period is now ending. Although the Serbian Government of the hard-line leader Slobodan Milosevic has promised companies emergency funds for their employees, industrialists say that the amounts are insufficient and that anger and anxiety among workers is certain to grow as they realize there will be no return to work.
Western officials hope that this anger will be channeled into powerful protests against Mr. Milosevic, which will in turn put pressure on him to end to the fighting in Bosnia. While that may happen, the bulk of the anger here does not now appear to be directed against the government.

HEADLINE: Chinese Seem to Be Risking More Open Protests

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 1

 BODY:
The campaign by Deng Xiaoping and other Chinese leaders for faster economic change seems to be having an unintended effect: Dissidents and ordinary citizens are becoming a bit bolder in challenging the authorities.
Partly because the hard-liners appear to be losing ground as the airwaves fill with calls for reform, many Chinese say they find the atmosphere looser and less ominous. Some say that the fear that has gripped the country for the last three years, since the Tiananmen Square crackdown of June 1989, is gradually easing. 
 Consequently, some dissidents are no longer hiding their activities. They now openly meet with foreign reporters, write for foreign publications and denounce human rights abuses in their country.
 
Overseas Publication
 Zhang Weiguo, a Shanghai journalist whose newspaper, The World Economic Herald, was closed during the Tiananmen democracy movement, is one of several democracy advocates who seem less afraid of the leadership than it is of him.
"I'm writing more articles now than when I was at The Herald," Mr. Zhang said in a recent interview in Shanghai. Since his articles cannot be published in China, he writes about China for leading newspapers in Taiwan and Hong Kong, and he has given telephone interviews to the BBC's Chinese-language service.
The security apparatus is clearly alarmed about such growing boldness, but it seems at a loss how to react. So the authorities settle for harassing Mr. Zhang, summoning him periodically for interrogation, as well as threatening him and refusing to allow him to leave Shanghai. But Mr. Zhang, who spent more than 20 months in prison after the 1989 crackdown, continues to speak.
Perhaps the only effective way to silence someone so fearless would be to re-arrest him and sentence him to a long prison term. But this might provoke a furor abroad, reinforce the image of China as a brutal and repressive place and increase the chance of American trade sanctions.
 
Order vs. Freedom
 The treatment of Mr. Zhang is relatively lenient compared with the repression of a few years ago -- in 1989, for example, a marine biology student named Chen Lantao was sentenced to 18 years simply for speaking against the Government.
As fear diminishes, China may be becoming a more open country -- but perhaps also a less stable one. For the three years after the army's crackdown, in which hundreds were killed, thousands hurt and many more imprisoned, the peace was preserved through a balance of terror: The people were afraid of the Government and the Government was afraid of the people.
Some of that fear lingers on both sides, but less than before. Some in the Government acknowledge their apprehension that people could eventually take to the streets and overthrow the Communists, but there is a clear division within the leadership about the nature of the threat.
Hard-liners say the risk comes primarily from the dissidents and from contact with the West, and so they favor harsh repression. But others -- including Mr. Deng, the 88-year-old senior leader -- suggest that dissidents will get nowhere as long as the economy is booming, and so the leaders fear trade sanctions perhaps more than outspoken critics.
Still, there are several indications that the greater boldness has affected not only dissidents but also ordinary Chinese, although in ways that are not overtly political.
When application forms to buy stock ran out in the southern city of Shenzhen last month, some 50,000 would-be investors accused the Government of corruption and rampaged on the streets.
"That rioting would never have occurred in the immediate aftermath of the Tiananmen crackdown," said a Chinese journalist in Beijing. "But this year, with all the new talk about reform, people are feeling more hopeful and braver than before."
The journalist added, however, that most people are still afraid of openly criticizing the Government. For now, a repeat of large-scale pro-democracy demonstrations is impossible, he said.
"Lots of people are willing to be followers," he said. "But no one wants to be the first to say anything. There's a saying: the first bird in the flock is the one that gets shot. So there are plenty of birds that want to fly, but not in front."
The greater public boldness reached Beijing late last month, when China's normally docile soccer fans stormed out of Workers Stadium in Beijing after a loss to South Korea and marched angrily down the middle of the street. They shouted curses at the Chinese team, the head coach and the police.
It was the third outburst in a week from soccer fans, and the authorities were quick to arrest a few people and denounce the behavior.
The official Beijing Daily wrote, "These riotous acts, totally alien to China's long-noted politeness and courtesy, smeared the image of Beijing as well as our country."
Chinese soccer hooligans may seem like paragons of obedience compared to the more violent British soccer rioters, but in one sense the disruptions here are much more significant than in Britain.
The glue that keeps most Western governments together is public support for the system; in China, according to many foreign diplomats and Chinese, the adhesive is fear. So if Chinese soccer fans dare to march on the streets because of dissatisfaction with a sports competition, there is at least some chance that they may dare to protest the form of government.
 
Pitfalls in Leniency
 Recent history also suggests that a diminishing fear of the authorities might eventually lead to political protest.
Throughout the last four decades, the times when Chinese have protested against the Government have not generally been the periods of greatest discontent. Rather, they have occurred when people perceived -- usually incorrectly -- that the atmosphere was sufficiently lenient that they could get away with it.
To be sure, the authorities do their best to let people know that they will not get away with it. Some democracy campaigners, though not the most prominent ones, reportedly were quietly arrested over the last few months, and political prisoners in northeastern China recently smuggled out a letter complaining of continued beatings in their jail cells.
The latest police move occurred today, when the authorities detained Shen Tong, a democracy advocate who had returned from exile in the United States, as he prepared to hold a news conference. If Mr. Shen's return was a sign of the dissidents' new boldness, his detention was a signal that the authorities are willing to fight back.
So far, however, the Government has not reacted to another recent development that may cause security officials to furrow their brows. Three prominent independent-minded Chinese openly joined the board of a New York-based organization, Human Rights in China, that is often critical of the Beijing authorities. While the Government has not punished the three, it is not clear that it will allow them to leave China to attend a board meeting in the fall.
This relative restraint is having an unintended effect: It is skewing the incentive structure for dissidents. A few years ago, any Chinese knew that denouncing the Government would mean immediate dismissal, arrest and incarceration. But now, some critics suffer only harassment, and they achieve international renown and invitations to be visiting scholars at foreign universities.
Likewise, relatives of political prisoners used to believe that they were best off keeping quiet so as not to offend the authorities. But in several recent cases, family members have concluded that they are better off causing a fuss or at least speaking to the foreign press. In part they believe that attention in the West may result in shorter sentences for their loved ones, and in part they seem to feel more daring and assertive than they used to.
"With all the talk about reform, the Government has been telling us to be bolder in our actions," said a worker in his 20's, flashing a mischievous grin. "And so that's what's happening. We're bolder."

HEADLINE: Harold Curtis Fleming Dies at 70; Tirelessly Fought for Civil Rights

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Harold Curtis Fleming, a white Southerner who became an early leader in the struggle for racial justice in a "new South," died Friday at his home in Washington. He was 70 years old.
Friends said he died suddenly after a brief illness.
As executive director of the Southern Regional Council, an organization formed in 1944 to promote equal opportunity for Southerners, Mr. Fleming joined the civil-rights cause well before it became fashionable. And long after others had lost their fervor, he continued to work for that cause as head of the Potomac Institute in Washington. 
 Born on July 27, 1922, in Atlanta, he spent his formative years there and on a farm in the red clay hills of northeast Georgia. After attending Boy's High School in Atlanta, he accepted a scholarship to Harvard University, where he worked on The Crimson, the college's newspaper, and The Advocate, Harvard's literary magazine.
 
Commanded Black Company
 When the United States entered World War II, he enlisted as an officer in the Army. Through "a quirk of fate," as he put it, he wound up on Okinawa as the captain of an all-black quartermaster company. He described himself later as being "shocked, traumatized" by the experience.
"I really came as close as anyone to realizing what it was like to be black in those days," he recalled in a newspaper interview 20 years later, "because I was intimately involved in these men and their treatment and on the receiving end in a sense myself. It amounted to being a straw boss in a very ugly, discriminatory system, which is rarely remembered today."
After the war, he finished his studies at Harvard and, returning to Atlanta, took a "temporary" job with the Southern Regional Council. It lasted 14 years. The council was a fairly timid organization until he transformed it into a militant agent of racial equality.
He led creation of the council's Voter Education Project aimed at getting black citizens to register en masse. As it kept tabs of voter data, the council became the sole repository for black voter-registration statistics in the South, a treasure trove of numerical evidence used in hundreds of voting-rights lawsuits.
 
Envisioned Long Struggle
 Mr. Fleming moved to Washington in 1962 to head the Potomac Institute, a not-for-profit agency that provided counseling in race relations to public agencies and the private sector.
In the Administration of President Lyndon B. Johnson, he served as deputy director of the United States Community Relations Service. He was also a founder of the National Urban Coalition, and for more than a decade he served as chairman of the National Committee Against Discrimination in Housing.
In 1956, 11 years after joining the Southern Regional Council and two years after the Supreme Court decision that outlawed school segregation, Mr. Fleming co-wrote the book "Integration: North and South," in which he optimistically reported "extensive progress" in reducing discrimination.
But 29 years later, the goal seemed as elusive as ever. The more he and other civil rights advocates overcame rudimentary problems of racism, he observed in a 1985 interview, the more complex became the problems that remained. The struggle against discrimination, he said, had merely shifted from leaping simple political and judicial hurdles to curing stubborn economic and social ills.
And he observed: "There is a tiredness at the moment. We get tired very easily." Yet he counseled persistence, adding: "I think the things that are achieved in a field as complicated as this are achieved by people who stay with it."
Although Mr. Fleming retired from the Potomac Institute about two years ago, he continued to write and consult about civil rights issues and affirmative action.
"The theme of Hal Fleming's whole life is summed up in the title of that Protestant hymn, 'Let Us Together Sweetly Live,' " said Claude Sitton, retired editor of The News & Observer of Raleigh, N.C., who was chief Southern correspondent for The New York Times from 1958 to 1964. "A brilliant, effective, indefatigable worker for an integrated America in which blacks and whites could prosper alongside one another."
Mr. Fleming's survivors include his second wife, Jenna, and two sons, Gary and Tony.

HEADLINE: Where 2 House Candidates Are as Far Apart as Voters

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOZEMAN, Mont., Sept. 2

 BODY:
Voters in this state have no excuse for complaining that all politicians are alike. Ideological differences as vast as Montana's mountains and prairies make the race for its only seat in the House of Representatives a classic political contest.
The two opponents -- each a popular incumbent, one a liberal Democrat, one a conservative Republican -- disagree about almost everything. 
 Representatives Ron Marlenee, the Republican, and Pat Williams, the Democrat, were forced into a face-off when the House was reapportioned after the 1990 census. Montana's population grew only 2 percent in the 1980's, much more slowly than the nation, so the state lost the second House seat it had had since 1913. Because the number of House seats has been fixed at 435 since the 1910 census, states with stagnant or falling populations lose representatives while growing states gain them.
 
A Vast, Expensive Campaign
 Now Montana has the most populous Congressional district ever created, with 799,065 people, and the largest in area after Alaska's. The area's vastness has kept the two candidates campaigning nonstop by car, plane, helicopter and horseback.
Unlike many other contests between incumbents, this race pits two veterans who have strong out-of-state allies. So Mr. Marlenee (pronounced MAR-li-nay) and Mr. Williams are both confident they can raise the $1 million each has said he plans to spend.
With two months to go, public and private polls show the race just about even, with each candidate running strongly in his former district: Mr. Marlenee in the agricultural east he has represented for 16 years; Mr. Williams in the mountainous west he has represented since 1979, from the union town of Butte to academic Missoula.
 
Strongly Conservative Views
 Mr. Marlenee's message is part classic Western conservatism that asks government only to go away and part traditional constituency concern; as the second ranking Republican on the House Agriculture Committee, he has won higher farm subsidies.
He told small businessmen in Great Falls last week that "well-intentioned" measures like the Americans with Disabilities Act, workers' compensation laws, various civil rights statutes and the pending family-leave bill forced employers to mechanize because machines neither complained nor filed lawsuits.
The bluff 57-year-old rancher says such laws "give people a headache" and are putting others out of work. Asked by reporters if his analysis was supported by economists or research, he replied, "No economists." He said, however, that the idea had been around for a while.
Later, at a combative meeting with elderly voters, one man pressed him about the family-leave bill, which would require employers to give as many as 12 weeks' unpaid leave for family medical emergencies. Mr. Williams is a chief sponsor. If his son could get an unpaid leave from work to care for him, the man asked, "that's a family value, isn't it?"
Mr. Marlenee said the bill, which the House is expected to send to President Bush for a likely veto in a week or two, was unnecessary. Instead of a new law, he suggested, "if you're working for a jerk who won't give you medical leave to take care of your family, quit your job and find another."
 
'Noon and Midnight'
 Mr. Williams, a carefully spoken 54-year-old labor advocate in the House, disagreed and predicted that the family-leave issue would help him. Finding another job is not much of an option in a state where the economy has been sluggish for several years -- where a new Wal-Mart recently had 1,700 applicants for 175 jobs that pay $6 an hour. Young people have been leaving the state in large numbers to look for work.
Mr. Williams says this disagreement reflects the "difference between noon and midnight" that measures the political chasm between two candidates who share little more than an opposition to handgun control.
Ratings by interest groups capture that gap. Since 1981 the American Conservative Union's average rating of key House votes gave Mr. Marlenee 90 percent and Mr. Williams 9 percent. The liberal Americans for Democratic Action gave Mr. Williams 87 percent and Mr. Marlenee 7 percent.
In Washington, Mr. Marlenee is influential only on agriculture while Mr. Williams cuts a broader swath. In 1990 he led the House fight to preserve the budget of the National Endowment for the Arts.
The eventual law banned grants for obscene materials or performances, but blocked Congressional efforts to specify what kinds of art were too vulgar for the Federal Government to finanace. That stand brought efforts by the Rev. Pat Robertson, head of the Christian Coalition in Virginia Beach, Va., to defeat the lawmaker he calls "Porno Pat."
 
Contrasting Campaign Styles
 The rhetoric of the campaign also mirrors the candidates' differences. Mr. Marlenee attacks his foe as part of a "politically corrupt" House leadership. Mr. Williams can match him with attacks on Republican "trickle-down economics" but is uncomfortable with hitting back personally and directly.
Mr. Williams, a former school teacher, prefers more elevated themes. He calls this election a referendum on the future of Montana, which, he said last weekend at a fund-raising lunch in Missoula, was the last state "in the lower 48 to have an opportunity to set our destiny in major and meaningful ways."
He explained later in an interview: "Montana is the brow of America's last hill. Montana is what America started out to be. Now we face the challenge of figuring out of how to manage the economy with the environment in a way that secures jobs." The state also needs to manage the growth that is coming suddenly to places like Missoula and the Flathead Valley, he said.
He is trying in the last days of the Congressional session to pass a bill that would open some of Montana's wilderness to logging while preserving other sections. Mr. Marlenee effectively blocked the last version of that bill in 1988 as too tough on development and logging.
 
Spats Smother Issues
 While Mr. Williams does not always please environmentalists, Mr. Marlenee almost never does. Since 1981 Mr. Marlenee has averaged a 13 percent rating from the League of Conservation voters, Mr. Williams 63 percent.
These differences come through in debates and personal appearances, but many Montana voters may miss them. The local news media concentrate on reporting small spats, like Mr. Marlenee's complaint of political "vandalism" when a bumper sticker on a supporter's car was ripped off and replaced by one saying "No Mo Ron."
But Montana voters may be spared squabbling over the House bank. Neither incumbent avoided problems. Mr. Williams had 66 overdrafts but Mr. Marlenee had 20.
Whoever wins will have a big job just representing this vast state. In addition to a record number of constituents, there is an immense area to cover. Montana's 147,046 square miles are 1,505 more than the combined total areas of New York, Pennsylvania, Ohio, New Jersey and Connecticut, which will have 90 representatives among them.

HEADLINE: Indians Become Foes In Bid for Tribal Rights

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANACORTES, Wash., Sept. 2

 BODY:
In a windowless room off the main street in this small port city, a handful of American Indians are waging a campaign to bring their tribe back from extinction. A few blocks away, another tribe, working out of a trailer, is making a similar effort to gain recognition by the Federal Government.
Such campaigns are not all that unusual. Like others who lost their tribal status in the last century, the Samish and Snohomish Indians of Puget Sound are basically invisible without the Government's recognition of their sovereign status or their claims to Federal rights and benefits. 
 But what makes this fight particularly hard for the tribes involved is that their worst adversaries are other Indians. Their most powerful opponent is the Tulalip tribe just south of here, who say the efforts by the Samish and Snohomish Indians could put at risk one of the strongest court rulings in the history of Indian affairs.
 
Half the Salmon Catch
 The focus of the dispute is a deceased jurist whose name has become a household word among Indians: George H. Boldt, a Federal District Court Judge who died in 1984. In a landmark 1975 decision, Judge Boldt awarded half the annual catch of salmon in Puget Sound, worth tens of millions of dollars a year, to Indians who could prove that their tribes had signed an 1855 treaty with the Federal Government.
That ruling is to the fishing economy of the Pacific Northwest Indians what Brown v. Board of Education was to the integration of public schools.
But four years later, Judge Boldt ruled that the Samish, the Snohomish and three other tribes did not have access to the fishing bounty because they were not formally recognized by the Government.
Now, after having virtually given up hope of regaining their tribal status, the Samish Indians have discovered that Judge Boldt's death certificate lists Alzheimer's disease as a contributing factor. According to the death certificate, the disease first afflicted the judge in 1978, a year before he ruled against the five tribes.
The Samish are appealing the decision, claiming that the judge was mentally debilitated when he uncharacteristically accepted the Government's position without comment in 1979.
But other Indians fear that challenging Judge Boldt's 1979 decision could unfavorably affect his ruling in the landmark 1975 case. They argue that expert medical testimony might indicate that the judge had the disease when he ruled to give Indians half the salmon catch. Thus, the Samish and Snohomish find themselves isolated in the Indian community.
Mary Hanson, a Samish working to win recognition, said it "is ignorant and inflammatory" for other tribes to insinuate that the Samish may want to open the original Boldt case. If the Alzheimer's began in 1978, it could not be used against the judge's 1975 ruling, she said.
Margaret Greene, the chairwoman of the Samish Tribe, which claims about 1,000 members, also finds opponents' argument suspicious. "It's just greed that makes some of the other tribes oppose us," she said.
 
Allotting Scarce Resources
 In the quincentennial year of Columbus's arrival in the Americas -- declared the Year of the American Indian by President Bush -- Indians increasingly find themselves pitted against other Indians over a shrinking pie of Government benefits. Those resources have become so small that allowing any new tribes to be recognized would only cause further hardship for other Indians, the opponents of the Samish and Snohomish argue.
"It boils down to trying to protect tribal fisheries from groups which the Tulalips view as not genuine Indians," said James Jones, a lawyer for the Tulalips.
Nationwide, 126 tribes are actively seeking acknowledgement. In the last 12 years, eight tribes have made it through the process, which requires them to pass seven tests to show that they have had "continuous existence" as a separate band of people since the days of their first contact with whites.
 
Growing Indian Identity
 "What we're trying to do is to protect the integrity of being an Indian tribe," said Bob Walker, a spokesman for the Bureau of Indian Affairs. "It's very fashionable now to try and be an Indian."
Administration officials say one problem with tribal recognition is that there has been a huge increase in the number of Americans calling themselves Indians. The 1990 census registered 1.9 million Indians -- 37 percent more than in 1980. It is unknown whether this increase represents an actual expansion of the Indian population or a decision by more people to declare themselves Indians on census forms.
But Mr. Kidder, for one, becomes furious when he hears his claim lumped with those he considers marginal. He can point to six ancestors whose names are on the 1855 treaty that ceded most of the Puget Sound country to the Government. Ms. Greene's ancestors from the Samish tribe also signed the treaty. Yet treaty status is not enough to gain formal recognition as a tribe, the Government says.
 
Fishing Rights Denied
 Among other things, the tribes must show that have lived as a community from the days of the initial encounter with whites, that they have a written constitution, and that they can prove to the satisfaction of genealogists that tribal members are descendants of the band that signed a treaty. In the 1970's, the Government decided that the Samish and Snohomish could not pass those tests. The Government pointed out that some of their members had joined the Tulalips, an entity created as part of a 1935 act that reorganized Indian tribes.
Judge Boldt, Ms. Greene argues, would not have concurred with that finding had he not been debilitated by Alzheimer's. "I knew something was wrong with him," she said. "After the first Boldt case, he asked me if there was anything he could do for me. I said, 'I would like to fish again.' He said, 'You will.' "
The Tulalips, who fish for the Fraser River sockeye salmon that once were netted by the Samish and Snohomish, have hired a Washington, D.C., lobbyist to fight the recognition attempt of the smaller Puget Sound tribes.
It could take 10 years or more before the tribes get to the end of the recognition process. But a decade is an eye blink in the history of the Samish, whose name means "first water people," in the dialect of the coastal Salish group of native tribes.
"Our Samish people have survived," said Ms. Greene. "We have conquered the urban area. We have people working at Boeing. We have teachers. We have pilots. But we still want our Indian identity."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Bush Tries a Personal Touch In Weekend Campaign Blitz

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: HENDERSONVILLE, N.C., Sept. 5

 BODY:
President Bush embarked today on a six-state Labor Day weekend blitz of ethnic festivals, folksy fairs and private homes in an effort to lend a more personal touch to his own re-election bid and tarnish the warm and caring image that Gov. Bill Clinton has tried to create.
In Asheville, N.C., he ate lunch at the home of Roy Harris, a Democrat who had challenged the President on live television to come down and tell his children exactly what the Bush Administration had done for them. Then he attended an apple harvest celebration here to denounce Mr. Clinton's policies across the board. 
And at a German-American fair 25 miles east of Cleveland, Mr. Bush tried to appropriate a central plank of Mr. Clinton's platform of change -- health care -- by accusing the Arkansas Governor of poorly managing his state's insurance system.
"My opponent just isn't up to the mark on health care," Mr. Bush said, asserting that after 12 years under Mr. Clinton, one in four people in Arkansas does not have health insurance.
"Bill Clinton has promised he'll do for America what he's done for Arkansas," Mr. Bush told an enthusiastic crowd packed into a steaming tent at Steve Bencic's Original American Oktoberfest. "And my question is: Why would we let him?"
The speech opened a campaign swing from the early-September Oktoberfest in Painesville, Ohio, to the apple harvest celebration here, Polish-American festivals in Chicago and Hamtramck, Mich., a Sunday morning baseball game in Louisville and a Labor Day morning trek across the Mackinac Bridge that links the Upper and Lower Peninsulas of Michigan.
It produced a tour of two regions where Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton are fighting for the votes of conservative Democrats who voted for Ronald Reagan and other blue-collar Midwesterners and Southerners whose election-year concerns seem focused almost exclusively on economic issues.
Mr. Bush went out of his way to welcome the Democrats who attended his speech in Ohio this morning. But The Cleveland Plain Dealer greeted him this morning with the headline "Mired in an Economic Rut" and articles about how the recession has hurt his campaign. Another front-page article quoted blacks who castigated Mr. Bush for not inviting them to his event today.
In that atmosphere, Mr. Bush seemed bent on furthering two central aims of his campaign: to strike a connection with voters by demonstrating concern about issues like health care and to elevate voters' fears about the Democratic nominee.
On the warm-and-fuzzy front, Mr. Bush ate lunch here with the family of Mr. Harris, who was one of about 200 people who questioned Mr. Bush in a breakfast-television broadcast from the Rose Garden on July 1. Mr. Harris asked Mr. Bush if he would consider "having lunch with my 7-year-old and my 5-year-old and telling them what you've done for them."
 
Visiting With Common Folk
 Mr. Bush demurred at the time, but his political staff later saw it as a chance for Mr. Bush, who has been battling the image of an aloof and unconnected President, to be seen with just plain folks.
At the same time, Mr. Bush tried to cast doubts on Mr. Clinton's record on health insurance. "My opponent backs a plan that goes by a different name, but in the end, it takes you to the same place: national health care," Mr. Bush said. "According to some studies, nationalized health care would mean a whopping $250 billion to $500 billion a year in new taxes," Mr. Bush said.
Presidential aides said those figures were derived by taking money now spent by individuals on medical care and transferring it to the Federal budget. Mr. Clinton does not advocate nationalized medicine. He has called for companies above a certain size to provide health insurance or pay into a Federal fund that would do so.
The President accused the Governor of paying only "occasional" attention to the issue, although Mr. Bush himself has not made a substantive speech on the subject for several weeks and has yet to send to Congress the proposed tax credits that are the centerpiece of his own health care plan.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE STORM;
'HOUSE FOR RENT' BECOMES A RARITY

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Sept. 4

 BODY:
When Ofelia Centeno's house near Miami's Metrozoo was wrecked by Hurricane Andrew, her frantic search for temporary housing turned up nothing until the other day, when her brother found a small apartment that was still available in his neighborhood near the airport.
As thousands of others desperate for temporary shelter are doing, Mrs. Centeno scraped together the $820 rent plus security deposit, paying it without question so that she could relocate to the two-bedroom apartment with her parents, a sister and two children. 
Later, Mrs. Centeno found out that only two weeks earlier, rents for apartments like hers were only $600. Still, with rental housing almost impossible to find as displaced residents of southern Florida seek a temporary place to live while they patch up their battered homes, she felt a measure of luck.
"They raised the rent over $200, but what can you do," Mrs. Centeno, a 30-year-old bank employee, said as she stood in line at the Federal Emergency Management Authority relief center in Kendall. "We had to get out before we could repair our house, and while we were looking around it seemed like there were no more vacant properties in all of Dade County."
 
A 'Big Joke'
 Displaced homeowners and real estate agents throughout the area say that Hurricane Andrew overnight turned what had been a soft housing market and the slowest time of the year for many realtors into the tightest market any had seen, making life yet more difficult for victims of the storm.
"The big joke among realtors when they come across each other is: 'Hey, have you got any rentals,' " said Carol M. Klock, a realtor at Coldwell Banker in Coral Gables, one of the areas where the hunt for temporary housing has been most intense. "The inventory of rental properties was zapped up already by the middle of last week. Now we are begging home owners who have even half their house vacant to open it up for rental."
Many people in badly hit areas used the first few days after the hurricane to take stock of their situation, recoup emotionally, visit insurance offices and clear debris from their homes rather than search for new housing, several realtors said.
Now that relocation checks are being issued by many insurers, almost all the available housing has already been snatched up by those who moved fastest.
"The people you see looking are pretty much in a state of shock," Ms. Klock said. "Everyone wants a three-bedroom for six months, but what they will find will be smaller, and most of the time they will be there as long as a year while their homes are being fixed. It's hard to tell them that."
 
Few Controls on Profiteering
 Many real estate agents said they had heard stories of owners demanding heavily inflated rents after the storm, but the agents asserted that most professionals in their industry were working with the renters to keep a lid on prices.
"I had an owner of a piece of property approach me and say that another broker told him he could get $1,200 for a $900 apartment," said Carolyn Cope, a broker at Coconut Grove Realty. "The argument that some will give is that it is a short-term lease and therefore should cost more, but I wouldn't touch it. In these conditions, that just doesn't wash."
Nevertheless, stories of gouging abound among displaced homeowners.
At a U-Haul trailer rental outlet on U.S. Route 1 in South Miami, a woman flew into a tearful rage when approached by a reporter, saying that she had found a house to move into by working the telephone for days only to find that someone had topped her $1,800 rent offer by $300.
"I've been looking for eight days in this town, and that was the first place we could find," said the woman, too distraught to give her name. "I've got no roof. What am I supposed to do now?"
 
Watching the Ceiling Leak
 Because of the tightness of the housing market and the rising prices, many are deciding to stay where they are, ceiling cracks and all, while they await repairs.
"Most of the people in our building are already moving out, but we've just got nowhere to go," said Susan Oneal, a 26-year-old student at Florida International University, whose second-story South Miami apartment leaks badly in the intermittent rains that have afflicted the city in the last week. "Everywhere there are places for rent, the prices are sky high. The management has promised us that a crew is on its way to do the repairs, and as long as they fulfill that promise we figure we'd be better off staying, even through the rain."
Another person who was staying despite considerable discomfort was Rigoberto Hernandez, a 41-year-old unemployed man who said he sits in his apartment, shared with his wife and daughter, "just watching the drops fall from the ceiling when it rains."
"I don't want to lose faith, because that is all I have left, but there are no more places a guy like myself can afford to rent in Miami," said Mr. Hernandez, speaking in Spanish. "When you can find a vacancy, the landlords want a fortune, even if it's a one-room shack."

HEADLINE: Georgia Newspaper Publishes Its Last Issue

 BODY:
The Daily News of Gwinnett County, Ga., published its last issue today.
The newspaper's owner, The New York Times Company, announced last month that it was closing the suburban Atlanta paper, which it acquired five years ago.
The printing plant and other assets of The Daily News, which has a weekday circulation of 50,000 copies and a Sunday circulation of 44,000, are being acquired by Cox Enterprises Inc., publisher of The Atlanta Journal and Constitution. The paper has 290 employees, some of whom have accepted transfers to other newspapers owned by the Times Company. 
 The Gwinnett Daily News was established in 1965 from a small weekly, the Gwinnett News-Herald, which was founded in 1898. The Times Company acquired the paper in July 1987 and moved its operations to a new color printing plant in 1990. "Despite these and other investments -- and an increase in circulation by almost twofold since 1987 -- the newspaper lost money each year since its acquisition," a Times Company news release said.
The Daily News was acquired "at a time when Gwinnett County was among the fastest growing in the nation," the release continued. "Readers were enthusiastic, but advertising revenues lagged as the national and local economies were hit by recession."

HEADLINE: Bush Takes Economics Out Beyond Voodoo;
No to Consumption Tax

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Aid for the Rich, Not the Economy" (editorial, Aug. 22) calls for a bolder plan of tax reform than President Bush seems willing to propose. As an example, you suggest we scrap our income tax code -- you say it discourages saving and investment -- and adopt instead a national consumption tax, which favors them. "That would be worth fighting for," you say, because it is "pro-growth and fair." 
 Actually, it is neither. A consumption tax (which is just another name for a sales tax) differs from our income tax in one major respect. Whereas our income tax applies to income from capital investment -- interest, dividends, rents and capital gains -- as well as to salaries and wages, a consumption tax really applies to salaries and wages alone and eliminates so-called capital income from the tax base.
In effect, while personal-service income would be taxed in full under a consumption tax, investment income would be "taxed" at zero. Even with an exemption for low-wage taxpayers, the system would inevitably favor upper-income people, who receive much more of their income as investment return than any other group. Why you regard that result as "fair" I can't imagine.
But what about "growth"? As you point out, the sharp reduction in marginal tax rates that took place under Ronald Reagan in the early 1980's not only failed to increase the national saving rate, but also "led to a consumption binge" for which our economy is paying a heavy price.
Why should we suppose things would get better if we reduced the tax on investment income to zero? They wouldn't. While exempting investment income from tax would be favorable to investors, every recent empirical study on the subject suggests no positive correlation between saving and the after-tax rate of return on investment. As in the recent past, the effect could be negative.
Other factors -- chief among them the Federal budget deficit -- are simply overwhelming as far as the domestic saving rate is concerned.
Substituting a consumption tax for our present income tax might be a good idea if it were coupled with a periodic wealth tax. The system would then at least be "fair" to those whose income consists of salaries and wages, and whose "wealth" is likely to be modest.
Your criticism of the Bush tax plan is correct, but your own proposal is no better.
 
MARVIN A. CHIRELSTEIN
Prof. of Law, Columbia University
New York, Aug. 22, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: The Lilting Sound and Soul of Immigration

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR

 BODY:
The laugh of the Mighty Sparrow these days is one of deep delight.
As he sits in a T-shirt and shorts at Jenille's Jamaican restaurant in Queens, the reigning "Calypso King of the World" dips his spoon into a bowl of red pea soup and then breaks into a rich laugh, slapping out a fast calypso rhythm on his seat cushion. 
 Such exuberance is nothing new for the Sparrow, the acknowledged father of modern calypso. But this year is special. Not only has the Granadan-born singer returned from a 17-year absence to recapture his crown as the world's best calypso performer, but he is also the star of the West Indian-American Day carnival and parade tomorrow in Brooklyn, which is celebrating its 25th anniversary in the borough.
"I want to be part of this parade until I can't do it no more," said the 57-year-old Sparrow, whose given name is Slinger Francisco. "In life, there are some things you just enjoy. At the parade, everything seems to come alive."
Alive is, perhaps, an understatement.
 
Second Only to Trinidad
 For the Mighty Sparrow and for West Indians throughout the nation, Labor Day in Brooklyn has become second only to Trinidad's Carnival in importance. It is a holiday that caps a five-day festival of West Indian concerts, parades, dancing and parties.
For New York City, it has become a defining cultural exposition for an immigrant group that at nearly two million people -- counting both English-speaking West Indians and their Spanish-, French- and Creole-speaking neighbors from the Caribbean -- makes up more than half of the city's newcomers each year and almost one in three residents in Brooklyn.
And by all accounts, including that of Mr. Sparrow, the Brooklyn carnival serves as a reminder of the growing social, economic and political influence of all of the immigrants from "the islands" -- including Haiti, the Dominican Republic, Jamaica, Barbados, Guyana, Trinidad and Tobago -- who speak deeply accented English, who often wear colorful head wraps and three-fold skirts and who favor the rhythms of reggae and calypso, salsa and merengue to American rock.
Since its early incarnation in the 1940's as a modest weekend dance in Harlem (held in February just before Lent), the festival has followed New York's West Indians from Manhattan to Brooklyn. Now celebrated on Labor Day, this year's festival is expected to draw more than three million participants and spectators from around the country, including pan (steel drum) orchestras, soca (soul-calypso) ensembles and at least 50 "mas" (masquerade) bands -- groups of people in elaborate costumes who dance down Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn in sequins and feathers and huge hoop skirts.
The festival parade is scheduled for 8 A.M. to 6 P.M. tomorrow, moving west along Eastern Parkway starting at Utica Avenue. Along the route, food vendors will offer roti (dough rolled around barbecued goat, chicken or beef), beef patties, rice and peas, callaloo and crab, fish cakes, Trinidadian coconut bread, Jamaican jerk pork and chicken, and drinks like ginger beer and sassafras-like mauby.
 
Signs of Growing Power
 Like many who have participated in the carnival since the 1960's, the Sparrow has seen the carnival, as well as its music, take on cultural and political significance for the larger community.
"In the beginning, when we were up in Harlem, it wasn't really a big thing," said the Sparrow, who got his name not because of his looks (he is a sturdy six-footer) but after his first public performance in Trinidad in the 1950's, when an older calypsonian chided him for "hopping around the stage like a damned sparrow."
When the name stuck, he added the "Mighty" because he admired the bolder monikers of other calypso singers, like "Lion" and "Spoiler."
Now, besides the fast-growing corps of Caribbean-American public officials and the increasing number of immigrants who have become citizens who participate in the festivities, both Mayor David N. Dinkins and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo are planning to march tomorrow too. A portion of Eastern Parkway near the Brooklyn Museum has been temporarily renamed Caribbean Parkway -- a change that Una Clarke, a City Council member who emigrated from Jamaica as a student in 1958, is seeking to make permanent.
And in response to a request by Caribbean community leaders, Governor Cuomo is scheduled to announce the opening of a state-supported Caribbean-American Community Cultural Center on Eastern Parkway that will help community members find out about and receive state services.
 
Crown Heights Commentary
 The Sparrow, whose rhyming lyrics are laced with social commentary on issues as diverse as the coup in Trinidad ("Abu-Bakr") to the scandals of England's Royal Family ("London Bridge Is Falling Down,") has added his voice to New York's political scene as well with a song titled "Crown Heights."
The song, to be performed tonight, speaks to the racial violence that shook the Brooklyn neighborhood last August when a 7-year-old boy from Guyana was struck and killed by a car driven by a Hasidic Jew. Hours later, the police said, a rabbinical student was stabbed to death by a group of black youths, apparently in retaliation. Tensions between the two communities continue to simmer.
Preacher man, rabbi or priest
We must learn to live in peace, live in peace.
Both of us suffered loss -- history will show
From slavery to Holocaust, the whole world know.
So we have to live in peace
No reason to fight like beasts.
Live in peace
Calypso, a buoyant rhythmic music that that traces its roots back to Africa, began as a mode of communication for slaves.
"It was used to make fun of the masters, to relieve oppression and bring the news of the day," said the Sparrow. "It finally emerged as the mouthpiece for the underprivileged."
When not performing, the Sparrow, father of nine and grandfather of two, spends his time shuttling between his apartment in Jamaica, Queens, and a home in Trinidad.
Since his first successes in his 20's, the Sparrow's fame has been built more around his charismatic abilities as a performer and his prolificacy (he has recorded 58 albums, averaging about two a year) than record sales. Though he is popular in Europe and Asia and won the "Calypso King" crown now 10 times, the bulk of his records are sold in the Caribbean. In the United States, he says, he has sold a grand total of 15,000 records, tapes and compact disks.
That is in part, he said, why after 17 years of staying out of the calypso contest, he re-entered the competition earlier this year in Trinidad. Now that he recaptured the title, he says, requests for singing engagements have been plenty, filling his calendar through the middle of next year.
But true to the West Indian culture, the festival and the Sparrow's music are not intended primarily for political or even commercial purposes, but for fun.
The Sparrow tilts his head to the side, somewhat whimsically, when asked if the carnival is meant to convey a message.
"In my music I try to express the life style in our part of the world -- how easy life can be even if things aren't so bountiful," he says. "If there is a message, it is that we want to show people how to have fun."

HEADLINE: On Queens Strip, Response to Neighbors' Protests

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED

 BODY:
Concerned about notoriety and a sharp drop in business after two highly publicized killings, bar and restaurant owners on a strip studded with nightspots in Queens have organized to respond to longstanding community protests about rowdiness and violence in the area.
About 30 businesses on Bell Boulevard in Bayside, the site of the recent slaying of an off-duty Housing Authority police officer and another man, have formed a coalition to change the atmosphere that many in the neighborhood say led to the kinds of brawls that prompted the slayings. 
 Before the killings, local civic leaders and residents held that the business owners were often indifferent to their longstanding complaints about drug use, assaults, noisy congestion and vandalism on a milelong strip of Bell Boulevard that, in recent years, has become increasingly popular with young crowds.
The noisy revelry on the street's growing number of bars and eating places contrasts sharply with the rest of quiet, middle-class Bayside.
The killings and the complaints about the strip "precipitated the coalition to be formed," the new group's coordinator, Thomas A. Croce, said on Friday. He said the coalition was formed late last month. The killings occurred early on July 18.
 
Resolving Complaints
 "There's been about a 40 percent falling-off of business since the shooting," he said of the bars and restaurants on the strip, between Northern Boulevard and 35th Avenue.
The men who were slain were the off-duty Housing Authority police officer, Paul Heidelberger, and John Camarda. A third man, Steven Moran, was wounded. An employee at one of the bars on the strip, Patrick Bannon, has been charged with murder and other crimes in the case.
Mr. Croce, a lawyer and Bayside resident, did not say why he thought the drop in business followed the killings, but others have attributed it to negative publicity combined with more intensive police activity that has included closer surveillance of the bars and orders that people congregating on the sidewalks disperse.
Mr. Croce said his coalition would work to "restore, if not enhance, Bell Boulevard's fine reputation in leisure-time activities."
He said one of the group's chief tasks would be to resolve complaints about problems around the nightspots like noise and litter. The group will also seek better cooperation with the police.
The coalition "would never be if not for the shooting," said Thomas Virgilio, president of the Bayside Chamber of Commerce. He said that in the past it was "very tough" to get the bar and restaurant owners "in the same room and to agree on anything because they're all competitors."
"Now they realize what a bad rap they can get if they don't make nice-nice to the community," he said.
