HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN -- Issues: Free Trade;
Clinton Is Pressed to Take Stand on Pact

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 6

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton, who is fond of seeking compromise where it did not previously exist, may yet be forced into a corner as President Bush works to push him toward taking a firm stand on the North American Free Trade Agreement that was announced last month.
It is a delicate problem for Mr. Clinton that could expose one of his weakest traits: his penchant for trying to have it both ways. 
 At various points in the campaign, Mr. Clinton has chosen obfuscation when a direct answer held some risk. The most noteworthy instances were his explanations of his military deferments during the Vietnam War and his explanation of whether he had smoked marijuana.
The issue of free trade poses such a risk. Mr. Clinton takes a chance on alienating an important group of supporters on one side, while giving the Bush-Quayle forces ammunition on the other side to attack him for caving in to labor interests.
 
Clinton Supports Concept
 The trade agreement, if ratified by Congress, would make Canada, the United States and Mexico the world's largest trading bloc. Representatives of organized labor have denounced the pact outright, saying it would cost thousands of jobs. But Republicans and business leaders have argued that a trade agreement would increase exports and strengthen the economy.
Mr. Clinton has said he supports the concept of encouraging free trade to help American exports, but he has also said he would support only an agreement that called for strict protections for labor standards and the environment.
"I very much want to be for a trade agreement," Mr. Clinton said tonight in an interview on NBC. "I hope I can be for this one but you've got to give me a chance to read it and analyze it."
Last week Mr. Clinton told the A.F.L.-C.I.O.: "With Europe becoming more integrated, and maybe more closed, with Asia becoming more integrated, and maybe more closed, we have to have some markets. And that's why I hope we can get the right kind of agreement with Mexico."
But Mr. Clinton has not taken a stand on what standards the agreement should meet. His advisers say they will not formulate details until they have a chance to scrutinize the complicated agreement, which is scheduled to be presented to Congress on Tuesday.
Mr. Bush said gleefully last week that Mr. Clinton was going to have "straddle sores" before it was all over. The President has made the trade agreement a central feature of his campaign, and his aides plan to continue criticizing Mr. Clinton on what they describe as his efforts to "backpedal" from supporting the plan.
 
'Trying to Please All Parties'
 "He is trying to please all parties," said Torie Clarke, a spokeswoman for the Bush campaign. "That is not leadership."
Mr. Clinton's aides and supporters, naturally, disagree.
"He has been forthright in saying the free trade agreement done right can be a good thing," said Gene B. Sperling, Mr. Clinton's economics adviser. "He rejected the philosophical argument that a free trade agreement is inherently bad."
So far, the Arkansas Governor has succeeded in deflecting questions on the agreement, saying he needed to study the final document, which is enormous, complex and not yet available to the public. Mr. Sperling says, "It's just not intelligent to have a position yet."
Part of the reason is that union leaders see little alternative to backing the Democrat this year. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. gave Mr. Clinton a pre-Labor Day endorsement last week.
 
Waiting to See Agreement
 Mr. Sperling said the only groups pressing the Clinton campaign to be more specific on the trade agreement were the Republicans and trade lobbyists in Washington.
"It would warm my heart if I got one phone call for Head Start for every 50 phone calls we get on trade issues," Mr. Sperling said.
Tom Donahue, the secretary-treasurer of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said he could accept Mr. Clinton's position for now.
"Our position has been clear," Mr. Donahue said. "His has been, too. He has said we ought to see the agreement, which I think is eminently responsible."
Mr. Donahue conceded that Mr. Clinton had to attend to political positioning in the interest of winning more votes than just those of organized labor.
"He is a candidate for President of the United States," he said. "I'm not. I can pop off about this."
Many labor unions were slow to support Mr. Clinton during the primary campaign, citing his spotty labor record in Arkansas. But after seeing the Democratic candidates many labor leaders preferred fall by the wayside -- first Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa and then former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California -- they have joined the Clinton fold.
 
Labor's Backing of Clinton
 William H. Bywater, the president of the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, said he was dead set against what he called "this crazy free trade agreement" and has told Mr. Clinton about his objections.
"I'd like to hear Clinton come out and say, 'As far as I'm concerned, the wage rates of workers in Mexico are far too low, and if you want to start raising the standard of living in Mexico, then bring them up to the minimum in the United States -- $4.25 an hour,' " he said. "That's what I think he should do."
Backing Mr. Clinton at this juncture has become the most pragmatic of decisions for many labor leaders. Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., has said Mr. Clinton need not take a position on the trade issue until after the election. The trade issue could prove crucial in several states Mr. Clinton is counting on to win, including Michigan and Illinois.
But it remains unclear whether these leaders speak for their rank-and-file members, many of whom are suffering from job losses brought on by the closing or relocation of manufacturing plants.
Danny Hoffman, the former auto worker who is now staff coordinator of the University of Michigan's Labors Studies Center, said Mr. Clinton's position has been "vague."
"I don't fault Clinton for saying he is in favor of trade," Mr. Hoffman said. "But what I want to find out is what kind of restrictions are you willing to put on Mexico?"
He said the auto workers he had talked to about the election were leaning toward Mr. Clinton.
"They're saying anything's better than Bush," Mr. Hoffman said. "But it's not a real clear choice right now."

HEADLINE: Gains Are Reported in Talks on Haiti

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6

 BODY:
Negotiators for Haiti's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, and the Government of army officers who overthrew him tentatively agreed last week in their first meeting here to send an international peacekeeping mission to Haiti, a representative of Father Aristide said.
Father Aristide's backers and diplomats from the region say the Bush Administration's support is vital to the success of the proposal to deploy unarmed neutral observers to Haiti's nine administrative regions to reduce the level of political violence and prepare the way for the restoration of an elected government. 
 The Administration has recently seemed lukewarm about Father Aristide, a charismatic priest whose government was overthrown on Sept. 30, 1991, nine months after an election monitored by American and international observers.
 
Military Response Sought
 The exiled President's representative at the talks, the Rev. Antoine Adrien, said in an interview on Saturday that the Haitian military has been asked by the Organization of American States to respond by Tuesday to the proposal.
Father Adrien said that the Secretary General of the Organization of American States, Joao Clemente Baena Soares, who mediated in the talks, was ready to dispatch the first 18 "democracy monitors" as early as Wednesday. Four officials of the organization are already in Port-au-Prince, the Haitian capital, to set up the operation.
The Haitian military's representative at the meeting, Foreign Minister Francois Benoit, has not discussed publicly what went on in the talks, which ended late Friday night. Officials at the O.A.S. would say only that the talks had been "useful" and had opened a new channel of communication to the military leadership.
Mr. Benoit and Haiti's current Prime Minister, Marc Bazin, can operate only with the sufferance of the military, which is suspicious of any international intervention and fearful that the return of Father Aristide could make officers vulnerable to criminal trials.
The military has nullified previous agreements reached under O.A.S. auspices.
In the interview, Father Adrien, who heads a 10-member commission appointed in July by the exiled President and based in Port-au-Prince, called on the Bush Administration to lend its active support to the new initiative by putting pressure on the military to accept O.A.S. monitors.
He said Washington appeared to view the military leader of Haiti, Gen. Raoul Cedras, with the same tolerance it accorded the former Nicargauan strongman, Antonio Somoza Debayle.
"We have been making concession after concession, but nothing is asked from the people on the other side of the table," he said, reflecting the opinion of many of Father Aristide's supporters that a leader who won two-thirds of the popular vote in a reasonably free and fair election should expect more help from the Bush Administration.
"The other side has made no concessions at all," Father Adrien said. "They preside over this incredible violence and yet nothing is asked of them. There is no accountability for what they are doing."
Recent reports by the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, Amnesty International and other groups have painted a bleak picture of Haiti. They say that the level and style of violence recalls the worst days of the Tontons Macoutes, the death squads of the Duvalier family.
Father Adrien, who has set up an office in the Haitian capital to represent Father Aristide, said repression by the military Government has grown more intense in the last three months. He attributes this to discontent among the people over the political stalemate and the economic embargo, however porous, which has hurt many Haitians.
"Repression is the sign there is resistance to the military," Father Adrien said, speaking by telephone from Brooklyn before his return to Haiti today. "It goes up because resistance is up."
The exiled President's representative said that the talks this week were not negotiations about Father Aristide's returning to Haiti.
"We were talking about stopping the violence," he said. "Only that."
The introduction of rights monitors, similar to teams operating in Nicaragua and Suriname, has been discussed for nearly 10 months. Volunteers from the United States and Canada who speak French or Creole have been asking to join, O.A.S. officials said.
The Aristide camp wanted to send 18 monitors to each of Haiti's administrative regions, called departments. Father Adrien said that Mr. Baena Soares told him and Mr. Benoit that only 22 monitors were available for the whole country.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN -- Issues: Taxes;
Clinton Painted as Taxer but Isn't Tarred

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6

 BODY:
Last month, President Bush's political strategists rolled out a political weapon so fearsome that it had destroyed three Democratic Presidential candidates in 12 years, and pointed it squarely at Gov. Bill Clinton.
On Aug. 20, on network television, Mr. Bush himself squeezed the trigger. 
 "Here's the question for the American people," he said in his acceptance speech at the Republican National Convention. "Who do you trust in this election? The candidate who's raised taxes one time and regrets it? Or the other candidate, who raised taxes and fees 128 times and enjoyed it every time?"
Thus did Mr. Bush fire off the accusation that a President Clinton would siphon voters' paychecks to feed a vast and indolent bureaucracy. It was the same charge that wounded the Presidential hopes of Democrats in 1980, 1984 and 1988, only more deadly: Mr. Clinton had already said he would impose $148 billion in new or higher taxes during his first term in office.
 
Charges of Distortion
 Yet two weeks later, the Democratic nominee appears not only to have dodged Mr. Bush's attack but even to have turned it against him. A counterattack accusing the President of distorting Mr. Clinton's record on taxes has been echoed by political columnists and amplified by approving editorials in major newspapers, including The New York Times and The Washington Post. The Bush campaign's own accusations of distortion, some verifiable, have passed mostly unnoticed.
Perhaps most ominous for the White House, the broader message about Mr. Clinton's tax policies has failed -- so far, at least -- to resound through the electorate as in past Republican campaigns. Polls show that, even coupled with a renewed pledge to cut taxes in a second term, Mr. Bush's attack seems to have barely dented Mr. Clinton's standing on the issue.
"We're putting out information that's documented and footnoted," one Bush aide said last week, "and Clinton's out there throwing spitballs at us with nothing to back it up. And who do you think is getting the play?"
In any case, the Republican attack's apparent inability to damage Mr. Clinton as effectively as it did Michael S. Dukakis, Walter F. Mondale and Jimmy Carter reflects a new reality..
Mr. Bush all but repudiated his low-tax image in 1990, when he broke his "no new taxes" pledge and assented to an increase in the personal income tax rate. Mr. Clinton and the Democrats, meanwhile, have hit on the notion of tax fairness (translation: soak the rich) as a way to get around public resentment of taxes.
Bush aides say they have no intention of slackening their assault, noting that they started late and that the two months left until the election can be a political eon.
But Mr. Clinton has dominated the debate so far with his swift response to Mr. Bush's declaration that the Arkansas Governor approved 128 tax increases during his 11 years in office.
Both sides accuse the other of distorting the facts, and both appear to have a point.
The Clinton forces correctly charge Mr. Bush with inflating the grand total of tax and fee increases by including some mundane state actions -- like a longer dog-racing season that raised the state's share of gambling revenue.
 
Add Up the Numbers
 The Clinton staff has issued a list that shows 127 tax and fee increases during the Governor's tenure. The Clinton list, compiled by the Arkansas Department of Finance and Administration, says there have been 34 tax increases and 93 fee increases during Mr. Clinton's 12 years in office. Fees include things like court costs for convicts, medical licenses, driver examinations, drunken-driving fines, birth certificates and water-safety studies.
The Clinton list also shows 73 instances in which taxes have been cut while Mr. Clinton has been Governor.
The Bush camp, for its part, correctly accuses Mr. Clinton of misrepresenting the source of Mr. Bush's data by contending that they were invented. In fact, the figure was drawn from the Democratic-controlled Arkansas Legislature's annual Tax Handbook, which records actions that raise or lower state revenues.
Some aides on both sides say privately that the true number of revenue-raisers is academic because the argument is meant to highlight the candidates' different approaches.
 
Backed Several Increases
 As Governor, Mr. Clinton supported and proposed several tax increases, including sales taxes on food and fuel that hit the poor proportionately harder than the wealthy. And the 1991 Legislature enacted more than 50 tax and fee increases that were expected to add more than $300 million a year to the state's budget, which this year is $1.9 billion.
But most neutral experts view his record as moderate, and the tax burden on the average Arkansan, measured as a share of total income, changed little during his tenure.
Mr. Bush's strategists, while insisting that their numbers on Clinton-engineered tax and fee increases are technically accurate, acknowledge that their aim was to grab attention.
"We firmly believe that increasing taxes costs jobs," Jim Cicconi, a senior issues adviser to the Bush campaign, said in an interview. "I don't care whether you raise them on small business, foreign investment or ordinary people. And he's raising them by the bucketload."
 
The Fundamental Difference?
 Mr. Clinton's advisers also say the broader issue is the economy, but they agree on nothing else. "The real issue here is, is there something systemically wrong with the economy -- something fundamental?" said Robert Shapiro, a Washington economist and senior Clinton adviser. "Bush believes the economy is fundamentally sound, and that all we need to do is make marginal changes like adjusting the capital gains rate for inflation. Our analysis is no -- the economy has fundamental problems, and we need an entirely new strategy."
In simple terms, Mr. Bush contends, as did Ronald Reagan, that lower taxes and less spending will free money for investment, create jobs and produce revenues to rebuild the country and lower the Federal deficit.
Mr. Clinton, not unlike his Democratic predecessors, contends that higher taxes on the wealthy and big business will create money to improve schools, rebuild public works and put in place other building blocks for growth.
If history counts, Mr. Bush's argument should carry the day. In 1988, the Republican label "Taxachusetts" demolished Governor Dukakis's image and helped carry Mr. Bush to his first term. In 1984, Mr. Mondale's candidacy withered after he declared that either he or Ronald Reagan would raise taxes as President, but that only Mr. Mondale had the courage to say so in advance. Part of what washed Mr. Carter out of office in 1980 was a tide of Republican votes against "tax-and-spend" Democrats.
 
Who Is More Likely?
 But the Republican argument, so potent for more than a decade, seems not to be persuading voters to shift their allegiances. A poll by Gallup for Cable News Network and USA Today of 1,001 registered voters in mid-August, before Mr. Bush's convention speech, rated Mr. Clinton by a margin of 43 to 39 percent as "more likely to raise taxes." The same question, asked last week of 1,007 voters, placed the margin at 49 to 36 percent -- a nine percentage point shift. The margin of sampling error in both surveys was three points.
But despite what the Republicans say about him and taxes, Mr. Clinton is still ahead in voter surveys, although his lead has narrowed since the Republican convention.
Almost everyone who follows politics has a theory about why this is happening, but in the end, it comes down to Mr. Bush's performance.
The President not only broke his no-new-taxes pledge, he has not consistently carried out his promise of less government. Since 1989, spending for agriculture, for example, has risen by 12.7 percent after inflation, and spending on interior programs, like parks, has gone up 27.3 percent. Housing and independent agency budgets have jumped 36 percent, and transportation spending by 32.4 percent.
"Bush is a guy who lives in a fiscal glass house and is running around with a slingshot shouting, 'Look at me!' " said Kevin Phillips, a conservative analyst. "After the record of this Administration, they can't simply turn around and do the old tax-and-spend thing when the Democrats can simply point to their record."
Other experts cite the state of the economy, which they say has eroded the Republican argument that what America needs is more Reagan-style economics. "The magic of no tax increases and lots of tax cuts, damn the torpedoes, isn't working this time around," said Charles Schultze, once President Carter's economic adviser.
Mr. Clinton's economic adviser, Mr. Shapiro, says he is pleased with how the public has reacted, or not reacted, to Mr. Bush's attacks on Mr. Clinton. "What we're seeing in the tepid response to the Republican attack is that the attack was so overdrawn that it's lost its credibility, and that the Bush Administration itself is not credible on the tax issue. And finally, the President is not credible with respect to what would be required to restore economic growth."

HEADLINE: Cuba Cancels Atom Plant, Blaming Costs and Russians

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Sept. 6

 BODY:
Disclosing a major setback to his country's fast-shrinking economy, President Fidel Castro announced late Saturday that work on Cuba's largest industrial project, a Soviet-designed nuclear power plant intended to relieve the island's crushing energy shortage, had been halted indefinitely by rising costs.
Although the 1,600-megawatt Cuban reactor complex was of more modern design than the failed Soviet reactor at Chernobyl, its construction at Juragua, near the southern port city of Cienfuegos, had long been a source of tension between Havana and Washington. Some American experts expressed concern that any accident could threaten Florida. The Cuban Government repeatedly dismissed such concerns. 
 Delivering an annual speech commemorating the start of the Cuban revolution, Mr. Castro instead described the suspended project as a casualty of the demise of the former Soviet bloc.
He bitterly attributed the suspension to Russia's insistence that the plant's skyrocketing costs be paid in hard currency, rather than through the subsidized barter arrangements of the past. Mr. Castro said the Russian terms were "totally impossible."
 
$1.1 Billion Cost Already
 With a tone of distress repeatedly creeping into his voice, he said that although the Juragua plant was 70 percent completed, "we don't have any other alternative but to halt construction." The project, which was begun in 1980, has already cost Cuba $1.1 billion.
Mr. Castro's speech, normally delivered on July 26, was delayed by a rare trip to Europe, where he attended an international conference and the opening of the Olympic Games in Spain.
For many Cubans, the nuclear plant was one of the few bright spots on an increasingly bleak economic horizon. In the last two years, as the withdrawal of aid from the former Soviet bloc has hit the economy, vehicles have all but disappeared from roads for lack of fuel, consumer goods and basic foods have become increasingly scarce and, most recently, electricity has been tightly rationed.
"This is a big blow, no question," said Wayne Smith, a former United States diplomat in Havana who runs the Cuban studies program at Johns Hopkins University. "This would have been a great help to their economy if they could have gotten the reactor going. For the people, it had become a symbol of Cuba's entry into the modern era."
In his speech, monitored in Miami, Mr. Castro described other ways the Cuban economy had been damaged by the end of Communist aid, saying that the island's imports had fallen 70 percent and that key industries like sugar and nickel were hurt by falling prices and reduced investment.
In the lone positive note, he said the country's sugar harvest had totaled seven million tons this year, well below record levels but far more than many had predicted.
Even this good news was blunted, however, by the fact that the harvest had to be extended by two months to compensate for the use of manual labor where machines once worked, and by an end to Soviet subsidies, meaning that the country will earn far less from its crop than in the past.
 
Senior Officials Dismissed
 As Cuba's economy has come increasingly unraveled in recent months, Mr. Castro, vowing to defend Communism to the death, has begun dismissing senior officials, fueling speculation that major rifts in the leadership are emerging between reform-oriented officials and hard-liners.
In June, Mr. Castro dismissed his son, Fidel Castro Diaz-Balart, as head of the nuclear energy program, citing "inefficiency." That was followed by the removal of Julio A. Garcia Olveras, the head of Cuba's Chamber of Commerce, who had enthusiastically recruited foreign investors for the country's limited program of economic liberalization.
There have also been persistent rumors of a fall from favor by two of Mr. Castro's senior lieutenants -- Carlos Aldana, the Communist Party's chief of ideology, who has dropped out of sight in recent weeks, and Roberto Robaina, leader of Cuba's Union of Young Communists.
"The basic economic assumptions have been so challenged that there is a real question of being able to hold things together politically," said Andrew Zimbalist, an expert on the Cuban economy at Smith College in Massachusetts.
"What you may have in the case of Aldana and with others is people who think the situation has to change more quickly, and Fidel is worried that that kind of change could threaten him."
In his speech, Mr. Castro denied that there were divisions in the leadership, but added: "There are those who become discouraged, who become cowardly. There are those who are traitors, those who desert. This happens in all eras, in all revolutions."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Fidel Castro announcing that Cuba's nuclear power plant project has been halted indefinitely. On Saturday night he made his annual speech commemorating the start of the Cuban revolution. (Canadian Press)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: In Prime Time;
Bush and Clinton Go After Each Other on NBC

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Sept. 6

 BODY:
In what amounted to a televised kickoff for the fall campaign, President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton used a pair of back-to-back live interviews on NBC to elaborate their core ideological differences, attack each other in relatively genteel terms and defend their records.
To what seemed the clear annoyance of both men, the center section of each interview with Tom Brokaw focused on issues of personal credibility that each man intensely wishes would be gone. 
 For Mr. Clinton, the subject was his conflicting explanations of his behavior in avoiding the draft during the Vietnam War. For Mr. Bush, it was the long-lingering, and recently resurrected, question of whether as Vice President he knew more than he has acknowledged about the Iran-contra affair in 1986.
 
'Just a Late Smokescreen'
 Mr. Bush handled the question about the Iran-contra case fairly smoothly, airily dismissing the notion that he had not told the truth about his activities.
"That's been looked into by millions of dollars' worth of investigations under this Walsh hearing," he said, referring to Lawrence E. Walsh, the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra case. "If I had done anything wrong, Tom, they'd have been all over me like you can possibly imagine. This seems to me to be just a late smokescreen out of that dead old saw out there."
Mr. Clinton, on the other hand, seemed angered by a question by Mr. Brokaw about why he told reporters last week that he knew nothing about a news article in The Los Angeles Times describing efforts by his uncle, Raymond Clinton, in 1968 to secure a slot in the Naval Reserve for him, when, in fact, he had been told in March of his uncle's efforts.
 
New Spending Without Taxes
 "I didn't say that came as a surprise to me last week; it came as a total surprise to me in March," Mr. Clinton began, in a statement that seemed both somewhat confused and at times at variance with the facts. "The press described The Los Angeles Times story to me in a totally different way. They never mentioned this issue."
He added: "The truth is I have told the same story all along. Maybe I have not handled it as well as I should have.
Mr. Clinton was much more self-assured when he told Mr. Brokaw that it would be possible, in a Clinton Administration, to reduce the Federal deficit and start a new array of spending programs without raising taxes.
"That is what I propose to do," he insisted. "That is what I believe will happen." He conceded that he did not know for sure if he was right, but he said: "Do I believe it? You bet I do -- because in my state that's what we have done."
In his interview Mr. Bush sought to soothe the anxiety of Americans over the nation's economic problems.
"I think things are getting better," he said. "And I'll tell you one thing: We are poised for a strong recovery. Interest rates are down. Inflation is down."
The President added: "We have had five consecutive quarters of growth; anemic though they may have been, they've been growing. I'm not prepared to say I think things are going to get dramatically worse at all."
Earlier today the President tossed the first ball at a baseball game in Louisville, Ky., for the benefit of the victims of Hurricane Andrew, attended a Polish-American festival in Chicago and finished his campaign day with the television interview from Sault Ste. Marie, Mich.

LENGTH: 1779 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
If Voters Won't Love Bush, He Hopes They Fear Clinton

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6

 BODY:
After all the oddities and subplots of the 1992 campaign, from the boomlet for Ross Perot to the challenges of Patrick J. Buchanan and Edmund G. Brown Jr., from the street theater of the New York primary to the morality plays of the Houston convention, the final 57 days will center on a few political basics.
Can President Bush, presiding over a sluggish economy and a nation that two-thirds of Americans say is "off on the wrong track," persuade a majority of the voters that things would be worse under Gov. Bill Clinton? 
 Some experts believe it is already too late for Mr. Bush to do much to change his own image or the perception of the nation's economy under his stewardship; one of the constants of this quirky year has been the voters' disenchantment with the Bush Presidency, with his approval rating in the New York Times/CBS News Poll hovering at 40 percent or less for seven consecutive months.
 
Simple Strategy for Bush
 So while there are a number of nuances to consider, outlined point by point below, the fundamental strategic imperative for Mr. Bush is as starkly simple as it was for Jimmy Carter in 1980: A struggling incumbent in tough times must cast his challenger as an unacceptable alternative.
If the voters cannot learn to love their President, in other words, they must be taught to fear his opponent. Or, as Mr. Bush has begun to put it, "Who do you trust?"
Mr. Clinton enters this final stage of the campaign with what must be, for him, a heady sense that the political winds are finally at his back. He is ahead in the national polls, and the electoral map, at the moment, looks more auspicious for the Democrats than at any time since Jimmy Carter's 1976 campaign, which also put the Republicans on the defensive throughout much of the Sun Belt.
But Mr. Clinton could lose these winds in the next two months. He must become more than the repository of anger and discontent with Mr. Bush and 12 years of Republican rule. He must fend off all the doubts about his character and persuade the voters that there are no further surprises in this Governor from Arkansas who has only recently arrived on the national stage. And he must defend his political philosophy and his readiness to be President against the questions that will be stoked by the Bush forces.
It was not so very long ago, after all, that Mr. Clinton's public image was heavily skewed toward the "slick Willie" that his critics portray, the untrustworthy pol always pushing the envelope of truth, whether in explaining his draft history, detailing his record in Arkansas or discussing his experience with marijuana.
This is the struggle of the next 57 days. Here is a guide, with mileposts, omens and numbers to watch.
 
The Debates
 The debates are the great formal events of a general-election campaign, and they take on added importance in a race like this. For a challenger like Mr. Clinton, simply taking the stage with a President confers stature, many analysts believe. For a struggling incumbent like Mr. Bush, the debates offer an opportunity to change the chemistry of the race and force a national audience to reassess and think anew.
The Commission on Presidential Debates has proposed three such sessions, with the first on Sept. 22 in East Lansing, Mich. But the Bush campaign served notice last week that the commission's proposal was unacceptable.
While Republicans are tight-lipped over exactly what they object to, some form of negotiation over debates is expected after Labor Day, with James A. Baker 3d, the new White House chief of staff, expected to play a prominent role.
"I dealt with him in '76 and '80," said Jody Powell, the former press secretary for Mr. Carter. "He's very good, very smooth, a real gentleman. And if you don't watch out, you'll find yourself wanting to work something out just to be gentlemanly about it."
Mr. Clinton, who has already begun his preparation for the debates, will try to use them to raise what aides call his "comfort factor" with the voters, and, obviously enough, to try to look like a President. In 1980, the one debate between Ronald Reagan and Mr. Carter was considered crucial in allaying fears about the former Governor of California, thus hastening the big swing toward Mr. Reagan in the final days.
"The only thing he had to prove to people was that they did not have to be scared if he had his finger on the button," said Eddie Mahe, who was an adviser to the Reagan campaign. "When he proved that, it was over."
For Mr. Bush, the debates are a chance to demonstrate his mastery of foreign policy, his accumulated experience on the national scene, even, perhaps, to highlight his war record. If Republicans have their way, the Governor from Arkansas will take the Presidential stature test before a national audience -- and flunk it.
 
The Map
 By mid-September, both campaigns will have a full round of post-Labor Day polling data and will begin to make some serious decisions on the map: Which states are winnable, which are safe and which should be written off.
At the moment, the all-Southern Democratic ticket is creating an unusually competitive map. Ordinarily, the South is a Republican stronghold in Presidential elections, but Mr. Bush is having to pay close attention to Texas and, particularly after the hurricane, even to Florida.
With 57 of the required 270 electoral votes, those two states are essential to any Republican victory, particularly since California, with a whopping 54 electoral votes, seems to be leaning so heavily to the Democrats.
If the Bush campaign locks up its Southern base over the next few weeks, while the Democrats cement their hold on the Northeast and the West Coast, the race will be fully joined in the big states of the industrial Midwest. While these states are expected to be exceedingly competitive, a Chicago Tribune Poll showed last week that Mr. Clinton currently has a formidable lead in Illinois, 51 percent to 32 percent.
This region is always susceptible to a bread-and-butter appeal: Mr. Clinton will be saying the country cannot afford another four years of Republican economics, while Mr. Bush will assert that the taxpayers are about to fall victim to another taxer-and-spender, and one with with environmental-extremist tendencies at that.
 
The Economy
 In the midst of this contest, in the first week of October, the Federal Government will issue the final unemployment statistics before the election.
These numbers can have an enormous impact on elections, as the Republicans discovered in 1982, when the unemployment rate broke into the double digits in October and they lost 26 seats in the House the next month.
Mr. Bush badly needs to inspire some hope in the voters about their economic future under a second Bush Administration. But the unemployment statistics issued Friday showed how difficult that task could be.
The latest numbers, showing that factory employment had dropped to its lowest level since April 1983, also prompted another round of worries among financial analysts that the economy is not recovering. There will be new statistics almost every week, from housing starts to unemployment claims, that will feed this debate. It will be capped a week before Election Day with the Gross Domestic Product numbers for the third quarter.
As Mr. Baker and his team try to improve the image of the Bush domestic record, they will have to cope with all these numbers.
 
October Surprises
 Every campaign pitting a challenger against an incumbent features feverish speculation about an "October surprise," some foreign policy coup or other development to make the President look larger than life. But as Jody Powell puts it, such "surprises" may be easier to speculate about than to produce.
"It's got to survive the smell test," he says, noting that policy moves are heavily scrutinized for political motivations.
What is clear, however, is that October is the month when campaigns go for broke. It is so close to the election that gaffes, scandals or damaging disclosures can be hard to recover from.
Candidates who have burst into the national consciousness quickly, like Jimmy Carter or Bill Clinton, are particularly vulnerable to last-minute controversies prompting last-minute doubts.
Mr. Clinton, in the New Hampshire primary, showed his ability to survive such a test, and while there is no current sign of another shoe dropping, there is much residual nervousness about it in political circles.
Moreover, if this campaign is like any other, Mr. Clinton will almost certainly face some kind of unpredictable crisis or test, whether it be a verbal gaffe or an associate's blunder, that will force voters to take his measure once again.
"In some respects, that could be the biggest event in the whole fall campaign," argues Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic poll taker, "because if he passes it, he's very likely to be President."
Republicans disagree with that optimistic assessment of Mr. Clinton's chances, but top strategists in the Bush campaign have believed all along that this election will, in the final days, come down to trust and leadership traits.
Not surprisingly, Mr. Clinton has recently tried to challenge the trustworthiness of the Republicans, largely over their economic promises.
 
The Numbers to Watch
 This year has been notable for wild swings in the polls, and the surveys of the past few weeks suggest that the trend is continuing. Still, there are a few numbers to watch that may be more telling than the shifting ranking in the trial heat.
One of the most important is Mr. Clinton's personal-image rating. Just three months ago, after the ferocious primary season, just 16 percent of the registered voters viewed Mr. Clinton favorably, while 40 percent viewed him unfavorably, The New York Times/CBS News Poll found. The most recent Times/CBS Poll showed a 36 percent favorable rating, to 28 percent unfavorable.
"Bush can't win without that number moving," said Mr. Mahe, the veteran Republican strategist. "If the Clinton unfavorable doesn't move, then the result in the final analysis can't be a great deal different than it is now."
Republicans take heart from the British Conservatives' against-all-predictions victory in the final days of the elections last spring. Democrats remember how Ronald Reagan finally allayed the doubts in 1980.
"The only thing that would surprise me in this race is if I wasn't surprised," said James Carville, a top strategist for Mr. Clinton. "If I'm talking to you the day before the election and I say, 'Well, things pretty much played out the way I expected,' that would surprise me."

HEADLINE: Stocks Higher in Tokyo

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Japanese stocks were higher today. At about an hour before the close of trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up about 140 points. Brokers said buying was supported by the belief that Japan's central bank would cut its discount rate. A lowering of the key lending rate was made more possible by the Federal Reserve's move in the United States last week to reduce the Federal funds rate, they said. On Friday, the Nikkei gained 168.81 points, to 18,555.30.

HEADLINE: With G.O.P. Faltering, Senator Is on His Own

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6

 BODY:
John Seymour faces two unanticipated obstacles in seeking election to the United States Senate seat that Gov. Pete Wilson appointed him to 19 months ago: The collapse of the Republican Presidential campaign in California and the plunge in popularity of his mentor the Governor.
Mr. Seymour insists that coattails mean nothing in this quirky state of ticket-splitters and that Mr. Wilson's nose-dive is temporary and of no consequence. But this relentless good cheer is drowned out by a chorus of prophets who say that a bland former State Senator plucked from obscurity needs all the high-powered help he can get. 
 "It looked like Seymour would be taken in hand and led to victory by Wilson and Bush," said Mervin Field, director of the statewide Field Poll, which recently found President Bush trailing Bill Clinton by a staggering 34 points here, Mr. Wilson with the lowest approval ratings of any Governor in the state's history and Mr. Seymour an 18-point underdog in his Senate race against Dianne Feinstein. "Now that Wilson and Bush don't have any credibility, it looks like Seymour's got to be on his own."
While Mr. Seymour says that "neither George Bush nor Pete Wilson will have a tremendous impact one way or another on my campaign," he seems to be trying to separate himself from both. That is an awkward task, which has left Mr. Seymour looking bold one minute and browbeaten the next.
A case in point was the Republican convention, where the party platform included a vehement anti-abortion plank. This was an opportunity for Mr. Seymour, a 1990 convert to abortion rights, to distinguish himself from the party hierarchy, reassure Republican women considering defection to Ms. Feinstein and pick up news media attention.
The results were mixed.
Mr. Seymour's crusade for a floor fight fizzled after the Governor, who generally favors abortion rights, begged the delegation to stand united with the President. And Mr. Seymour's losing battle antangonized many right wing Republicans, who are now threatening to stay home on Election Day.
The Senator's hand was slapped for his convention speech, in which he said that he was "not entirely happy" with the platform. The speech was delivered in a nearly empty hall, because Mr. Seymour was assigned an unfavorable morning time slot. And the party chairman blue-penciled another part of his speech, eliminating a reference to Barbara Bush, rather than her husband, as the conscience of the party.
 
'They Swatted Him Away'
 "They swatted him away like a little fly, they edited his copy and he had a nowhere role in the convention," said Kam Kuwata, campaign manager for Ms. Feinstein, the former Mayor of San Francisco who narrowly lost the 1990 race for governor.
But Mr. Seymour found rewards as well as punishments at the convention. The Senator, who had earlier but without notice challenged the President on his slow response to the sagging economy, had his first real moment in the sun, appearing on the "Today" show and the "MacNeil-Lehrer News Hour." And Mr. Seymour won the thanks of many Republican women.
Mr. Seymour's record as a Senator includes at least two votes involving issues that Ms. Feinstein promises to exploit: a "yes" vote on the confirmation of Judge Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court and a "no" vote on a family-leave bill.
In his Senate tenure, Mr. Seymour says, his proudest moment was his authorship of a bill, now in conference committee, that would protect the interests of agriculture while modifying the way water is allocated here. His bill won Senate approval over a competing one by Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, which was less favorable to farmers but preferred by environmentalists. In this situation, as in his pleas for revision of the Endangered Species Act, Mr. Seymour argues that wildlife cannot be protected at the expense of jobs in these recessionry times.
The fortunes of the President and the party could affect Mr. Seymour in more subtle ways than the coattail effect, which was weak here even during the Reagan landslides.
Marty Wilson, the state chairman of the Bush-Quayle campaign, said all Republican candidates could suffer in a state staggered by the recession because "people seem to believe at the moment that the Democrats are better able to handle the economy."
And Republican candidates also suffer the effects of the recession in fund raising, Mr. Wilson and others said, because the party's most dependable contributors here -- aerospace, real estate savings-and-loan interests -- have been hardest hit.
Mr. Wilson added that national party's focus on family values could hurt candidates here, as well, because this is a "very tolerant" state where "people may hold their noses and turn off" to that kind of rhetoric.
The Governor's problems have another set of side effects for Mr. Seymour, who hoped to model his campaign on the 1990 race for governor, when issues of special interest to women did not dominate.
 
The Governor Is Busy
 Pete Wilson was to have been at the forefront of Mr. Seymour's fund-raising effort, helping fill the war chest necessary to buy television time. But money has been scarce, which some political experts blame on the Governor's preoccupation with a two-month budget standoff that ended last week, a ballot initiative that he wrote to revise the welfare system and other anxieties.
"To say Pete Wilson's plate is full is an understatement," said one prominent state Republican, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "He's got the Seymour race, the initiative, the budget. He's chairman of the Bush campaign, which is a shambles. He's worried about his own political rehabilitation. You have to ask yourself, how much time does he have to help?"
Despite the gloomy forecasts, the 54-year-old Mr. Seymour is a plucky campaigner, always 15 minutes early at campaign stops and eager to jump out of the car. He looks like a lounge singer and has the same improbable optimism that the main stage is just one perfect song away.
At a group home for delinquent boys in San Diego last week, he wielded a broken microphone with the verve of Phil Donahue and told every boy that it was "neat" or "super" to hear of his success. At a speech before hundreds of Agriculture Department employees, he told jokes about his short stature and his former job as mayor of Disneyland, formally known as Anaheim.
And at a buffet luncheon in Newport Beach for his Orange County volunteers, he led the others in the Pledge of Allegiance, answered all questions with an impressive array of facts, shook the hand of every man, kissed the cheek of every woman and remembered what precinct each ran.
If only sheer energy could win the race, Ms. Seymour seems to be saying, he soon would be California's senior Senator. Just look at how he's spent his freshman year in the Senate: racking up a 96 percent attendance record for votes and also spending 208 days on the stump in California.
"He's trying valiantly," said Mr. Field. "But he's cast adrift without much of a record at a time when the tide is running against him. He's like someone taken on an ocean liner by his parents or some protector. Then the ship sinks, he's in the lifeboat alone and he's wondering, 'Where did everybody else go?' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: John Seymour, who is seeking election to the United States Senate seat that Gov. Pete Wilson of California appointed him to 19 months ago. Mr. Seymour's campaign has been hurt by the collapse of the Republican Presidential campaign in California and the plunge in popularity of Mr. Wilson. Mr. Seymour campaigned in San Diego. (Suzanne Kammerer for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1992
 
The Economy
New economic reports demonstrate starkly how Americans' incomes have stalled, painting a picture of workers struggling to crawl up a down escalator. Together they give the Democrats fresh ammunition for what they hope will be a potent weapon in the election campaign. "Stagnation in wages is at the heart of this election," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic poll taker. [Page 1.] 
 In cutting a key interest rate, the Federal Reserve is walking a tightrope, trying to nudge the economy forward without pushing the dollar off a cliff. The dollar has slipped to record lows against the German mark in recent weeks, principally because short-term interest rates are so much lower in the U.S. [37.]
Corporate charity has not dried up, but executives squeezed by tough economic times, global competition, and sometimes hostility from City Hall are more likely to be minding their own business than providing civic leadership. [1.]
Cool weather meant a dismal summer for the air-conditioning industry. Despite a late-August week of brow-wiping heat and humidity, most of the summer in the Northeast and Midwest -- which constitute 60 percent of the air-conditioner market -- has had mild temperatures. [38.]
While President Bush has promised that the Government will pay for rebuilding South Florida and Louisiana, the Government is fighting requests for millions of dollars for repairs in communities struck three years ago by natural disasters. [7.]
 
International
The founder of the GPA Group, Tony Ryan, will take over the chief executive's post at the world's largest aircraft leasing company, which is based in Ireland. [37.]
The European Fighter Aircraft, an ambitious attempt by Britain, Germany, Italy and Spain to set aside national rivalries and cooperate in the development of an advanced warplane, has run into snags. And at the Farnsborough air show in England, American, French, Swedish and Russian aircraft makers were only too glad to try to pick up the slack. [37.]
Soaring prices on Shanghai's stock exchange reflect the growing enthusiasm, bordering on desperation, of ordinary Chinese to become shareholders -- preferably rich ones. After six years of on-and-off experimentation with shares, China is accelerating the development of a modern stock market. [37.]
President Fidel Castro said work on a Soviet-designed nuclear power plant had been halted indefinitely in Cuba. The plant had long been a source of tension between Havana and the U.S. [5.]
 
Companies
As auto workers prepared for Labor Day at General Motors' Willow Run plant in Ypsilanti, Mich., they were brooding over what had happened to their vision of the future. G.M. is closing the plant next year. For thousands of people, black and white, from Kentucky, West Virginia, Tennessee and Arkansas, the plant was a ticket out of the coal mines and away from dead-end jobs sweeping floors. "G.M. was security," said Linda Robbins, whose husband worked at Willow Run for 23 years. "How could this happen? Why didn't anyone stop it?" [1.]
It is hard to see what the U.A.W. gained through the nine-day walkout at the Lordstown, Ohio, plant that idled more than 40,000 workers nationwide. When the auto workers struck, they said their goal was to force the company to keep open a tool-and-die shop that provides 240 jobs and that G.M. wanted to close. Under the agreement overwhelmingly ratified Saturday, G.M. agreed to keep the shop open only for a few additional months. News Analysis. [37.]
 
The Media Business
 Nielsen remains the only game in national TV ratings, even though the networks and advertisers are generally unhappy with the service. Bill Carter: Television. [41.]
There may yet be life after death for Punch magazine, the British institution that shut in April [41.]
Black Dome Press has succeeded by specializing in books about the Catskill Mountains and the Hudson River. [41.]
A new magazine, Seesaw, is seeking to bridge the cultural gap between the U.S. and Japan by focusing on children. [41.]

HEADLINE: AFTER THE STORM;
Life on Fringes of Ruin Makes Cautious Comeback

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Sept. 6

 BODY:
Well north of the worst hurricane damage to Dade County, Shawna Drew, a beautician, sat in bumper-to-bumper traffic on Interstate 95 for 90 minutes, six times as long as her usual commute. Tears streamed down her face, as rain fell in sheets around her car.
"At first, after the hurricane it was like, 'I'm alive, I'm alive, Heaven be praised,' " Ms. Drew said Thursday. "Now it's like, 'I'm alive and I have a home, but I'm stressed and I'm sad and it seems real trivial to paint ladies' fingernails for a living.' " 
 In Miami, Miami Beach and the other heavily populated areas of northern Dade County that escaped the brunt of the storm, life gradually began returning to normal -- a very somber normal -- last week. But Hurricane Andrew has wrought dramatic changes in the landscape and psyche of the place, and hardly anyone is untouched.
"Everyone knows in their bones that this is a defining moment for Miami, as was the hurricane of 1926," said Arva Moore Parks, a local historian and author.
Nearly everyone in northern Dade County regained electricity last week, relishing their first hot showers since the hurricane struck early on Aug. 24. Television stations dropped their 24-hour emergency programming. Businesses, most notably gas stations and supermarkets, reopened.
On Wednesday the National Guard left Coconut Grove, and the 11 P..M. curfew was lifted in Miami Beach. On Thursday bus service resumed, and the county rescinded its order to boil water. And on Friday the county manager, Joaquin Avino, donned a suit and tie -- a sign, he said, that the county was back in business.
But many said it was hard to find a tasteful way to move on with life while neighbors about 40 miles south were still struggling to find food and shelter.
"There is a real feeling of guilt -- and compassion -- among those who did not suffer serious damage," said Ruth Shack, president of the Dade Community Foundation. "The mood is very restrained."
At the trendy News Cafe on Ocean Drive in Miami Beach, Su Rudy, an actress, halfheartedly ate a piece of chocolate cake on Wednesday, her first night back out on the town. "We're sort of walking around in a fog, like why were we spared?" she said. "All the damage we have at my condo is fish in our swimming pool."
Even far north of the military encampment in South Dade, where 24,000 troops were stationed amid the rubble, it was impossible to forget. Navy PT boats docked next to glittery cruise ships at the Port of Miami, and Army helicopters buzzed overhead.
 
Volunteers Directing Traffic
 Further, half of the county's traffic signals were out, and 5,000 out of 23,000 traffic lights were not just dead but blown away. At some intersections, volunteers, including a 73-year-old woman and 14 county attorneys, were directing traffic. At others, extremes of courtesy or aggression prevailed, depending on the drivers.
Most trees and shrubs have vanished, denuding a once-lush environment and, in particular, the parks that were a point of local pride. On Labor Day, instead of picnicking in those parks, hundreds of families planned to head south to volunteer their help.
Many Miamians said they considered it unseemly to enjoy a glass of wine or a night at the movies, believing that any indulgence in normal pleasures to be an insult to the enormousness of the moment.
Writing under a headline that read, "Do Touchdowns Really Matter Now?" Edwin Pope, sports editor of The Miami Herald, even dared to question the importance of sports here.
"So many people who thought their whole lives were wrapped around the Dolphins and the University of Miami Hurricanes -- irony of ironies, hurricanes as heroes! -- have learned that sports represent neither wall nor roof," he wrote in a column that would have been heretical before Aug. 24.
Still, even in the immediate wake of the storm, there were those who considered restraint unnecessary.
Four days after the hurricane, at Wolfie's, the seemingly indestructible delicatessen-restaurant on Miami Beach, Gerald Schwartz, a publicist, had a political breakfast for five judges up for re-election.
"Would you believe, in the middle of all this, every top condominium leader in the Beach I got out here?" Mr. Schwartz said proudly.
Judge Jack Coe of Dade County Circuit Court wriggled uncomfortably at his side. "It can't be politics as usual," he said. "Frankly, I'm embarrassed to even be campaigning."
That same day, a sign of how some relationships were indeed changing after the storm, The Herald collapsed the distance between journalist and subject. Its front-page banner headline, directed at the Federal Government, read, "WE NEED HELP."
 
A Very Personal Story
 "This story is more personal for every one of us, and every one of our readers, than any I've experienced in my career as a journalist," said David Lawrence, the paper's publisher.
Among The Herald's 2,600 employees, 70 lost their homes, and many more suffered damage. As the newspaper ran a relief program for its own workers, its editors and reporters put out a special hurricane section for 10 days, which included a bulletin board containing scores of poignant inquiries about missing persons.
All employers in the county were caught in a double role, that of tending to their own while also servicing their customers.
Carnival Cruise Lines was forced to cancel one cruise after the storm. But the loss proved beneficial for Carnival's homeless employees, who moved their families onto the ocean liner Fantasy for almost a week.
While most major employers have issued paychecks to employees who could not show up for work, smaller businesses and not-for-profit companies could not afford to do so.
 
Hot Weather and Frayed Nerves
 In Coral Gables, Books & Books, an independent bookstore, reopened, without electricity, four days after the storm. Its few customers bought children's books, because their children were climbing the walls without television, and photographic books about Miami, mementos of the way things were.
Farther south, at the Everglades Alligator Farm, Charles Thibos prayed that his 100 breeder alligators would survive without their weekly feeding of five chickens each. Meanwhile, more than 100 newly hatched alligators swam in his bathtub.
With temperatures in the 90's every day, tensions ran high throughout the county. The immediate adrenaline rush that followed the hurricane had given way to frayed nerves and a depressing realization of how much effort it would take to rebuild.
Judge Cindy Lederman of Dade County said domestic violence, particularly cases involving weapons, had surged since the hurricane. She and a colleague have issued twice as many temporary restraining orders against husbands and boyfriends in the last week, about 20 a day.
"And those were just for those who were able to make it to the courthouse," Judge Lederman said.
One sign that things were returning to normal could be found in Miami Beach, where young people on in-line skates were hawking the inevitable "I Survived Andrew" T-shirts. Meanwhile, TWN, the gay weekly newspaper, featured "Himicane" Andrew on its cover.
Jodi Kurry, a 22-year-old saleswoman at Victoria's Secret in Coconut Grove, where few women were buying lingerie last week, frowned at such levity. "I think we have to get back to normal life with a good deal of sensitivity, because it will never be back to normal down south," she said.
Ms. Kurry, a University of Miami graduate student, had never been to Homestead until she went there as a volunteer worker last week. For many in Dade County, until last month's storm Homestead and Florida City were little more than towns they passed through on the way to the Keys.
 
Parallels With 1926 Storm
 The hurricane blitzed the poorer residents of the county and spared most of the big condominiums, hotels and banks at the county's center. As a result, recovery for the county as a whole should be easier than it was in 1926, said Ms. Parks, the historian.
She said there were many parallels between the aftermath of the 1926 hurricane, the last real big one to hit Dade County, and the weeks after Hurricane Andrew. In 1926 the hurricane was followed by looting; food was donated quickly but distributed slowly, and martial law was established. But the 1926 hurricane wiped out Miami and Miami Beach, not Homestead and Florida City.
Some of the many fashion photographers at South Miami Beach were back behind their cameras last week. They cleared the debris from a patch of the beach and used long lenses that blurred the fallen trees in the background.
One fashion model suggested that the hurricane would make Dade County an even more desirable location, because the lunar landscape and thousands of soldiers in Homestead would provide a dramatic setting.
But Barbara Cominsky, vice president of the Michele Pommier Modeling Agency, discounted that idea. "No one has asked for that, and I hope no one does," she said.
The hurricane has provided a temporary economic lift for northern Dade County. Hotels, usually all but vacant in September, are filled with electrical workers, insurance adjusters and displaced families.
Miami Beach is welcoming back tourists, although Key Biscayne's oceanfront hotels and state park are still closed.
For Dade County residents, it was a peculiar week, and not only because of the devastation.
Smoke curled into the air from fallen trees being burned in 34 open pits.
Some 200 monkeys, on the loose from a research institute, were shot and killed by people who feared that the animals might be carrying AIDS.
While dead horses rotted in south Dade County canals, some northern residents complained that their cable television service was not being restored quickly enough.
But, with good will not always characteristic of this area, about 400 volunteers rode 10 county buses to South Dade on Saturday to rake up the debris.
The hurricane has unexpectedly made Dade County, a splintered community of diverse and often warring groups, feel almost united.
"We have survived riots, refugees, scandals and bankuptcies, but with each survival we have given away a quality of life,' said Ms. Shack, the head of the community foundation. "Maybe, now that we're cooperating, we have the chance to rebuild what was ticky-tacky and actually make it better."
